the oscarmath I absolutely tanked in the office Oscar pool. We voted on nine categories -- I correctly predicted a whopping three (best picture, best actress and best supporting actress). But it's not my fault! Really! There were many surprises. For one thing, "The Pianist" came up with three major wins -- best adapted screenplay, best director, and perhaps the biggest surprise of the night -- best actor. Although my money (literally) was on Scorcese nabbing best director and Daniel Day-Lewis taking home the best actor trophy, I was extremely happy to see "The Pianist" win those awards. Brody was amazing and Polanski, who is easily one of my top ten favorite directors, was finally rewarded for his stellar work behind the camera. Can I just get this whole Michael Moore thing off my chest? Please? I'll try to be brief. First of all, I admire Moore as a filmmaker. Although I didn't see "Bowling for Columbine," I'm a big fan of his 1988 documentary, "Roger & Me." I have lots of respect for his left-leaning anti-war, taking-care-of-the-working-people agenda. More power to him. But his bitter, clumsy tirade at the Oscars last night was completely ridiculous. It was the televised equivalent of farting at the dinner table. I'm all for freedom of speech, but by stomping all over his alloted time, he wasn't able to eloquently put into words what were obviously strong feelings against Bush and the war in Iraq. As much as I am for people stating their opinions, I have to say that with all the madness going on in the world right now, I was looking forward to a few hours of no war and a few cheesy musical numbers and Hollywood self-congratulation. That's what it's all about on Oscar night. Am I wrong? Oh, and if you are going to make a plea for peace, then do just that. Look at Chris Cooper. When he received his best supporting actor award, he was all class. He thanked the appropriate people and made a brief plea for a quick resolution to the conflict. Ta da! That's all there is to it. Susan Sarandon gave the crowd the peace symbol. I like it! Adrien Brody -- who, understandably, was flustered and ill-prepared to accept an Oscar -- rambled a bit, but was classy enough to give out a modest, positive plea for peace as well as a shout-out to a childhood friend serving in Kuwait. No boos, no rolling of the eyes. If you want to shout above your audience, go on "Hardball." Thanks. Now that the Oscars are over, some of the movies on my "must see" list are "Frida," "Talk to Her," "The Hours" (which I've been resisting for some time now) and "Spirited Away" (which I've heard nothing but good things about and am glad it won the animated feature Oscar instead of the assembly-line Disney films). In other weekend movie news, I watched my new "Three Colors Trilogy" box set on Saturday night while dogsitting for my sister who was away for the night. I first saw the individual films several years ago when they were first released on VHS. The DVD transfers are amazing, and the extra features are pretty sweet as well. All for $35.99. Nice. I also rented a strange yet haunting film called "A Taste of Cherry." It's an Iranian film about a guy who wants to kill himself and drives around the countryside in his Range Rover looking for someone to bury him. Not exactly the feel-good hit of the year, but the cinematography was amazing and I'm sure there's plenty of symbolism to take in after repeated viewings. And any DVD released by urlLink The Criterion Collection can't be half-bad (except "Armageddon"). Three days before I get on the big plane to Phoenix. I'm not as scared shitless about flying as I was a few weeks ago.

helen rocks, natalie rocks, and the war sucks British acting goddess Helen Mirren has urlLink agreed to revive her character of Police Inspector Jane Tennison for another installment of the critically acclaimed miniseries Prime Suspect. As a fan, I myself am very much looking forward to this. Unfortunately, the rest of the country will be too wrapped up in the latest reality show to give a crap. Too bad for them. Dixie Chicks lead singer Natalie Maines made a comment blasting President Bush at a recent London concert (which she later apologized for). Im not surprised that it pissed off the notoriously close-minded conservative country music community, but the last straw was when various Republican hick politicians urlLink suggested that the band perform a free concert for servicemembers as a way of further apologizing. Let me get this straight: Maines spoke out against the president, which is a perfectly legal form of freedom of expression, and now shes being forced to participate in a free concert like she owes some sort of community service? Excuse me while I step out of the 1950s Way-Back Machine and get my ass back to the present. What? Im already in the present? Oh, shit. For the first time since I started this blog, I went a whole day without posting (yesterday). I noticed that a lot of my fellow bloggers failed to post yesterday and I wonder how much of it has to do with the war. Personally, I didnt feel a need to not post. I just didnt get around to it. Actually, I was about to post something yesterday afternoon when I looked out my office window and happened to notice approximately 5 or 6 helicopters circling over downtown Boston. My first wartime paranoia instinct was to mildly freak out about it. Then when I made my way downtown en route to Borders, I realized that it was probably due to the massive anti-war rally taking place. I walked by Government Center and witnessed an enormous gathering of people, which was nice to see, but later I talked to Liza and she told me of the walkout protest at urlLink her school. Apparently the students were treating it as some sort of excuse to get out of school and party, and on top of that, Liza is probably going to be ostracized by these people for wanting to stay in school in order to get some much-needed studying done. Folks and this is mainly for the younger ones out there -- if youre going to protest, thats great. But at least treat it with the attention and focus that it deserves and know exactly what youre protesting. I have a feeling that a large portion of the bongo-playing hemp set wouldnt know urlLink Tariq Aziz if he sat on them. Tonight Im going to a party at my friends Nate and Joshs place. Ive been told that their apartment is rather small and totally non-conducive to parties, so this should be interesting. Saturday Im working in the morning, then Lizas going to accompany me on a mad urlLink shoe-shopping expedition (this is an undertaking that requires the company of either a woman or a gay man), then were going to dog-sit my sisters dogs. I like sitting for Barney and Bea we get to stay overnight at my sisters place, which always feels like Im staying at a nice homey hotel. Then Sunday night is Oscar night! This year I feel I just might win the jackpot. Keep your fingers crossed.

doing my part to boost the economy Between my Oscar picks, my attempts at political commentary and my random observations concerning the new Joe Jackson CD, Ive failed to mention that Ive made some pretty nice CD/DVD purchases over the last few days. Even though I work at urlLink Borders and am able to take advantage of their generous employee discount program, I like to stop into urlLink Newbury Comics every once in a while, since they have a nice selection of used and import discs (Borders has no used discs, and our selection of imports is laughable). So Friday after work I wandered into our competition and began searching for something cheap I might want to buy. I was pleasantly surprised to see that they had a copy of urlLink Mike Keneally's excellent Wooden Smoke. I already own it (the two-disc special edition, that is), but its always nice to experience that rare treat of seeing Mikes music in stores. After much indecision, I ended up getting the Afghan Whigs urlLink "Black Love." It wasnt used and its not an import, but Im never able to find that title in Borders. Plus, it was only $11.99. I remember reading a lengthy magazine article about the Whigs in March 1996, the day I moved to Italy (I in fact read it on a bus from Rome to Naples, if you must know). A few days later, I bought their acclaimed 1993 release "Gentlemen," which took a long time to click with me, but when it did, it really did (their mostly-covers EP urlLink "Uptown Avondale" is nice, too). I once described them as grunge and debauchery meet in a sleazy nightclub, but after hearing Black Love, I think a better description would be Nine Inch Nails as a bar band. Lead singer and songwriter Greg Dullis Tortured Sexual Persona bit gets a little tiresome once in a while, but its fun in a way that cheesy horror movies are fun. And the music is great evil, dark and funky all at the same time. I havent owned Black Love long enough to be able to compare it to Gentlemen, but so far, initial impressions are strong. Saturday afternoon (on my way to meeting Liza and Ilsa at the Museum of Science), I got my Newbury Fix once again and grabbed a used copy of Nick Drakes urlLink "Five Leaves Left" for $6.99. Another Wooden Smoke reference I was listening to this amazing disc last week and was thinking that a lot of it reminded me of what I imagined Nick Drake would sound like. I never really heard his stuff before, but I was told he was sort of a brooding British folkie. He made three albums before dying in from a drug overdose in 1974 at age 26. I havent heard Five Leaves Left in its entirety just yet, but what Ive heard so far is really beautiful. Yesterday, Francois Truffauts urlLink "Day For Night" was finally released on DVD (for $14.99!) so I grabbed it but havent had the chance to watch it yet. There are tons of great extra features on the DVD. Ive only seen two Truffaut films so far (The 400 Blows, which I own, and Love on the Run) and I think he was a really amazing filmmaker. Very humane and emotional without being sappy. Next month, his four Antoine Doinel films will be released by Criterion in a urlLink wonderful box set. I think I might just have to drop some money on that. I planned on getting the urlLink Three Colors Trilogy this week as well, but we sold out at an alarming rate and havent gotten any more in yet (I think my current obsession with French films is my way of combating the whole France-bashing thing). Today is my brother Garys birthday. Wish him a happy one.

my 75th annual guilty pleasure I hate awards shows. I really do. Theyre all multiple-hour self-congratulatory ass-kissing self-important wastes of time. The Grammys (and even more so, the American Music Awards) are for people with no taste in music and no comprehension of anything that isnt played on the radio. The various MTV awards are for people who possess no discernible brain cells. The Emmys? The only prime-time shows I watch (besides Boomtown) are Law & Order and its spin-offs, and they get shut out every year by whatever hip show of the moment is in the spotlight. The Tonys? Sorry, Im a straight male. Im forbidden by law to watch those. And dont get me started on those inane Blockbuster Awards. I wont even rent movies from those anti-widescreen morons. Im sure as hell not going to watch an awards show that recognizes their idea of talent. Wow, Im angry today. Must be all that pre-war rage. Having said all that, I will admit to one thing. You must keep this to yourself (and everyone else who surfs the Internet): I watch the Oscars. Thats right. Never miss em. Im an Oscar freak. Yes, its pompous. Yes, the red carpet gauntlet is a pathetic excuse for Joan Rivers to show off her latest plastic surgery freak show. Yes, its very political and a lot of films and filmmakers get the shaft in favor of less-deserving ones. But two things: first of all, I love movies. I absolutely adore them. Second, the Oscars are really the closest thing we, as a civilization, have as far as matching film quality to recognition. I suppose arguments can be made that the Cannes Film Festival, the Independent Spirit Awards, Sundance, etc, are more accurate in terms of proper recognition, but those arent given enough coverage to really allow for good, accurate analysis. So today Im going to give you my Oscar picks. A few points to make first: First of all, I have not seen every film nominated. I am going to go by what I know of the films and filmmakers, in addition to how the politics of Hollywood and the Academy work, as well as predictions made by some critics whose work I admire. Second of all, I am going to give my predictions in only nine areas (actor and actress, supporting actor and actress, director, picture, adapted and original screenplay and song). These are the categories we vote on in our office pool (wish me luck!) and besides, I could care less who wins for Best Sound. Finally, I will be listing my predictions on who I think will win, in addition to telling you who I think should win. Theres often a big difference. Are you ready? Lets get this over with, Ive been putting it off long enough Best Picture: Chicago Gangs of New York The Hours Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers The Pianist Is there really any doubt in anyones mind that Chicago will win? Not since Titanic has there been such a sure thing. I personally enjoyed the film, but thats beside the point. It was nominated for umpteen and a half awards, theres a huge buzz behind it, and it did well at the Golden Globes, which is usually a pretty strong indicator. As far as personal tastes go, I personally feel that The Pianist should win. Chicago was a fun movie but I can only take so much of musicals; Gangs was very good but not great; I didnt see The Hours and Lord of the Rings was basically a really sophisticated action film. The Pianist was a gorgeous, heartbreaking work of art, Adrien Brody was superb and Roman Polanski proved once again that hes one of the finest directors alive today. What should win: The Pianist What will win: Chicago Best Director: Pedro Almodovar: Talk to Her Stephen Daldry, The Hours Rob Marshall, Chicago Roman Polanski, The Pianist Martin Scorcese, Gangs of New York Pedro Almodovar is an accomplished director, but not a lot of people saw Talk to Her, and besides, whenever a director is not nominated in a Best Picture category, thats a bad sign. Daldry would normally have a decent shot if it werent for Marshall and Scorcese. Same goes for Polanski, plus he has that whole statutory rape thing hanging over his head. Marshall is a definite contender, but I think that theyre going to give Scorcese one of those infamous career achievement Oscars. In other words, the man responsible for Taxi Driver, Raging Bull and Goodfellas was shamefully never given an Oscar, so the Academy will attempt to make it up to him by giving him an Oscar for a film that is decent, but nowhere near what hes capable of. Who should win: Roman Polanski Who will win: Martin Scorcese Actor in a Leading Role: Adrien Brody: The Pianist Nicolas Cage: Adaptation Michael Caine: The Quiet American Daniel-Day Lewis: Gangs of New York Jack Nicholson: About Schmidt Brody is the textbook definition of underdog here. Hes the only non-Oscar winner here and the only one who hasnt even been nominated before. Unless theres a Pianist sweep (highly unlikely), well have to write him off right away. Cage was excellent in Adaptation but the film might be a bit too quirky for the Academys notoriously conservative tastes. Caine was excellent in The Quiet American (from what I hear I still havent seen it yet), but hes already got two Oscars, the most recent one just a couple of years ago. Nicholson Christ, is anyone else sick of seeing this guy at the Oscars? In the seventies he was great in a series of brilliant films (Five Easy Pieces, One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest, The Last Detail). Now I just get the feeling that, for the most part, hes coasting, cultivating that image of the aging Ray-Ban-wearing hipster. Granted, hes a great actor. About Schmidt was terrific. He was terrific in it. But the guys already got three damn Oscars! And the Academy fucked up when they gave him one for the schmaltzy As Good as it Gets. Which leads us to Daniel Day-Lewis. Not only is there lots of buzz about his performance, its quite possibly the finest performance Ive seen all year. He was easily the best thing about that movie. Who should win: Daniel Day-Lewis Who will win: Daniel Day-Lewis Actress in a Leading Role: Salma Hayek, Frida Nicole Kidman, The Hours Diane Lane, Unfaithful Julianne Moore, Far From Heaven Renee Zellweger, Chicago I havent seen Frida, by all accounts it was great, but Hayek is a first-time nominee and thats a big minus. Diane Lane was great in Unfaithful, but isnt getting the buzz that movies like Chicago and The Hours are getting. I would love to see Julianne Moore get an Oscar for the amazing Far From Heaven, but that movie was unfortunately obscured by flashier competition. Renee Zellweger, in my opinion, was not even close to being the best thing about Chicago, and lets face it that movie was more about singing and dancing than acting. Which leaves us with Nicole Kidman. The Hours was a big hit with the critics and if anyone gets the Oscar for that film, its her. Its probably also a bit of a make-up Oscar after she didnt win for Moulin Rouge. Who should win: Julianne Moore Who will win: Nicole Kidman Actor in a Supporting Role: Chris Cooper, Adaptation Ed Harris, The Hours Paul Newman, The Road to Perdition John C. Reilly, The Hours Christopher Walken, Catch Me if You Can Harris and Reilly will probably cancel each other out. Besides, Reilly was in so many damn movies last year, the Academy will probably forget what film he was nominated for and give up. Despite his excellent performance in Road to Perdition, (didnt see it, but I heard he was great), Newman was probably nominated because hes Paul Newman. The two serious contenders here are Cooper and Walken. Cooper has the Golden Globe going for him, but everyone is talking about how great it was to see Walken (who normally plays psychos) in a brilliant, touching, low-key role. I personally loved it. But I loved Cooper too. Crap. It could go either way. But Im going with my heart and picking Walken for this. Who should win: Christopher Walken Who will win: Christopher Walken Actress in a Supporting Role: Kathy Bates, About Schmidt Julianne Moore, The Hours Queen Latifah, Chicago Meryl Streep, Adaptation Catherine Zeta-Jones, Chicago Bates and Latifah are the underdogs here. About Schmidt might as well have been called About Jack, since everyone else involved in the film has been unfairly brushed aside. Latifah was great in Chicago, but I think she needs a few more good roles under her belt before taking home the statue. Streep was good but I think her step down from actress to supporting actress will hurt her chances. I didnt see The Hours, but Im guessing that Moore will be shot down by Zeta-Jones. I know that Chicago may not be an actors film, but its got to win at least one actor award, so there you go. Plus, political correctness aside, shes pregnant. Thats gotta help. Who should win: Julianne Moore Who will win: Catherine Zeta-Jones Adapted Screenplay: About a Boy Adaptation Chicago The Hours The Pianist Id love to see About a Boy win something, but I think I was the only person on earth who saw that film. Too bad. How cool would it be for a screenplay about a screenwriter to win an Oscar? I think the Academy recognizes that. It will win. Who should win: Adaptation Who will win: Adaptation Original Screenplay: Far From Heaven Gangs of New York My Big Fat Greek Wedding Talk to Her Y Tu Mama Tambien Everything about Far From Heaven was terrific, and the screenplay is no exception. But My Big Fat Greek Wedding is the big success story of 2002, and Im sure the Academy wants to give Nia Vardalos something. What should win: Far From Heaven What will win: My Big Fat Greek Wedding Best Song Chicago I Move On, John Kander and Fred Ebb 8 Mile Lose Yourself, Eminem Frida Burn it Blue, Elliot Goldenthal and Julie Taymor Gangs of New York The Hands That Built America, U2 The Wild Thornberrys Movie Father and Daughter, Paul Simon U2 won the Golden Globe. Its a done deal. Nothing here really does anything for me, except for the Frida soundtrack, which Ive heard a few times and really like. Who should win: Frida Who will win: Gangs of New York I got at least ten bucks riding on this people, so cross your fingers and hope for the best.

take it away, dad Yesterday's screed against France-bashing prompted my father and I to engage in some rather interesting e-mail exchanges. As one of pressure drop's (few) devoted readers, he gave me his own two cents about the coming conflict with Iraq, so I thought I would give Al Ingalls (aka Dad) of Orlando, Florida, a spot as "guest commentator." After this, I promise, I'll lay off the political rantings. I'm hardly qualified to be a political blogger. Here is a big chunk of what he sent me in his e-mail yesterday: "We have managed to elect to the highest political position in the entire world....a person who is totally devoid of intellectual reasoning and/or sophisticated communication skills. His principle support (I believe) comes from folks who stand to profit from his brazen, ill-disguised and ill-advised international and financial objectives. My life experiences tend to indicate that the hardest position to define is that which is taken against an undefendable, hard-line position. Please note that currently there is very little communication taking place in our government which approaches 'reasonable inter-position discussion and debate.' Media 'personalities' are taking great liberties with the cavalier labelling of our citizens as 'liberals' or 'conservatives.' The labellers have also taken similar liberties with their definitions of these groups. I don't know which I fall into, because they haven't provided me with the groundrules, however, I do know that in spite of my personal patriotism, my four years of military service during the Korean War, my technical contributions to our defense industry for a period of nearly 50 years and my dutiful and uncomplaining payment of taxes since I was 13 years old....I am treated and labeled by some as a (negative) 'liberal!' Mr. Bush's speeches, regardless of length or content, usually consist of a single, simple message which (agree with it or not) could be stated in 30 seconds or less. Today I listened while Mr. Bush's Secretary of State elequently presented his loyal support for his President. Sadly enough, I believe that if Colin Powell were our President, we would not be anywhere near our current political, international position. (Mr. Bush made it a point during the 'Azores Summit' to relate the current situation to a Texas poker game.......Give me a break!) I'm rambling! I do feel disenfranchised and (sadly enough) alone! I can only hope and pray that somewhere in this great country we can manage to find an intelligent, moral, inspirational and forceful leader who can bring us together and above all of this idiocy."

ugly americans, indeed Can we please stop the France bashing? Please? It really makes us look like idiots. Im not going to try and get into a political debate here, since there are plenty of people who are better suited for that type of discourse (like urlLink this guy ). But come on. Lets see if Ive got this straight: France is pressing the United Nations to give weapons inspectors in Iraq more time, saying that war is premature. So all of a sudden theyre a scum-sucking bottom feeder of a people? First of all, lets say that we should go to war (I personally believe we shouldnt, butjust play along). If we should, and France doesnt agree with us, do you know what that makes them? Ignorant scum? Misguided fools? Boorish Jerry Lewis fanatics? No. That makes them a country that disagrees with us on a particularly hot geopolitical topic. Thats all. Also, just because the French government doesnt want to go to war, that doesnt mean that the general population of France doesnt either. By the same token, our government wants to attack Iraq, but there are huge amounts of Americans who think that war is a bad idea. But that apparently doesnt click with Joe Six Pack. I was walking by the Fleet Center Saturday afternoon and a guy was selling two different types of t-shirts: one of them said Saddam Sucks Osama Swallows. Okay, fine. I think that most of us can agree that Saddam Hussein and Osama bin Laden are a couple of raving lunatics who should be stopped. Im not going to wear the t-shirt, but I can appreciate the sentiment. But the guy was also selling a t-shirt that said France Sucks. This bothers me on a number of levels. I have a rather sentimental attraction towards France. I lived there from ages five to ten and as a result, I was exposed to a vast amount of culture at a very young age. I had a number of American friends from the English-speaking school I attended, but I was also very good friends with the French kids in my neighborhood. It was an amazing time in my life and Ill never forget it. Being raised in France was one of the greatest things my father ever did for us. France gets a good kick in the ass from lots of other countries, particularly the U.S. An inaccurate image has been cultivated of the French: theyre rude, they hate everyone else and they believe theyre superior to everyone else. Im going to go out on a limb here, but that sounds more like a description of our own people of late. Im willing to bet that the t-shirt salesman I saw on Saturday has never been to France. I bet hes never befriended a French person, dined in a good French restaurant or even rented a film by urlLink Truffaut or urlLink Godard. Judging by where I saw him, Im sure hes been to a Bruins game. But has he ever attended a soccer match? I doubt it. Americans are stubborn about embracing any activity that isnt inherently American. Instead, any opinion or pastime that differs from our own is idiotic, and we show our true feelings with moronic t-shirts and dipshit Republican representatives whose idea of a constructive use of taxpayer dollars is to rename French fries Freedom Fries. Theres also the story I saw on the news the other day about a French-born woman in Texas whose garage door was vandalized with spray-paint (they wrote some erudite comment like French scum go home, I think). This behavior, in my opinion, is no better than cross-burning. urlLink Frank Zappa said it best: A mind is like a parachute it doesnt work if its not open.

in praise of anonymous actors Lynne Thigpen urlLink died two days ago at her home in Los Angeles. The world has lost an extremely talented woman. Whos Lynne Thigpen? I dont blame you for asking. Shes in a category of actors who always seem to garner recognition, once their faces are shown. But the names never seem to stick. Hell, they never seem to even come up. Im talking about the thankless role of the character actor. Character actors are those people you see a zillion times in supporting roles, either on television shows or theatrical releases. One of the best-known character actors (relatively speaking, of course) was a gentleman by the name of urlLink J.T. Walsh. According to the Internet Movie Database, J.T. appeared in 67 films from 1982 to 1998. Youd recognize him if you saw him, believe me. J.T. passed away in February 1998, and unfortunately, neither Oscar nominations nor eight-figure salaries ever came his way. Why? Because hes a character actor, for cryin out loud! (though I thought it was a nice touch for Jack Nicholson to dedicate his 1998 Oscar to the recently deceased actor). Thigpen is another actor youd recognize if you saw her face. An African-American woman of 54, she appeared in more than 40 films, in addition to countless television roles. My two best recollections of her are in her portrayal of Judge Ida Boucher on a few episodes of urlLink Law & Order (if youre a character actor, chances are youve done time on that fine show) and as a pissed off television interviewer who grills Tim Robbins in the excellent, underrated film urlLink Bob Roberts (which also features a young, thin urlLink Jack Black ). Like J.T. Walsh, Lynne Thigpens greatest amount of publicity occurred when she passed away. This is a shame, not just because people should be around to hear their greatest accolades, but because she, like so many other character actors, worked tirelessly and turned in stellar performances that always seemed to get overshadowed by the big-name stars. Do yourself a favor: check out Thigpens urlLink IMDB page and rent a few of those movies. Youd be surprised how much great acting came out of such an anonymous actor.

return of the fabulous four Morning subway commutes are a necessary evil. I dont have a car, so Im a slave to the urlLink MBTA. Im grateful that it exists, but sometimes its just a royal pain. I dont like to be shoved that close together with total strangers, some of whom apparently have yet to discover this fascinating new invention known as deodorant. There are two things that can save my commute from being a completely miserable experience a good book or a good CD in the Walkman. This morning I was blessed with the latter, and I almost didnt want the commute to end. As I mentioned yesterday, I picked up urlLink Volume 4, the brand new urlLink Joe Jackson CD. I listened to it a bit last night on my way home and my impressions were very positive. But I waited until this morning (due to the longer commute) to really dig into it. A little background first: I first heard Joe Jackson in 1979. My initial exposure to his music came in a rather odd manner. I was ten years old and just starting to learn the drums, but I didnt have my own set just yet. Our family was really good friends with the Hilliards, whose dad worked with our dad. They lived in nearby Chelmsford and the oldest kid, Scott (who was probably around 20 at the time) played the drums and whenever we went over to visit, I would go to his room (in the basement of their split-level), put the headphones on, turn on some random rock radio station and play along. That was the first time I ever heard Is She Really Going Out With Him. In fact, to this day, that song still conjures up memories of banging away on Scotts gleaming five-piece drum set (before the adults yelled down the staircase for me to keep that racket down). A few years later, during my 1985 Year of Discovery (when I first started buying albums by Elvis Costello, the Jam, Squeeze et al), I picked up Joes Look Sharp album and to this day I still consider it one of my all-time favorites. I suppose you could call it punk or new wave, but like Costello it was intelligent punk. Scrappy guitars and snarling vocals were paired with smart songwriting and killer hooks. Look Sharp had all that in spades. Joe made two more albums with guitarist Gary Sanford, drummer Dave Houghton and bassist Graham Maby (Im the Man and Beat Crazy) before moving off into such eclectic territory as big band, classical, jazz and more. When it dawned on Joe that 2003 would mark the 25th anniversary of his original four-piece band, he decided to reform the band with a new album and tour. Volume 4 (its the fourth album with this particular band configuration) is the resulting album and it was released yesterday. Life is good. Anything crappy that happens this week can be alleviated by a quick listen to this marvelous disc. Volume 4 pays tribute to his past (and even apes it) without being condescending or overtly nostalgic. Like Elvis Costellos recent return-to-roots album (When I Was Cruel), Joes latest shows his original new wave blueprint updated with the things hes learned along the way. In other words, he can still be a snot-faced hellraiser but isnt afraid to shake things up with some sophisticated musical interplay or inventive arrangements. The opener, Take it Like a Man is a brilliant, piano spiked number reminiscent of Look Sharp with a little Body & Soul (Joes 1984 album) thrown in for good measure. Awkward Age shows how great Joe is with catchy hooks. The album has its fair share of ballads -- Chrome, Love at First Light and Blue Flame and the latter would sound right at home on Joes 1982 Night & Day album. He knows exactly when to update his sound and when to stick to the basics. The only real low points and this is really just nitpicking are the rather forced Little Bit Stupid and Thugs Are Us (which has a nice ska beat, but lets face it: do we really need another song about suburban white kids who try to be black?). Joe and his band may have lines on their faces, but as far as musical ability goes, they havent aged a bit. I know that Maby has worked extensively as a session musician over the years (most notably with urlLink They Might Be Giants ), but I havent heard a peep from the other two. Apparently their instruments havent been gathering dust for the past 20 years, because they sound as good as ever. The four musicians were recorded live in the studio in a very simple style that seems refreshing in this era of Pro Tools and mixing board touch-ups. I dont know if its just a limited edition, but my version of Volume 4 comes with a bonus disc of six songs the band performed last fall at two small clubs in England. They tear through a half dozen nuggets from the early days. If youre planning to see Joe live on his current urlLink tour, this makes for a great preview of whats to come. Ill be there myself (at the Paradise in Boston on April 5). Ill be the one trying to get my vinyl copy of Look Sharp signed by the man himself. Wish me luck.

"when you're spitting out the kodachrome..." I received an e-mail this morning from a guy named Scott, who enjoyed reading the list of my favorite Elvis Costello CDs thats on urlLink my amazon.com page. He prodded me further, asking me a few more questions related to my opinions on EC. Since I dont have any other ideas for posts at this time, I thought I would post his questions and my responses Q: Top 20 Costello songs? A: Ouch. Elvis has been making records since 1977, and about 95 percent of them I love wholeheartedly. Thatsa couple hundred songs, maybe? Let me just let out a stream-of-consciousness, totally unprepared, non-scientific list of 20 EC songs that make me really happy: The Imposter, Clubland, White Knuckles, Ill Wear It Proudly, Imagination (is a Powerful Deceiver), Deep Dark Truthful Mirror, How to be Dumb, Girls Talk, Lipstick Vogue, Man out of Time, Shipbuilding, Party Girl, Battered Old Bird, 45, Miracle Man, Motel Matches, Youll Never be a Man, Big Sister, I Hope Youre Happy Now, Its Time. Q: Are you pro or con the Costello/Bacharach era? A: Scott is referring to Painted from Memory, a 1998 album that Elvis made with songwriting legend Burt Bacharach. I find that album to be an interesting diversion. Elvis and Burt make a good team, and there are definitely some accomplished songs here: a couple of flat-out masterpieces (The Sweetest Punch, Toledo), and songs that are very good but dont necessarily rank among ECs finest (I Still Have That Other Girl, This House is Empty Now, God Give me Strength). There are, unfortunately, a couple of songs that in my opinion are bona fide stinkers: The Long Division and Such Unlikely Lovers are so hopelessly syrupy they make Celine Dion sound like Black Flag. Overall, its definitely a noteworthy entry in the Costello catalog and a respectable piece of work, but Im honestly quite happy that he made a return to good old-fashioned rebellion a few years later with When I Was Cruel. Q: Have you heard the Almost You tribute album and if so, is it worth checking out? A: Almost You is a recently released EC tribute album. I havent heard it, but we received a promo copy at the Borders where I work part-time, and my name is on it (Basically that means that once the disc has finished its stint in our listening posts, I have dibs on it). The only artist on the disc that Ive even heard of is Fastball (a good-not-great power-pop band, IMHO). I have to say that the song selection is a good sign: a lot of good, obscure EC songs. So the short answer is: no, I havent heard it, but I plan to hear it soon. Q: What is your opinion of Mitchell Frooms production job on Brutal Youth? To my ears that album didnt quite sound like vintage Attractions, despite a number of good songs. A: Brutal Youth was ECs Attractions Reunion Album. After making records from 1986 to 1993 with a variety of musicians as opposed to his crack three-piece combo of Bruce Thomas, Pete Thomas and Steve Nieve, Elvis brought the lads together again for this impressive 1994 album. I like Brutal Youth. I think the songs are good and the band plays extremely well. But I honestly think that its not quite as good as classic Attractions works like Get Happy, Trust and Armed Forces. I dont know how much of this has to do with the production. Mitchell Froom is an excellent producer who's helmed works by Los Lobos, Crowded House, Richard Thompson, Suzanne Vega (whom he eventually married) and scads of others. He has a unique style that I think works well with Elvis. But Nick Lowe was the studio mastermind behind much of Elvis early output, and his production was one of the things that made those albums great. So while I like Froom, Ill take Lowe if I had to choose. Q: How infrequently do you listen to The Juliet Letters? A: Ive never heard it in its entirety. Its one of the few EC albums Ive never owned. I dont have a pathological repulsion towards it, but I heard a few songs from it when it was released, and I saw Elvis performing some of it on the Tonight Show when it came out, and it didnt do much for me. The Juliet Letters, for those of you who dont know, is a song cycle that Elvis made with the Brodsky Quartet in 1993. Basically its Elvis singing with a string quartet. I dont have any objection toward the concept in theory, but I dont think this particular match works well. I may very well buy it eventually, just to be an EC completist. By the way, I also feel that For the Stars, Elvis 2001 collaboration with Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie Von Otter, was another example of nice idea, dont enjoy listening to it. I have a healthy respect for both rock and classical, but its a rare feat for them to work well together. Sorry. The title of this post, by the way, is a line from the Elvis song "Watch Your Step," another great song that I failed to include in the above Top 20.

my stupid irrational fear I have a somewhat intense fear of flying. There. I said it. Its in print, its out there. Actually, its not really some deep, dark secret. Many of my friends know this. The thing is, I wasnt always like this. As a child, I didnt mind flying at all. It wasnt until my adult years that I slowly developed this strange trait. There are really only two things that bother me during a flight (not counting the crappy movies and the uncomfortable seats): turbulence and take-off. I dont care how slight the bumpiness may be, if the planes hitting what the pilots so casually refer to as a little rough air, Im a Class-A basket case. If the plane is flying smoothly, Im perfectly fine. Take-off freaks me out because the plane has to tilt at all these ungodly angles and for some reason, that disturbs the crap out of me. Descending, on the other hand, doesn't bother me at all. In fact, I kind of enjoy it. Go figure. People always tell me the same thing: The statistics show that its safer than a car! You're not scared of a car, are you? Well no, Im not. Im not even scared of the subway, and those things break down all the time. Cars break down all the time, too. But heres the thing: when a car is experiencing trouble, you can PULL OVER. If a planes experiencing trouble, ta-da! Youre 30,000 feet above the earth! Theres no breakdown lane or gas station up there, folks. Its a feeling of helplessness and frankly, I dont care for it. I bring this up because at the end of this month, I will be getting on an airplane for the first time in about 20 months. An old friend of Lizas is getting married in Phoenix and were going to the wedding. And I want to go. I want to be there with Liza. Her family out down there and theyre about the nicest people you could ever meet. Ive been there with her three times in the last three years and I always have fun. As much as I hate flying, Ive always managed to pack up a carry-on with my CDs, my Walkman, a plethora of reading material, and get on that plane. That is, untilyou guessed itSeptember 11. September 11 was a horrific day for people all over the world and were still feeling the effects. We always will. But for people like me who hate flying, that day made us airplane-phobics even more irrational in our fears. Theres something about a bunch of assholes flying planes into buildings that really makes me think twice about boarding. I know the statistics. I know that many, many planes take off and land every day and crashes are so rare that they make national news when they occur. Thats whats keeping me optimistic. I feel bad for Liza I know that shes there for me when my white knuckles are grabbing the armrest, and she wants to be. But I also know that deep down inside, shes asking herself, what is the deal with this freak? Why cant he just chill out? Dont ask me to try and sleep, by the way. I cant sleep on planes. Thats like saying, theres a good chance that a crazed escaped axe murderer is going to visit your house sometime tonight and hack you to pieces, but try not to think about it. Get some sleep. And dont suggest that I get wasted on the plane, either. Ive seen drunk people on planes and I dont want to be one of them. I just have to calm down, remember the statistics, and try to avoid watching "Die Hard 2" or "Alive" in the next three weeks.

another tuesday, another street date First things first: when I told Tom Johnson -- who has a great website called urlLink unproductivity -- that I was starting a blog of my own, he warned me that I would begin by posting several times a day. Its addictive, he explained. So consider this the Addicted Phase. I imagine it will taper off after a while. Today is Tuesday, and for the those of us in the music/video retail biz, that means its Street Day. For a few vague, obscure reasons, all CDs and DVDs are released on this day of the week. Its when the product hits the street. Get it? urlLink DVD Journal , my all-time favorite DVD website, even goes so far as to use street as a verb in their release announcements (i.e., Mexican cinema sensation The Crime of Padre Amaro streets on April 1.) How snooty! Anyway, a couple of things are streeting today that Im fairly excited about. First is Krzysztof Kieslowskis urlLink Three Colors Trilogy , finally available on DVD. Kieslowski is a Polish director who died in 1996, but not before making three stunning films dealing with women in French society: Blue, White and Red. The films star Juliette Binoche, Julie Delpy and Irene Jacob, respectively, and have an undeniable power, dealing with loss, jealousy, desperation...you knowall that cheerful stuff. I must admit, Ive seen each film only once (at least five years ago), but I was struck at the time at the mesmerizing power of each of these films. Each film also imaginatively incorporates its respective title color into the cinematography. If youre put off by foreign films (a puzzling character trait that Ill never understand Ill save that subject for a separate post), you might want to stay away from these, but if youre at all interested in striking, daring filmmaking, check it out. The entire trilogy goes for about $35.99you cant beat that. By the way, if youre curious about certain films that are not yet available on DVD (and why), DVD Journal has a section entitled urlLink DVD MIA , which lists the most requested unavailable films and suggests possible reasons for the hold-up (usually its a rights issue, sometimes theyre dealing with a temperamental director, etc). Im also happy that the entire urlLink Police catalog is being reissued. Say what you will about Stings massive ego, not to mention the fact that hes become the king of adult contemporary pap; the first three albums by the Police are terrific. Quasi-punk mixed with reggae, ska, and funk. Nothing wrong with that. The fourth album, Ghost in the Machine, slipped a little. Not that its a bad album in fact, One World (Not Three) is one of my favorite Police songs. But Stings megalomania began really showing itself here, and by the time of Synchronicity (not a terrible album, but not good enough to drop money on, if you ask me), dissolution was fairly evident. Im not going to harp too much on the fact that these reissues are a blatant example of triple-dipping (this is the third time this catalog has been issued), but Ive never owned Outlandos DAmour on CD and its high time I pick it up. How can you go wrong with an album that contains Next to You, Masoko Tanga and Be My Girl - Sally (Andy Summers infamous ode to a blow-up doll). The reissues, by the way, come in the nifty Digipak-style case. Yay for Digipak! Im headed to my part-time Borders gig tonight, where new releases will be flying off the shelves. How about doing your part to fight this recession and drop some coin in our fine store? Youll be glad you did. Just do me a favor and dont simply use our store for the restroom, okay? We really hate that. Again, thats another post for another time. If by some chance youre reading this, please urlLink drop me a line and tell me what you think. Thanks.

A case for the Modfather In the fall of 1985, I was a junior at Palos Verdes High School in California. I guess I didnt really fit in, but I belonged to a small group of friends who shared a deep love for music. One of my best friends was a guy named Goran Radovanovic. I will be forever indebted to Goran for turning me on to the music of Elvis Costello. He also was responsible for getting me to listen to a band called the Jam, who had actually broken up about three years before we met. The Jam were one of Englands biggest bands during their 1977-1982 recording and touring career. A tight punk rock trio influenced heavily by the mod stylings of bands like the Who and the Small Faces, they also incorporated a heavy mix of American soul into their sound (which would become more pronounced as their career progressed). The band consisted of bass player Bruce Foxton, drummer Rick Buckler, and, leading the band on vocals, guitar, and a majority of the songwriting credits, Paul Weller. The band amassed a strong following in their native UK, racking up hit after hit, and earning a reputation as a fiery live combo. As Weller steered the band towards a more Motown-influenced sound (as evidenced by songs like Town Called Malice, Absolute Beginners and Precious), the public continued to hang on their every note. Meanwhile, US audiences more interested in Foghat and Debby Boone wouldnt give the Jam the time of day. Weller broke up the band at the peak of their popularity, expressing a need to move on. Which he did, forming the Style Council with keyboard player Mick Talbot. This band became increasingly political lyrically, while the music reflected Wellers need to expand beyond the requisite three-chord punk sound. Jazz, lounge, salsa and other exotic hybrids gave the Style Council a unique sound that initially caught on with the British public, but after a while, even they couldnt handle Pauls musical Attention Deficit Disorder. The Americans, in the meantime, were blissfully ignorant, as usual (remember, musical geniuses like Whitesnake and the Cutting Crew were busy taking over the nation). The band fell apart after their 1990 album, Modernism a New Decade, was refused by their record company. Paul fell off the radar for a while, and eventually released a solo single in 1991 called Into Tomorrow. The song found its way on his full-length solo debut, released the next year. The following year, a critically acclaimed second album, Wild Wood, was released. Pauls been consistently releasing albums ever since. His latest, Illumination, was released in the US earlier this year on the tiny independent label YepRoc (based out of North Carolina. Paul is still packing them in across the pond, where his solo career is bigger than ever, and hes acquired an unofficial nickname, the Modfather (which I heard he really doesnt care for). Last month he embarked on a US tour in which a third of the dates were cancelled due to poor ticket sales. I was fortunate enough to see him on one of the non-cancelled shows, at the Orpheum Theater in Boston. I was treated to what was quite possibly one of the greatest shows Ive ever seen (and Im sure my fellow rapt audience members would agree). Backed by a solid four-piece band, Paul sang, played guitar, electric and acoustic grand piano, shook up a variety of percussion instruments and gave the crowd a thrilling, two-hour ride through his solo repertoire, in addition to a couple of nuggets from his Style Council and Jam days (even throwing in a gorgeous cover of Marvin Gayes Whats Going On). He didnt coast on his former bands reputations and never has. So why is Paul ignored over here? Is it because hes too British? Paul himself refuses to agonize over it, but doesnt feel that being British is a stumbling block in the States. Monty Pythons fucking massive in the States, he said in a recent interview, and you cant get more British than that! The overtly Oi! British punk sound of the Jam, not to mention the decidedly political and musically schizophrenic sound of the Style Council, may have been hard pills for yanks to swallow, but Pauls solo career is surprisingly accessible without being pandering. The sound is hard to describe but very easy to digest combining a folky Neil Young/Nick Drake sound with a soulful swagger reminiscent of classic American Stax/Volt. Illumination is easy to find in your local stores. Pauls earlier solo albums are a little harder to find, but the worst case scenario is that you may have to pay a slightly higher price for an import. The same goes for the Jam and Style Council albums, most if not all are still in print. Paul's official site is one of the music links listed on this site. You have no excuse. So do me a favor...put down that damn John Mayer CD and try something new.

"I just cut the hair..." Saturday afternoon I revisited urlLink The Man Who Wasn't There , the most recent film by the Coen Brothers. My girlfriend Liza and I rented it last summer and loved it, and last week I decided that it belonged in my DVD collection. So there. I cant tell you how much I love this movie. Let me start by saying that I believe Joel and Ethan Coen are two of the most brilliant filmmakers working today. As Billy Bob Thornton says in the DVDs interview segment, they dont suck. Thats quite an understatement. Ill go Billy one better: it seems to me that theyre incapable of making a bad film. Theres only one film of theirs that Im not crazy about, and thats Raising Arizona. Sure, its funny in parts, and has a certain charm to it (my favorite line is when Nicolas Cage goes into a convenience store and asks the old guy behind the counter if they have any balloons with funny shapes, to which the old man responds, nopeunless round is funny). But its rather tedious in parts, and in my opinion, ridiculing white trash while entertaining to a point -- is overrated. Mullets and wife-beater shirts can only make me laugh for so long. One of the Coens many strong points is their ability -- not unlike the late, great, Stanley Kubrick -- to experiment with a variety of different genres in a completely effortless manner. Film noir. Mafia drama. Screwball comedy. Period pictures. They make it all seem so easy. The Man Who Wasnt There is obviously an homage to film noir. Taking place in 1949, the film is shot in sumptuous black and white and stars Billy Bob Thornton, Frances McDormand, James Gandolfini, Michael Badalucco, and Tony Shalhoub, among others. Billy Bob Thornton plays Ned Crane, a near-comatose barber in Santa Rosa, California, who suspects his wife (McDormand) is sleeping with her boss (Gandolfini). I dont want to reveal too much of the plot, so lets just say that Thornton engineers a blackmail scheme that goes horribly wrong. Thornton is pretty much flawless. He plays the quiet, passive Crane with amazing ease. Everyone in the film is great, in fact, but the other standout is Tony Shalhoub, who plays Freddie Riedenschneider, the vain, fast-talking defense attorney. Hes one of those guys who loves to hear himself talk, even though most of it is hot air. He also loves talking about himself in the third person (I know you didnt hire Freddy Riedenschnider to hold your hand during a sentencing trial!). Most people know Shalhoub as the Middle-Eastern cab driver on the TV show Wings, but here (and in a previous Coen Brothers film, Barton Fink), he shows a much different side. Hes truly fantastic in this film. The music is great too. Carter Burwells score, in addition to the use of Beethoven piano sonatas, provide a haunting backdrop. The DVD looks great, and the extras are very entertaining as well. Theres some interesting interview soundbites from cast members, a thoroughly entertaining and lengthy interview with the films directory of photography, Roger Deakins, but the best feature by far is the audio commentary. Joel and Ethan are joined by Thornton in what has to be the most entertaining commentary Ive ever heard. Theyre funny, informative and informal. Sometimes these commentaries tend to get stuffy and inscrutable, but this is like having three of the films collaborators hanging out in your living room. At the risk of sounding like an old fart, why dont they make movies like this anymore? I dont just mean black and white movies, but movies with great performances, plots that arent contrived and formulaic, movies that pay tribute to the past while at the same time blazing new trails. I guess as long as the Coens are alive and well, we can still enjoy stuff like this.

the obligatory madonna rant Madonna is an easy target in the weblog community, I'm sure, but I feel I have to get this stuff off my chest. Yes, I watched her interview with Matt Lauer last night (I missed the first 15 minutes of it, though). I don't particularly care for Madonna, but urlLink TNT's Law & Order reruns have been on hiatus due to a big stinkin' heap of basketball games that apparently take place this time of year that we, as Americans, should apparently be glued to the TV for or else we're cowards and traitors. Or something. Jesus, that was quite a little mini-rant. Where was I? Oh. Madonna. Right. Anyhoo...I watched it, trying as hard as I could to eke out a bit of respect for Mrs. Ritchie. But you know what? This woman just doesn't do anything for me. I love how her supporters (and even some of her detractors) claim that she knows how to "play the media." "She's the queen of self-promotion," they all trumpet. Well, sorry if I don't jump on the bandwagon, but she didn't exactly have me eating out of the palm of her hand last night. First of all, Matt broached the subject of Madonna's questionable film career, particularly her disastrous remake of "Swept Away." Each and every statement she made concerning her trainwreck of an acting career was enhanced with petulant whining and childish defensiveness. I was expecting her, at one point, to ask Matt, "I know you are, but what am I?" At one point, Matt started to read reviews of "Swept Away," an action that was met with anger and frustration. "Stop! Don't! I don't want to hear it!" blurted Madonna. She claims she "doesn't read reviews," but when Matt later asked her if she thought she was relevant anymore, Madonna asked: "Are you referring to that New York Times article?" You mean the ones you never read, Madonna? At one point in the show, Matt sat down with Madonna and her guitar teacher and she showed him a few chords that she's recently learned. She even cranked out a shaky version of that old classic rock warhorse, "Stairway to Heaven." Call me a snob, but shouldn't someone who's been in the music business for the past 20 years have acquired at least the slightest hint of music theory along the way? Apparently not. What matters to Madonna is her image, her ability to "reinvent herself," and her dance moves. I'll be the first to admit that dancing and choreography require immense talent, concentration, and practice. But why on earth would I buy a CD of someone who dances really well? I sure as hell wouldn't do it for her mediocre singing voice. So why exactly do we worship Madonna? She's in the pop music business, but she can't sing. She's just learning to play music, so she obviously doesn't write her own songs. And we all know that she can't act. Wow! What a talented woman! Last night's special concluded with a short "unplugged" performance at a Tower Records store. The crowd went absolutely insane, but were they hearing the same mix as I was? They were obviously ga-ga over the fact that a "celebrity" was in the room, because the music sounded like ass. As I've said before, unplugged, back-to-basics performances tend to showcase the songs and the performers. "No frills" means you can concentrate on the music. Unfortunately for Madonna, that's exactly what happened at Tower.

like a ton of kubricks I bought Stanley Kubrick's 1956 classic urlLink "The Killing" DVD a couple of months ago, and I just got around to watching it last Sunday. Why? I kept forgetting I had it. Anyway, it's a remarkable film and you should check it out. Maybe even purchase it. Most places only sell it for around 10 to 12 dollars. The film, like most of Kubrick's work, is way ahead of his time. It tells the story of a racetrack heist from a series of different perspectives in a non-linear sequence (a friend of mine told me that it was a major inspiration for Quentin Tarantino's "Reservoir Dogs"). For those of you who didn't already know, I'm a huge fan of urlLink Stanley Kubrick. Like Frank Zappa, Kubrick was an artist who refused to compromise his vision and insisted on complete creative control at all times. Control freak? Maybe. But that attitude help him turn out some of the greatest motion pictures of all time. While he worked slowly (he directed only 13 feature films in about 48 years), but his perfectionism was worth it. He rarely worked in the same genre twice: he made war films, black comedy, period pieces, science fiction, horror, mystery and film noir and made them all seem effortless. Films like "2001: A Space Odyssey" and "Barry Lyndon" revolutionized filmmaking (the former was a quantum leap in special effects; the latter used natural light like never before, employing camera lenses originally designed for NASA). For Kubrick fanatics, the urlLink Stanley Kubrick Collection DVD box set (re-released in 2001 after the 1999 release was deemed a shambles of horrible transfers) is a feast for the eyes and ears. The set encompasses eight films ("Lolita," "Dr. Strangelove," "2001: a Space Odyssey," "A Clockwork Orange," "Barry Lyndon," "The Shining," "Full Metal Jacket" and "Eyes Wide Shut") in addition to a terrific domcumentary, "Stanley Kubrick: a Life in Pictures," that is almost worth the price of the whole set. As far as the box set goes, the individual films don't have much in the way of extras. Kubrick was a notoriously private person who shunned interviews and likely couldn't be bothered to record commentary tracks. One exception is "The Shining," which includes a rough-but-entertaining behind-the-scenes documentary shot and produced by Kubrick's daughter, Vivian. The film shows what a lot of people have been curious to see over the years -- Kubrick at work. Also, Vivian recorded a commentary track for it, which has to be one of the funniest, most entertaining tracks I've ever heard. It's full of stories about the production, background information, and catty asides about extras and whatnot. It's an absolute delight. Most of the rest of Kubrick's oeuvre can be found on DVD. While his early short films ("Day of the Fight" and "Flying Padre") and his first full-length feature ("Fear and Desire") have never been released on DVD or even VHS, subsequent films like "Killer's Kiss," the aforementioned "The Killing" and the excellent "Paths of Glory" are all available at quite reasonable prices. "Spartacus" is also available, both in a bare-essentials edition and a double-disc Criterion release. I urge you to get the Criterion one. It's more expensive, but looks a whole lot better and contains umpteen extra features (Kubrick practically disowned "Spartacus," by the way. He was brought on to direct it by its star, Kirk Douglas, after the original director was fired. It was the last time Kubrick was not given complete control over a film). I have a hard time picking my favorite Kubrick film -- they're all great -- but if I had to, it would probably be a tie between "Dr. Strangelove" and "Barry Lyndon." "Stranglelove" is just so damn funny, and "Lyndon" has the most amazing cinematography I've ever seen, particularly for a period picture. The Zeiss lenses that were used for shooting this film made candelight and other natural light sources come alive. It's been accused of being a slow-moving film (over three hours), but it looks absolutely gorgeous. And the story really is interesting. Kubrick films, by all accounts, were a pain in the ass to put together, but the final results were always astounding. I wouldn't rush out and by the box set without seeing the films first. But if you're a fan of daring, revolutionary filmmaking, this is one director whose work is worth your time. Rent a few of them and see what the fuss is all about.

the middlebrow reader I decided not to finish reading urlLink "The Emperor of Ocean Park," not because it was a bad book -- in fact, it was quite good -- but because I wasn't really in the mood for it. I will definitely get back to it eventually. Plus, it's a hardcover, and I always put my reading material in my Old Navy "man bag," which tends to get really weighed down when there's a 650-plus page hardcover inside. It may not sound like a big deal, but try hauling that around all day long. So I reverted back to my simpler tastes, a.k.a. espionage novels. I picked up a nice cheap "mass market" copy of urlLink "The Devil's Alternative" by Frederick Forsyth and started reading it last night. I suppose I consider myself a "middlebrow" when it comes to books. You won't necessarily see my nose buried in "the classics," although I will occasionally try them out for variety's sake -- I read a few urlLink Shakespeare plays earlier this year and enjoyed them in small doses. Also, urlLink "Lust for Life" is one of my all-time favorite books. At the same time, I'm not a fan of romance novels, "Oprah" books, most cookie-cutter mysteries, or those damn "Sex and the City"-inspired urban-woman "Bridget Jones"-type books that seems to pop up every two seconds. I do enjoy a good mystery -- urlLink Michael Connelly is an amazing writer who is always able to weave a good crime case around interesting characters. urlLink Jay McInerney is probably my favorite "urban fiction" writer, if such a category exists. Oh, and while I'm thinking of it, the next time you're in a bookstore, pick up urlLink "The Ice Harvest" and urlLink "The Walkaway" by Scott Phillips. I read them both last summer and they're simply amazing. I don't know where my fascination with espionage thrillers started, but I love them. Among my favorite authors of this genre are Jeffrey Archer, Joseph Finder, and the man I consider to be the master of the genre, Frederick Forsyth. Some of my favorite Forsyth books are urlLink "The Deceiver," urlLink "No Comebacks" (an excellent short story collection) and the classic urlLink "Day of the Jackal." The latter was made into an equally excellent urlLink film. (but for the love of God, don't see the awful remake with Bruce Willis). here comes the weekend A couple of nice things are going on this weekend. An apparently, during all of these fun-filled events, I'll be dealing with some really shitty weather. So what else is new? Have a great weekend!

bagels and ecomonics I adore the bagel sandwiches at urlLink Bruegger's. Really. Particularly the smoked salmon sandwiches. Theres a Brueggers in the building where I work, and theres even one across the street from the Borders where I work part-time. Theyve got it in for me. They know that Ill spend my hard-earned pay in their fine establishments. Although, I have to say that Ive curbed my Brueggers consumption in a major way over the last few months. I used to go there almost every day and have a smoked salmon sandwich, a drink (usually a Nantucket Nectar iced tea), a french vanilla muffin (mmmm.french vanilla muffins), and a coffee. About nine bucks. Almost every day. In the interest of keeping my waistline down to at least 35, and keeping a little more money in my pocket, I now only go there once in a while (two or three times a month is my current average, Id say), and usually bring my lunch with me. Another advantage to resisting the mighty Brueggers urge is that I have considerably more spending money. Which Ive been sinking into my CD collection lately. Not exactly the same as putting it away, but hey Ill get to that endeavor eventually. old french perverts and ocean park emperors Speaking of sinking money into CDsI really am getting into this Serge Gainsbourg fella. As I told you yesterday, I bought the compilation Initials SG over the weekend. Last night I picked up urlLink "Du Jazz dans le Ravin" and urlLink Aux Armes et Caetera. Du Jazz is pretty self-explanatory, a 1997 compilation of his jazzier stuff, mostly from the late fifties and early sixties. Lots of little jazzy instrumentals in addition to some jazzy crooning. The whole thing is great (and jazzy), and Im particularly taken by the song Intoxicated Man, which features some killer Hammond organ, and a really unusual combination of French and English in the chorusCes araignees sur le plastron / dmon smoking / ces chauves-souris au plaford / du livingroom. The way he says dmon smoking, I just cant describe it, its very cool. Aux Armes is very different. Its Gainsbourgs reggae album. Really. Its hardcore reggae, recorded in Jamaica with reggae session vets like Sly Dunbar, Robbie Shakespeare and the I-Threes (Bob Marleys back-up singers). He may be French, but when Serge wants to do reggae, he apparently doesnt do it half-assed. This stuff is the real deal. Of course, instead of some dreadlocked Jamaican toaster, youve got Serges monotone French voice gliding over the whole thing. Which is nice. The lyrics of the title track, by the way, are apparently La Marseillaise, which is the French national anthem. In front of a reggae song. Sung by a middle-aged party animal chain-smoker. Not exactly Britney Spears. As I mentioned yesterday, I put Michael Connellys Lost Light on hold for the time being and decided to start reading urlLink "The Emperor of Ocean Park," a novel by Stephen Carter, an African-American Yale professor who received a $4.2 million advance for this, his first work of fiction. Despite all the idiosyncratic backstory, the book is turning out pretty interesting so far, an engaging story and a unique, dense, very descriptive narrative style.

thats quite an eclectic selection youve got there I suppose the above line is what the average person might say to me when they found out about the pile of compact discage I acquired over the weekend, in between enjoying the weather, logging in the requisite four hours at the urlLink Borders gig on Saturday morning and spending some time with my extended family. Nice weekend, overall. Heres how it happened: After I punched out of Borders around noon-ish on Saturday, I added two more urlLink King Crimson CDs to my ever-growing collection: Beat and Three of a Perfect Pair, both from KCs excellent Belew/Fripp/Bruford/Levin period. I havent had a chance to fully digest these discs yet, but so far Im enjoying what I hear. Theyve both acquired a shaky reputation in some circles as being dumbed-down, commercial pop versions of the excellent Discipline (the 1981 debut release of this particular line-up), but they sound fine to me. In the world of King Crimson, commercial is a relative term. Also, there was a huge listening station change-out on Friday night, so there were plenty of promo discs available for pick-up. I nabbed both a Mozart piano trios disc and a Boccherini guitar quintet disc from the excellent urlLink Classical Express budget label, in addition to Diana Kralls urlLink "Live in Paris" album (I dont own any other DK or am even that familiar with her, but I figured a live album would be a nice place to start). I also got the new urlLink reissue of Yes Fragile album. Yay! Rhino's recent reissue includes extended liner notes and two bonus tracks (a rough early version of Roundabout and their impressive, totally Yes-ified cover of Paul Simons America, which I havent heard in eons since I lived with my brother and heard his version from the Yesterdays compilation). To top it off, the jewel case is enclosed in one of those nifty slipcase things. Im all about cool packaging. After work, I met Liza for lunch at Annas Taqueria. Do you live in Boston? Do you like Mexican food? Well, for crying out loud, get your ass over to Annas. Theres four locations and theyre all great. We were at the one on the corner of Summit Avenue and Beacon Street, which has become so popular that theyve added a second serving line. After a trip to the urlLink Body Shop where Liza used the rest of the $50 gift certificate I got her for Valentines Day, we met my sister Julie at her house and then all headed up to lovely Windham, New Hampshire, where my Aunt Elaine hosted a wonderful little get together for my Mom, who was in town from Maryland over the weekend. Mom and Charlie (her companion of the last thirteen years or so, and an all around excellent dude) came up to New Hampshire to pass papers on the condo shes owned since 1983 and had finally decided to rid herself of. So Saturday night was a night of heavy Boston accents, Italian food, and three, count em, three birthday cakes for my Aunt Linda, whose birthday was the next day. Liza and I blew off an originally planned brunch at the urlLink House of Blues in favor of sleeping in, and finally made it out of my house by around 4 p.m. We ended up wandering around Harvard Square, an activity I absolutely love, where the urlLink HMV store was selling everything for 30% off. Thats roughly the same discount I get at Borders, so it was like visiting a completely different Borders location. Yay! Their classical selection is probably the best in the city (Virgin Megastore comes close, and ours isnt too bad), but I ended up getting a Serge Gainsbourg compilation entitled urlLink "Initials SG" and the soundtrack to urlLink "Barry Lyndon," which Ive been searching for interminably and is apparently only available as an import. Ive been contemplating getting some Gainsbourg CDs for the longest time. His popularity among people like Beck and John Wesley Harding has always intrigued me. The music is sort of hard to explain. Hes a sort of French dirty old man whose music straddles the borders of jazz, funk, cabaret, reggae and a whole bunch of other stuff. His voice, by the way, sounds completely different that what I expected. Its a smooth, rather accessible voice, and I was expecting a raspy, Tom Waits/Paolo Conte sound (considering the fact that he was a Gitanes-smoking fiend). After the productive trip to HMV, we went to urlLink Chili's for dinner and headed back to Brighton in a rather unconventional manner, taking the train to Central Square and then walking to Allston by going down Brookline Street through Cambridgeport. One of my favorite Boston walks is the length of Brookline Street from Mass Ave to the BU bridge. The houses have a funky edge to them, but are located in a gorgeous, woody, residential area. If anyone out there can recommend some other worthwhile Serge Gainsbourg discs, please let me know. Oh, and Ive abandoned urlLink Michael Connelly's Lost Light for the time being. I love Connellys books, but this particular book just doesnt seem to be grabbing me. Maybe Im just not in the mood. I started, for the umpteenth time, John LeCarre's urlLink "The Spy Who Came In From the Cold" this morning. We'll see how that turns out. Given my weakness for espionage novels, I don't know why I haven't read this book yet, since it's supposedly the Rosetta Stone of the genre. I have a feeling that once I get going with it, I'll be glad I did. In regards to espionage novels, I've had the urge to read urlLink "The Devil's Alternative" by Frederick Forsyth for about a year now. It's weird: the first time I ever set foot in what was to become my apartment in Dorchester was when Frank was hosting a going-away party for a fellow Borders employee. I was somewhat sure that I would be moving in there a couple of weeks later, and it was a wonderful rainy Saturday afternoon. I was looking out the living room window, onto a view of Dorchester, and I caught a glimpse of a tanker moving across the Boston Harbor. I suddenly began thinking of this novel, in which a Soviet tanker plays a pivotal role (I think -- I listened to an abridge audiobook version several years ago). Suddenly I felt like it was the perfect time to read this book and it never really went away. I'm funny like that.
