ive suffered for something/anything Have I mentioned how much Im loving this amazing weather? I am. A lot. As I remarked in a recent post, Im a winter person. I love rain, snow and cold. But this winter the most brutal New England winter I think Ive ever experienced -- has really tested my patience and Im welcoming the warmth. This morning, on my way to the subway, I was not only enjoying the rays of the elusive sun, but also the sounds of my CD Walkman. Specifically a great live unplugged CD by Marshall Crenshaw called urlLink "I've Suffered for my Art...Now It's Your Turn." I acquired my promo copy of this disc in 2001, shortly after it was released, and it got some pretty heavy rotation in the portable CD player for quite a while. Now its back on the personal playlist. I really enjoy these live unplugged affairs. A singer/songwriter playing his songs on an acoustic guitar in front of a small, appreciative crowd really brings out the quality of the compositions. Paul Wellers urlLink "Days of Speed" and Warren Zevons urlLink "Learning to Flinch" are two other great examples of this format. Crenshaw is another one of those artists who rarely gets mainstream recognition, but most people love the songs once they hear them. In my opinion, he ranks right up there with Elvis Costello and Chris Difford and Glenn Tilbrook (Squeezes songwriting team) as one of the best songwriters of the eighties. He had a minor hit in 1982 with a song called Someday, Someway and then promptly fell off the pop culture radar (with the exception of a brief acting role as Buddy Holly in the Richie Valens biopic La Bamba). Despite the lack of exposure, Marshalls been quietly making enjoyable, often brilliant albums to this day. A few years ago, Rhino released a great Crenshaw compilation entitled This Is Easy, but I would personally recommend Ive Suffered for my Art as the ultimate primer on the brilliant songwriting of Marshall Crenshaw. The songs are front and center here, not to mention Marshalls wonderful voice and guitar playing. The crowd (recorded at the Stone Poney in Asbury Park, New Jersey) is hugely appreciative as well. Another disc I spent part of my commute enjoying this morning is Todd Rundgrens urlLink "Something/Anything?" Ill admit that my knowledge of Todds music is somewhat limited, but about a year ago I began hearing some great things about this particular album on urlLink alt.music.mike-keneally (Mike himself is a huge Rundgren fan), so I picked up this double-disc and began immersing myself in some important early seventies rock history. The album really is amazing, if only for the fact that Todd played all the instruments himself (except for a couple of live tracks) and wrote all the songs himself (except for a couple of covers). But unlike a lot of one-man-band affairs, this doesnt sound like a silly novelty project. This could easily be a highly skilled group of session musicians, which speaks volumes for Todds expertise and ambition. The songs themselves run the gamut from pop masterpieces (I Saw the Light, "Hello Its Me) to bizarre artifacts of the time period (the quirky instrumental Breathless, the prog-rock Song of the Viking). All for $17.99 (thats what I paid for it, anyway).

get over yourself, explained (sort of) Yesterday's post was supposed to be a jab at the ridiculous rock star behavior of Chan Marshall, a.k.a. Cat Power. Then I veered off into a bit of a tangent near the end. I ended up disturbing someone whose opinion means a lot to me. I sent her an e-mail as a clarification. Here it is, more or less: I'm not invalidating anyone's opinion on any type of art. There is tons of art, music and film that moves me tremendously. I think that when a "rock star" (I'm really limiting these opinions to music, by the way) has the gall to suggest that his or her music is so powerful that it will change the world simply because he or she is expressing a profound statement, then that person needs to get over him or herself and realize that they're only reaching a certain percentage of the world's population, and also that there are people out there who a) may not agree with their statement, and b) may not feel that rock or pop music is a valid avenue for world change. I think what I was trying to say -- and apparently I didn't say it correctly -- is that pop/rock musicians have placed themselves on such a pedestal that they don't realize their music isn't as universal as they may think. It's possible that a John Lennon song, a U2 song or a Bob Dylan song will make people think. It can change their perceptions. If an artist has enough fans, he can give people guidance and advice on a world situation because they listen to him. But rock music reaches a relatively small part of the world. We are led to believe otherwise. I am a realistic person, but also a hopeful one. Music, art and film are very important to me, but there are a lot of people out there who view them simply as entertainment and to think that we're going to change the opinions and actions of Saddam Hussein or any other war-mongering nut, is unrealistic.

get over yourself On his TV show Politically Incorrect, the often-misunderstood and occasionally brilliant Bill Maher presented from time to time a segment he called the Prince Rogers Nelson Get Over Yourself Award, given to celebrities he felt took themselves and their status just a little too seriously. Howard Stern, Claudia Schiffer and even Judge Lance Ito were some of the recipients of this dubious honor. Now that Bills show is off the air, Id like to bring back that award, at least on occasion where I feel a certain celebrity has gotten a little too smug about his or her status as a famous person. What brought this idea on, for me, was an article I read this morning about a singer/songwriter named Chan Marshall, who inexplicably goes by the pseudonym of urlLink Cat Power. Ive heard Miss Powers music before, and to be honest, shes not really that bad. Shes developed a rabid following among the hip indie crowd for her depressing, minor-key quasi-folk music, which I can actually appreciate in small doses (think a female, dissonant Nick Drake with even more of a suicidal streak and youve got the general idea). About a year ago I first heard her 2000 covers album (helpfully entitled The Covers Record), and her latest album, You Are Free is getting played ad nauseum by selected fellow employees of the Borders music and video department. Like I said, her musics okay, but a bit overrated. Anyway, on to the article I read this morningit was actually a review of her concert at the Somerville Theatre last Friday. The review required some backstory: apparently Her Catness canceled a sold-out show last year at the last minute, then blew off the rescheduled date. Shes known for this type of thing. Oh, these temperamental artistes! At her concert last week, she actually showed up, albeit in a dark corner behind the piano during the entire performance (oohhow mysterious! ) Marshall/Powers erratic behavior tended to get worse as the show went on, as she forgot lyrics, abandoned some songs altogether, fumbled for long stretches between songs, etc etc etc. The kicker, for me anyway, was when she broke a fingernail (after about a third of the audience had already left, apparently) and asked if anyone wanted it. Some obsessed uber-fan apparently took her up on the offer and went home with a little piece of Cat Power. Its easy to blame the moronic, get-a-life behavior of this fan-cum-cuticle enthusiast, but Cat/Chan herself is to blame for encouraging this sort of thing. She actually suggested that there may be people in the audience who would want this fingernail. She has the gall to assume that her cuticles are worthy of praise and adulation. Three words, Chan. Get. Over. Yourself. Ill admit that there are artists out there I admire greatly who have a moody, mercurial personality that often translates to erratic behavior onstage and off. urlLink Van Morrison comes to mind. But you know what? Thats Van Fucking Morrison. If Cat Power were responsible for Astral Weeks, Moondance and Veedon Fleece, Id excuse the behavior. But otherwise, show up for your scheduled gigs and throw your nails in the trash like the rest of us commoners. What the average rock star cant seem to get through his or her thick skull is that, despite what Bono tells you, rock stars are not going to change the world. Woodstock did not end the Vietnam War. Live Aid did not cure world hunger. John Lennon did not put a stop to people killing each other. Rock stars are entertainers, and many of them are capable of creating art that is beautiful and transcendental. As someone who owns roughly 850 CDs, it may seem strange for me to say this, but its just music. The people who create it are human beings. Cat Powers fingernails may have a bit of polish on them, but otherwise theyre just like mine. If you or I were scheduled to show up for a job interview and ended up blowing it off twice, there isnt a chance in hell we would get hired. Why should be accept the same behavior from a rock star?

rain, beethoven and clean underwear I really wish I had something wise and wonderful to share with you this afternoon, but it aint happening. Sorry. Laundry may be free in our apartment, but its an excruciating undertaking. Until now. Well, let me back up. Huzzah! Saints be praised. Oh, and in case you were wondering Im still hip-deep in my ever-growing urlLink King Crimson CD collection. the mellotron players wearing a cape I hate to tell you this, but Im starting to develop a reemerging interest in urlLink progressive rock. Progressive, or prog as the kids call it today, used to be called art rock. Im glad its changed. Prog sounds more fun, which is a good thing, since that particular brand of music could certainly use a sense of humor in between all its ruminations on knights and swords and planets and starship troopers. In the mid to late seventies, when I was a wee grade-school tyke, I was not lucky enough to be exposed to the revolutionary sounds of Elvis Costello, the Jam, the Clash, Joe Jackson or Talking Heads (that would take me a few more years). Instead, as my older brother and older sisters ruled over the turntable, our household was oblivious to the lean sounds of punk and was instead subjected to bands like Yes, Supertramp, Queen and Emerson, Lake & Palmer. Im sorry to have to tell you that. Why am I apologizing? Well, progs gotten a bad rep over the years. Its completely uncool to even acknowledge this type of music. To put it in perspective, prog is the musical equivalent to reading fantasy novels and playing Dungeons & Dragons. But as I get older I find that its not necessary for me to shun or ignore a type of music simply based on its dork factor. I know who I am. I dont need to tap my peers on the shoulder for approval. Plus, I think that the most important factor in an individuals musical taste is eclecticism. I not only like Elvis Costello, Los Lobos, Beck and Flaming Lips, but also Yes, Beethoven, Glenn Gould, Queen, Frank Sinatra, Horace Silver and Claude Bolling. I can listen to them all in one sitting. Some of those artists get a hard time due to their lack of being part of the zeitgeist . But I dont care. Lets take Yes, for example. Theyre one of the best-known prog bands of all time, and even though I really only enjoy three of their albums (The Yes Album, Fragile and Close to the Edge, released between 1970 and 1972), those are some damn good albums. There is some extremely engaging, well-played stuff going on there. Jethro Tulls Living in the Past is a great album too, as is Supertamps Crisis? What Crisis? (purists may not acknowledge them as prog, but I think they have managed to take the essence of prog and squeeze it quite nicely into the pop song format --- it's sort of a Beatlesque Prog), Queens Queen II (easily their proggiest moment), and Ill even go so far as to say that there are segments of Emerson, Lake & Palmers Brain Salad Surgery that I really like a lot. I like to think that my obsession with he music of Frank Zappa, which started in the early eighties and continues to this day, is an extension of my prog leanings that never really went away, but Zappa is really in a class by himself. His music particularly in the seventies definitely had a prog side to it, but a lot of that was due to his interest and implementation of both classical and jazz. Dont get me wrong theres lots of prog out there that is bloated, pretentious and boring (the main criticisms of the genre). Theres a lot of it out there thats just too ungainly for me (like a lot of ELP) and some of it call it teenyprog, if you will is sugary and too pop-oriented (like Styx -- blecch). Also, almost all prog that attempts to fuse orchestras with rock bands is horrific and deserves all the ridicule its subjected to (why hire an orchestra when a mellotron will do?). But if youre a music fan who wants to venture beyond the three-minute pop/rock single and isnt ashamed of listening to something totally uncool, you should try some of these bands. There are even current prog bands out there, like Spocks Beard, Porcupine Tree, Kings X (and I understand Tool is considered prog in some circles). Hell, if Lord of the Rings can be cool again, why not these guys? By the way, this whole rambling speech on prog rock was supposed to be a preamble to an essay on my recent discovery and current obsession of one of prog's originators, King Crimson. That will have to be a separate piece for another time. Soon.

we never leave the past behind, we just accumulate It looks like its up to me to give you all a review of the Joe Jackson concert, since none of the Boston papers felt it was worthy of their time. Strange, especially since the urlLink Herald wrote a nice article about Joe earlier in the week. As you probably already know, my sister Julie and I went to see urlLink Joe Jackson at the Paradise last Saturday. It was the second of two sold out shows he performed there over the weekend (the first one was Friday night). It was general admission, so we got there fairly early in order to get a good space up front (which we did we were directly in front of Gary Sanford, the guitarist). The opening act was a band called urlLink Mary Lee's Corvette actually a trio led by a female singer name Mary Lee Kortes. She sang and played acoustic guitar and was accompanied by a drummer and bass player (who looked like a stoned Albert Brooks and did this really weird walk/dance when he was playing that looked oddly gorilla-like). Their music sounded like something I wouldnt really care for (kind of country/folkish) but they were actually really good. Apparently last year (or maybe it was 2001) they made the extremely ballsy move of doing a cover album of Dylans urlLink "Blood on the Tracks." The entire album, song by song. They only did one song from that album (Youre Gonna Make Me Lonesome When You Go) but it sounded great. The music played over the PA before the show was quite good. Its always interesting to hear what music the artist chooses to have playing before the band hits the stage. This mix was very appropriate for Joes fan base, I think. Lots of late seventies/early eighties punk/new wave. Ian Dury, Graham Parker, Nick Lowe, the Clashit was awesome. I was easily one of the youngest people in the audience. A lot of fortysomethings and graying fiftysomethings, even (fortunately I didnt see any male ponytails what is it about aging hippies that makes them think the ponytail will somehow stop the aging process?). What can I say about Joes set? He was fantastic. The band was simply astonishing. Its hard to believe that these guys havent played together since 1980. There was a tremendous amount of energy onstage. He played a bunch of new stuff (from the excellent new album, Vol. 4) in addition to lots of classics, borrowing heavily from his first two albums, Look Sharp and Im the Man. For the most part, Joe stuck pretty close to the studio arrangements, with one notable exception: the angular reggae of Fools in Love was slowed down considerably, giving it a hypnotic, dirge-like quality. He even spiced it up by adding a segment of the Yardbirds For Your Love right in the middle of the song. In addition to the electric piano, Joe also found time to shake the maracas and broke out a urlLink melodica on a few songs. I love melodicas! About halfway through the set, the band left the stage and Joe played four songs by himself on the piano. He did two originals (Stepping Out and a personal favorite of mine, Hometown todays post title is a line from that song) in addition to two excellent covers (Steely Dans Any Major Dude Will Tell You and the Beatles Girl). Unfortunately, this part of the show also caused the biggest inconvenience for me and Julie, since a trio of inebriated tools (a guy and two girls) apparently didnt realize (or didnt seem to care) that their loud, drunken talking was getting in the way of a pretty quiet, intimate group of songs. I was about two seconds away from telling them to shut up until I realized that it probably would have made it worse (What? What? Why you want me to shut up? Issa free country, isnt it? Hey! What? Im not drunk! Cmere, Im gonna kick yer ass! Belch.) The newer songs mixed in quite nicely with the old. Vol. 4 definitely sounds a lot like Look Sharp, but the ballads add a new dimension (reminiscent of his quiet 1982 masterpiece Night & Day). The wardrobe angle isnt really important, but I have to say that Joe really personified the attributes of dorky GQ. Thats the only way I can describe it. Black pinstripe suit, black shoes and white socks. I love it! And while he never really was a very attractive man, he was so pale he almost appeared translucent. I would have been concerned for his health, but judging by the amount of jumping around he was doing, Joe is apparently doing just fine. The last several songs were definitely the highlight, energy-wise. Uptempo numbers like Dont Wanna Be Like That, Im the Man, Got the Time and Look Sharp were given an extra jolt thanks to the manic live setting. Joe Jackson is one of those artists Ive been listening to for a long time but have never managed to see in concert. I can certainly cross him off the list, but I certainly hope its not the last time I see him! Oh, and I got a nice t-shirt, even though urlLink the one I really wanted wasn't being sold at the gig like I originally thought.

on joni and the art of waking up I find as I get older I oversleep a lot less. In my early twenties I didnt exactly have a handle on the whole punctuality thing, mainly due to my increased love of carousing. Now that Im older and more boring, I find that getting up when the alarm actually goes off is much easier. Not this morning. I finally crawled out of bed about an hour later than I was supposed to. First, let me explain my whole alarm/waking thing to you (can you tell I dont have anything particularly exciting to post today?). When I bought my cell phone, I threw my clock radio in the closet and began using the phone as an alarm. I also set my TV to turn on at the same time. I dont have any type of snooze feature to fall back on, but I feel this is a good thing. As a society, we are far too dependent on the Almighty Snooze. I know people who hit snooze for over an hour before actually getting up. This fitful hour of half-sleeping should not be construed as an extra hour of sleep. Rather, its 60 minutes of being awakened every nine minutes. Big difference. My cell phone/TV alarm system works nicely. When I set them to go off (at 6:30 a.m.), I turn off the phone alarm but keep the TV on, so I can gently ease into the waking up process. The local news is on until seven, which gives me the opportunity to half-hear news reports under a haze of sleep (I cant tell you how many strange Iraq-related dreams Ive experienced lately). Why am I telling you all of this? To kill time before I leave the office in a half-hour. Oh, and also to tell you that the reason for my oversleeping this morning was because I was hypnotized by a urlLink PBS documentary on Joni Mitchell the night before. I was getting ready to turn off the TV and go to bed when I did a cursory last flip around the channels and caught this very enjoyable and well-produced program on one of the most celebrated rock artists that Ive never really paid much attention to. Ive hesitated diving into Jonis music mainly because I get the feeling that shes influenced a lot of the "Lilith" crowd. I dont care for Sarah MacLachlan, Natalie Merchant, Mellisa Ferrick, Ani DiFranco, the Indigo Girls or anyone else in that category. Oh, and before you start writing to me, complaining that one of those artists is not like the others, etc, etc, keep in mind that I realize that it may come off as gross generalizations but I just dont care for the whole female folkie thing. I cant get into any of it. Im not misogynistic, I just dont like the music. Im sure theyre all nice people, but that doesnt mean I have to buy their albums. But Joni strikes me as completely different. First of all, she was doing it long before anyone else, and second of all (and I know this because I saw a show about it last night), she has always been a tireless musical experimentalist. Just when you thought you were safe with her vocals and acoustic guitar, she makes albums with jazz alums like Jaco Pastorious, Tom Scott and the great Charles Mingus. She was doing world music long before it was hip. Hugely talented artists as diverse as Elvis Costello and Prince(!) have cited her as a major influence. So I think its time I investigate this womans music more thoroughly. If any seasoned Joni-philes out there can give me some recommendations, Id be glad to get your input. The address is at the top of the page. This should be a fun weekend. Saturday night my sister Julie and I are going to dinner and then catching urlLink Joe Jackson at the Paradise. Yay for Joe! Sunday were going up to New Hampshire to visit our other sister Karen and her kids, Mike and Lauren. Old-school New Wavers on one day, kickin back with the fam on the next. Oh, and some bittersweet news: Liza has been accepted to a urlLink semester abroad program in Holland. Its a great opportunity for her and Im extremely happy for her. But now I have to figure out what to do with myself from September to December. Oh, and if there's any young Dutch guys reading this, keep your hands off my woman. Have a great weekend and remember to "spring forward."

judy blume for president I dont remember how it started, but sometime today I began thinking about Judy Blume. You know, the woman who wrote all those childrens books (and a few for adults as well). Anyway, I began snooping around the Internet and I found a nice little urlLink essay she wrote about Harry Potter and censorship. I used to love her for her books. Now I love what she thinks about censorship, too. The first time I ever read Judy Blume was in fourth grade, when it was actually read to my class. Our teacher, Mrs. Robinson, read us Otherwise Known as Sheila the Great and (naturally) Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing. At the time, I was a full-fledged fan of both urlLink Tintin comic books (I was living in France at the time) and the urlLink Hardy Boys. I gobbled those suckers up one after another. But the Blume books were a wonderful diversion, not unlike throwing on a silly chick flick or angst-ridden ensemble comedy after living on a diet of espionage films. A couple of years later when my parents were going through a divorce, my mother gave me a copy of Its Not the End of the World, another Blume book, this time chronicling the ups and down of a young girl (who was probably about my age at the time) dealing with the split of her parents. I found the book engaging and quite touching, and in some parts it hit close to home a bit more than I wanted it to. On a different note, I really liked the main characters best friend, a brainy pre-teen who enjoys reading the Sunday New York Times in its entirety. Im 34 and I cant even do that. In the eighth grade, I read Then Again, Maybe I Wont, which is probably one of my favorite books from childhood. A young boy (again, about my age), moves with his family to a fancy neighborhood after his father gets a big promotion. He meets new friends, still feels out of place, and to top it all off, he develops an enormous crush on a girl next door who has a habit of undressing with her shades open. Holy crap! Talk about tapping into the neurosis of a young pre-teen boy. Its probably the only book for this age group that hints at the subject of, well self-love. I know for a fact that at least a couple of Blumes books were banned, and this is probably one of them. Why is that? Well, nobody is gunned down or raped in this book, but a young boy does in fact commit the unpardonable sin of getting a hard-on (sorry! Off the soapbox!). Theres not really much point to this post, just a stroll down memory lane, and a reminder that not to sound like an old fart it may be a good idea for you parents out there to encourage recreational reading. Judy Blume is just one example, but a damn good one.

i am trying to write a review In April 2003, urlLink Wilco released urlLink "Yankee Hotel Foxtrot," which to me was easily the best album Id heard all year. It was also an album that had more of a backstory than any release in recent memory. First of all, the band started recording it shortly after firing their original drummer, Ken Coomer. Then, conflicts between co-leaders Jeff Tweedy and Jay Bennett came to head and Jay was asked to leave. To top it all off, when the finished product was delivered to Reprise Records, the company after a considerable period of silence and collective head-scratching asked the boys to make the album more commercial sounding. Tweedy Wilcos singer and principal songwriter said no way. Reprise dropped them from their label, and the band had a finished album but nobody to release it. Eventually, after shopping around to different labels, Nonesuch Records agreed to take them on and release YHF as is, with no alterations whatsoever. Nonesuch is somewhat of an avant-garde label, known primarily for classical and world music. And get this theyre a subsidiary of Time-Warner, just like Reprise. So I guess that means that Warner Brothers rejected the album and then bought it back. Ha! Wouldnt it have been great if someone had filmed this whole soap opera? Well, guess what they did. urlLink I Am Trying To Break Your Heart is billed as a film about Wilco, but its really the story behind this fantastic album that the general public almost didnt get the chance to hear. Sam Jones a magazine photographer who had never shot a film before this one was given almost total access to the band during rehearsals, recording sessions, and various concert dates. All the while he gives us interviews with all concerned, even one Reprise executive (the only one willing to talk, apparently). You get to see firsthand Tony Margherita, Wilco's manager, on his cellphone as he first hears the news that Reprise doesn't want to release the album. There are a few verbal tiffs caught on camera, including a memorable one between Tweedy and Bennett arguing over how a particular track should be mixed. They dont actually raise their voices, but the tension is palpable and is a harbinger of things to come. Tweedy is apparently a quiet man who lets his music do the talking, and when he does perform onstage and on camera, his talent and charisma are obvious. The whole band, in fact, kicks ass in this film, whether rocking out with Im Always in Love or an electric version of Kamera, or working their way through an early, gorgeous version of Jesus, Etc. One of the reasons I assume that Reprise refused the album is its experimental bent. While the band hadnt abandoned their country-tinged, no-frills rock and roll roots, the sounds on YHF are supplemented by bits of radio static, unusual instrumentation, and the occasional primal scream moment. As a die-hard fan of this album for the past year, I was delighted to see where it all took place, especially witnessing the odd assortment of steel drums, antique keyboards and vintage guitars that make up the albums sonic landscape. The DVD is packed with extras. In addition to an extra disc of additional performances and a few silly, throwaway scenes, theres a short documentary called I Am Trying To Make a Film (a documentary about a documentary?) and an excellent, insightful and often hilarious audio commentary featuring Sam Jones and Wilco (who cryptically exit the sound booth when Jones discusses the above-mentioned mixing fiasco between Tweedy and Bennett). One of the journalists interviewed in the film explains that this is not VH1: Behind the Music, in other words its not about celebrity rock stars or drug overdoses. Its about the music. Its about a genuinely talented bunch of musicians making a fantastic album. In black and white.

on the bubble I dont consider myself a huge fan of prime-time network television theres just so much junk out there -- but there are a small number of shows that I watch regularly. Well, four, actually: urlLink "Law & Order" (and its two spin-offs) and urlLink "Boomtown" (I will occasionally watch urlLink "The West Wing," but I have to admit that their smug, sanctimonious liberalism is sometimes too much even for this die-hard liberal). I was mildly shocked and more than a little disappointed when I learned that the excellent Boomtown is on the bubble for next seasons line-up. Thats industry jargon for its not a huge success, so it may or may not be renewed. Thus Boomtown may be joining steaming piles of dung like My Big Fat Greek Life and Good Morning, Miami in the heap of discarded shows. Whats wrong with this picture? Apparently I dont keep up on the Nielsen ratings, because I was under the impression that Boomtown was a huge success. But its only the critics who love the show, because the general viewing audiences are too busy falling over themselves to get to whatever new reality TV craze is sweeping the nation. Reality TV, from what I can remember, started with MTVs The Real World. While I found the show (and MTV in general) more than a little grating, I appreciated the concept. It was an interesting sociological experiment. But umpteen seasons later, the show has run its course and has become a parody of itself. While they purport to use a random sampling of roommates, its obvious as dirt that they are scrambling for a cookie-cutter demographic. Theres always The Minority, The Lesbian, The Extrovert, The Square, etc etc etc. Booooring. While The Real World stopped becoming interesting about halfway through its first season (more than ten years ago), reality TV is riding high in the new millennium. For the life of me, I cant understand why. The subjects of these shows are either brainless studs or brainless bimbos, sporting a horrible fakenbake tan and trying so hard to be as hip as possible while sporting the IQ of a goldfish. These are all stupid people, leading shallow, materialistic lives, all the while enlisting the aid of a team of nitwit TV producers to help them search for a stupid, shallow, materialistic soul mate. Who needs the intricate plotting and stellar acting talents of a show like Boomtown when we can all follow Mr. And Mrs. Moron on their quest for true love? Or maybe we could follow the Morons on their enriching quest to win heaps of money by simply performing the daredevil tasks assigned to them by the producers and host of Fear Factor. But wait! Theres some Morons out there who want to mate with other Morons, but must first face the wrath of their parents! So lets copy the plot of a marginally funny movie and crank out a series! Do the lie detector thing! Thatll get some laughs, especially when the tech shows everyone that the subject is lying by flashing the grim thumbs down! Ha! Stop! Its too funny! I have an idea. Rename Boomtown to make it sound like a new reality show. Who Wants to Go To Boomtown? No? How aboutMeet My Boomtown? Or maybe Donnie Wahlbergs Showcase of Dirty Cops? That way, itll be sure to make the cut for the next season.

who says you can't buy trust? I forgot to mention that I stopped by the urlLink Newbury Comics on Newbury Street last Friday afternoon (as I often do) and after much perusing, I finally picked up a used copy of the Rykodisc reissue of Elvis Costello's stellar urlLink "Trust" album, which I find to be his second best, right behind the incomparable urlLink "Get Happy!!" As you may know, all my Elvis Costello discs were stolen from my apartment almost two years ago (along with all my Miles Davis, Bob Dylan, Bob Marley and Van Morrison), and I've been working hard at rebuilding the collection. Fortunately, urlLink Rhino has been hard at work reissuing EC's catalog with deluxe two-disc versions of all his titles. Porkchop: Behind the Music I got an e-mail from my friend Jamie Salafia this afternoon, basically complaining that I never mention him on my blog. To be honest, Jamie, most of the cast of characters who make a regular appearance on pressure drop are people Im in touch with on a daily basis (Liza, my sister, etc). But maybe I can dig into the recesses of my past and come up with an interesting anecdote or two. Jamie Salafia is probably one of my closest, dearest friends. We met in the summer of 1992 when we were both in the military (he in the air force, me in the navy). We were both stationed in Keflavik, Iceland, working as broadcast journalists (and please dont ask me if I ever went on the radio and said Gooood morning Iceland! Its a stupid question, everyone asks it, but for the record: no, I never did that). Jamie and I had recently become married men. Not to each other: he, to the lovely Debbie, and me, to my (now ex-) wife Cynda. Jamie and I were also friends with several other fellow military journalists, including an unusual fellow named Gerard Johnson. I really dont know where to begin with Gerard. Hes from South Dakota and is the youngest of something like thirteen kids. Hes extremely hyper and rarely lets anyone else in the room speak. He reminds me a little of Kramer from Seinfeld. Gerard is also an accomplished guitarist and drummer. As a lapsed drummer myself, we decided to try forming a band (I was conveniently able to use Gerards drum set while he concentrated on the guitar). One of our stations technicians was a guy named Wade Martin, who not only played bass, but owned a Rickenbacker bass! Very cool. Wade was in the band in a heartbeat. I dont know exactly how Jamie came to be in the band, but one thing led to another and this guy who doesnt really know how to sing was suddenly a singer. Keep in mind that when I say Jamie cant sing, hell be the first to agree. But we all had roughly the same taste in music, we all got along, so what the hell. Madonna cant sing either (see Tuesdays rant). A band name was in order. An early contender for a name was Go Meinhold, our subversive way of paying tribute to Keith Meinhold, a Navy submariner who admitted on national television that he was a homosexual (this was during the beginnings of the whole dont ask, dont tell era). But we chickened out, and eventually settled on the name Porkchop. Our standard answer whenever people asked us why we used that name was that it was Homer Simpsons favorite food. We used to rehearse at this quonset hut/rec room-type facility that was located literally in the middle of nowhere, somewhere between the bases airfield and the USO. We eventually hammered out a setlist consisting of some relatively safe alternative fare from the 80s and 90s. Some of the songs included In Between Days by the Cure (due to our lack of a keyboard player, Gerard played the keyboard riff on a kazoo), These Important Years by Husker Du, Suedehead by Morrissey, I Melt With You by Modern English (that was to be our set closer, if Im not mistaken I have videotape of us rehearsing that song and Jamie is writhing on the floor during the final choruses), Alive by Pearl Jam (early nineties, anyone?), Ma and Pa by Fishbone (a song Ive always loved, but we could never really nail the tempo, in my opinion), Its the End of the World As We Know It by Jamies favorite band, REM (we had an interesting arrangement of this song we did the first verse extremely slow and then repeated it at the regular frenetic pace we were so damn cool), Here Comes Your Man by the Pixies and Kill Your Television by Neds Atomic Dustbin, a song whose ass I happen to think we totally kicked. Overall, we didnt really practice as much as we should, and as a result I have to say that we achieved moments of occasional above-average musicianship but thats about it. Jamie wasnt much of a singer, but he had spirit and the four of us had lots and lots of laughs during those rehearsals. We never seemed to know how to end songs properly and I remember when I came up with the idea of melding Suedehead and Alive into a medley, it must have taken us all afternoon to try and pull that off. The band went through phases of activity and inactivity throughout 1993, but we never really got a gig. We were just permanently rehearsing. At one point, however, there was a base talent show sponsored by the USO, and we jumped at the chance, but not before making a few unorthodox band changes that may or may not have contributed to our shame and eventual demise. First of all, we hired fellow navy journalist Terry Welch (a.k.a. urlLink Nitpicker ), a very cool, funny, and blazingly intelligent fellow, to be our second guitarist. The thing is, Terry couldnt really play. So we just kept him really low in the mix (he was known as our urlLink Stu Sutcliffe ). Second of all, we decided to audition for the talent show with an original song. Kiss of death, I know, but we wanted to prove that we werent just musicians, but songwriters too. So we (actually Jamie and Gerard) ended up writing a song called What About Brandon, which was a spoof of Beverly Hills, 90210. Jamie wrote the caustic lyrics and Gerard set it to rather generic, grungy music (even throwing in a bit of the shows theme song into his guitar solo). At the last minute, however, we decided to add a second original song (really short, kind of tacked on to the end) to make it a sort of Porkchop Medley. The second song was called Henrys Theme, named after an Icelandic barber on the base who owned his own shop and had a propensity for hittin the sauce, if you know what I mean. Henry cut a mean head of hair, but you had to watch out for those DTs when youve got sharp instruments in that area. He also had dirty magazines in his waiting area. Not Playboy, mind you. Im talking about publications with titles like Juggs and Cumshot. In the barbershop. In plain view. Henry also gave little cards to his customers and would punch a hole in it every time you got your hair cut. The tenth one was free. The sign outside his store said: Henrys Barbershop: You Get What You Pay For. Does this guy need a theme song or what? We loved Henry, so we wrote a totally punked-up song about him, called it Henrys Theme (inspired by REMs Walters Theme). Using all those quirks as a guide, I wrote the lyrics: You walk in the door, dirty magazines. Henrys hung over, but the tenth ones free. Henrys! You get what you pay for. Henrys! You get what you pay for. Henrys! You get what you pay for. Dont move or Ill fuck it up! We actually changed fuck it up to mess it up for the talent show. We told Henry about the song, and he not only approved but he also provided us with Henrys Barbershop t-shirts (I still have mine, but its as thin as tissue paper now). So after practicing the medley ad infinitum, we felt we were ready for the talent show. Unfortunately, entry into the talent show required an audition. Also auditioning for the show was our rival band, a rather clich heavy metal outfit named Joker. Its not really accurate to call them rivals, however, since they occasionally got gigs. Joker totally played into the hands of the meat-and-potatoes military crowd. Their audition song was Were an American Band. After sitting through a rather odd assortment of perfomers (including a middle-aged Filipino gentleman in a red nylon track suit singing Mr. Lonely by Bobby Vinton), our turn was up. I remember while we were testing sound levels with a brief snippet of Here Comes Your Man, I began thinking that maybe that was the song we should be auditioning with. Fuck it. Its now or never. The medley it is. It went off fairly well, I think (except for the fact that Jamie had to borrow Jokers microphone stand, which was festooned with Steven Tyler-style bandanas), and by the general reaction of the bystanders in the theater, it sounded okay. But it was not to be. We didnt pass the audition. I dont think you heard me. We didnt even pass an audition for a lousy military base talent show. Translation: we sucked. Thus, Porkchop went out with a whimper, but there never really was much of a band to begin with. Jamie and Debbie now live in Connecticut with their ever-growing family and we see each other occasionally. Last October we met up, along with Terry and his girlfriend, for a rather drunken afternoon/evening in Boston. I havent the slightest idea what became of Wade or Gerard. But I would kill for a reunion. Maybe well get that medley down just right.

adventures in music retail, part three Anyone out there work in retail? Really? Me too. If you ever have to spend any time whatsoever behind a cash register, I'm sure you've run into this situation: you're scanning an item and it doesn't seem to be going through. So the customer will say something clever like, "It must be free! Huh huh huh huh..." Usually, I'll smile and give a polite chuckle, when what I really want to do is strangle the customer and scream, "I HEAR THAT EVERY FUCKING DAY AND IT'S NOT GETTING ANY FUNNIER! SHUT UP!" I talked to my co-worker Brian about this last week and we came up with a nice solution. The next time someone makes an unoriginal, unfunny comment about the scanner not working, we're going to pause for a second, as if we're taking in the joke, then, once we "get it," laugh maniacally for a full minute. I think that'll shut them up.

lizas big day (the weekend edition) So yeah, the weekend. Saturday was Lizas birthday, so she and I did some nice little things, nothing fancy, but still nice. Friday evening we had ourselves a little picnic in the park on Summit Avenue in Brighton. I bought some food at urlLink Whole Foods Market (the snooty market formerly known as Bread & Circus), made sandwiches, got the side dishes together, poured a bottle of wine into a plastic container just in case the park enforces some sort of medieval rule about bottles (this is Massachusetts, after all), and there you go. You have to understand that I am not the kind of person who does stuff like this. Im normally far too selfish and lacking in romantic imaginationperhaps theres hope for me yet. Saturday we both woke up early, me for my normal 8-11:30 shift at urlLink Borders, she because she was asked to come in and work a few hours. The first order of business was to purchase Lizas copy of the new urlLink Harry Potter book (yeah, shes a fanyou got a problem with that?). The night before, the store did something unprecedented stayed open past midnight to sell a brand new product. It went well we apparently sold 308 in the first hour and the store was steadily busy throughout the weekend. By Sunday night, Liza has already read more than 200 pages. My attitude towards the Harry Potter phenomenon is strangely mainstream (for me). Its easy for me to get all jaded and indie about it, you know like the snooty types who claim that its a hip bandwagon that so-called literary wannabes are jumping on. But the truth is Im happy that its getting kids to read. Forgive me for getting all old man on you here, but when I was a kid, I was a huge reader. It was mostly Hardy Boys and Judy Blume, but hey I was reading. Playstations and the Internet have replaced the common book in kids lives and its a crying shame. So Im all for Miss Rowling foisting these tales on us every couple of years. My only hope is that kids will not develop tunnel-vision and avoid non-Potter books. The series is a great starting point now lets see kids explore even more. After work on Saturday, I took Liza clothes shopping. We ended up at the urlLink Gap, where I was greeted by the sound system playing this amazing version of Sunshine Of Your Love. A female singer, some sort of brass-spiked Motown-meets-Shirley Bassey version. It was incredible. A search through allmusic.com this morning proved useless. If anyone knows which version this might be, let me know. Rarely have I been excited about any music played in the Gap. Go figure. A couple days earlier, Liza let a bunch of co-workers know that they were all invited to urlLink King's for a little birthday to-do. Nothing formal, just some impromptu drinkin and bowlin. Apparently it wasnt enough notice because turnout was pretty low maybe eight people total. But we had fun. The two-and-a-half hour wait for a bowling lane made bowling pretty much impossible, but we drank plenty and commandeered a Ms. Pac-Man machine in the clubs corner (note: there are few things in life more fun than watching Liza play Ms. Pac-Man). The evening ended with a buzzed visit to urlLink Redneck's in Allston (is there any other kind of Rednecks visit?) and a viewing of urlLink "The Big Lebowski" at Lizas place while scarfing down those nasty Rednecks egg sandwiches. Liza and I were both out like a light by the time The Dude met Maude. I discovered Kings last month when my brother Gary came to visit. Its a really nice place, a sort of retro-loungey bowling alley / pool hall / bar. The drinks are a tad pricey, but I was really impressed by the lack of meat-market features, not to mention the almost total absence of hootchie-mamas. Kings. Across from the Back Bay Sheraton. You should try it. Sunday was spent nursing mild hangovers and braving the pouring rain to the convenience store to get sugar (for Lizas coffee) and Gatorade (for aforementioned hangovers). We then headed over to my place where Liza continued plowing through the Harry Potter book and I put on my DVD of urlLink "Rosemary's Baby." Ive seen this film umpteen times, but I just bought the DVD a couple of weeks ago. Its really a terrific film. Roman Polanski is still one of my all-time favorite directors and the film has an uncanny ability to scare the hell out of me with a bare minimum of horror film standbys. Its very creepy in its un-creepiness. The extra features of the DVD are pretty decent. Theres a nice documentary made a couple of years ago that features interviews with Polanski, producer Robert Evans (speaking of creepy), and production designer Dick Sylbert. Theres also a making-of featurette that was produced back in 1968. The problem with featurettes from the 60s and 70s is that they always seem so hopelessly tacky and dated. This one has some priceless behind-the-scenes footage, but the whole thing really makes Mia Farrow out to be an annoying, flaky space case. I almost forgot! Last week I picked up an excellent urlLink Paul Weller DVD that had been out for a few months but I didnt even realize existed. Its called urlLink Two Classic Performances and features a full outdoor concert from last summer as well as an extended acoustic performance from Later With Jools Holland. Very good stuff. If youre a fan, you should get this. If not, get it anyway. Youll be a fan by the time the end credits roll.

caveat emptor Remember the good old days, when you would go to your local record store, buy something that you weren't 100 percent sure about, then you take it home, listen to it, and decide that it's not really that hot after all? Okay, that may not exactly sound like an ideal "good old days" situation, but it illustrates quite nicely what I like to think of as the "excitement of unpredictable music purchases." (I just made that up two seconds ago -- it's not like some term that I've been throwing around for years or anything). If I see something in a record store that looks interesting enough to buy, and I have the money to spend on it, I'll probably buy it. If I don't like it, hey -- tough shit. Caveat emptor... buyer beware. In the words of Bruce Cockburn: you pay your money and you take your chance. Try telling that to today's music consumer. I work part-time in the music/video department of urlLink Borders. Unlike most stores, we don't have those fancy computers that allow you to scan a CD's barcode and listen to song samples. We used to have a "Listen on Demand" set-up where a customer would be able to give us up to two CDs, have us open the discs, put it them in a listening station and let them go nuts with those two CDs for up to ten minutes. This was designed to give the customer the opportunity to hear CDs that they are considering purchasing. If they decide not to purchase them, we re-shrinkwrap them and put them back on the shelf. But we had to do away with this service when it was getting some serious abuse. In other words, people would have us open discs just so they could listen to them, with no intention of buying them (incidentally, this feature was a big hit with our drunk customers). "Listen on Demand" may be dead and gone, but we still have listening stations scattered about the music department (filled with pre-selected titles). Assuming that all listening stations are working properly (which is rarely the case, I'll admit), that amounts to more than 500 titles to peruse at your leisure. But we still, quite often, get the petulant customer who strolls up to the desk, asking if there's any way that the disc they're holding can be opened and listened to. In this case, I will first check our list of listening station titles to see if that disc is available to listen to. If not, I explain to them that we are not allowed to open the product. Usually they're okay with that, but sometimes we'll get a ticked off customer who will ask, "if I don't like it, can I return it?" At which point I will respond, as politely as possible, by saying, "You can only return an opened CD or DVD if it is defective, in which case it can only be exchanged for the same thing." The customer, in all likelihood, will then become enraged, sputtering, "but...but...what if I don't *like* it??" If you don't like it, hey...you made an error in judgment on that particular selection. C'est la vie. One of the joys of music purchases is taking chances. Sometimes you'll buy something that turns out to be not so hot. Perhaps you were enticed by the snazzy cover art. Maybe a friend who has spotty tastes in music recommended it. Whatever. Two things to keep in mind: first of all, you can preview practically anything on the internet first. Second of all, it's quite possible that the disc may grow on you over time. Believe me, I own nearly 1,000 CDs and there are several of them that took me years to appreciate. But if it turns out you can't stand the thing and are convinced that you never will be able to listen to it again, take it to a used store. Particularly urlLink CD Spins ...they'll take anything. (This post was inspired by urlLink April, who recently experienced her own little retail hell the other day. Check it out.)_

a case for fishbone Sony Music has been busy the last couple of years, releasing urlLink "Essentials" compilation discs, which span a wide range of artists on their roster. Some of these releases are worthwhile (Bob Dylan, the Clash, Willie Nelson), while some seem baffling to me (is there such thing as essential Journey? Or Kenny Loggins? Were told on the website that an Essential Eddie Money is in the worksooh, pinch me!). Either way, these compilations are a nice way to be introduced to the artists work. If you really want to give your money wisely to the folks at Sony, plunk down $11.99 for the urlLink Essential Fishbone , one of the latest in the series. urlLink Fishbone is a band you may have heard before, but if you have a passing interest in their music and would love to get a big hunk of their best songs on one disc, this is the one to get. 16 tracks and barely any filler. My love of Fishbone goes back a long way (a Mighty Long Way, to quote one of their songs). As a senior in high school, I sat next to a guy named Robert Owens in Mr. Boytes English class. I was not hugely popular in high school, but I gained some points with the students in this particular class because I did a dead-on impersonation of Mr. Boyte. Eventually I befriended Robert and it turned out that we had some similar tastes in music. He asked me at one point if I had heard of Fishbone and I said yes, but admitted that I hadnt heard a note of their music. He lent me a cassette of their second album, In Your Face. The production was a bit slick (they were most likely vying for radio airplay), but the songs were terrific, especially A Selection, (a rapid-fire ska number that I played over and over) Cholly, (a hilarious reggae tribute to full-figured women) and Simon Says the Kingpin (a perfect marriage of funk and punk). The music combined ska, punk, funk and soul, completely manic and designed with one thing in mind to get you off your ass. Lead singer/sax player Angelo Moore, keyboard player Chris Dowd, trumpet player Dirty Walt Kibby, bass player extraordinaire Norwood Fisher, drummer Fish and guitarist Kendall Jones were all accomplished musicians, songwriters and a bit of an anomaly in the music business an African-American band who embraced punk rock (and complicated matters further by acknowledging more diverse artists like Frank Zappa and Rush as influences). But they were, make no mistake, completely funky in every way. I eventually bought their self-titled debut EP (which contains Party at Ground Zero, one of my all-time favorite songs by anyone), the masterpiece Truth and Soul, and the dense, experimental The Reality of My Surroundings. I bought the soundtrack to Say Anything simply because it contained the unreleased Fishbone track Skankin to the Beat (John Cusack is apparently a Fishbone fanatic he wore one of their t-shirts in the film, he hired them to play a bar band in his little-seen gem Tapeheads and he originally wanted their song Party at Ground Zero to be used as the song that Lloyd Dobler plays on the boombox in Say Anything, before less adventurous types decided that Peter Gabriels weepy In Your Eyes would be a better choice). My brother and I saw them in concert in 1991 in a tiny venue in Orlando called the Beecham Theatre, where they proceeded to rip our collective senses to shreds still one of the best concerts Ive ever attended. Then, around 1993, something strange happened. They released the difficult, uncharacteristic Give a Monkey a Brain and Hell Swear Hes the Center of the Universe. Apart from a few funky, Fishbone-esque numbers (Unyielding Conditioning, Lemon Meringue), the album was generally light on the horns, harder on the guitars, and determined to be more Soundgarden and less Sly and the Family Stone. The album angered me. These guys were apparently cashing in on the then-enormous grunge movement and leaving their roots behind. It was, for me, the ultimate sellout. Ive since revisited Give a Monkey and found recently that its actually quite an accomplished piece of music, but ten years ago it threw me for a loop and, quite frankly, the band hasnt been the same since. Theyve undergone a number of personnel changes and released some adequate-to-mediocre albums (Chim-Chims Bad-Ass Revenge, Psychotic Friends Nuttwerx), but Im told they still kick ass in concert. Oh well. Its hard to pin down exactly what went wrong with Fishbone. A talented African-American artist who doesnt stay within the traditional parameters of jazz and R&B is usually doomed (just ask Living Colour or Terence Trent DArby), so that may have a lot to do with it. Perhaps Fishbone realized that their addictive blend of music wasnt selling enough, but then the grunge idea alienated what fan base they already had. Who knows? What really does matter is that some of their best music is gathered on this one amazing compilation. Their 1985-1991 heyday is brilliantly chronicled with little to no fat. They even culled the best tracks from Give a Monkey If you want to relive a terrific band at the top of their game, buy this immediately. And play it loud.

the mix that time forgot Over the weekend, I rediscovered a mix disc that I made about four years ago. Its called Thirteen Crown and the song list can be found urlLink here. I acquired my very own PC in early 1999 and made mixes virtually non-stop until early 2002, when I decided to let my computer live at Lizas apartment since she, as a student, needs it a lot more than I do. I honestly dont miss it that much, except for the fact that I cant make mix discs anymore. Well, I can do that at Lizas place, but the PC is so old and slow that the time I should be spending with her ends up being time spent yelling at a computer. Not good for the relationship. So anyway, I dug out this particular mix and once I started listening to it, I instantly remembered why I liked it so much. Even though it was made during a rather unpleasant, scary, depressing time in my life (summer 1999 -- lots of financial/job/relationship issues), the songs are almost all great. There was a theme to it theyre all songs culled from the CDs of CMJ Music Magazine, which I bought religiously for about two years in the late 90s. A lot of the songs are from bands who I never heard another song from again, and who seemed to either fade into obscurity or never really took off at all (Karas Flowers, Jonathan Fire*Eater, Getaway Cruiser, Hepcat). And for the life of me, I dont know why on earth Drinking in L.A. by Bran Van 3000 didnt become some sort of party anthem of the late 90s. The song just makes me feel like getting drunk and doing some sort of sloppy drunk dance in a crowded apartment party. What else...Garbarges cover of Big Stars Thirteen is luscious and beautiful and makes me realize how incredibly cool Shirley Manson can be; Death Car by Bostons own Wheat is mixes catchiness and loneliness just perfectly; Captain of the Teenagers by Nelson Hubbard is one giant hook, sounding like Weezer with less guitars and more keyboards; Hand In Your Head by Money Mark sounds like Nick Lowe with an extra large helping of funk. And thats just off the top of my head. There are a couple of songs I regret including on this mix. As much as I love Shinehead, I have to admit that his cover of Stings Englishman in New York (renamed Jamaican in New York) doesnt really age well. I always seem to skip over the Connells song as well, probably because I was never really crazy about the Connells in the first place. Hey, if you want a copy of this thing, drop me a line and maybe we could negotiate a trade. I'm all about spreading the love.

why friday? We all know that Friday the 13th is considered to be an "unlucky day." But why is that? I understand the concept that 13 is an unlucky number, but why Friday? It seems to me that Friday is a pretty nice day of the week. You know, the weekend's almost here and all that. Why not Monday the 13th? It's universally accepted that Mondays suck. Why ruin the Friday vibe by making it an unlucky day every few months? Just wondering.

street date jocularity Tuesday is street day. All new music and video comes out on Tuesdays. This makes Tuesdays at my urlLink part-time job pretty interesting, especially since we get to see what sells and what languishes on the shelf, unnoticed and unloved. For some crazy reason, we completely sold out all 50 or so copies of urlLink "Old School" on the very first day (by about 3 p.m.). Can someone please explain this to me? I realize that there are people out there who laugh their asses off at films starring SNL alum, but to sell out of this tripe a mere eight hours after it arrives on the shelf is just plain sad. I understand that a majority of the public has horrible taste in films (I have scientific proof), but come on people. Will Ferrell? He was funny on Saturday Night Live, but that's really where it ends for me. I had people coming up to me about every two minutes or so (literally), asking me where "Old School" was. "Sorry, we're sold out." "Sorry, we're sold out." "Sorry, we're sold out." I tried to bring an air of class to the sales floor by occasionally adding, "we're also sold out of urlLink "Once Upon a Time in America," but that was only met with confusion and apathy. Apparently Robert DeNiro and Sergio Leone are no match for a streaking Will Ferrell. Dave H., one of the music supervisors (who has an encyclopedic knowledge of music -- I can talk to him for hours), commented that there are three new releases this week that include covers of "What A Wonderful World" -- Sarah Brightman, B.B. King and Kenny G (ewwww). A co-worker named Mark asked if it was on the new urlLink Radiohead as well. I thought this was pretty funny, but not nearly as funny as what happened next, which was Mark doing an impersonation of urlLink Thom Yorke singing the Louie Armstrong classic. I can't really explain it to you, suffice it to say that I was laughing pretty hard. Also, the new urlLink Steely Dan album, "Everything Must Go," was released yesterday. We received a promo for in-store play, but it's a total joke. Not only is it just a five-song sampler, it's a "Borders Exclusive" promo that has an announcer breaking in every thirty seconds with a line like "The new Steely Dan, 'Everything Must Go,' is available at Borders on June 10th." Well there's a promo nobody's going to be taking home with them. Perhaps there's a Borders employee who enjoys skeet-shooting. The disc would come in handy then.

wallet, shmallet So far, the wallet boycott has been going strong for about three days. As I mentioned last Friday, Ive decided to do away with my wallet. Its a hassle. I dont like it. All I need from it is my bank card, my subway pass, my ID and my cash. Thats it! Apart from reaching for my wallet every twenty minutes (which Im sure will go away eventually), its been great. I feel free! preferred by who? There are two types of people in the world: those who love urlLink Cheez-Its, and those who love urlLink Cheese Nips. Im the former. For the life of me, I cant understand the appeal of Cheese Nips. They always taste stale to me. And the Nips people are being even more ridiculous by trumpeting Preferred Over Cheez-Its! on their boxes. Who are they surveying, people with no taste buds? theyre shouting lou, not boo If you read last Fridays post, youd know that my sister Julie and I got free tickets to see urlLink Lou Reed's Saturday night show at the urlLink Orpheum. Bearing in mind that the tickets were, once again, FREE, we had no room to complain about anything and we really didnt. Even when we found our seats, which were in the upper balcony, row Y (thats one row from Z, if you get my drift). Actually, sitting in the nosebleed section was kind of nice. Our particular section was almost empty, so we were able to put our feet up on the seats in front of us and really relax. It was honestly one of the most relaxing shows Ive ever attended. Julie brought her opera glasses, which we took turns using. Before the show, we talked about shows wed seen here and she told me the always-entertaining story about when she saw the urlLink B-52's there and the crowd was jumping up and down so hard that the ancient theaters balcony started shaking. Im not exactly an expert on Lous music, but Ive heard quite a bit of it, mostly the stuff everyone else knows, and overall Id have to say that the show was quite enjoyable. The instrumentation was unique, and made for some interesting arrangements: he had a guitarist/keyboard player, a cellist, a bass player and a back-up singer. No drummer, but the bass player (longtime Reed sideman Fernando Saunders) played a small electric kit on two songs. The cello was a wonderful idea, and the songs had a strange, haunting quality (which I suppose had a lot to do with Lous haunting songwriting style as well). The back-up singer (named simply Antony) was an odd one. He looked a lot like urlLink Frank Black, but wore make-up and he did lots of Joe Cocker-style mannerisms. The song selection was interesting. I didnt want to get all Top 40 and complain that he didnt play Walk on the Wild Side, but I noticed some of the hard-core fans after the show being a little confused by that omission as well. He opened with the amazing Sweet Jane (he played a lot of urlLink Velvet Underground stuff). Huh. Maybe I do know a lot about this guy after all.

lou reed, keeping cool and the wallet boycott One of the things Iike to do when I'm bored at work and need a laugh is check out urlLink this great unofficial Seinfeld website. The site contains, among other things, the full scripts of every single episode. Even if I've seen the episode before (and I've seen most of them), reading them can still make me giggle like a mental patient. I happen to think that Seinfeld is perhaps the best-written TV comedy show ever (after the initial first couple of seasons, which were a bit spotty), and without a doubt the greatest sitcom known to man -- it gave that tired genre a swift kick in the ass that has yet to be topped. And oh, don't bother telling me that there's some hipper-than-thou HBO show that's ten times funnier. You're probably right, but I don't get HBO, so let me enjoy my "basic cable" opinions, okay? Thanks. Anyway, I was reading the script for "The Reverse Peephole," and one of the subplots involved Jerry getting rid of his wallet (at Kramer's insistence, who assured Jerry that they "went out with powdered wigs"). I find wallets a necessary evil, but I also hate the fact that this big hunk of vaguely cow-ish material is hanging onto my ass at my every pants-wearing moment. It's uncomfortable and also creates a small rectangular outline on my back pockets that, after a while, make my nice "office pants" look like crap (and reminds me a bit of the rednecks I would see when I lived in Florida and how they had outlines of chewing tobacco cans branded onto their back pockets). All I need a wallet for, honestly, is my money, my bank card, and an ID. That can all fit in my front pocket -- I think. That will be my experiment for the weekend. To go wallet-free. Thanks, Kramer. Other weekend plans involve something that just came up this morning -- my sister Julie was given two free tickets to urlLink Lou Reed's Saturday night concert at the Orpheum. I'm not really a huge fan -- I can appreciate his place in rock music history, and what I've heard of him is usually pretty good, but I don't think I would pay 40 or 50 bucks to see him live. Which is why Julie and I are seeing him for nothing. Yay! Sunday Julie is taking me to urlLink Yale Electric where I'm going to finally break down and buy an air conditioner. Last summer's heatwave convinced me of this. My roommate Frank has two of them -- one in his bedroom and one in the dining room, which is right across the hall from my bedroom. The dining room one works okay for cooling my room, as long as the door is open. Well, Yale is selling their basic a/c for a pretty darn good price, so I'm going to get one, close my bedroom door, and let the freezing, artificially-cooled air work its magic.

the friday five There's a rather popular website out there called urlLink the friday five, which urges readers (and bloggers) to fill out the five-part questionnaire (updated every Friday, I guess) and, if you blog, post the answers. I've checked it out on occasion, but always felt that the questions had a ridiculous, junior-high-school feel to them. This week's is especially wretched, but I checked out the one from a year ago, and it seems okay. Since it's Friday and I'm vaguely bored, here you go: 1. Where are you right now? At my desk, at work. 2. What have you lost recently? I lost my umbrella yesterday, but that doesn't really count, since I lose them all the time. Last week I lost my subway pass, which wasn't too big of a deal since it's a monthly pass and I lost it on the 30th. It could have been a lot worse. And of course, yesterday I lost my patience with my office scanner. Ha ha. 3. What was the first CD you ever purchased? Does that embarrass you now? In 1986 (at age 17), I saved up enough money from my part-time job to get a portable CD player. CD players in general were not nearly as commonplace as they are now, and this one cost something like $225. And it had no shock protection. Big, bulky, piece of crap. But it was a CD player and nobody else I knew owned one. Then I bought a batch of CDs, some of which I'm still proud of, a few that are not so great. "Parade" by Prince (still great, in my opinion), "Time Pieces" by Eric Clapton (before I realized that 99 percent of what EC has done as a solo artist blows chunks), "Empire Burlesque" by Bob Dylan (easily my least-favorite Dylan album) and "Stop Making Sense" by Talking Heads (a great album and a great movie, but since rendered obselete by the deluxe edition, released in 1999). About a year later, the CD player bit the dust, and instead of getting it fixed, I gave my discs to a friend and didn't buy another one for about two more years. That's a really long answer to a short question. 4. What is your favorite kind of writing pen? What a strange question. I'm not really a "pen fetishist." I love Sharpies, though. 5. What is your favorite ice cream flavor? I go through phases. Right now I'm torn between Ben & Jerry's Brownie Batter and Breyer's Reeses Peanut Butter. There's a couple of Ben & Jerry's flavors that I never see anymore but would love to find them if they're still around: Apple Crumble and Ooey Gooey Cake. In a pinch, however, Coffee is always a good flavor. Here's to do-nothing Fridays.

hip-hop folkies in the rain (cha-cha-cha) Whenever I'm not in one of those big pontificating essay-writing modes -- and it's Monday -- I feel an obligation to cop out and give you a report on my weekend. So here it is...Friday, after work, I went home, changed my clothes and headed over to Boston University's urlLink Tsai Performance Center, where the Jeanette Neil Dance Studio presented one of their semi-annual dance shows. I never miss them. Why, do you ask? Well, 'cause I'm as queer as a three-dollar bill. No, actually, it's because Liza participates in it every year. She's in their hip-hop class (despite being a white girl from Minnesota, Liza is one hell of a...hip-hopper. Is that a word? Whatever...). Can I go off on a tangent here? Sure, why not. For the life of me, I can't figure out why, as many urlLink Dunkin' Donuts as there are in New England (4.5 billion at last count), there's never one around when you get anunexpected hankering for their java. I'm on the T, headed for BU, when I realize that I'm going to be early (I'm meeting my sister Julie there at 7). A nice cup of French Vanilla would be perfect, I think. When I get off the train, I realize that there isn't one for at least five or six blocks and I just don't have that kind of time. So I go across the street to Campus Convenience (or "CampCo," as the kids call it) and get myself an urlLink Orangina. A far cry from a hot cup of coffee, but I'm always up for an Orangina. Liza's show was terrific. As always, there were some slightly boring numbers, but most of them were great. One group totally jumped on the "Chicago" bandwagon and did a song from that movie/musical, and there was also a Tom Jones medley that made me smile. Liza's group, in all honesty, probably got the biggest reaction of the night. Not only did they do an extended hip-hop piece, but half the dance group (including Liza) ended the piece with a short tap-dancing number, which was really amazing. It may all sound completely dorky to the average person reading this, but they were really outstanding. Saturday was more of the same Saturday stuff: Did my morning shift at Borders, which ended up being extended into mid-afternoon, since my boss (Nancy, the music manager) asked me if I'd stay to work on a "merch" project and what the hell, I could use the extra money. What I didn't realize at the time was that our A/C is on the fritz and while I got a lot accomplished, I probably lost a good five to ten pounds with all the sweating. Holy crap it was hot up there. Saturday ended with a terrific night out with Julie at urlLink Club Passim, where we caught an amazing show by the one and only urlLink John Wesley Harding. I've been a huge JWH fan since around 1990, but had only seen him live once, and that was as an opening act. Wes was up there by himself with just an acoustic guitar and his amazing arsenal of songs, and boy was it fun. He's a bit of a folkie, but very British, and can probably best be described as a cross between urlLink Elvis Costello and urlLink Billy Bragg. He talks a lot between songs, and like Billy Bragg, is very, very funny (but not nearly as political as BB). He played piano on two songs and warned us all ahead of time that he has hardly ever played the piano in concert since he's not very good at it, but was advised to start doing so by his therapist. A violinist (or perhaps "fiddle player" is the best term in this case) joined him onstage for a few songs. Wes ended up playing several of my favorite songs..."Humble Bee," "I'm Wrong About Everything" (which you can find on the soundtrack to High Fidelity), "Into The Wind," "The Devil in Me" (the very first song I'd ever heard of his) and a whole bunch more. I noticed also for the very first time that he looks a tiny bit like Jerry Seinfeld, which is kind of strange. The only real downside to the entire show was this really, really, fucked up guy in the very back who hooted and hollered REALLY LOUDLY during the applause, and continued to clap really slowly for about 30 seconds after everyone had stopped. Wes handled him with real class, like all professional acts deal with hecklers, and eventually he was escorted out of the venue (after about the third song). After the show, Julie and I split up since she was meeting a friend for dinner (I was invited but was too tired). I headed to urlLink Newbury Comics since I didn't have anything to read or listen to on the train ride home. I snagged an overpriced British music magazine called "The Word" simply because it contained a huge interview with urlLink Morrissey, who still fascinates me after all these years. The article was hugely entertaining, although I was a bit disturbed to see that one of my high school heroes is starting to get really gray. Oh, and I also got a used copy of urlLink "Summer Teeth" in my ongoing pursuit of all things urlLink Wilco. So far I like it, although I prefer the more adventurous sounds of urlLink "Yankee Hotel Foxtrot" and urlLink "Being There." A good deal of Sunday was spent at home while the rain was busy pissing off everyone who had to be outside. I did laundry, watched some bad television and vacuumed. Then I headed to Liza's house where I helped her clean her room, made some tortellini and watched a urlLink Law & Order: Criminal Intent rerun, followed by bits and pieces of urlLink "A Time To Kill," which I'd seen several years ago but forgot how incredibly sappy it was. Liza pointed out that everybody in the movie sweats an awful lot, which is true. What's also true is that, although I think he's a good actor, the character played by urlLink Oliver Platt was such an annoying caricature I wanted to throw stuff at the TV every time he was on. And with that abrupt, un-graceful ending, today's long-winded rant comes to a close. Forgive my stream-of-conscious nature -- I was reading urlLink Dougie's blog prior to starting this. Blame him, the little scamp.

hes got a force field and a flexible plan Im totally digging my copy of Rushs urlLink Signals, which I bought last Friday as part of my rediscovery of this band that guided me through my pre-teen years. The band took a little guff from their fans when the album was released in 1982, mainly due to the fact that the keyboards are taking a much bigger role than on previous albums, and consequentially Alex Lifesons guitar playing takes a bit of a back seat. I see this album as a natural progression from their two previous works, 1980s urlLink "Permanent Waves" and the mega-huge smash from 1981, urlLink "Moving Pictures." Permanent Waves saw Rush drummer/lyricist Neil Peart moving a bit away from the Dungeons & Dragons lyrical style (although the song Jacobs Ladder does in fact begin with the line whos come to slay the dragon?) and more into areas of science and technology. It may just be geek rock of a different flavor, but at least the new lyric subject matter is a bit more rooted in reality. Also, the band began phasing out the epic 10-minute-plus tracks, for the most part (Jacobs Ladder is a bit epic-y and the closer Natural Science is a long one, too its even divided into little chapters, urlLink Yes -style). Moving Pictures only contains one big long number, the underrated Camera Eye, and by this time the keyboards were definitely coming out of the woodwork. Signals definitely has a heavy keyboard sound, but its not nearly as intrusive or dated as one might think. The keyboards provide a melodic base, and the killer bass, guitar, and drum chops of previous albums are still alive and well. The bands songwriting is as strong as ever here, with more of an emphasis on traditional melody and structure. This is the album, after all, that produced Rushs only bona fide top 40 pop hit (New World Man). By this point, Geddy Lees vocals were nicely reined in with a minimal amount of shrieking (my main complaint of their early stuff). The band was definitely in the process of reinvention at this stage. The more down-to-earth lyrics are a breath of fresh air, with Peart's erudite pen handling such subjects as teenage suburbia (Subdivisions) and fear (The Weapon), while the music veered from reggae (Digital Man, New World Man) to pseudo-techno-dance (The Weapon almost sounds like Depeche Mode in parts) to a beautiful combination of frantic rock anddare I say itsoulfulness (The Analog Kid, one of the most diverse and consistently listenable tracks on the album). I dont yet have the stomach to dig into the early, shrieking sounds of Rushs first few albums, nor am I terribly interested in their post-Signals stuff (yet). But for a perfect mixture of rock, prog, power-pop and just a hint of reggae, you cant beat the late 70s/early 80s incarnation of this band.
