how i spent my sunday Sunday afternoon I headed over to the dance studio where I was to meet Liza. We were going to eat lunch and see a movie. As I approached the studio (right across the street from the Fleet Center), I noticed a line a mile long (or maybe a hundred years) of slutted-up, overly made-up and underdressed hoochie-mamas. They were all in a long line that led up to the building where Liza's dance class takes place. As I tried to decipher the meaning of this surreal sight, I noticed a sign by the entrance to the building that read "Coyote Tryouts." As I made my way through the line (choking through the odor of too much perfume) and grabbed the elevator, I met Liza on the fifth floor where she explained to me that the second floor was the location of auditions for a new "Coyote Ugly" bar that's opening right down the street (next door to Boston's very own Hooters -- this is the classy part of town, as you can tell). I didn't know these bars existed. Apparently, the smashing success of the brain-cell destroying "Coyote Ugly" movie has spawned real-life bars where clothing- and intelligence-deprived bimbos dance on the bars. I don't know if they double as bartenders or not, but for me, all I want in a bartender is the ability to pour and serve a drink. Save the dance steps for someone who cares, okay? Afterwards, Liza and I made our way across the street to urlLink Hilton's Tent City, where Liza got a brand new mega-huge travel backpack for her semester abroad. Let me just say that this place is simply astonishing. Four floors packed with merchandise, the friendliest, most easygoing (read: not pushy) staff you could ever meet, and prices way lower than those trendy REI stores. Hilton's Tent City. Check it out. Anyway, while I was in there, I noticed the ever-growing Coyote Ugly line forming across the street, with a curious addition. A male thirty-something truck-driver type with a red ball cap and a beer gut had joined thier ranks. I pointed that out to the Hilton's employee standing next to me and he told me that the he talked to the guy earlier while he was outside. Apparently Red Ball Cap "always wanted to be a bartender," so what the hell. I sure hope he didn't have to wait too long before he was told that "you're not what we're looking for." After lunch, Liza and I went to see urlLink "28 Days Later," which we both enjoyed muchly. I wasn't sure what to expect, but it was directed by Danny Boyle, who did such a marvelous job with urlLink "Trainspotting," and the reviews were pretty positive, so why not?. It was quite the creepy, intense (and extremely gory) affair. Shot almost entirely on digital video, it had a grainy, sometimes inpenetrable feel to it, which only made the film more intense. One of the early scenes consisted of the main character wandering around a deserted London, wondering what the hell he missed during his 28-day coma. Very effective. Excellent music score, too (very unconventional and highly entertaining).

The mother of all guilty pleasures In the summer of 1981, I was 12 years old, and at the time had been a serious rock music fan for about five years. The benefit of having older siblings playing their records around the house helped me appreciate music at an early age. My parents didnt really buy a whole lot of kids music for me, becausewell, I guess they figured Id constantly blow it off in favor of the heavy stuff. After all, who needs a Sesame Street record when you can have urlLink Who's Next? Most of the stuff I was listening to at the time was progressive rock. You know, all that nerdy stuff with the overbearing keyboards, long hair and capes, playing impossibly complicated music that will never get you chicks. I hadnt yet discovered punk rock, new wave, reggae, ska or even jazz. So it was business as usual that summer when my brother Gary brought home a box set called Archives. Archives, you see, was a vinyl three-record set comprising the first three albums of the group urlLink Rush (you can check it out on urlLink eBay ). I had heard of Rush briefly. I think my first exposure to them was a year or two before that, when I happened to notice some of their sheet music for sale at the music store where I took drum lessons (this was about a month before the arrival of MTV, so I had never even seen videos of them yet). Anyway, my brother began playing the records non-stop and we were both hooked. The first, self-titled album, was a pretty raw, basic affair, with lead singer/bass player Geddy Lee shrieking away about love and the working man, guitarist Alex Lifeson cranking out Zeppelin-style boogie riffs and drummer John Rutsey pounding away, not realizing for a second that he would soon be the Pete Best of prog rock. Their second album, Fly By Night, was a considerable step forward. Rutsey was out, and Neil Peart was in. Peart was not only a skilled drummer (if Keith Moon were sober and had a grasp of music theory, he might have sounded a bit like this), but a rather cogent lyricist as well. The third record in the set, Caress of Steel, was along the same lines as its predecessor, but in my opinion a bit of a step back in the songwriting department. Whatever the case, these three records were undoubtedly the soundtrack of my 1981 summer. On the rare occasion that I happen to hear something from these albums, I automatically think of drinking lemonade in Nashua, New Hampshire. Its that simple. Soon Gary and I were grabbing all the Rush albums we could find. Fortunately, there was a new album right around the corner: the ever-popular Moving Pictures, which contained some of their best known songs, Tom Sawyer and Limelight, to name a few. Gary then bought 2112 (which, for some time, was my hands-down favorite Rush album) and the live albums All the Worlds a Stage and ExitStage Left. In 1982, they released another commercial smash, Signals, notorious for its heavy accent on keyboards, as well as a bona fide pop top 40 hit (New World Man). There was even a cool video for the song Subdivisions. (Rush was actually in fairly heavy rotation on MTV in the early 80s, an unthinkable concept today). At this point in my life, my love of music went beyond the mere emotional impact of the sounds. As a young pre- and early teen who not only played drums, but -- as a condition of my parents allowing me to play -- taking lessons, I enjoyed picking apart the intricacies of Pearts drumming and making lame attempts to ape his rudiments. It was hopeless, but fun. In 1982, I even entered a contest sponsored by urlLink Modern Drummer magazine to win Neil Pearts drum set. I had to write, in 100 words or less, an essay explaining why I wanted the set. (I didnt win.) After Signals, my interest in Rush began to waver. I felt I got everything I could out of their music up to that point. For a while, the only post-Signals songs I heard from them were Distant Early Warning and The Big Money (thanks to the videos). For reasons still not clear to me this day, I went through a massive urlLink Grateful Dead phase from about 1983 to 1985, continued to obsess over urlLink Genesis , and even went through an intense urlLink Bob Dylan discovery phase. Then of course, in 1985, I discovered urlLink Elvis Costello. Thats when it all changed. Rush took a serious backseat to my musical tastes for many years. I took no notice of the albums they were cranking out through the remainder of the 80s and 90s and joined all my fellow pseudo-punks in ridiculing these old farts with their Ayn Rand obsessions and oversized drum sets. In recent months, however, Ive realized that, at age 34 (or at any age, really), its ridiculous to shun or even hate a band simply because a) the music is too complicated or b) the cool kids dont like it. I began rediscovering some old prog stuff and even discovering bands I never listened to back then (like urlLink King Crimson ). Several months ago, for the pure sake of nostalgia, I bought a used copy of Rushs Moving Pictures and was pleasantly surprised at how much of it I still appreciated. Prog tends to get a little cold and soulless, but a good deal of it is still fascinating to me. Last night I picked up a copy of Rushs A Farewell to Kings (which I first bought used on vinyl in 1983 at urlLink Headlines, a record store/head shop in Nashua). While the lyrics (to me) dont seem to have aged very well, I was really enjoying the music, particularly the epic Xanadu. Rush may not be party music (unless its a Dungeons & Dragons party), but theres a lot of great stuff to dig into. If you have skeletons in your closet, dont just let them out. Embrace them.

welcome to my umpteenth reality tv rant David E. Kelley, one of television's most prolific writer/producer/creators, took the opportunity as a panel member of the Television Critics Association's summer press tour to do something I always admire in anyone: berate reality televison. "There has been erosion in respect for the media by its guardians, and the proliferation of reality television is probably the best example," he said. While in years past network executives championed quality scripted television, "today they celebrate the junk," he said. "Once, they were ashamed of it; now they throw parades for themselves." Bravo, David. I'm not a huge fan of "The Practice" or a lot of Kelley's other shows, but I really enjoy when someone takes a well-deserved swipe at those morons responsible for "Who Wants To Marry My Dad," "World's Ugliest Hoochie Mamas," "Help Pay for My Cousin's Hooker" or whatever reality show is foisted on the American public. Enough, already! By the way, as far as my current mindset of trying to be more "positive" in my blog...this, in my opinion, is a positive post. Reality shows degrade the general population and reward both greed and shallow behavior. Criticizing reality television is extremely positive.

depravity in classical music and korean war comedy Its Tuesday, which, in the music and video retail business, is street day (Ive covered this before, but it makes for a somewhat coherent post, so indulge me). Today is the day of the week when virtually all CDs and DVDs for the week are released. I noticed that a ridiculous, supposedly hipper-than-thou term that gets around a lot is drop, as in the new P. Diddy disc drops on Tuesday. Personally, Id like to drop all of Diddys releases off the top of a tall building, but the point is, its a ridiculous term, so try not to use it around me, k? All righty. Liza mentioned to me the other day that my blog has a tendency to get too negative. Perhaps I should try to be a little nicer. Sorry. Where was I? Street date. Right. Not much of note coming out today, Im afraid. I work the closing shift at Borders on Mondays, so I help put out new releases after the store shuts its doors at 9 p.m. On the classical side, theres a brand new urlLink disc with a really cruel-looking cover, but I havent heard the music yet, so I cant really give you a yea or nay just now. Look at that cover urlLink again, will you? How evil. On a barely-related note, in my three years of manning the classical section of my store, Ive come across exactly one classical disc with a Parental Advisory sticker. Its called urlLink The Art of the Bawdy Song. The fact that there's a song on there called "My Man John Had a Thing That Was Long" might have something to do with it. Oh, that bawdy Renaissance era! One thing Im kind of interested in that was released today is the urlLink Complete Fourth Season of M*A*S*H. I love urlLink M*A*S*H , and for me, their "middle period" was my favorite. While I liked early characters like Henry Blake and Trapper John McIntyre, I felt that the first two seasons were too focused on slapstick and caricature. The third season (the last one with Blake and McIntyre) was pretty good, but I really liked it when Potter and Hunnicut came aboard. Pierce and Hunnicut had a great rapport, while I felt that the McIntyre character was too cynical and bullyish. The writing during this period was excellent. When Winchester joined, it was good for a season or two (his Beacon Hill snob brought a unique perspective to the cast), but the last three, maybe four seasons were horrible. It's not that the seriousness and preachiness got on my nerves (though it occasionally did); it was the lack of effort in the comedy writing. Any attempt to make the show funny during those last few seasons fell flat. I've often watched reruns from that era without cracking a smile once. Oh, and here's a tip on how to avoid anything from that period when tuning into M*A*S*H reruns: if Sergeant Rizzo (played by G.W. "Police Academy" Bailey) is in the episode, it's a stinker. Trust me.

in time, you can turn these obsessions into careers Saturday nights urlLink Elvis Costello concert at the Fleet Pavilion was my third EC show, and for a lot of people, that would be more than enough. But like a lot of my favorite performers, Elvis is an eclectic sort, and every show so far has been different. In April 1987 I saw him perform a solo acoustic concert (as part of his 87 college tour) at the University of California at Irvine (it was during spring break of my senior year in high school and I was visiting a friend who lived in Los Angeles). I saw him again in June 1999 as the headlining act of the Guinness Fleadh Festival at Suffolk Downs, here in Boston (he was joined by his keyboard-playing partner-in-crime, the incomparable Steve Nieve). The show last Saturday was the first time Ive seen him perform with a full band, the Imposters (basically the Attractions with Davey Faragher replacing bass player Bruce Thomas), and I wasnt disappointed. You could say that Elvis pulled a Van Morrison at the show no chitchat, just the songs, often one after the other with no pauses. The uptempo triple-threat of Waiting For the End of the World, the rarely-played Beyond Belief and Radio Radio opened things up quite nicely. Our seats werent the best, but the Pavilion (a venue Id never attended before) had video screens presented on both sides of the stage, which seems cheesy when you hear it described, but is actually very convenient. Elvis dialed it down with the mid-tempo Sulky Girl, the merseybeat version of Everyday I Write the Book (which Ive heard him do as one of the bonus tracks of the Rykodisc version of Punch the Clock), and a cover of Mose Allisons bluesy Everybodys Crying Mercy --- which Elvis recorded for his covers project Kojak Variety and was probably included in the set for the line everybodys crying peace on earth / just as soon as we win this war. One of the few disappointments of the night followed, with the excellent Clubland, one of my favorite EC songs. This sophisticated, intricately arranged song was ruined by a rather muddy sound (as nice a venue as the Pavilion is, the sound quality could be improved). Clown Strike, a song I was never too crazy about, seemed to sound better with the live vibe, and the pounding Complicated Shadows was a highlight, as was the classic Miracle Man. After Just About Glad, (the third song from Brutal Youth, which is a bit much to pull from that particular album), Elvis launched into a brand new song, the beautiful ballad Either Side of the Same Town. The slower tempo continued with I Cant Stand Up For Falling Down, a Sam & Dave cover from Elvis Get Happy!! album. Actually, he sang the first verse slow, then launched into a fast version, but the truth is, Sam & Daves original recording was indeed a ballad. The noisy, fun Uncomplicated, a stretched-out, slower version of Watching the Detectives and a bluesy Pump it Up closed the set proper. New bass player Faragher may not have the fluid moves of Bruce Thomas, but proved a capable replacement and sang great back-up as well. Nieve was a bit low in the mix, but sounded great nonetheless. Drummer Pete Thomas is certainly not mellowing with age either. The first encore had an acoustic feel, as Elvis played a beautiful rendition of Deep Dark Truthful Mirror (nothing can top the original piano and brass arrangement, but this came damn close). He then tacked on a wonderful version of Smokey Robinsons You Really Got a Hold on Me, before going back into the original song. Patsy Clines Sweet Dreams, which Elvis covered on Almost Blue (his 1981 country-western album) closed the first encore perfectly. The second encore focused more on the rowdy numbers. As Elvis and the band reemerged (with Elvis himself showing the crowd a Red Sox jersey with Costello 03 on the back), they tore into I Hope Youre Happy Now, Tear Off Your Own Head and the epic Man Out of Time before slowing things down with the anti-war Shipbuilding and then speeding back up again with an exhaustive rendition of (Whats So Funny Bout) Peace, Love and Understanding (world affairs seemed to have a hand in the setlist). Former Black Crowes vocalist Chris Robinson seemed like an odd choice for an opening act, but his short acoustic set was well-received and sounded great. He played acoustic guitar and was joined by another guitarist. My only major beef was that there was absolutely NO Elvis merchandise on sale. Im a concert t-shirt guy I pretty much always buy a concert shirt. The extremely unhelpful duo selling Robinsons merch at the show mumbled something along the lines of Elvis' management didnt think that it would be profitable. Huh? Folks, Ive been to shows where the acts made less money than the audience members, and they still sold stuff. Mike Keneally is one of the hardest-working, least rewarded artists in the universe and he sells three or four different t-shirts and several CDs at every show Ive seen. Youre telling me that Elvis Costello, a multi-millionaire, cant afford the dollar or two it takes to print up each shirt -- especially when they usually go for about thirty bucks? Okay, rant mode off. The show itself was excellent.

five new discs and one happy blogger Twice a year (usually in July and again around November, to facilitate Christmas shopping), Borders does something nice for its employees by holding a 40 percent off employee weekend on most of their products. We already get a nice year-round discount (25 percent for full-timers and 33 percent for part-timers, like me), but that extra percentage really makes a nice difference. It doesnt apply to everything, though; DVDs are still 20 percent across the board, and periodicals 15 percent. But in a way, those restrictions are a big help, because they force me to place parameters on the needless stuff I end up buying in these situations. Fortunately, I took advantage of 40 percent off weekend and only spent $6.02. I was lucky enough to be named my stores employee of the month, an honor that carries with it a cheesy Polaroid photo on a plaque near our breakroom, in addition to a lovely $50 store gift certificate. (Note: I am not deliberately tooting my own horn; the employee of the month part of the story is simply being used to aid the narrative thread). So, with gift card in hand, I punched out of my Saturday shift at noon and picked up five CDs that I had been hanging on to for a few days. Wanna know what they are? Sure you do. urlLink Beethoven, Lieder (Dietrich Henschel) Last year, I managed to snag a free copy of a Harmonia Mundi sampler and since then, Ive managed to purchase at least seven discs that were featured on it. One of them was a collection of lieder by Erich Korngold, sung by Dietrich Henschel. I enjoyed it a great deal, and when this Beethoven lieder collection also sung by Henschel was released earlier this month, I jumped at the chance to hear this great singer once again. Im enjoying this a little more than the previous release, mainly because as far as 20th century classical music goes (like Korngold), its a little harder for me to get into the vocal stuff. Beethovens songs are a little more traditional and therefore easier to digest. (As open-minded as I am about classical music, modern opera is one of the hardest pills for me to swallow in that format) urlLink Elvis Costello, Mighty Like a Rose Ive spent the last two years rebuilding my EC catalog after it was all stolen in a burglary (along with all my Bob Dylan, Van Morrison, Miles Davis and Bob Marley kudos to the burglars for their good taste). Fortunately, Rhino Records has made it a little easier for me by reissuing Elvis entire catalog, three releases at a time, for the past year or two (I still believe that they were responsible for the burglary, those bastards). Rhino has outdone the otherwise excellent Rykodisc EC reissues by making every reissue a two-disc affair, with the standard album on disc one, and an entire disc of bonus tracks on disc two. I waited a while to get Mighty Like a Rose, mainly because I never felt it was one of his stronger works. While I still wouldnt put it in my EC Top Ten, after listening to it Saturday afternoon I concluded that it is still quite a strong album, albeit with a few weak tracks. If you enjoy the everything-including-the-kitchen-sink beautiful baroque mess of ECs 1988 album Spike, this one is along those same lines. Call it Spike II. urlLink The Jam, Setting Sons -- Although Ive been a Jam fan for just about as long as Ive been an Elvis Costello fan, I havent been too quick on picking up individual Jam releases, mainly because they havent had a good reissue program for some time. Recently, Universal saw fit to correct that error, and Setting Sons, the fourth Jam album, is the latest in my collection. It contains several of my favorite Jam songs (Eton Rifles, Thick as Thieves), in addition to a slew of b-sides and rarities, and one of my favorite Jam covers (their superb take on Martha and the Vandellas Heat Wave). urlLink Stravinsky, Rite of Spring (Valery Gergiev, Kirov Orchestra) While I prefer smaller ensembles for modern classical music (string quartets, piano sonatas), the power of Stravinskys most famous work in undeniable. Arguably one of the best-known and most controversial pieces of modern music, its 1913 Paris premiere literally caused a riot. While I already own a lesser-known recording of this composition (which I received for free last year), I jumped at the chance to pick up a copy of this, mainly since it was recently reissued as part of the Gramophones Choice series (a series of notable recordings that were all given extremely positive reviews by the excellent British magazine urlLink Gramophone ). If you like your classical music scary, noisy and foreboding, by all means, get this. urlLink Yes, Remixes Go ahead and laugh, everyone else does. First of all, heres my standard prog-rock apology: progressive rock is one of the music formats that I constantly have to defend (see my April 8 entry, The mellotron players wearing a cape). While Ill admit that a large portion of this format is silly and pretentious, there is a lot of it that I admire a great deal, not only for the skill required to play the music, but also the eclectic nature of some of the genres best stuff (this is a result of growing up with three older siblings who loved prog, back when it was oddly labeled art rock). Yes have certainly made their share of icky music, but three of their albums are, in my opinion, amazing classics that I revisit often: urlLink The Yes Album (1970), urlLink Fragile (1971) and urlLink Close to the Edge (1972). With that in mind, when I saw that a collection of Yes remixes was being released, I jumped at the chance (knowing full well that it may sound like utter crap, but was dying to hear it out of curiosity). The tracks were all remixed by Virgil Howe, the son of Yes guitarist Steve Howe. While Im no expert in the remix field, I have heard my fair share of remixes, and this is a highly enjoyable album. Ive already read some reviews on Amazon, which are equally positive and negative. The negative ones are mostly by old farts who apparently dont understand the concept of remixes. It sounds like the CD is defective! sputters one reviewer who wouldnt know Fatboy Slim from Fat Albert. Heres a lesson in musical open-mindedness: theres nothing wrong with manipulating older songs to give them a fresh perspective. Wake up and smell the 21st century. I first listened to this disc on my headphones while walking downtown Saturday afternoon and I literally giggled out loud at least twice, which must have looked interesting to my fellow pedestrians. Hearing a trip-hopped Heart of the Sunrise and a funky, drum-machine infested Siberian Khatru certainly had a giddy effect on me, considering the fact that Ive known these songs by heart since I was about nine years old.

it's a dry heat Im safe and sound and back on the ground in Boston, and boy did I have a nice, stress-free enjoyable time in Phoenix. The last time I posted it was Saturday afternoon. Saturday night was a nice relaxed affair as Liza and I took our 2,500th dip in the pool, ate some dinner, and were given a urlLink Target gift certificate from her sister for our babysitting duties earlier in the day. Then we all sat around the living room watching urlLink "The Godfather" on HBO. Did I mention that Lizas parents have digital cable? Something like two billion channels, a super-friendly on-screen TV guide feature, and every pay channel you could think of. Nice. Sunday, Liza and I hit the retail trail and spent the Target gift certificate (and then some). Liza bought two pairs of shoes and I got a nifty CD-player clock radio. Ive always wanted one of those and now I have one. Then I visited a local urlLink Borders and used my employee discount on two CDs: urlLink "Early Music" by the always amazing Kronos Quartet and urlLink "Take a Break," the latest effort by Me First and the Gimme Gimmes. I also picked up a copy of a book Ive been wanting to read for years: urlLink "Paris to the Moon" by Adam Gopnik. urlLink Me First and the Gimme Gimmes are not exactly a hit in the hard-core punk indie community, but theyve always been a glorious guilty pleasure for me. Basically, theyre a punk/pop supergroup (consisting of members of NOFX, Lagwagon, and No Use for a Name) who do nothing but punked-up covers, mostly oldies. The albums are usually arranged by theme: Have a Ball covers mostly 70s hits; Are a Drag decimates showtunes; Blow in the Wind takes care of the 60s and the latest one skewers R&B, old (Stevie Wonder, Aretha Franklin) and new (R. Kelly, Whitney Houston). Some may say the shtick gets old, but for the life of me, I cant seem to get sick of these guys. I seriously want them to play at my wedding. We also discovered a rather scrumptious restaurant chain down there in Phoenix (although they might have them elsewhere, I dont know). Its called urlLink Bahama Breeze. Liza had never heard of it, so it could be a new thing. I guess you could call it a family restaurant. It had a sort of island theme, with the staff all dressed in Hawaiian shirts and whatnot, and reggae music piped through the PA. As cheesy as the atmosphere seemed, the food was amazing. If youre hungry and happen to pass by one of these places, check it out. Sunday night was spent dining at Lizas sisters house and Monday was spent at the airport, on a plane for five hours, and back in Boston. Fun trip. Minimal turbulence on the plane, thus a minimally freaked out Chris. Yay. Now all I have to look forward to is this Saturdays urlLink Elvis Costello show. Oh, is that it? Just Elvis? Jesus, I cant wait. Elvis is King. Id like to get back into essay mode sometime soon I havent written a good screed advocating a particularly good musical artist or film in a while. Look for that soon. This week. Really.

if i told you, i would have had to kill you Here I am! Where am I? Why, in Phoenix, Arizona, of course. Liza and I got here Thursday afternoon and will return to Boston on Monday afternoon. Why haven't I written word one about this trip in my blog? Because it was a surprise. Let me explain. Liza's mother's fiftieth birthday was last Thursday and Liza's dad flew us out to Phoenix for a surprise visit (it was a surprise for her mom, not for us -- we've known about it for more than a month). Needless to say, when her mom saw us lounging in her living room Thursday afternoon, she proceeded to freak out. In a good way. Liza's dad didn't stop with plane tickets for the two of us, no sir. He took us, along with Liza's mother, sister, brother-in-law, neice and nephew to a place called Gold Canyon Golf Resort, where we spent yesterday afternoon to this morning, lounging, swimming, eating, drinking and watching Liza's mom swoon over her birthday presents. And while the resort is kinda in the middle of nowhere, we were still able to witness fireworks on the horizon coming from Tempe. This Gold Canyon resort is a pretty nice place (and I would provide a link for you, but I'm on Liza's sister's computer, which is a bit temperamental, so I'm not going to fuck around with creating links if you don't mind). Each couple got their own little suite, and everyone gets driven around in golf carts. I find out more and more that people just aren't into walking anywhere in this part of the country, but I suppose 100-plus temperatures are partly to blame. Anyway, we spent a good part of yesterday afternoon in the resort's lovely swimming pool, then returned to our suites for quick showers, and proceeded to the bar & grill for a couple of beers at the "bar" (where I was informed, sadly, of Barry White's passing) and a wonderful dinner at the "grill." After the aforementioned present-opening and fireworks-watching, Liza and I returned to our room to find out that our key-card thing didn't work. We walked over to the front desk where the woman working there aplogized profusely and gave us two new keys. Which didn't work. We walked back to the desk again. More profuse apologies. The bellboy brought us back (via the omnipresent golf cart) with master key-card in hand. Didn't work. Apparently the key-card door mechanism had a dead battery. I cursed "advances" in technology while Alfonzo the maintenance dude was summoned to open our back patio, which was locked with a bona fide regular, non-electronic lock. the confused urbanite I've been having the strangest notion lately -- well, I guess you don't really "have" notions, to be more accurate, you tend to "entertain" them. Anyway, I've been thinking a lot about where I am right now, not really in an abstract sense, just "where I am." Geographically. In Boston. You see, I'm originally from this fine state, and although I've lived in a ton of other places over the years (including nearly half my life overseas), I've always considered myself a Bostonian, even more so since I've moved here, presumably for good, in February 1999 after my abrupt departure from Italy. My father was born in nearby Malden and grew up in a variety of different towns on the ouskirts. My mother was born in Somerville and lived in nearby Medford, etc. So I'm from here and my parents are from here. I love the city. Urban life is very exciting to me. The mundane parts of it are even interesting, even if it's just on a sociological level. The subway interests me. I love walking the streets. I love elevators. The proximity of tall buildings. The culture, the traffic, the honking of horns. But maybe not so much anymore. As much as I love taking the subway and loathe the responsibility, paperwork and costs involved in owning and operating a car, I've been getting more and more frustrated lately at the necessity of "carrying my shit around." What I'm trying to say is, as a subway commuter and pavement-pounder, I don't have a trunk or backseat to throw my stuff into (or onto). When I leave the house for the day, I take my messenger bag that almost always contains my CD player, my 24-disc CD case, a book, and perhaps a few other things. They add up, and when you have to drag this stuff around with you all day, it gets frustrating. If I want to stay over at Liza's place, I have to make sure that I have clothes over there, or else I have to stuff some underwear socks, etc, in the bag (or bring a separate bag that makes me seem like some sort of vagrant). And let's not even get into the problems associated with food shopping. And then there's the subway. It's a necessary evil, and as relatively reliable as it tends to be, it forces me to do one more thing on somebody else's timetable. Instead of just saying to myself, "Anna's Taqueria. That's a 15-minute drive. I'm meeting Liza there at 8, so I'll leave at 7:45," I have to figure in how long the T will take, how long it may take -- worse-case scenario -- to wait for *two* trains, since I have to change from the red line to the green line at Park Street, in addition to walking to and from each station. All this for a super carnitas burrito with my girlfriend. I need a damn calculator every time I leave the house. I could go on and on, but the point is that I'm starting to get fed up with the city and sometimes I feel that the cons outweigh the pros. In the past, I've occasionally -- though not entirely seriously -- broached the subject of moving to Liza's home state of Arizona. The last time I brought it up was a couple of days ago, and while she feels that eventually we may make our way out there, it's just not really conceivable at this juncture. I realize that she needs to finish school first, but from a long-term professional standpoint (hers), there aren't a lot of theater programs out in the desert. For her, city living's where it's at. For now. I read posts by urlLink Tom out in Phoenix about his new car and how he swings by all these places on his way home from work and I get jealous. I think about Liza's parents, quite possibly the nicest people you could ever meet, along with Liza's sister, her husband and their two kids, and I long for my long-lost suburban life. Am I getting too old? Is this type of life really what I need? Will it make me healthier? Could I live without urban culture that I hold so dear? They have Banana Republic there. They have Borders. Tough-to-find CDs can be ordered online. Then again, I may get over this in a few days. Now if you'll excuse me, I have a hot, smelly subway to board.

new release tuesday: the aftermath Have you been waiting for me to comment on this week's CD purchases? No? Well, as you may have read earlier, Tuesday evening I snagged three of the brand new urlLink Yes remasters ( urlLink "Close to the Edge," urlLink "Tales From Topographic Oceans" and urlLink "Relayer" ) in addition to the latest (and final) Warren Zevon album, urlLink "The Wind." First things first: the new Zevon album is very, very good. I wouldn't put it in his Top Five, but it's still very strong, with excellent singing, playing and writing throughout. It does occasionally veer into some fairly sappy lyrical territory (in songs like "El Amor de Mi Vida" and "Please Stay"), but for crying out loud, the man is dying of cancer. Let him reflect all he wants. Plus, he's written a veritable truckload of masterpieces in the last 30 years, so he's entitled to rest on his laurels a bit. But there are only a couple of tracks that don't really do anything for me -- most of the songs are top-notch. The grand piano-driven "Numb as a Statue" harks back to his late seventies heyday. "Knockin' on Heaven's Door" may be a too-obvious cover choice, but it's done extremely well (although, like "Twist and Shout," it's the kind of song that's pretty hard to fuck up). I'm not much of a Springsteen fan, but "Disorder in the House," Warren's collaboration with The Boss, kicks lots of ass. Overall, a very strong album, and a fitting swan song. urlLink Rhino has been doing a splendid job of remastering and reissuing the Yes catalog, several albums at a time, and this batch is no different. Four releases by my favorite guilty pleasure have been added this week. 1972's "Close to the Edge" is one of my favorite Yes albums, with the title track spanning the entire first side of the vinyl and "And You and I" and "Siberian Khatru" rounding things off on side two. It doesn't really let your CD player's "random" button do much work, but prog rock is all about the endless experimentation and showing off musical chops while pondering mysticism and Tolkein. And this album does it pretty damn well. The bonus tracks include a couple of "single" edits and alternate takes. 1973's "Tales From Topographic Oceans" is pretty much just as bloated and overreaching as most of its critics claim, but that doesn't make it any less fun. There's something satisfying about consuming four twenty-minute suites spread across two discs. Celebrating pointless excess is something I recommend to any self-respecting music fan from time to time. In all honesty, while the band tends to veer off course -- inspiring listeners to use the fast forward button generously -- the playing is superb and true to form, Yes does in fact have an ear for catchy melodies. (Interesting Yes-related tangent: have you seen/heard the latest Volkswagen commercial, featuring music by urlLink Polyphonic Spree? The first time I saw that commercial, I thought to myself, "Damn! They sound just like Yes!" And they're supposedly getting oodles of critical acclaim, too. Does that mean the critics secretly love Yes?) Anyway, the third Yes disc I bought on Tuesday, 1974's "Relayer," is perhaps the most exciting revelation of the three. An album I heard briefly several years ago, it has a fresh, vital sound, thanks to the arrival of some new talent (Patrick Moraz, who replaced mad wizard keyboard player Rick Wakeman) and a shift toward more aggressive soloing and an almost jazz-fusion sound. Beautiful stuff. All the remasters contain bonus tracks, tons of new liner notes and exciting Digipak cases. Mmmm...Digipak...

just say yes Tomorrow is Tuesday. Street date! Lots of new stuff coming out on CD and DVD. As you can imagine from my previous post, I have every intention of picking up (sometime this week if possible) the latest (and sadly, final) release from urlLink Warren Zevon, "The Wind." Allow me to indulge my guilty pleasure known as prog rock and tell you about some other new releases as well. Everybody's favorite bloated band of hyper-noodling mystics, urlLink Yes, are continuing their reissue project (in conjunction with the good folks at urlLink Rhino ) with the release of special editions of "Close to the Edge," "Tales From Topographic Oceans," "Relayer" and "Going for the One." I plan on eventually picking up all but the last one. "Close to the Edge" is one of the three Yes albums (along with "The Yes Album" and "Fragile") that I consider undeniable classics. Pretentious? Sure. But I still love it. I own a 14-year-old CD of "Close to..." and it's high time I upgrade it. "Tales..." is a different story altogether. The album is routinely cited as the ultimate example of what is wrong with prog. It's considered the nadir of the genre and at least one Amazon.com reviewer praises it simply because its bloated excesses helped birth punk rock. How bloated? It consists of four songs, all approximately 20 minutes long, spread out over two records (or discs, in this case). To make matters worse, the album was inspired by hippie-dippy vocalist/lyricist Jon Anderson's discovery of some sort of Asian Shastric scriptures or something. Still awake? Well, okay then. Guess what? I'm still probably going to buy it. I remember when my brother Gary bought this album in the fall of 1983. I loved it, but it didn't really stand up to repeated listenings. Maybe it was drowned out by the critics' protests. Call me crazy, but all the negative buzz (in addition to the fact that not having heard it in 20 years) has aroused my curiosity. I will probably get "Relayer" too. It has two strikes against it: drummer extraordinaire Bill Bruford ain't on it (he left to join urlLink King Crimson before "Tales" was released); and keyboard player Rick Wakeman (the original Caped One) vamoosed as well, replaced by Patrick Moraz. But what little I've heard of the album (several years ago, mind you) intrigues me. It supposedly has an aggressive, fusion feel to it. All the Yes remasters come with bonus tracks, extended liner notes and slip cases. I love all that stuff. If you're interested in reading some good, unbiased reviews of Yes (or any other prog bands), I urge you to check out urlLink Ground and Sky, an excellent prog review site. The site is easy to navigate and the reviews are intelligent and thoughtful. Oh, and one reviewer tells of a Pink Floyd/Wizard of Oz-type game you can play with "Relayer" and urlLink "2001: a Space Odyssey." Far out!

he'll sleep when he's dead Yesterday I made sure that anything and everything I had to do was done in plenty of time to watch urlLink VH1's documentary on Warren Zevon. The program, entitled "Inside/Out," chronicled the life and times of the legendary singer/songwriter since last August, when he learned he was diagnosed with urlLink mesothelioma, a rare and terminal form of cancer. In addition to being the subject of a documentary, Warren -- who was initially given three months to live, one year ago -- decided to write and record one last album. That album, urlLink "The Wind," will be released tomorrow. Not surprisingly, Warren's diagnosis has given him more press coverage than he's probably ever received. The New York Times, the Los Angeles Times, the Boston Globe and countless other publications and media outlets have been vying for his attention. This VH1 program is probably the most any fan has ever seen of Warren's day-to-day life, including many revealing moments in the studio. For this final hurrah, friends and admirers of Warren's have asked to make appearances, including Bruce Springsteen, David Lindley, Jackson Browne, Ry Cooder and Emmylou Harris. The documentary includes doctors' visits, photo shoots, studio sessions and a particarly emotional appearace last October on urlLink David Letterman's show. For that gig, Dave, a huge Zevon fan, devoted the entire episode to Warren, interviewing him and letting him perform three songs. Some of the documentary's most disarming moments include some tough-to-handle recording sessions, as Warren's health begins to deteriorate and he takes on stronger doses of painkillers. In one scene, co-songwriter/producer Jorge Calderon asks Warren if he's up for one more vocal take, while Warren sits by the microphone with bottles of meds in his lap. Warren's daughter Ariel announces that she's pregnant with twins and plans to name one of them after her father. Too weak to make it to the studio for later sessions, Warren records a take of "Keep Me In Your Heart" seated in his living room while friends look on admiringly. If it sounds like a sloppy, emotional pity-fest, think again. Zevon, whose morbid sense of humor has always kept death at arm's length, is known as a musical and lyrical tough guy with a strong dose of wry wit. Kind of a rock and roll combination of Norman Mailer, Martin Scorcese and Ernest Hemingway. Anyone who's regularly written songs about mercenaries, mass murderers, werewolves and alcoholics deserves to sit back and get reflective while staring death in the face. Warren Zevon is not in the rock and roll hall of fame, has never appeared on MTV's Total Request Live and will never outsell Madonna or P. Diddy. But his death will be an enormous blow to anyone who's ever appreciated songwriting with wit, class and intelligence.

a decidedly un-freaky friday One of the hardest things about returning to blogging after a long absence is wondering how to resume. Seriously. I don't really know where to start. What I can tell you is that our trip to Maryland went amazingly well. The last time I posted was Sunday night. Monday my mother and I took my daughter Audrey (who was visiting from Illinois, where she lives with her mom) clothes shopping for the coming school year. Tuesday Liza and I took Audrey to see urlLink "Freaky Friday," which Audrey had already seen back home but really wanted to see again. Like most films aimed at the pre-teen set, it was fairly predictable, with a generous smattering of lameness. But I actually enjoyed it quite a bit. I laughed out loud several times. So to all of you who scoff at my snooty obsessions with urlLink Bergman and urlLink Kubrick: chill out, already. I laughed heartily during a cheesy "body-switch" movie. The road trip back to Boston on Wednesday was relatively eventless, with my sister Julie generously taking all the driving chores while I was the DJ and Liza...well, hung out in the back seat, basically. Two things I learned on this trip: Connecticut is the most annoying, headache-inducing, traffic-clogged state to drive through; and Cheesequake, New Jersey, is perhaps the funniest town name in the history of the United States. I defy you to find a funnier one. Wednesday was a bit hectic, what with getting back into the grind at work and implementing all the fun new responsibilities of my re-tooled job position, but I managed. I'm in a new cubicle, which doesn't have that snazzy Boston skyline view anymore, but I have to admit that my current view of the intersection of Longwood and Brookline Avenues is much more fun on a people-watching level. hen you think about it, the skyline doesn't really do anything. It just sits there. I came in nicely under-budget on my trip, so I celebrated by blowing some money at Borders last night. I got a copy of a fabulous 15th century mass by a French composer named Antoine Brumel. It's called urlLink "Et Ecce Terrae Motus" (I heard a sample from a free urlLink Harmonia Mundi sampler I received recently) and is really something. I also satiated my love for all things espionage by getting a copy of the controversial book urlLink "The Puzzle Palace," which is basically an expose of the ultra-secret National Security Agency. I was inspired to pick up the book last weekend when we drove by the NSA headquarters in Maryland. Oh, and I also broke down and bought the box set of the first two seasons of urlLink "Homicide: Life on the Street." Holy shit, was that a great TV show or what? For the life of me, I still can't figure out why it only garnered a tiny (but mighty) cult following, despite the fact that it received multiple urlLink Peabody Awards and was hailed by every critic under the sun. No matter. It lives on in the DVD format. I watched the pilot episode last night and plan to hold a little "Homicide" marathon over the weekend. What else is going on this weekend? Well, there's a going away party for two Borders employees tonight -- Nate aka "Hate" and Steph are sadly leaving the Boston area. Nate is trailing behing the Border Mass Exodus of 2001 and heading for the Pacific Northwest, while Steph -- true to form -- is settling down in lovely Las Vegas. Liza's starting to get the sniffles so we probably won't stay long. Just long enough to see someone throw up or the cops get called. Either way, we'll be happy. Speaking of Liza, I've saved the best news for last: Liza is starting a blog of her own. Actually, I started it for her this morning. Since she's going to be spending the fall semester abroad, she figured this would be the best way to keep the peeps back in the States abreast of her goings-on in Europe. So there's not much on the site at the moment, but in the meantime -- urlLink here it is. Have an absolutely peachy weekend.

adventures in tourism I'm a little over halfway through my week-long excursion in leafy Columbia, Maryland. Liza, my sister Julie and I drove down here to spend about six days with my mom, who moved down here about two years ago with Charlie, her amour of the last thirteen years or so. Also, my 10 1/2-year-old daughter Audrey flew out here from Chicago. Now I know how all those tour-ons who I scowl at when I'm home in Boston feel like. Boy, have I ever been a tourist these past few days. So far we visited a handful of historical sites in Washington, DC, in addition to Annapolis (which is really really nice and I was able to dial down my pacifism enough to thoroughly enjoy a tour of the Naval Academy) and the Washington Zoo (or the Smithsonian National Zoo or whatever the hell they call it). I don't have much of an urge to discuss any current events. Well, maybe the blackout. Holy crap, was that weird or what? still the man I was going to write a long, detailed review of the urlLink Joe Jackson concert Liza, Julie, Julie's friend Paula and I attended at Avalon last Sunday, but if you want an accurate assessment of the show, check out my review of the April 4 show at the Paradise. It was very much the same show, especially considering the fact that they were both amazing. Joe and his late seventies band (Graham Maby, Dave Houghton and Gary Sanford) are still an incredibly tight, sharp band, capable of both tender crooning and old-school punk/new wave asskicking. Get yourself to a JJ show while his tour is still going on. Sunday night's Joe Jackson highlights: Guitarist Gary Sanford, still recovering from a broken foot, was seated at an office-stype swivel chair (on wheels) during the show, but he ended up gleefully spinning his way around the stage during especially intense, up-tempo portions of the show. At Maby's insistence, the entire audience sang "Happy Birthday" to Joe when he came out for the encore -- his birthday was the next day. Joe's solo piano portion of the show: "Be My Number Two," "Real Men" and "A Slow Song." The fact that "Is She Really Going Out With Him" will never, ever get old, even 25 years later, and can turn any venue into a giant karaoke bar. The fact that Joe is the dorkiest rock star dancer since the Beautiful South's Paul Heaton. ...and that's just off the top of my head. Joe's pushing fifty and I doubt I'll ever be as cool as him.

insert obligatory arnold movie quote here I don't normally get too bogged down with politics on this site...if you want political blogging, urlLink here's someone who knows what they're talking about. when work gets in the way of blogging The scant few of you who read this blog on a daily basis may have noticed a general lack of posting lately. My job is mostly to blame for that. Lots of changes, mostly good. I was interviewed for a job -- a sort of "lateral transfer" -- within my department and I did not get it. But my current job is being modified to include a lot of interesting, creative things. I'm going to be a lot busier, but doing things I enjoy. Part of this change also involved me moving to a different desk, which is more frustrating than you might think. All computer equipment in our office is locked down, literally. So anytime you need to move a piece of equipment, a locksmith (located in another building) needs to be called. After the locksmith was called and my computer freed from its shackles, I physically moved the PC to its new cubicle. Then the monitor stopped working. Then I had to find a usable one in our junkheap of computer equipment. During all of this I had to do my regular work, all without a working computer. But everything's fine now, thank you. gas up the honda, let's go Today feels like Friday. Because tomorrow I'll be starting my vacation. Liza, my sister Julie and I are road-tripping it. We'll be waking up at the crack of dawn, leaving at 5 am and heading south, to Columbia, Maryland. My mom and Charlie (her better half for the last 14 years) are living there now, and we will be seeing them, in addition to the sights and sounds of Baltimore, DC, Annapolis and other points of interest. Julie and Liza will be doing the driving, and since I haven't had a valid driver's license in more than four years (long story, let's not get into it), I've been given the task of...wait for it...compiling music for the trip! What an easy gig. Last night I took my 64-disc case, in addition to my 24-disc case, and put together 88 CDs for the drive. I plan to turn that mother out, as they say. Actually, compiling music for this drive is a bit easier than usual, since I have to keep in mind that there's probably a lot of stuff in my collection that Julie and Liza won't care for. So...no urlLink Frank Zappa, no overly "skronky" jazz music, and I suppose my latest obssession with urlLink King Crimson will have to take a backseat for the next week or so as well. No big deal, that leaves plenty of room for other audible delights. Liza's also buying some urlLink Mad Libs. What trip would be complete without that? One of the best things about our trip to Maryland is that my daughter Audrey will be flying out from Chicago. Your daughter, Chris? That's right. You all know that I was married for a few years in the early-mid 90s, but I don't know if I've ever mentioned on this blog that my ex and I have a daughter who lives with her in Illinois. I suppose I tried to avoid it for a long time because I thought that blogging about my kid seemed at tad...I don't know...exploitative. But I realize that it's really not, so be prepared in the future to hear more than you ever needed to know about my 10 1/2 year old daughter, who happens to be the greatest kid in the world. Interesting Audrey development...I was talking to her on the phone last week, and this diehard Justin Timberlake fan tells me that she really likes urlLink the Donnas. Now I've never, ever been one to tell my daughter that she needs to listen to this band or that band...kids can listen to whatever they want (well...within reason), and if it's a teenybopper singer, fine. Chances are they'll get over that phase eventually, but if they don't -- hey, they don't. Besides, there's nothing more dorky than liking the music your parents like, and I certainly don't want to make Audrey feel dorky. But I have to admit that it's pretty cool that she likes the Donnas. I still have more things to blog about before my trip, so you haven't heard the last of me today.

This is the twisted weekend of my life The title of todays post comes from the song Weekend by urlLink Mike Keneally, and on the surface it seems to be a fitting way to begin describing my past weekend. But if you know the song, you know that its a harsh, grating, venom-spewing (yet irresistibly rockin) story of a particularly horrific weekend Mr. Keneally experienced several years ago. And my past weekend was really not horrific at all. So I dont know why Im using a line from that song. Maybe its just because the song is called Weekend. Yeah. Thats it. My weekend was not super-eventful, but enough stuff happened to warrant a recap with little vignettes that wont change your life but wont repulse you with boredom, either (I hope not, anyway). After work on Friday, I got my haircut on Boylston Street and afterwards, while heading to the subway (grappling with my man-bag, a compulsively-bought cup of coffee and my Walkman), I noticed that, somewhere along the line, my work ID badge had fallen off my belt, leaving only the clip. This would have been a sad inconvenience if not for what happened this morning (more on that later). Later, after I went home to change, I headed over to Lizas apartment for dinner. The subway ride was a pleasant one as I continued to enjoy my new copy of King Crimsons urlLink The Power to Believe, My Borders co-worker Nate took home a free promo copy from the store a couple of months ago, not realizing that I was a budding KC fan. Since he wasnt too crazy about the disc himself, he gave it to me the other day and Ive been enjoying the hell out of it. Saturday was a fun day at Borders as one of our managers arranged to rent one of those big truck-length dumpsters in order for us to throw away giant heaps of shelving units we no longer use, desks that are broken, non-functioning CD keepers, outdated wooden fixtures, and lots of other stuff that needed to get thrown away. The manager who set this up, Heather, is one of our newer managers and kicks lots of ass. She has a fresh attitude towards the store, especially considering the fact that we have managers and supervisors whove been there forever and refuse to throw anything away. Being the anti-packrat, I seized this opportunity to help rid the store of useless clutter. A lot of the wooden fixtures needed to be broken down before being dumped into the dumpster and I do mean broken down. We were issued sledgehammers and instructed to go to town. Im telling you, nothing assuages retail frustration more than a heavy hammer against aging wood. Yippee! Saturday night, Liza and I used her two monthly comp tickets to the urlLink Improv Asylum (she works at the box office there part-time). The show was fantastic, as always (the new love song to urlLink Mitt Romney is a scream), but about fifteen minutes before the end of the show, the fire alarm went off. Everyone milled about outside the theater for a good ten to fifteen minutes, where Liza stated, what a buzz-kill. We were then instructed to go back inside and watch the rest of the show. About two minutes into the show, the alarm went off again. The audience (and cast) groaned in frustration, everyone headed upstairs, and unfortunately (but understandably), several audience members took off for good. After all, there was only about 10-15 minutes of show left, and the 10 pm show was going to be starting fairly soon. Liza and I toughed it out and headed back into the club, where the audience (only about 25 percent full at this point) was told that they could not continue the show since the 10 pm show was already going to be delayed. We were all issued two free comp tickets for any future show. I thought this was a great move on the clubs part. Theyre going to take a pretty big loss, not just in handing out some free tickets, but also when you consider that some of the patrons, many of them first-timers, may tell their friends not to waste their time by going to this venue because of one unfortunate event that is in no way typical for this club. Ive been a huge supporter of the Improv Asylum for more than three years, ever since Liza and I started dating. Ive probably seen the show at least a dozen times and its always flat-out hilarious. So if you were in the audience for the Saturday 8 pm show, please come back. A couple of frat boys jokingly pulling a fire alarm in an apartment above the club (thats what I heard, anyway) is not the fault of the establishment. Sunday morning was a typically lazy one, and I began sorting through some VHS movies that I own but are at Lizas apartment since she has a VCR and I dont anymore. I put on urlLink Still of the Night, an obscure mystery thriller starring Roy Scheider and Meryl Streep. Ive always loved this movie, despite the fact that its a bit hokey. There are in fact some genuinely scary scenes and the direction (by Robert Benton, who directed Kramer vs. Kramer, one of my favorite films) is quite good. We all know Meryl Streep is great, but Ive always loved Scheiders work as well. Hes really one of the most underrated actors of his generation. Liza needed to go downtown around 11:30 for her tap class, so I followed her and picked up a disc I special ordered from Borders: King Crimsons urlLink Night Watch. I spent a good hour or so wandering around the city while listening to this disc on my Walkman. Its actually a two-disc live album of a 1973 Amsterdam concert. Im still not completely sold on live Crimson albums. The only other one Ive heard so far is urlLink USA, which I really am not crazy about. Night Watch is good, and its really growing on me, but at this point I really prefer their studio stuff. After Liza and I went home, I continued my search through the long-ignored pile of VHS tapes. We watched the trippy, often mesmerizing urlLink Altered States and Spike Lees underrated urlLink Mo Better Blues before Nate called us and asked if we wanted to see urlLink Pirates of the Caribbean at 9:25. We said yeah, and grabbed dinner at Burrito Max in Kenmore Square and walked from there to the theater (Leows Boston Common), which is a really long walk but we had time to kill. Pirates was an enjoyable film, nothing groundbreaking, but fun in a silly, action film kind of way. Johnny Depp was a lot of fun to watch, especially once I heard that his inspiration for this performance was urlLink Keith Richards. He really nailed Keiths swaggering wino bit perfectly. So, this morning. I meant to tell youI received a phone call at work from a woman who found my ID card on Boylston Street Friday night. She doesnt work for our company, but she does consulting for us and has a meeting scheduled in our office on Thursday. Talk about coincidences.

the friday five Here it is, ladies and gentlemen...the ultimate cop-out of the writer-blocked blogger: the urlLink Friday Five! I decided to do it this week since the questions were a little less dorky than usual. So here we go. 1) What time to you wake up on weekday mornings? I set my television to turn on automatically at 6:45, and I usually crawl out of bed just before seven. 2) Do you sleep in on the weekends? How late? Not on Saturdays, because I work a morning shift at Borders on that day. On Sunday, my waking schedule varies. If I have nothing to do and nowhere to go, I will usually get up somewhere between 9:30 and 10:30. Unless I was up late the night before (not likely these days), in which case it would be more in the 11 to 12 range. I usually like the morning. If I could get up at dawn every day, I would. But I can't. 3) Aside from waking up, what is the first thing you do in the morning? Get a bowl of cereal and a cup of coffee, bring it in my bedroom and watch the first fifteen minutes of the Today Show. Yes, I'm a creature of habit. 4) How long does it take to get ready for your day? I get out of bed just before seven and leave the house around 7:40, so I guess that's about 40 minutes. If I'm rushed, I can do it in 25-30. But I hate being rushed. 5) When possible, what if your favorite place to go for breakfast? Sunday is the only day I can do that, and I don't do it often. Liza and I love the urlLink Pour House on Boyslton Street (excellent brunch, very inexpensive), and when she lived in Allston we used to go to this great place on Harvard Avenue called urlLink Grecian Yearning (strange name, great food). I used to love sitting at the counter and watching the dudes work the grill.

if tomorrow's tuesday... ...then there must be a veritable buttload of new CD and DVD releases on the way. As for CDs, off the top of my head I know that there's a sweet new Randy Newman urlLink anthology on the way, in addition to Lyle Lovett's first urlLink album of all-new material in several years (it'll be nice to hear that, after putting up with umpteen compilations and covers projects). The DVD side of things is where it gets really good. First of all, a decent "special edition" of urlLink "Fargo" is finally coming out. I firmly believe that the Coen Brothers are the finest filmmakers alive today (since urlLink Kubrick died, anyway), and this is probably, in my opinion, their most accomplished overall work. I found urlLink "The Big Lebowski" funnier, and urlLink "The Man Who Wasn't There" more impressive on a cinematographic scale, but "Fargo" sort of combined the best elements of the Coens' unique style in one masterpiece of a film. The folks at urlLink Criterion are earning their keep as well, releasing an early film of Roman Polanski's (another one of my favorite directors): urlLink "Knife in the Water," which also includes a bonus disc of early Polanski short films. I love you, Criterion. The long-awaited special edition of urlLink "The Kids are Alright" finally hits the shelves. If you're a Who fan, a music historian, or a lover of insightful documentaries on rock stars living to excess, you owe it to yourself to get your hands on this one. I first saw it on HBO in the early eighties, and it's still one of the best music documentaries I've ever seen. It includes their controversially explosive (literally) appearance on the Smothers Brothers TV show, John Entwhistle skeet-shooting, an exuberant Keith Moon leading his bandmates in the studio for a rough-but-rousing version of "Barbara Ann," tons of concert footage and more. Buy it tomorrow. Do it for the music. Do it for the memory of Keith and John. And last but certainly not least, urlLink Paul Weller is releasing a new concert DVD, "Live at Braehead Arena." Oi!

eight simple rules for riding the T 1) Don't bring hot food (burgers, fries, Chinese, etc) on the train. It stinks up the place a lot more than usual. The T ends up smelling like the Corner Mall -- not a good thing. 2) Don't bring a hot beverage on the train during rush hour. I realize that you need your caffeine fix, but nobody is coordinated enough to handle that. Plus, there's always the chance you'll spill it, enraging an already cranky bunch of commuters. Get your coffee at work. 3) If you know that you're going to be on a crowded train, do us all a favor and slap on some anti-perspirant before you leave the house. If you think hot french fries are a stifling odor on the T, try an unwashed, sweaty, overweight passenger. Like my friend Jamie said when he visited me in Naples: "blue cheese is not a deodorant." 4) Let the people out before you get in. It's just like an elevator. Why do so many people find this confusing? 5) Don't spread out across two seats when the train is crowded. I don't care how long your legs are -- it's just plain rude. The same goes for those jerk-offs who put their bag on a separate seat. That's what your lap is for, you ingrate. 6) Don't stand in front of the entrance when other people are getting on or off the train. That little alcove isn't your own personal space, it serves a function: to funnel people on and off. Common sense, people. 7) You know what I hate? People who stand in front of an empty seat. What the hell is that all about? I realize that your manly stamina allows you to stand while lesser men choose to sit, but if there's a seat available, someone out there wants it, and you're blocking it. I'm not impressed, Abs of Steel. Move out of the way. 8) This one is for the conductors. I've got plenty of beefs with you people, but here's a glaring problem I encounter all the time, particularly on the Green Line: TURN DOWN THE DAMN SPEAKERS!! I realize that Copley is the next stop, I don't need to hear it at decibel levels that would overpower a Who concert. "BING! BONG! NEXT STOP COPLEY! THIS IS A 'D' RIVERSIDE TRAIN!!" I get the idea! Dial it down a bit. What, did the MBTA get a special bargain rate on the "Earsplitter" model? Jeez...isn't it enough that you're raising the damn fares in January?

i'm glad it will rain today It would be easy to describe urlLink Elvis Costello's latest album, "North," as a continuation of "Painted From Memory," his 1998 collaboration with uber-songwriter Burt Bacharach. In fact you could even draw comparisons to his 1993 string quartet-fueled "The Juliet Letters." But the fact is, "North" is a unique entry in the Costello catalog. One that may alienate fans, but still a worthwhile effort that will grow stronger with repeated listens. That's easy for me to say...I just bought it last night. But initial impressions are strong. The album's potential staying power is aided in large part to the timeless nature of the arrangements. While his work with Bacharach employed ornate, flashy -- shall we say, "Bacharachian" -- arrangements, the sparse yet lyrical use of orchestral instruments on "North" suggests mature classics-in-the-making. It's a given that people waiting for Elvis' New Wave Angry Young Man persona should sit this one out -- unless they have open minds and are willing to experiment. The fact is, despite Costello's undisputed position as one of the first Thinking Man's Punks, his ability to create works that impress the jazz and classical set is difficult to deny, especially after hearing his latest release (the venerable classical label Deutsche Grammophon was impressed enough to release the album, after all). While "Painted..." evoked a classic 60s pop sound, "North" is most definitely rooted in jazz, albeit of the torch-song brand. Elvis sings a lot of the songs in a melancholy low register, aided by longtime partner-in-crime Steve Nieve and a host of other musicians, including the Brodsky Quartet (the string ensemble that accompanied him on "The Juliet Letters"). Orchestrations are lush and inventive (arranged and conducted by Elvis himself). The lyrics are not among Elvis' most imaginative. Long considered one of rock's most inventive, literate writers (and still is, if you've heard last years vitriolic "When I Was Cruel"), the songs here mainly concern love, both gained and lost. The break-up of his 16-year marriage to Cait O'Riordan and his current relationship with jazz singer Diana Krall are reportedly the inspirations behind the words sung here. And while lines like "I've wasn't very conversational / except to say that 'you're sensational'" can make me cringe, overall the lyrical content is pleasant enough. It's the impressive, unique and sophisticated arrangements that stand out on "North." Piano is the main instrument here (with Nieve's beautiful playing, it's no wonder he's been Costello's right-hand-man for more than 25 years), and there's barely a guitar to be heard (the liner notes say that Elvis plays guitar on "When It Sings," but I'll be damned if I can hear it). The "bonus disc" is a DVD with Elvis playing three songs at the piano (an old, dirty upright piano in some mock-forest soundstage -- kind of strange, if you ask me). He also discusses the songs a bit before playing them -- two "North" songs in addition to the unreleased title track. In fact, Elvis says (with a mischievous gleam in his eye) that you can find the song if you look around for it. The truth is, you have to download in online. The disc comes with a card that includes a PIN number to get to the track. I have to go along with urlLink Tom and say that this is a practice that needs to stop. If it's good enough to be released, put it on the damn album already. Tom also referred to "North" as "a good 'winter' album," which I feel is an accurate description. I'd also call it a good "rainy" album (the title of this post is one of my favorite lines from the album so far). It's a good album to listen to while walking cold, rainy city streets, thinking about love. A bit corny? Maybe. But it's still beautiful.

born to eat Zagat, the folks responsible for those ubiquitous restaurant guides, have taken it upon themselves to release the urlLink results of a survey of the top albums of all time. I have no idea why they've chosen to branch out in this manner, but let's give them the benefit of the doubt. In the meantime, I'll good-naturedly pick apart their top ten choices... 1) "Born to Run," Bruce Springsteen: I'm not a Springsteen fan. He just doesn't do anything for me. But I appreciate the fact that a lot of people do and accept the fact that he's very good at what he does. This is supposed to be a good album, and I guess if I was a fan I'd approve. 2) "Abbey Road," The Beatles: Definitely one of their best (although not my personal favorite). Lots of good songs, and the medley on side two is brilliant. 3) "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band," The Beatles: I think this album is very accomplished and has some very nice songs, but in the end I find it overrated. Nowadays is sounds a bit quaint and dated. 4) "The Joshua Tree," U2: Not a big U2 fan (but I used to be). There's some good stuff on this album, but they were really at the peak of their self-importance here. Still, I guess I can see why it was so huge. 5) "White Album," The Beatles: Now we're talking. Undoubtedly, hands-down my all-time favorite Beatles album. This is the one that should have gotten all the huzzahs they gave Sgt. Pepper. Dense, intense, adventurous and endlessly creative. Besides the obvious experimentalism (in songs like "Revolution 9" and "Piggies"), there's also lots of very beautiful music ("Mother Nature's Son," "Cry Baby Cry"), lots of kick-ass rockers ("Yer Blues," "Everybody's Got Something to Hide Except Me and My Monkey") and quite possibly the Beatles' most underrated song (George Harrison's funky "Savoy Truffle"). 6) "Kind of Blue," Miles Davis: I was under the impression that they were just rating rock albums, but that's okay. Miles' 1959 classic transcends genres. The album is regularly hailed as a groundbreaking masterpiece and it's easy to see why after only one listen. It's gorgeous stuff (although I prefer "In a Silent Way," if I could only have one Miles Davis disc to listen to). 7) "Darkenss on the Edge of Town," Bruce Springsteen: see #1. 8) "Revolver," The Beatles: There's a lot of people out there who consider this their best album. It certainly broke a lot of ground, and there's several excellent songs on this album, but they would do much better work afterwards. 9) "Dark Side of the Moon," Pink Floyd: This album has suffered what I feel is an unfair backlash. Like most classic rock of the 70s, this album was played to death on the radio and has unfortunately diminished its power. But if you revisit it with fresh ears, you'll notice that it really is an amazing, moody piece of work. 10) "Achtung Baby," U2: Huh? While I find it odd that this album found its way on to the Top Ten, I have to admit that it's my favorite U2 album and blows the prententious "Joshua Tree" out of the water.

enjoy the view The name urlLink Bryan Beller may not ring a bell with you, unless you're a jazz/rock/fusion fan living in Southern California, or better yet, if you're a fan of the gargantuanly talented urlLink Mike Keneally. Bryan has been Mike's bass player on and off for about ten years, which is no easy task. Not that Mike is crankier than Van Morrison on the Atkins Diet -- it's just that Keneally's music is pretty tough to play. Complicated jazz/rock/alternative stuff that veers from the jaw-dropping stylings of Frank Zappa (Mike's former mentor) to the lush power-pop of XTC and Todd Rundgren. What I'm getting at is that Bryan, stellar musician that he is, is getting ready to release his very-first solo album, entitled "View." If you appreciate challenging music played well with a touch of bizarre humor, you should drop a few bucks on this upcoming release. Bryan's urlLink site even has some tasty audio samples. This is your chance to open your mind to new music, and in the process, support a struggling musician who runs his own label (Onion Boy Records), as opposed to funneling more of your hard-earned cash into the latest MTV Flavor of the Month.

the latest controversy I rarely edit posts after they've been published, unless it's to clear up a spelling or grammatical error that I notice after the fact. But a post from this morning about certain opinons I have toward Elvis Presley have caused me to rethink a couple of things. Mainly, I wanted to change the title of the post, "Chuck D was right." I was referring to the Public Enemy song "Fight the Power," which calls Elvis a racist. I don't know of any substantial proof that Elvis was a racist. There was an alleged quote from Elvis that made the rounds years ago, something to the effect of African Americans only being good for "shining my shoes and buying my records," but as far as I'm concerned that's an urban legend. I decided to replace the title with a line from a Living Colour song that gets to the heart of what I was trying to say. Elvis was in fact a deeply talented artist. People who like his music are by no means racist simply by virtue of their musical taste. I just feel that labelling the man "the king of rock and roll" is grossly inaccurate when you consider how many great artists were writing and performing rock and roll before him. That's all I wanted to say. I guess this is why I hesitated for so long about adding a comments section.

two movies i saw over the weekend urlLink "American Splendor." If Paul Giamatti isn't nominated for an Oscar, my faith in the human race will futher dwindle. Paul plays Harvey Pekar, a file clerk whose main obsessions are jazz and comic books. In the 1970s he meets comic artist R. Crumb and together they create "American Splendor," a comic book about Harvey's dull existence. Pekar himself narrates the film and appears every so often in surreal interview segments. The film give non-comic book enthusiasts (like myself) a new appreciation for the genre. Harvey's rumpled, no-nonsense persona gets him an occasional gig on David Letterman's show, but once he's sick of being the source of Dave's bemusement, Harvey appears on the show for the last time and berates the host and audience in what will be his final appearance. Never have I seen a film that has made an ordinary guy so winning and engaging. Although Harvey is not much of a sentimental guy, and he warns us early on that this isn't some sappy Hollywood story, He does in fact come off as an old softie on occasion. A unique move about a unique guy. urlLink "Anything Else." This latest Woody Allen movie is being heralded by some critics as a return to form after several mediocre disappointments ("Curse of the Jade Scorpion," "Hollywood Ending"). Here, Woody goes back to what he does best: romantic comedy with typical barbs about life in New York and being Jewish. Jason Biggs plays a comedy writer whose relationship with his girlfriend (Christina Ricci) is complicated by the fact that she has trouble committing and is a bundle of vices. Does this sound like classic Woody yet? Of course it does. Woody himself plays Jason's paranoid mentor, Stockard Channing is brilliant as Ricci's overdramatic mother (playing what Woody fans might call "the Dianne Weist role"), Danny Devito is Biggs' incompetent manager, and Jimmy Fallon even gets in on the act as Biggs' best friend who introduces the Ricci character. There's a lot of the Woody Allen standbys here: trips to the shrink, the lead character ranting on to the camera, and of course, those comforting white-on-black title cards with the big band music in the background. This isn't anything that would take "Hannah and Her Sisters," "Annie Hall" or "Crimes and Misdemeanors" off my list of favorite Woody Allen movies, but it's a fun treat and a nice return to form.

a black man taught him how to sing, and then they crowned him king Some people have been a bit on the peeved side regarding my comments about Elvis Presley. While I dont despise the man, and will admit that he released some fine recordings and was an excellent, unique singer, my main beef with the guy is the fact that he was (and still is) called the King of Rock and Roll. Now listen closely, Elvis fans, because this is where youll begin your long, bitter hatred and resentment toward me. I believe it is racist to call Elvis Presley the King of Rock and Roll. Why? Thats an easy one. Long before Elvis came along, there was rock and roll, and it was being performed by some pretty talented people. Chuck Berry, Ray Charles, Fats Domino, and -- perhaps the most underrated and overly screwed-over figure in music history -- Bo Diddley. Those are just a few of Elvis predecessors. But along came Presley, white as a loaf of Wonder Bread, and now society can put an acceptable Caucasian face on rock and roll. We cant call a colored person the King of anything, now can we? Well heres a white man who can sing that crazy rhythm music just fine. So here you go, Elvis! Youre the King!
