my weekend at the movies I didnt exactly spend the entire weekend in a movie theater, but it certainly felt like it. And thats good. Just as I planned it, I attended three movies this weekend, and guess what? They were all great. That doesnt happen too often, now does it? I decided that one of the things I can do to stay busy, entertained, and relatively happy while Liza is in Europe for three months is go to the movies a lot. Im thinking about maybe at least one movie every weekend, which is quite do-able, as long as I dont raid the concession stand every time (Im proud to say that I didnt give the overpriced snack counters an ounce of my business during any of my three trips to the theater this weekend I love noshing at the movies, but the trick is to eat a meal beforehand; it seems to work). Before I go into any reviews of this weekends films, how about some movie theater observations that Ive been dying to get off my chest? Ill try to keep it brief. First of all why the hell cant people figure out how to get to the movie on time? You know when the movie is playing; you presumably know how to get to the theater; so do us all a favor and show up on time. When Im in the theater, I want zero distractions. None at all. So get in your seat before showtime and shut the hell up, okay? Thanks. Speaking of shutting up the unwritten rule during a movie is NO TALKING. I rarely use all caps, so you know I mean business here. Shut up. I didnt pay $8.75 to listen to your inane observations. And if your attention deficit disorder-addled date cant follow the plot, whisper in his/her ear. Talking in full voice during a movie should be punishable with possible jail time, as far as Im concerned. Okay, when did they start showing commercials in the theater? Im not talking about previews I enjoy those Im talking about commercials for cars, soda, whatever. File that one under the I-didnt-pay-$8.75-for rant. And lets not even go into the insipid Coca Cola Football Town commercial thats being shown ad nauseum . Although I admit that I really love the Inconsiderate Cell Phone Man spot (Its pronounced Kara-TAY). I wont get into cell phone rudeness in the theaters because I rarely, if at all, encounter anyone idiotic enough to actually leave their phone on in the theater (although Im sure it happens). And what about these Fandango ads? Does anyone use this Fandango thing? I dont know a single person who does, but I sure know a lot of people whove seen the ads. Wow, that was cathartic. Friday night: Lost in Translation Jumpin Jesus on a pogo stick, you have to see this movie. Sofia Coppola, who directed 2000s Virgin Suicides, does the complete opposite of the sophomore slump she makes a film more brilliant, mature and insightful than her already-impressive debut. Bill Murray plays an American actor in Japan to shoot a whiskey commercial. In his bored stupor he meets a fellow American, played by Scarlet Johanssen (whose mussed, thrift-store looks are ten times sexier than any of the standard Cameron Diaz bimbos, if you ask me), whos accompanying her husband (Giovanni Ribisi), a rock photographer whos always off on shoots and doesnt seem to care much that his relatively new bride is bored stiff in the hotel. Murray and Johanssen strike up an unusual friendship and spend most of their time wandering around the gaudy, neon-lit streets of Tokyo. The music, the cinematopgraphy, and the understated acting all make this a total pleasure to watch. See it. Saturday: Le Divorce Despite the mixed reviews, Ive wanted to see this movie for some time. I enjoy the films of Merchant/Ivory, and although they normally specialize in period pieces, their forays into the modern world are often just as entertaining. This one caught my attention especially for its subject matter: Americans in Paris. Paris in general has always been a soft spot for me, whether its music, art, film, literature living there for five years as a child had an effect on me that that remains to this day. Kate Hudson in a surprisingly low-key role plays an American woman visiting her sister in Paris. Her sister played by Naomi Watts is married to a Frenchman. They have one daughter and are expecting a second child. Hudson arrives at her sisters apartment just as her brother-in-law is walking out the door, presumably forever. This sets up an often amusing, occasionally sweet, and sometimes brutally serious story about divorce, and how American and French cultures react differently to myriad social situations. Watts in-laws a tight-lipped, rich, influential lot obviously side with the husband, and they seem to be more concerned about how the property will be divided up than how this will affect the husband, wife, child, and expected child emotionally. A painting that Watts brought with her to France when she first arrived in the country is quite possibly worth a great deal of money, and the two families fight bitterly about its worth and ownership. Watts family visits from the States to help clear up some of the squabbles. Her parents (played expertly by Sam Waterston and Stockard Channing) want whats best for their daughter, while her brother is the typical Ugly American and is concerned about the painting and little else. Stephen Fry has a hilarious scene as an appraiser from Christies who meets the American family for lunch to discuss the paintings worth. The movie is fun, beautifully shot and paints Paris in a gorgeous light, despite the fact that it shows its people to be rather callous. The film is a bit schizophrenic, however; it occasionally cant decide whether its a social farce, a mystery or straight drama. And the whole subplot with Matthew Modine as a jealous American whose wife is cheating on him with Watts husband was ridiculous. It ruined the flow of the film and was pretty far-fetched. Overall, though I recommend it. Sunday: Dirty Pretty Things Stephen Frears is nothing if not eclectic. Hes directed slices of urban England (Sammy and Rosie Get Laid, My Beautiful Launderette), con artist yarns (The Grifters), period pieces (Mary Reilly) and one hilarious adaptation of a book about record store employees (High Fidelity). His latest film is billed as a thriller, but its really more along the lines of a social drama with occasional thriller overtones. In the film, Chiwotel Ejiofor plays a Nigerian illegal immigrant named Okwe who works as a cab driver by day and a hotel concierge by night. A fellow hotel employee, Senay (played by Audrey Tautou of Amelie) is Turkish and is allowed to live in England for the time being while her immigration status is under review. In any case, she cant take employment or rent out her apartment until her status is approved. So what does she do? Gets a job and lets Okwe crash on her couch. Needless to say, these two have a lot to fear. Deportation, jail time you name it. Okwe discovers that the sleazy hotel manager is involved in an organ donation scheme that allows illegals to obtain passports as long as theyre willing to give up a kidney. Okwe's skills as a doctor in his native country give the manager an excuse to cut him in on the operation. Okwe is torn between his values, helping is friend Senay, and maybe getting legal status too, while hes at it. What follows is a gritty look at underworld London. Sweatshops, hookers, morgues and illegal, botched operations are all part of the fabric of this truly original film. Tautou, who I adored in Amelie but was afraid would seem inauthentic in this role, totally blew away my misconceptions. She pulls off the impressive trick of being a French actress speaking English with a Turkish accent. Shes amazing. Ejiofor is also brilliant. A British born-and-raised actor who apparently learned the accent from his African-born parents, hes completely believable. The film is a tough, uncompromising look at an unforgiving world where nothing is easy.

warren zevon: making sense of the catalog Checking out amazon.com this morning, I couldn't help noticing (quite happily, I might add) that not only is Warren Zevon's last, almost-posthumous album "The Wind" the number-one seller on their site, but most of the rest of his releases are scattered liberally throughout the chart (including two more titles in the top ten alone). This is a bittersweet victory for Warren's legacy. While it's great to see the attention his music has been getting since he was diagnosed with terminal cancer, it's a shame he's not here to see it happen. Since I'm willing to bet a good deal of these Amazon customers are plowing through Warren's catalog without a strong sense of what they're looking for, I'm only too happy to provide an unoffical guide to these amazing albums. Warren Zevon made lots of great music. Here's a breakdown (note: these are my opinions. If you disagree, my apologies): "Wanted Dead or Alive" (1969) -- I'm no expert on this album since, well, I've never heard it. But by most accounts, it's an amateurish effort for completists only. Warren released this album in 1969 and after it bombed, he wrote jingles, traveled around Europe, and toured with the Everly Brothers until meeting Jackson Browne, who produced his follow-up, the cleverly titled... "Warren Zevon" (1976) -- This is where it gets good. A beautifully produced album and a launching pad for a brilliant career. Some of Warren's best songs can be found here: "Poor Poor Pitiful Me," "Mohammed's Radio," "The French Inhaler," "Carmelita" and the gorgeous "Desperados Under the Eaves," which urlLink Palmermix called "perhaps the best song I know of about living in Los Angeles." "Excitable Boy" (1978) -- A brilliant follow-up and one of my personal favorites. In my opinion, there isn't a single weak track on the album (not even "Night Time in the Switching Yard" -- its dated disco-funk sound is a fun listen). Warren's "hits" can be found here ("Werewolves of London," "Excitable Boy," "Lawyers, Guns and Money") along with some classic ballads ("Accidentally Like a Martyr") and mid-tempo stompers ("Johnny Strikes Up the Band"). Essential stuff. "Bad Luck Streak in Dancing School" (1980) -- Despite the ambitious experimentalism (the string quartet interludes), Warren was slipping a bit here. There are definitely some strong numbers here (like the riff-heavy title track, "Play it all Night Long," the jubilant cover of "A Certain Girl" and the dense, violent "Jungle Work"), but there's also a lot of filler. If you become a huge fan after getting some more vital releases, check this one out. But it's not a good first choice. "Stand in the Fire" (1981) -- This album has never been released on CD, but I hear rumors that Rhino is planning to put it out next year. If so, do yourself a favor and grab it. This incendiary live album features Warren tearing up the Roxy with a band of young, hungry unknowns. The live version of "Mohammed's Radio" is far superior to the tamer original, and Warren's penchant for changing lyrics around is used to hilarious effect throughout the album. Absolutely insane live work and one of the finest live albums I've ever heard. "The Envoy" (1982) -- Another one that's not out on CD -- yet. A bit uneven, like "Bad Luck Streak...", and the presence of cheesy keyboards is a bit of a distraction. There are some nice, sweet tunes here ("The Hula Hula Boys," "Looking For the Next Best Thing"), in addition to some heavy rockers ("The Overdraft," the hilarious "Ain't That Pretty at All"), but overall, this one can wait until you have most of the others. "A Quiet Normal Life: the Best of WZ" (1986) -- Avoid this one. Seriously. First of all, it was released in the mid-eighties when CD mastering was still sketchy, and song selection -- in my opinion -- leaves a lot to be desired. There are two other far superior compilations out there, and we'll get to them in a minute. "Sentimental Hygiene" (1987) -- Zevon returns from a self-imposed exile (where he quit drinking and got his shit together) with this strong album. One of his best and definitely his best of the eighties. Bill Berry, Peter Buck and Mike Mills (three-quarters of REM) are his backing band for most of the tracks, and they sound terrific. Lots of great, great songs ("Detox Mansion," "Boom Boom Mancini," "Even a Dog Can Shake Hands," "The Factory") and tons of guests (Bob Dylan, Neil Young, Michael Stipe, Flea). The only less-than excellent parts are a couple of ballads that don't really do anything for me and an ill-advised collaboration with the otherwise great George Clinton (on the horribly dated "Leave My Monkey Alone"). Overall, an outstanding album. "Transverse City" (1989) -- This "cyberpunk" concept album suffers from too many overbearing keyboards, but the more organic tracks ("Splendid Isolation," "Turbulence," "Gridlock") are excellent. A mixed bag. "Hindu Love Gods" (1990) -- Unreleased jamming from the "Sentimental Hygiene" sessions (featuring Zevon, Buck, Mills and Berry). A rough, crazy mess and lots of fun to listen to. Mostly blues covers, but does contain a great garage band version of Prince's "Raspberry Beret." "Mr. Bad Example" (1991) -- Warren is still suffering from keyboard overdose at this point, but the songs are the saving grace here, from the brutal "Finishing Touches" to the tender "Suzie Lightning" and the hilarious "Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead." The title track is a scream. "Learning to Flinch" (1993) -- An excellent acoustic "unplugged" live album (featuring Warren on piano and acoustic guitar). Lots of great classic songs are given new life, and some of them actually sound better (the solo piano version of "The French Inhaler" blows away the original). The crowds are fun and appreciative, egging Warren on to some inspired performances (especially on the manic, almost psychotic version of "Poor Poor Pitiful Me"). "Mutineer" (1995) -- A commercial bomb, this album features Warren on most of the instruments, recorded at his home studio (with occasional help from guests like David Lindley and Bruce Hornsby). The songs have a "demo" quality to them, and are mostly very good (like "Rottweiler Blues," "The Indifference of Heaven" and the moving title track). But there's also a bit of filler. Above average. "I'll Sleep When I'm Dead" (1996) -- If you're going to get an anthology and you're not on a budget, get this one. Two discs packed with the essential stuff, plus lots of TV and film soundtrack stuff not available anywhere else, and a booklet stuffed with photos and song-by-song commentary from the man himself. If you're going to get only one thing by Warren (but don't!), get this. "Life'll Kill Ya" (2000) -- Warren returns after five years with this strong album. A sparsely arranged masterpiece. Most of the songs are amazing ("I Was In the House When the House Burned Down," "For My Next Trick I'll Need a Volunteer," "Don't Let Us Get Sick") with minimal filler. Get this. Now. "My Ride's Here" (2002) -- Another mixed bag. Some good rockers ("Sacrifical Lambs," the hilarious "Hit Somebody") but some so-so tracks as well. "Genius" (2002) -- If you don't want to go all out for the two-disc anthology, this is an excellent single-disc retrospective. Twenty-two tracks, and maybe two of them I'm not crazy about. Great stuff. "The Wind" (2003) -- Warren's health is a bit fragile at this point, but he comes through. The album is a bit ballad-heavy, but the songs are great. The fiery "Disorder in the House," the piano-driven "Numb as a Statue" and the touching closer "Keep Me In Your Heart" are all terrific. Get this not just for the great songs and performances, but as a fitting swan song for a man whose career was filled with wonderful moments.

music related memories: 1988 I dont know if this is going to work or not, but this is my attempt to show how music has always been a part of my life, year by year. Im choosing 1988 as a starting point because it was the first full year that I was living as an adult and as a result my own music was probably more present than ever. I will jump around from year to year as this project progresses (if it progresses at all). For the record, I spent October 1987 to August 1988 at the Defense Information School in Fort Benjamin Harrison, Indiana (where I was training to be a navy broadcast journalist) and in September 1988 I began a two-year tour at the Navy Broadcasting Service detachment in Diego Garcia, a small island in the middle of the Indian Ocean thats actually owned by the United Kingdom. January: Listening to my new cassette copy of the Elvis Costello b-sides collection Out of Our Idiot in my dorm room while the Indianapolis deep-freeze raged on outside. February: Buying a used cassette copy of Concerts for Kampuchea in a nasty little used store in Broad Ripple with my girlfriend, then listening in horror while it squealed away noisily in her cars tape deck. Dont buy used cassettes. March: Going totally apeshit when Public Image Limited broke into the Sex Pistols Holiday in the Sun at their Market Square Arena concert (opening for INXS). April: Realizing how beautiful the orchestral tracks on Erasures Two Ring Circus album sound. May: Being informed by a bemused Lieutenant Gordon Cole that I would be authorized to do a no-rules punk/new-wave program for my final SITE radio show class just so he could get an idea of what exactly this crazy music was that I listened to so much. June: Listening to Morrisseys Viva Hate and Thomas Dolbys Aliens Ate My Buick over and over and over. July: Docked points on my pop/rock radio show by choosing The Purple Lagoon by Frank Zappa as my instrumental outro music. Petty Officer Vince Vidal informed me that the selection is more appropriate for a jazz show. August: Buying the sampler cassette of Frank Zappas You Cant Do That On Stage Anymore box set and listening to it with unabashed glee in the tape deck of Ron Pooles car as we were driving back from the mall. September: Listening to Elvis Costellos Trust album on my Walkman and chain-smoking Marlboro Lights on the final, dead-of-night leg of my marathon plane ride from Philadelphia to Diego Garcia. October: Listening to the sadly out-of-print Urgh! A Music War soundtrack in my barracks room with roommate Bob Shunk. November: Receiving the first of many cassettes from my sister of random WFNX broadcasts, back when it was an interesting, innovative radio station with little regard for playlists. I first heard the Pixies (Where Is My Mind), They Might Be Giants (Purple Toupee) and John Wesley Harding (The Devil In Me) through these tapes. December: Obsessing over the cassette my brother mailed me, with Living Colours Vivid on one side and Fishbones Truth and Soul on the other.

i cannot prove that i exist It's true, I can't. One of my worst traits as a human being is that I proscrastinate. A lot. I'm also pretty lazy. As a result, I have no valid identification. I often let my various forms of ID lapse and don't bother to renew them until it's too late. Is it difficult to function in society like this? You bet it is. For the record, this is what I currently have for identification: An out-of-state (Virginia) drivers license that expired in March 1999. A passport that expired in February 2001. A military dependent ID card that expired in March 1999. A photo ID from my place of employment that doesn't really get me anywhere but my office. And that's about it. In March 1999, just before my Virginia license expired, I went to the Boston DMV to get a new Massachusetts license. I waited patiently in the never-ending line, filled out the necessary forms, even smiled for the camera as they were seconds away from taking my photo when the clerk noticed a red flag. Only two words were necessary for them to utter before I realized the hold-up: North Carolina. You see, it's not just my procrastination that's to blame for my lack of identity. The state of North Carolina should shoulder some responsibility for this as well. In the fall of 1994, when I was living in Virginia Beach, my (now ex-) wife and I took a leisurely drive through parts of North Carolina. Maybe it was the feel of that 1994 Hyundai under my control, or perhaps a particularly bracing mix tape in the deck, but the next thing you know there's flashing lights over my shoulder, then a no-nonsense state trooper in the driver's side window is informing me that I was doing 86 in a 55. 86, for the record, is considered reckless driving. After a particularly ridiculous court appearance the following month (in a courthouse that makes "Deliverance" look like a Woody Allen movie), I was fined $100 and not allowed to drive in North Carolina for one year. Fine. Fast-forward back to 1999, Keep in mind, this is a good three-and-a-half years after my driving privileges have been reinstated (in a state nowhere near Massachusetts). But for some reason, the Massachusetts DMV wants proof that I can still drive down there. They won't budge on my new license until this mystery is solved. So I get in touch with the folks in North Carolina, they send me the appropriate paperwork, but by this time I'm getting ready to move into a new apartment, there's lots of new job issues, etc etc etc, long story short: procrastination sets in once again. I attempted to get a license again about a year ago. By this time I've let it lapse to the point where I have to take a written exam. I studied like crazy for this thing and finally schlep all the way out to the only DMV office open on weekends that's within access of public transportation (in Watertown). I have my study guide and all the appropriate proof of identification, but by the time I get through the line, I'm informed by the extremely rude and unhelpful clerk that I do not in fact have the correct forms. All the cliches you hear about rude DMV employees are 100 percent accurate, folks. I was practically looking around for Patty and Selma from the Simpsons to creep out of the woodwork. You see, that's the problem. Yes, I'm a procrastinator. Yes, my dependence on public transportation (irony, anyone?) makes getting this damn thing such a hassle. But every time I manage to make it to the DMV, one more thing goes wrong and my efforts are shattered. This time, I'm going to make it easier. I'm just getting a Massachusetts ID (no license). I'm not going to be driving anytime soon and the standard ID is much easier to obtain (no test, less paperwork, considerably cheaper). All I have to do now is find my social security card (I think it's still around here somewhere) and get the ball rolling once again. Although I have to admit it's kind of interesting not having any valid identification. It's like I'm the center of some twisted psychological thriller. "This is Chris Ingalls. He has no identity."

whinings of a music snob The last eighteen hours have been a whirlwind of emotions for me, regarding a band I've just sort of discovered. Well, except for those seven hours when I was sleeping. A few days ago, I became the proud owner of a promo copy of "Welcome Interstate Managers," the latest album by urlLink Fountains of Wayne (thank you, part-time Borders job!). I finally got around to listening to it on my Walkman during my circuitous but well-worth-it trip to Porter Square on my way home from work in order to get a super carnitas burrito with chips and salsa from Anna's Taqueria (I also listened to Peter Gabriel's vastly-underrated second album, another shining example of why psychotic, early Gabriel is so much more appetizing to me than latter-day, World Music Gabriel). Where was I? Oh, yeah. Fountains of Wayne. So anyway, I've heard so much about this band over the years, but have never really listened to them. "Welcome Interstate Managers" was a revelation to me when I first popped it in last night. It's as if you put Elvis Costello, Squeeze, the Beatles, the Cars, Brian Wilson, Weezer and the Monkees in a blender and hit "puree." Gleaming, 24-karat power-pop with great lyrics and sumptuous hooks. I especially love "Bright Future in Sales," about a guy who gets drunk at office parties but really needs to "get his shit together," as the chorus proclaims, in order to succeed in the workplace. I love songs about mundane office jobs! Really. But here's the problem. After perusing FOW's website this morning, I was horrified to discover that the band is poised to be "big pop stars!" To wit: "Stacy's Mom" is #1 on VH1's Top Twenty Video Countdown (for the second week in a row); the song is also being added to numerous "hit" radio stations, like Z-100; you can vote for the song on TRL; it's listed in a "Teen People" poll; it's a "buzzworthy" track on MTV and MTV2; and the most horrifying fact of all -- the song is featured in the latest "Now!" compilation. I don't listen to the radio or watch MTV (because, after all, I am a music fan), so I was unaware of all this "buzz." HELP! I like these guys! Don't do this to me! I pride myself on an eclectic taste in music, in addition to discovering music not through MTV "buzzworthy" status or appearances in People magazine or TRL. If I hear something and I like it, I'll buy it. Additionally, if something becomes deathly popular, I'm almost automatically repelled by it. I don't want to be one of these automatons who buys into corporate hype. I see enough of those people in the store. I like having my own personal playlist or top twenty. Frank Zappa put it best when he put popularity and chart success in personal perspective in relation to his own works: "As far as I'm concerned, they're all hits. Every one of them. Even 'Dwarf Nebula Processional March.'" In the meantime, I'm going to continually love Fountains of Wayne. But if anyone asks, I've never seen the video for "Stacy's Mom."

that's entertainment: paul weller at avalon Last Friday was the third time Id seen Paul Weller in concert. The first time was a thrilling acoustic solo show at the Berklee Performance Center that effectively showcased just how brilliant this man is as a singer, guitarist and songwriter. In February of this year, I saw him with a full band at the Orpheum Theater in a show that was, no exaggeration, one of the finest concerts Ive ever witnessed firsthand. So for this third concert, my expectations were understandably high. This was again an acoustic show, but Weller was joined this time by a second guitarist, Gem Archer (the latest rhythm guitarist to pass through the revolving door that is Oasis). Its still unclear to me what exactly Paul was promoting on this short US tour. In his native England, Paul tours simply because theres air to breathe. Hes such a huge icon over in Europe that he doesnt need a reason to tour. Unfortunately its a different story in the states. Ill spare you my usual rant about how Paul gets no respect on these shores. But on the somewhat rare occasion that he makes it over here, its usually under the auspices of a new album to promote. This time around, my guess is that hes hawking his excellent new box set, Fly on the Wall, a three-disc collection of b-sides and rarities (still only available as an import here, although his US distributor, Yep Roc, insists that will change soon enough). While I doubted that his February performance at the Orpheum could ever be topped, I was excited about the prospect of seeing Paul in a club close-up. My friend Bob and his friend Dave met me outside the Avalon just before seven and we promptly found our place to the right of the stage, right by the bar (a location I would soon take full advantage of by drinking copious amounts of beer). The opening actGod, I hate support acts. I understand that theyre struggling musicians trying to land a big break, butoh hell, never mind. I love them. Whatever. Anywaythis one was actually pretty good. Chris Stills, yep, you guessed itthe son of Stephen Stills. Im not really much of a fan of dear old dad, but this guy was actually quite good. He sounded a lot like Jeff Buckley, playing an acoustic guitar for all songs, except for one song when he sat at the piano (and sounded damn good). Bob, Dave and I spent part of this set wondering who Chris mother was and figured that if Stephen Stills was his father, it could have been anyone (although Joni Mitchell was a reasonable guess). During the break, I checked out the merch booth, and spoke very briefly with a woman I believed to be Pauls sister, Nicky. I know that Nicky runs her brothers website and also deals with merch, and she had a British accent. But I didnt want to say something stupid like, are you Pauls sister because Im sure she gets that all the time. I mentioned the fact that I blew a load of money on the last Weller show (t-shirt, program, key chain for Liza) and that I would just be getting a pin this time. And I did! A cute little Style Council pin that says Our Favourite Shop is now proudly affixed to my man-bag. Paul hit the stage soon afterwards and tore into a lovely b-side called The Loved, followed by the title track to his album Illumination. Gem then joined him, and they played a variety of songs, new (Going Places) and old (Amongst Butterflies), in addition to a smattering of Jam songs that had the crowd roaring (English Rose, Tales from the Riverbank, Thats Entertainment, Town Called Malice). I seem to remember shouting out for Friday Street a few times myself, which may have been the beer talking. A Style Council song (Headstart for Happiness) even made an appearance. Paul even stepped up to the piano for a rendition of You Do Something To Me. I dont know myself what the highlight of the show was. I have to admit that singing quite loudly along with my fellow fans to Thats Entertainment made me very happy. I was also pleased to hear Hes the Keeper, which Id never heard him do live before. Paul plays in New York City tonight (at Town Hall) and tomorrow night (Irving Plaza). If you live down there, do not pass up the opportunity to see him blow the roof off these venues.

handcream for a generation About a year and a half ago, I was e-mailed by a guy who ran a pop culture website called Killer Flamingo. He saw my Amazon.com reviews and asked if I'd be willing to submit some articles for his site. I sent him a review of Mike Keneally's "Wooden Smoke," which was published on the site. Later I sent him reviews of Elvis Costello's "When I Was Cruel" and Cornershop's "Handcream for a Generation," and was working on a review of "In Our Gun" by Gomez when suddenly the site disappeared. E-mails to the site's editors proved fruitless. What started out as a fun little endeavor became a thing of the past. I hate for anything I've written to wither away into nothingness, so here's a look at that Cornershop review that I wrote for Killer Flamingo back in May 2002. Yes, I'm fully aware that this is a lazy thing to do. Deal with it. Its been almost five years since Britains Cornershop released an album, and apparently they havent spent that half-decade dilly-dallying. In addition to band members Tjinder Singh and Ben Ayres releasing an album under the name Clinton, the boys have been busy soaking up sounds and influences that make up their current new release, Handcream for a Generation. There can be no other explanation. Music this wide and varied cant just be thrown together in a week. If Singh, the bands singer/songwriter/de facto leader, formed his own country, Handcream sounds like a flip across Tjinderlands radio band. Cornershop has always been known for genre-hopping. Their last album, the justly praised When I Was Born For the 7th Time, combined lo-fi indie-rock/pop, reggae dub, psychedelia, scratching, a country-flavored duet, and of course, plenty of sitar and tabla. Singhs Indian background has always been a key element of the Cornershop sound. And its not just a gimmick The last album not only pulled off the deliciously trippy, sitar-drenched Were In Yr Corner, but a cover of the Beatles Norwegian Wood that brought the song full circle by translating it into the Punjabi language. The albums single, the endlessly catchy-yet-simple Brimful of Asha, paid tribute to legendary Indian singer Asha Bhosle. This time around, Singhs Ravi Shankar jones is still present, but to a much smaller degree. Sounds Super Recordings and Spectral Mornings are the only overt nods to that genre. The latter is a 14-minute epic featuring Oasis Noel Gallagher (more proof that the Unibrowed One has been doing his more interesting work away from his bratty little brother). Elsewhere, the emphasis on Handcream is fun. This is probably the best white boy party funk Ive heard since Becks Midnite Vultures. Heavy Soup opens things up as a funky faux-concert intro. R&B crooner Otis Clay introduces the band behind a cooking rhythm section interspersed with cheesy canned applause (these guys revel in the lo-fi thing). The next track, Staging the Plaguing of the Raised Platform, is about as blatant a rewrite of Brimful of Asha as you can get, but Singh gets away with ithe charms our socks off with a distorted guitar lick, a kiddie chorus, and keyboard patches that sound like they were lifted off the Cars first album. Lessons Learned from Rocky I to Rocky III is a scathing (and much-deserved) attack on the music business, dressed up as a long-lost Faces or Stones raver, circa 1973. Keith Richards-style rhythm guitar pounds the song home, accompanied by sassy female backing vocals (although I doubt Mick or Rod would be caught dead singing the line Miami Beach/chicks with dicks). The album veers from experimental (The London Radar) to relaxed, De La Soul-style hip-hop (Wogs Will Walk), all the while keeping the old-school retro vibe alive (the wonderful Slip the Drummer One sounds like it was recorded immediately after the band discovered the invention of the Vocoder). While its a fun album that I cant picture anyone disliking, I doubt Handcream for a Generation will widen Cornershops fan base. Which suits me just fine. Wildly popular bands play arenas, and these guys are the perfect club act. Lean back your head, close your eyes, listen to the scratching and the sitars and shake your ass.

fun with disposable income To paraphrase Salt'n'Pepa, "here I go, here I go, here I go again -- girls, what's my weakness: CDs and DVDs!" A harmless visit to urlLink Newbury Comics on Wednesday yielded a disc I've been awaiting for weeks now: the latest single from the Beautiful South, urlLink "Just a Few Things That I Ain't." The single is from their long-awaited forthcoming album, "Gaze," slated for a November release. I doubt it'll be released stateside anytime soon, which means I'll have to pay an inflated import price, but hey -- this is the Beautiful South we're talking about. I won't mind. I've been a TBS fan since 1990 when their first album was released, and they make me very happy indeed. Their sound is hard to describe. Sort of early Elton John Meets Squeeze, with a touch of Morrissey. The band consists of three lead singers, and one of them -- Paul Heaton -- co-writes all the songs with guitarist Dave Rotheray. One of the other singers is always female. I say "always" because as of right now, TBS in on their third female singer. The first one, Briana Corrigan, apparently quit after finding Paul's lyrics to the song "Mini-Correct" a tad disturbing. While it's true that their is an occasional sexist thread in their always-clever (and infinitely British) words, the band's songs that are in that vein are usually told from a point of view of a complete tool (like Randy Newman's). But she hit the road, replaced by the earthy voice of Jacqueline Abbott. Jackie was a fine singer (she lent her voice to some of the band's most memorable covers, including "Everybody's Talkin'" and "Dream a Little Dream of Me"), but she had enough of the band smack dab of the middle of their 2000 US tour. As a matter of fact, she quit about two days before the band's arrival in Boston, at a show Liza and I attended. The band actually made the most of her absence, by employing third singer Dave Hemingway to take her vocal parts in the duets, giving the songs an interesting "gay" edge that wasn't there before. After a notable absence, TBS has reformed, with Alison Wheeler taking over the latest vacant vocal slot (Liza and I joked that she herself should have auditioned for the band, being a singer herself. Pity that never happened). The first single is incredibly infectious, a bouncy number with typically self-deprecating lyrics ("trendsetter, go-getter, international jet-setter, just a few things that I ain't") that even manages to get in a well-deserved dig at Bono and Sting. I was a bit disappointed last night, however, while playing the song at Borders last night, when a co-worker (Brian C, the bitter aging drama queen-- if you ever meet him, ask him how his dissertation is going and watch the rage ensue) pointed out to me that the piano riff is a blatant rip-off of the mid-60s hit "Cool Jerk." But I still like it. I also picked up "Confessions of a Pop Group," the final album from Paul Weller's often-misunderstood 80s band, urlLink The Style Council. Weller raised an awful lot of eyebrows when he broke up the seminal 70s punk/mod band the Jam to focus on more jazz and soul-influenced sounds with this new band, which mainly consisted of he and keyboard player Mick Talbot. They released some excellent singles ("My Ever Changing Moods," "Long Hot Summer," "Speak Like a Child," among others), but it always seemed as if their grasp extended their reach. By employing too many different sounds and tackling way too many social topics in their lyrics, the band sounded unfocused. Nowadays, it doesn't help that their obsession with fashion and capturing the right sound for the right moment makes them sound horribly dated. Still, I enjoy enough of their songs to buy the albums...although this most recent purchase is testing my loyalty. While their are some wonderful, piano-focused ballads ("A Very Deep Sea," "Confessions, 1, 2, 3"), there's also an awful lot of embarrassing synth-dominated dance music ("Iwasadoledadstoyboy," the title track). Maybe it'll grow on me. I also succumbed to media hype last night and bought the DVD of the British TV sensation, urlLink "The Office." The show, which chronicles the day-to-day goings-on of, you guessed it, a British office, is a smash hit in its native country and is starting to cause a sensation on these shores (presumably due to its appearance on BBC America -- I don't watch that channel due to its overdependence on crappy reality shows, which are apparently an international phenomenon). I watched the first three episodes last night and it's indeed a scream. The office's boss, David Brent (played by Ricky Gervais, the show's co-creator) is the ultimate asshole boss, but what's really excruciating about him is that he thinks he's funny when he's pathetically not. His attempts at humor almost always fall flat. He tries to be "one of the guys" by throwing out blatantly sexist jokes, and when they don't go over, he backtracks by saying that he despises sexism. Other characters include Gareth, the high-maintenance creep who calls himself Assistant Regional Manager when he's actually Assistant to the Regional Manager (an important distinction). Gareth wears his cell phone in a holster, like a detective wears his gun. It's sad. There's also the receptionist, Dawn, who's engaged to a guy who works in the warehouse but isn't above flirting with Gareth's nemesis, Tim. And so on. The show is shot almost documentary-style (DVD Journal points out quite accurately that it's "as if Christopher Guest directed 'Office Space'") and appears to be somewhat improvisational. See this show. If you've ever worked in an office environment, I guarantee you'll find yourself nodding in agreement at the bureacracy and the constant presence of pathetic goon co-workers. That is, when you're not peeing your pants with laughter. Of course, it's just a matter of time before the US attempts to create an "Office" of its own. Which will, of course, fall flat on its face.

all the world is football shaped, it's just for me to kick in space I don't really know a whole lot about Mandy Moore, except for the fact that she's a pop singer and that my ten-year-old daughter likes her. I don't think I would ever buy any of her albums, but if I was forced to, I suppose that I could deal with her latest album, urlLink "Coverage." Why? Well, it's an all-covers album, and Mandy (or her producers) happen to have damn good taste in music. The album's first song is a cover of...wait for it..."Senses Working Overtime," an excellent song by an excellent band, XTC, who would fit comfortably in my list of Top Ten Amazing Musical Artists. If such a list existed. That's not all. She also covers Joe Jackson's gorgeous "Breaking Us In Two," Todd Rundgren's "Can We Still Be Friends," plus songs by the Waterboys, John Hiatt, Joan Armatrading and even some old-school Elton John (when he was still relevant). Call me crazy, but there's something oddly comforting about the possibility of young female teenybopper fans singing urlLink Andy Partridge's lyrics.

my weekend at the movies Another weekend with Liza in Europe, another weekend by myself at the movies. There's actually some good points in seeing a flick solo. I don't have to share my snacks with anyone. I don't have to struggle to find two seats right next to each other when one will do fine. Also, nobody seems to mind when I insist on getting to the theater unbelievably early (sorry, it's just a thing I have). So anyway, me, myself and I decided to hit the theater early Saturday evening after watching my brand-new DVD of urlLink "Prime Suspect" (Helen Mirren kicks ass six ways to Sunday, lads) and poring over my delectable new urlLink book about Tintin. I didn't know what I was going to see or where I was going to see it. I just hopped on the subway and hoped for the best. I got off at Kendall Square and headed to the oh-so-snooty Landmark Theater in hopes of seeing a good indie flick. The only one there that really caught my eye was urlLink "Wonderland," which wasn't playing for about two hours. Since there's really nothing to do in Kendall Square but go to the movies and admire giant, personality-free biotech buildings, I headed to Harvard Square, where urlLink "Intolerable Cruelty" was playing...again, not for another hour or two. Up to this point, I'm in total denial about refusing to consult a newspaper. It's the cinematic equivalent of the sterotypical guy who won't ask for directions. So I grab one of those ridiculous free Metro papers ("news in McNugget-size bites," snarks the Boston Globe) and see that "Intolerable Cruelty" is playing in about a half-hour at the Loews Boston Common. Leaping onto the subway like Gene Hackman in "The French Connection," I get to the theater in time to see that "Intolerable Cruelty" is sold out. Someone's got it in for me. Long story short: I sprint over to Lowes Copley Square in time to catch "Wonderland." How was it? Well, I enjoyed it. Val Kilmer really impressed me with his portrayal of John "Johnny Wadd" Holmes, the drug addict porn star with the enormous appendage. The film centers around the 1981 murders of Holmes' drug dealer pals, which he was suspected to be involved in. It's brutal, funny, intense, and has a great soundtrack. Oh, and Lisa Kudrow is in it and doesn't play an airhead. Sunday saw me finally getting to see "Intolerable Cruelty." There's nothing like going to the movies on a rainy Sunday afternoon, let me tell ya. Loews Boston Common was filled to the brim, presumably with Coen Brothers fans such as myself, waiting to see what the inimitable Minnesota filmmaking duo would do with a romantic comedy. "Intolerable Cruelty" was a fitting description of what I wanted to inflict on a few moronic audience members. The viewing experience was somewhat ruined by a small gang of pre-teens who were obviously on their last leg of an afternoon-long theater-hop. They laughed exaggeratingly loud at all the humorous lines, talked liberally throughout the film and inserted moronic comments (George Clooney: "I have something to tell you." Idiotic pre-teen: "I'm gay! Haw haw haw haw!"). Folks, it's only funny if the movie is bad and you have the intellect of a Mystery Science Theater cast member. Otherwise, shut the hell up. Why do people do this? I understand that they're just kids, but can't they get it through their puberty-filled skulls that lots of people paid good money to sit in a theater and not be distracted by nitwits? Good movie nonetheless. A bit sappy towards the end, but the cast was great and even though he's often thought of as a pretty boy, dammit if George Clooney isn't one hell of an actor.

grudges are overrated Oh, I just can't help it. urlLink Sarah's blog makes me laugh. I drop-kicked her link a couple of months ago after something she said rubbed me the wrong way. What a cranky thing to do. Sorry about that. Think of this as my olive branch and my way of turning the blogging community into a gag-inducing, Hands-Across-America lovefest. Belch.

at the show Concerts, concerts, concerts. I've got a whole heap of 'em to attend in the coming weeks. Of course there's the highly anticipated urlLink Paul Weller show at Avalon next Friday. I'm sure that most people who know me or read my blog wish I would just shut my yap about Weller, but what you should really do is redirect that energy toward purchasing the man's music. He truly is an amazingly talented singer/songwriter/musician. Really. Buy urlLink "Wild Wood" or maybe urlLink "Modern Classics" if you don't believe me. Paul always puts on a fantastic show, too. The guy seems to tour constantly (like Bob Dylan) and this time, he's in the middle of an acoustic tour of the States. I'll be there, along with my sister Julie (a recently converted Weller fan) and my friend Bob. Avalon. October 24. Check it out. Hey, it's not like you have a Red Sox game to go to or anything (sorry -- had to get that one out. It sucks that they lost, but they lost, so let's move on, shall we?). November 5 is the date that urlLink Bill Bruford blows everyone's collective musical minds at Scullers. Bruford is a drummer who started out in the prog community as a drummer for Yes during their early years, then went on to play for King Crimson during their exciting, noisy mid-seventies era (including the amazing "Red" album) as well as their sporadic Adrian Belew-driven 80s and 90s incarnations. Although he made his initial big bucks playing rock music, he's first and foremost a jazz drummer, which is even evident on his rock recordings. He's sort of a prog version of Stewart Copeland. He was also my primary inspiration for learning to play the drums at the tender age of ten. Anyway, Bill and his jazz band, Earthworks, will be at Scullers and so will Bob and I. Fun! Oh, and if you want to hear Bruford at the peak of his powers, check out his excellent 1979 solo album urlLink "One of a Kind." Speaking of urlLink King Crimson, I'll be correcting an error I made back in March of not seeing them by, you guessed it, seeing them on November 12 (also at Avalon). Although my interest in prog rock dates back to my grade school days, I've only recently discovered this fascinating band and am excited to catch them. Their opening act is no slouch, either. The gloriously re-formed urlLink Living Colour is opening. I hear they do a fierce version of AC/DC's "Back in Black." The only downside is that I'll be going solo. I can't find anyone else to go to this show. That's okay. It's not like I'll be able to talk to them over Corey Glover's screaming.

confessions of a slacker Okay, well, first of allsorry for the lack of activity round these parts. My video game nostalgia trip took a lot out of me, and I was so proud of it that I rather enjoyed having it at the top of the blog. Thus, I spent the last week resting on my blog laurels. So sue me. But seriously, Ive missed blogging and am going to gently ease back into it. Id like to remind you first of all that urlLink Bryan Beller is releasing his first solo album, View, on October 28, but pre-orders are being accepted on Bryans site until this Saturday. So whip out that credit card and point your browsers accordingly. Who is Bryan Beller, you ask? You should be reading this site more often Lots of music and video purchases recently. Besides my recent obsessions with urlLink Randy Newman and urlLink The Promise Ring (wouldnt that make an interesting double-bill), I impulsively snagged a budget-priced Boomtown Rats compilation disc. The disc, entitled urlLink "Great Songs of Indifference," is actually a mix of Rats songs and selections from Rats leader Geldofs spotty solo career. This annoys me because I was never crazy about Geldofs solo stuff and theres plenty of Rats stuff to fill several discs, let alone one. Admittedly, Im finding myself skipping the lesser-known tracks in favor of the ones I used to see on MTV back in the day: the mind-bogglingly infectious, horn-driven reggae of House on Fire, the scathingly political-yet-soothing Banana Republic, and of course, the ubiquitous I Dont Like Mondays. Im disappointed, however, at the absence of Up All Night, a creepy little number that was all over MTV in the early eighties (speaking of creepy the video featured a shirtless Geldof cavorting with a python). I also immersed myself deeper into the strange, dissonant world of French composer Olivier Messiaen and purchased a CD of his organ work urlLink Meditations Sur le Mystere de la Sainte Trinite. Those of you who dont know Messiaen, he was a 20th century French composer (1908-1992) who created dissonant, groundbreaking works not unlike Edgard Varese and Anton Webern. Lots of noise. Very atonal. Sounds lovely, doesnt it? The interesting thing about Messiaen is that almost all of his works were deeply rooted in his profound belief in God. People like Bach used to create works of choral harmony and chromatic symmetry to express their religious beliefs; Messiaen barreled along with little disregard for structure or key. And I love it. The organ stuff is a bit harder to take than my favorite work of his, the two-hour piano opus urlLink "Vingt Regards Sur L'Enfant Jesus," but its still a thrilling ride. A couple of music DVDs have been making me pretty happy lately. Paul Wellers urlLink "Live at Breaehead" was released a couple of weeks ago its not that much different than the July 2002 London show captured on the Two Classic Performances DVD, but is still a worthy addition to any Weller fans DVD library. Paul and his band are in particularly good form and they break into some great Jam songs (Pretty Green, Man in the Corner Shop and Town Called Malice), in addition to a few Style Council numbers as well (Down in the Seine, Man of Great Promise). I also picked up the recently released special edition DVD of urlLink "The Kids are Alright," an amazing documentary of the Who, originally released in 1979. If youre a fan, youll be in heaven. Tons, and I mean tons, of concert and TV footage, performances, interviews, etc. Theres the classic Smothers Brothers TV show segment where an explosion in Keith Moons drum kit sets Pete Townshends hair on fire (and seriously damages his hearing), footage from Woodstock, recording sessions for Who are You and lots more. Plus a plethora of extras. If youre a fan of the films of Luis Bunuel, thenwellyoure one seriously twisted individual. No, really, Im starting to get into his films, and I bought the urlLink Criterion Collection's reissue of The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie about a year ago. Its a terrific film, a surrealistic milestone and winner of the Best Foreign Film Oscar for 1972. The movie consists of a group of well-to-do friends who keep meeting for dinner and always have their plans thwarted for one reason or another. Did I mention Bunuel was strange? His last film, 1977s That Obscure Object of Desire, was also released through Criterion, and I finally bought it the other day. Fernando Rey (who is probably best-known as Charnier, a.k.a. Frog One in The French Connection) stars as a successful French businessman and widower who begins a relationship with a beautiful woman who constantly rebuffs his desires. The woman is played by two different actresses, for reasons that have never really been explained. My snooty quota is all set for a while. forgive the overwhelming rush of nostalgia George Plimpton made me think about video games this afternoon. Really. I know it sounds strange, but it actually makes sense, if you follow the twisted corollary that is my existence. I was reading an article about the recently-deceased Plimpton, which was actually written by a sports writer, who tracked the writers early exploits in boxing, football, baseball and other sports. He then went on to document his affiliation with the Paris Review, his books, film appearances, etc. Then I remembered the first time I had ever heard of Plimpton. In the early eighties, he made a series of television commercials for Intellivision, a home video game system manufactured by Mattel. I grew up in the advent of the video game age. It seems as if, growing up, new games and systems were popping up all the time. When I was a grade school kid living in Paris, I remember those cool Mattel handheld electronic football games (lovingly discussed on VH1s I Love the 70s). I think it was Christmas 1978 when any kid who was anyone got one in their stocking. Those little red blips on the screen, the tiny buttons that moved you around the field and caused premature arthritis (but the painso sweet), the little bleating whistle noises, and of coursethe charge anthem that came out of the tiny speaker whenever a touchdown was scored. Ah, bliss. It was around this time that I encountered my very first TV video game system. No, it wasnt Atarithis was the stark, black-and-white prototype known the world over as Pong. We didnt have it in our house, but our friends the Richards (whose dad worked with my dad) had one, and it was amazing. You have a controller that actuallymoves a little disc up and down to block the little pong dot from scoring a goal. Forget curing cancer, putting men in space, or feeding the worlds starving childrencheck out Pong! This, my friends, was a scientific advance. Well, Im afraid that even Pong got old. When I got back to the States in 1979, it was only a matter of time before TV video game consoles not to mention the arcade games were being made better, sleeker, and with more intense graphics (relatively speaking, of course). My sister Julie got a job at the Holiday Inn in our hometown of Nashua, New Hampshire, and the lobby area not only included a Star Trek pinball machine (this was a classy joint, mind you), but also a wondrous behemoth known as Asteroids. My most vivid memories of the summer of 1980 include the times my brother Gary and I spent freeloading off my sisters hotel job by hanging out at the swimming pool. Sometimes Julie would even join us on her days off, often bringing her little Sanyo boom box, tuned, of course, to a classic rock radio station (I seem to remember hearing a lot of Bob Seger back then). As fun as the pool was, it was actually rather pale in comparison to the fun my chlorine-soaked brother and I had as we careened back into the hotel lobby to dutifully pump quarters into our Beloved Asteroid Machine. Usually it was Gary who did the playing since I rather sucked at this particular game. Garys spaceship would speed through outer space, smashing to bits these enormous transparent space-rocks. It was quite the time. My cousin Stephen was having the same kind of fun, but didnt even have to leave his house, the bastard. First, his dad (my Uncle Jack) was computer-savvy enough at the time to purchase an Apple 2e home computer. Thats right, a home computer. The jealousy seeping through my veins was greener than the little plastic bucket of Slime my mother finally made me throw away. Stephen had two actual games on this computer a primitive, text-heavy football game, and an Olympic Decathlon game (the javelin throw was a real bitch, I remember). Soon Stephen moved on to bigger and better things with the arrival of the Magnavox Odyssey2. The first Odyssey system, developed in the early seventies, was the genesis for those early Pong games, and now the new model was a quantum leap in graphics and game variety (again, relatively speaking). Odyssey2 not only had the requisite sports games (Intellivisions specialty), but also featured sci-fi and action puzzlers like Take the Money and Run! Crypto-Logic! and War of Nerves! Apparently, exclamation points were a vital retail strategy. The Odyssey2 was indeed impressive, but it was around this time that the more-popular Atari began popping in every other American household. Atari, now immortalized in self-consciously retro-ironic t-shirts at your local Urban Outfitters, developed a system that didnt necessarily break new video ground, but was massively popular. Call it Video Games For the Masses. I didnt own an Atari, but I knew a lot of people who did. In 1982 and 1983, my neighbors, the McFaddens, had an Atari. Around this time, puberty was kicking my ass and I knew enough about inter-gender desire to con Alicia McFadden into let me come over to play Pitfall. It turns out her younger brother played it a lot more than she, so he and I played while Alicia and Paula Davis stared out the window at the object of their affection, my older brother. My best friend in eighth grade, Jeff Kudalis, owned an Atari and we spent countless hours playing Berserk and Wizard of Wor when we really should have been doing homework. Jeff and I were truly partners in video game crime. On the way home from school, he and I would hit the World of Games on Main Street and play all our favorites. WOG wasnt a huge arcade, but had all the essentials: Centipede, Turbo, Missile Command, Joust, Galaga, Dig Dug, Defender (my brothers personal favorite)World of Games was able to satiate our video game needs. The game I ruled over with an iron fist was most definitely Tempest. I could play that game until my fingers bled. Ill never forget one afternoon when the machine, through some inexplicable computer glitch, suddenly issued me 50 credits for no reason. It was one of the greatest afternoons of my life. If we wanted a bigger selection, wed have to go to the other side of town. Fun World was known for two things: a killer go-cart track and an adjacent two-story video arcade. Fun World was one of the only places where I ever saw Speed Freak, a car-race video game that included terrified stick-figures on the sidewalk that always had me in tears. Once I moved to Orlando in 1983, my interest in the games began to wear off, but only slightly. There was an arcade on International Drive called Castle somethingCastle Games, the Castle, I dont rememberthe building was designed to look like a castle, but of course, looked cheesy and fake and touristy like everything else on that God-forsaken street. Anyway, the two games I loved in this pseudo-medieval building were Star Wars and Pole Position. I was a mild Star Wars freak and was glad they finally made a video game out of it, I always loved car race games, and both games had excellent graphics. It was soon after this that my sister and her husband had mysteriously acquired an arcade game of their own. In their basement, they installed a Donkey Kong game in the sit-down model (you know, like the ones they had in Pizza Hut). Then they got a Nintendo. This, of course, made the Atari look like the graphic equivalent of writing down the action on a pad of paper. I was growing sadmy primitive graphics days were becoming a thing of the past and I was having trouble catching up. I think my last gasp of video game action occurred in 1989 when I was overseas in the military and my girlfriends family sent her a Gameboy. It included two cartridges: Super Mario Brothers and Tetris. Tetris, as most of you may know, is about three times more addictive than crack cocaine (but cheaper). There were more than a few times when insomnia would hit me and I would get out of bed, quietly grab the Tetris off the nightstand and sit in the bathroom playing for at least an hour. Girlfriends, bills, paychecks, shaving, not having mom make you breakfast anymorethese things will replace everything eventually, but a video game will always lobotomize you for as long as youll let it.

I am so filled with just one girl Why Im just now discovering and digging into the catalog of a semi-famous band that was only around from 1995 to 2002 is beyond me, but Milwaukees urlLink Promise Ring is kicking my ass and Im loving it. About 18 months ago, I bought the bands 1999 album Very Emergency. I heard a lot about these guys, mainly that they fit the emo description, which can be either a curse or a blessing. I despise labels, but I think what appeals to me (tangentially, anyway) about the whole emo thing is that it seems to be a continuation of a lot of bands that I loved in the late eighties (particularly the Smiths). The emo sound is heavily rooted in emotional vocals, normally evolving into self-pity, while the band hammers away. While many emo bands have been plying their trade over the past several years and accumulating a small yet rabid following, a few of them manage to get some national attention and appear either on the verge of superstardom or perhaps smack-dab in the middle of it. Im no expert, but I would think that Weezer is a good example of a band with emo stylings that, through some freak of nature, became huge. While emo may not always embrace catchy hooks and singalong choruses, these Promise Ring guys tend to revel in it at least, on the albums that Im familiar with. Very Emergency is an album that I loved when I first heard it. Then I put it away, rediscovered it about six months laterand repeated this cycle until last week when, for reasons not quite clear to me, I obsessed over it. The album starts off with little fanfare. Davey Von Bohlens voice kicks things off with the line I got my body and my mind on the same page, and honey now, happiness is all the rage. The song, Happiness is all the Rage, celebrates the joys of staying indoors all day with someone you love. We could do more outdoor things, Davey opines, if we werent so busy getting busy. Amen. Love and emotion seem to be the common themes in the lyrics, while the band chugs away with crunchy guitars and boisterous drumming. One of the albums most manic tunes, Happy Hour, is centered around the simple chorus Where are we living now, which ends up sounding more like a celebration than a confused query. The last minute of that song is probably the high point of the entire album for me. Just try to listen to it while sitting still. One of the slower songs, Jersey Shore, is an affectionate tribute to getting older and moving on. The lyrics are uncharacteristically straightforward but no less poignant: Bored walking on the boardwalk, New Jersey shore / If I come to New York, can I sleep on your floor? Living out of a suitcase on the motel floor / and running up tabs at the corner store. After spending much time immersed in this amazing album, many online reviewers informed me that their earlier stuff is more adventurous. My curiosity piqued, I grabbed a copy of Nothing Feels Good, a 1997 release. Like Very Emergency, this earlier album is still fast, intense, and catchy as hell, but a bit more inscrutable and idiosyncratic. Especially the lyrics. It seems to me that the lyrics were probably not written with any narrative objective in mind. Its almost as if Davey likes the way the particular words sound and seems to find joy in repeating them over and over. Why else would he choose to sing Delaware, are you aware of Air Supply and Television, over and over and over (in the song "Is This Thing On?")? Perfect Lines, probably my favorite song on the album (so far), confuses the hell out of everyone concerned with the interminably repeated line Lets talk about the sound of the phone outside of Texaco / from Bell South down to a Southern Belle. I dont know what it means, but I sure love it. The band is an intense combination of guitar, bass and drums, who dont necessarily do anything groundbreaking, but seem to ooze energy with their lightning pace. When the band chooses to slow things down, like on the nostalgic Red and Blue Jeans, they give Van Bohlen plenty of room to say whats on his mind, as in the memorable line, Nothing feels good like you in red and blue jeans and your white and night things. So, yeah, buy these albums. If the idea of a more introverted combination of the Pixies and Weezer appeals to you, youll be in heaven. And if anyone can clue me in as to what the rest of the Promise Rings albums sound like, Id love to hear it.

randy takes on the south I mentioned the other day that I was beginnig to develop an appreciation for the music of Randy Newman. I acted on that appreciation last night and picked up the deluxe two-disc reissue of his classic 1974 album urlLink "Good Old Boys." I was originally going to get urlLink "Sail Away," but I couldn't find it, even though my store's inventory computer says we have it (not that the computer is ever right). So far I've listened to the entire first disc of "Good Old Boys" and I like it a lot. There's something about Randy's early work, the string arrangements, that George Gershwin-meets-Lyle Lovett rolling piano, whatever it is, something really gets me about the songs and how they're arranged. Anyway, "Good Old Boys" is basically a concept album (or is it a "song cycle?" What's the difference? Does anyone know?) about the Deep South, examining the prejudices and personalities of that unique part of the country. Of course, the album's first song, and perhaps the most infamous, is "Rednecks," which probably wouldn't be so notorious if it wasn't for Randy's liberal sprinkling of the "N" word all over the song. Obviously, he's singing the song from the point of view of an ignorant, bigoted Southerner, but that argument still won't get the song played on the radio. The album also includes the marvelous "Louisiana 1927," which is currently my favorite song of his. The second disc of this "deluxe edition" consists of piano-and-vocal demos of "Johnny Cutler's Birthday," which was the original "rough draft" behind what would become "Good Old Boys." I haven't heard it yet, so I can't comment. But I imagine I won't be disappointed.

infidels My discovery of Bob Dylans music occurred in 1984 at age 15. Oh sure, Id heard of the guy before that, but wasnt really that familiar with his music. Rolling Stone magazine published a urlLink revealing interview with the legendary singer/songwriter. What started as a mild curiosity developed into a fascinating read and I was determined to find out more about his music. Its safe to say that the years 1984 through 1986 were Dylan-obsessive for me and I consider myself a huge fan to this day. Revealing interview is a relative term with Dylan. The notoriously mercurial and publicity-shy king of folk-rock declared much of his private life off-limits in this Q&A with Kurt Loder, and he dodged specific questions about his recent born-again Christian phase, which he claimed had been misrepresented in the media. He was being interviewed to promote his latest album, Infidels. This album was probably going to be a pivotal one for Bob, since his last three Slow Train Coming, Saved and Shot of Love -- had not done well commercially or critically, and the religious bent of this trilogy resulted in lots of head-scratching from fans. Even the secular album that preceded those three (Street Legal) was considered a stiff. Infidels went a long way in restoring the publics faith in Dylan it sold respectably and is considered to be one of his best albums of the eighties. Unfortunately, Bob foisted a lot of crap on us in that decade does anyone but hard-core completists actually own Down in the Groove, Knocked Out Loaded or Empire Burlesque? Still, this album tends to get knocked out of the way when people list classic Dylan albums. It doesnt help that for the longest time, Columbia wasnt doing much in the way of remastering and reissuing the Dylan catalog, which has been available for the most part on CD, albeit in ones of inferior quality. Sony has seen the error of these ways and last month began reissuing Bobs catalog on CD/SACD hybrids (playable in standard CD players), starting with 15 classic titles, all with original album design in the Digipak format. Ive been fiscally foolish enough to buy seven of them already, but who needs groceries when youve got Blonde on Blonde, anyway? One of the other reissues I picked up was, of course, Infidels. Its a sentimental favorite, sure, but its also a great album no matter where or when I first heard it. Since my original purchase back in 1984 was a (dont laugh) cassette copy that had worn out years ago, I was excited to hear it with fresh ears. It still holds up. In fact, I probably like it even more. Infidels is great in an uncomplicated way: great songs and great performances. Bob enlisted the help of Dire Straits frontman Mark Knopfler to handle production duties, as well as add his distinctive brand of lead guitar. The musicians consist of Straits keyboard player Alan Clark, former Rolling Stones guitarist Mick Taylor, and the legendary reggae rhythm section of Sly Dunbar and Robbie Shakespeare (which is odd, since the album doesnt really have any reggae flavored songs but they still sound great). Since its 1983, it would be understandable to hear a little overblown production, and there are faint echoes of that here a big, echoey drum sound is as bad as it gets. But the sound overall is one of relaxed confidence. Knopflers guitar playing is a comforting, familiar sound, and the playing is expert throughout and a great companion to the songwriting. Apart from the spiritually-themed Man of Peace, Dylans subject matter seems to move away at this point from Christianity on to the familiar subject of romance, coupled with a rather bitter anger toward the general evil of the world. Not many are spared in the indictments. Hes apparently not too thrilled about the space program (in License to Kill, he sings man has invented his doom / first step was touching the moon), mistrusts both capitalism and labor unions (Union Sundown), and has some pretty strong opinions about Israel and Palestine (the apparent subject of Neighborhood Bully, according to countless critics and newsgroups). Dylan was going to call the album Surviving in a Ruthless World, until someone pointed out to him that his last four albums all began with the letter S. So I said, Well, I don't wanna get bogged down in the letter s." Dylan said in the Rolling Stone interview. And then Infidels came into my head one day. I don't know what it means, or anything. It turns out that Infidels is probably one of the more fitting names he could have come up with for this album. Dylan certainly does his share of finger-pointing at politicians and heathens while pining for a more innocent time, which is why his romantic side sounds particularly enticing on tracks like the lovely Sweetheart Like You and the albums closer, Dont Fall Apart on Me Tonight. The albums high point, for me, is probably the opening track, Jokerman. Against a rolling mid-tempo, organ-fueled soundscape, Dylan unfolds an ambitious, wordy, literate set of lyrics. It starts out: Standing on the waters casting your bread While the eyes of the idol with the iron head are glowing. Distant ships sailing into the mist, You were born with a snake in both of your fists while a hurricane was blowing. Later on, the lyrics get even heavier: It's a shadowy world, skies are slippery gray, A woman just gave birth to a prince today and dressed him in scarlet. He'll put the priest in his pocket, put the blade to the heat, Take the motherless children off the street And place them at the feet of a harlot. This is an epic, on par with Dylans classic Idiot Wind, and perhaps some of the best lyrics hes penned since the mid-seventies. Although, for the life of me, Im not really sure what hes talking about.
