gazing at island queens An innocent diversion into urlLink Newbury Comics last night ended up costing me about 68 bucks, but I'm three CDs happier now. Have I mentioned that my CD purchase rate has skyrocketed lately? Perhaps it's due to the fact that my girlfriend is in Europe for three months and therefore I have no life. Beefing up my already overflowing music collection is my way of coping. Yeah, that's it. It may seem odd that I frequent this store, since I work part-time at urlLink one of their competitors, but the fact is that Newbury Comics has a few things on Borders. First of all, they have a nice used selection. I've bought used CDs there simply to save money and have yet to encounter a defective disc (knock on wood). Also, they have an impressive selection of import discs (perfect for a guy like me who enjoys a lot of artists who rarely release anything stateside). They also have various bric-a-brac like buttons, games, comics (hence the name), Reservoir Dogs action figures, t-shirts, etc. (I'm not sure if that's the correct usage of the word "bric-a-brac," but I like the fact that I've used that in a post. So there.) It works the other way around, too. Borders, of course, stocks books (a veritable shitload). We also have much greater jazz and classical sections (Newbury's classical selection is, quite frankly, pathetic, but then again, that's not their target audience). The bottom line is, Newbury Comics often stocks things I can't get anywhere else. If that makes me a "retail traitor," so be it. So last night I'm wandering down Newbury Street on my way home from work when I realize that the new urlLink Beautiful South album, "Gaze," was probably released recently. Having been a fan practically since the band's inception more than a dozen years ago, and knowing full well that this new release may never see an official stateside distribution, I headed into Newbury Comics to see if they could relieve my wallet of some import-priced dollars. Ta-da! There it was. Thirty bucks? Not exactly a bargain, but eh...what are you gonna do. Not happy to just take what I came for and leave, I began browsing. Keep in mind that Chris browsing in CD stores can outlast the Mesozoic Era, but I was determined to wrap this up quickly. Besides, I was highly anticipating plopping that new Beautiful South disc in my Walkman as soon as possible. I came across two other discs worthy of my attention. The first was an American reissue of Queen's second album, urlLink "Queen II." Now I've been a Queen fan almost as long as I've been listening to music. My older siblings listened to it constantly when we were growing up. They all passed on "Queen II" (perhaps due to some less-than-favorable reviews), so at the age of ten -- September 1979, I remember it like it was yesterday -- "Queen II" became the first record I ever bought. I enjoyed it thoroughly, and even though it had a somewhat juvenile, prog-rock Dungeons and Dragons feel to it, it was mine. You could say I've developed a sentimental attachment to it over the years. A couple of years ago, I bought a used British reissue CD of this album, which I enjoyed, despite the fact that the sound quality left a lot to be desired, particularly the dull, muffled drum sounds (it sounded like the drum kit was covered in damp towels). Since I've developed a whole new appreciation for this album, I've been halfheartedly on the lookout for the superior US reissue (released, like the rest of their stellar 70s catalog, on Hollywood Records). Last night I broke down and picked it up. In addition to a clearer sound and liner notes, there are also -- like the other Hollywood reissues -- a few bonus tracks. There's a rather limp remix of "Ogre Battle" as well as a campy-but-enjoyable dance remix of "Seven Seas of Rhye" and a rather forgettable bluesy b-side called "See What a Fool I've Been." A couple interesting highlights of the album: "March of the Black Queen," which seems like an early blueprint of "Bohemian Rhapsody;" the lovely, melodic pop of "Funny How Love Is," which is fueled by a terrific Phil Spector-ish Wall-of-Sound production; and one of guitarist Brian May's most underrated songs, the epic "Father to Son." In fact, I think the only song I outright dislike is the overly busy, Renaissance Fair-obsessed "Fairy Feller's Master-Stroke." Even the title makes me ill. I also finally updated a cassette -- a dubbed cassette, for crying out loud -- of a Grace Jones compilation called urlLink "Island Life." In 1990, a flamboyantly gay African-American friend of mine named Davien lent me a cassette of this album, which I promptly dubbed. I was initially interested because Roman Polanski's excellent thriller urlLink "Frantic" prominently featured Grace's song "Libertango (I've Seen That Face Before)" and I loved it (I also like her version of the Police's "Demolition Man," but it's unfortunately not included in this compilation). Why I waited thirteen years to upgrade this to CD I'll never know. The disc is basically highlights of her tenure with Island Records (hence the title, duh) and includes a delightful tropical take on Edith Piaf's "La Vie En Rose," in addition to a couple forgettable paint-by-numbers disco songs ("Do or Die," "I Need a Man"), some excellent covers (the Pretenders' "Private Life," Roxy Music's "Love is the Drug"). Almost every song is completely enjoyable and I love it. This is actually an import version, titled "Island Life 2," which includes a couple of remixes that I haven't heard yet. I've yet to be disappointed by a Beautiful South album, and urlLink "Gaze" is certainly no exception. Granted, they're certainly not breaking any new ground here, and their last album (2000's "Painting it Red") was slightly more ambitious (and longer), but this is exactly the kind of album you'd expect from the Beautiful South. All the right components are in check: witty, caustic lyrics, sweet voices and a musical style that manages to balance the contemporary and the classic. The main change in the band this time around is the addition of a new female singer. The band has an interesting configuration: one guitarist, one bass player, one drummer and three lead singers (one female and two male). The first two female singers -- Brianna Corrigan and Jacqueline Abbott -- quit in 1992 and 2000, respectively (female singers in this band are not unlike Spinal Tap drummers). The latest woman to join the band is Alison Wheeler, and although this sounds like a lazy analogy, she sounds like a perfect combination of the first two. Common lyrical themes with the Beautiful South are alcohol, self-deprecation, and how men are such assholes. In fact, a song on the new album, "The Gates," encapsulates their feelings on the latter subject quite nicely: A woman goes to heaven, it's not important when, As soon as she arrives, God has to send her down again. "You've got an extra five years to clean up after men." "I mean no disrespect, God...but you'd better make it ten." Sometimes -- as they have in the past -- the band's lyrics (written by vocalist Paul Heaton) tend to stumble in an attempt to cram as much verbosity into a song. Case in point on "Gaze" is a song called "101 Percent Man," which is apparently about homophobia, but the references and analogies are so overreaching you can't tell the point they're trying to make. Still, I'll take it over Britney's lyrics any day. For more samplings of the band's lyrical witticisms through the years, go urlLink here.

interesting power-pop fact I just found out this morning that urlLink Andy Partridge and urlLink Marshall Crenshaw were both born on the exact same day (November 11, 1953). Pretty unusual, especially when you consider that a lot of their songwriting is cut from the same cloth. Partridge is, of course, the principle singer/songwriter behind XTC, those masters of punk/new-wave power-pop (and the author of at least two dozen songs that make me very happy indeed), while Crenshaw is a solo artist who's been crafting lovely, you guessed it, punk/new-wave power pop for more than twenty years (you should buy all his albums and make him very rich). So they both turned fifty last week. Raise your glass, take a good swig in their honor, and play XTC's "English Settlement" album, in addition to "This Is Easy," a terrific Crenshaw compilation. And wish them both a happy belated one.

rock you like a hurricane You need this book: urlLink "Fargo Rock City" by Chuck Klosterman. Well, I need it. I picked it up last night without ever even hearing of it, and I'll probably be done with it my the time I go to bed tonight. It's consuming all my free time and I love it. Chuck Klosterman is a critic for the Akron Beacon Journal and grew up a heavy metal fan in the middle of North Dakota. In the eighties, he was weaned on a diet of Motley Crue, Poison, Bon Jovi, Metallica and Judas Priest. This book basically chronicles his obsessions and reexamines them in an adult light. He makes no apologies for his love of cheesy hair metal, but has a great sense of humor about it all. He's an excellent, insightful and very humorous writer (I found myself laughing out loud several times). Why should I care about a hair-metal memoir, you ask? No, I never liked the stuff. I was in high school when that particular genre was at its peak, and I hated it. When the school jocks were wooing the cheerleaders by blasting Poison out of the speakers of their Camaros, I had Elvis Costello on the Walkman, or sometimes I would be in my best friend Nick Fraser's Pontiac Sunbird with a Smiths tape in the deck. Heavy metal was boring, vapid, and didn't do a damn thing for me. It was Music For Other People. But I knew all the names, mainly because they were on MTV and plastered on umpteen high school classmates' t-shirts. So I can relate to what's being explained in this book, albeit from a secondhand pont of view. Besides, it's funny as hell.

you can get it if you really want it God bless the folks at Universal. A couple of years ago, they began to urlLink re-release several classic albums that fit under the Universal umbrella and put them out as two-disc "deluxe editions." This particular project has encompassed a wide variety of artists, including Bob Marley, the Who, Joe Jackson, John Coltrane, Donna Summer, Blind Faith, Howlin' Wolf, the Velvet Underground and more. I've picked up a few of these over the past year or so, and have never been disappointed. While I take issue with a few of their reissue choices (do we really need a special edition of Lionel Richie's "Can't Slow Down?" Even as a retro-ironic gag gift?), for the most part, they've made stellar choices. I picked up one of the best ones over the weekend: a deluxe edition of the soundtrack to urlLink "The Harder They Come," a 1973 cult classic about a reggae singer in Kingston, Jamaica. The film starred reggae singer Jimmy Cliff, who sang a good deal of the soundtrack's songs. The rest of the songs are a virtual Who's Who of late sixties/early seventies reggae: Desmond Dekker, the Melodians, Toots and the Maytals (whose seminal "Pressure Drop" -- included here -- was the inspiration for the name of this blog). I bought my original copy of "The Harder They Come" in 1991 and not only does this disc go a long way in adding to the sound quality of these recordings, the second, "special edition" disc adds to an already excellent collection. Basically, it's 18 more songs of the same era. Some of the artists already appear in disc one, but there are others, too. Some of the tracks are well-known among even casual reggae fans (Desmond Dekker's amazing "Isrealites," Jimmy Cliff's "Viet Nam," Johnny Nash's crossover smash "I Can See Clearly Now"), while others may be familiar to those who've heard UB40's whitebread - but not altogether bad - versions (Eric Donaldson's "Cherry Oh Baby," the Melodians' "Sweet Sensation"). The original disc, coupled with the second one, make up an essential reggae primer, especially for those who think that reggae began with Bob Marley (with all due respect to Bob, it didn't), in addition to those misguided souls who feel that Sean Paul and Shaggy are decent examples of the genre.

don't let the british accents fool you When my roommate and I recently updated our cable system, we discovered that one of our new channels is urlLink BBC America. This joy was compounded by my discovery of a hilarious, addictive show called urlLink "The Office." Unfortunately, I have yet to find any other redeeming qualities in this newfound channel. But that doesn't stop BBC America from launching an iditiotic, misguided, inaccurate ad campaign. Basically, it's a series of ads that consist of smug American yuppies going on and on about how much they love BBC America and how much "cooler" it is than regular U.S. network television. Now I won't argue that 99 percent of stateside TV is total crap, but the fact that BBC America somehow rises above it is a complete non-truth. get your prog on: king crimson at avalon You know it's a good concert if your ears are still ringing by the end of the following day. Wednesday night I had the pleasure of attending a show by not only a terrific headliner, but a strong, energetic support act as well. urlLink King Crimson, one of my favorite discoveries of 2003, played what could be considered an unfitting venue: the Avalon Ballroom. I say unfitting because Crimson are undoubtedly (even among their detractors) musician's musicians, playing highly intricate, disciplined, sophisticated, and rather loud, music. This is music to be listened to. A venue like the Berklee Performance Center, or maybe the Orpheum (two places they've played before) would have made the experience a bit nicer, but hey -- I'm not going to complain. These guys tore it up, and I'm perfectly happy with the show. I was surprised upon arriving at the venue (at 7, just as the doors were to open) that the line outside Avalon was seemingly interminable. But it made sense: many people were just as happy to see the opening act -- the newly reformed urlLink Living Colour -- they were the headliner. This made my goal of getting as far to the front of the stage as possible (Avalon is general admission) a bit more challenging than I had hoped. Instead of "rushing" the stage, I sauntered around the merch table and picked up a very nice long-sleeve KC t-shirt. There was an amazing selection of shirts, and even a black hooded sweatshirt that was "verra" cool (to use urlLink Heather's expression). But sixty bucks is a bit much for a hooded sweatshirt, I don't care if it's made from the Shroud of Turn. The demographic of this particular crowd was a bit different than I expected. I was thinking that there would be a lot of middle-aged ponytails (although there were some of those). It was mostly geeky urlLink Berklee students who spent their pre-show time discussing things like music theory and open tunings. Living Colour was greeted by the crowd like no other support act I've seen. I'm convinced that many people came just to see them. Which is fine, because they blew the roof off the place. They played a lot of songs from their brand-new album, urlLink "Collideoscope," in addition to some older stuff. Cory Glover, who has adopted a great sort of alien geek look ( dressed in orange with orange-dyed hair), paced the stage like a kid with ADD. This band may have been out of commission for the past several years, but Glover's voice was flawless as ever. Also playing flawlessly were dummer Will Calhoun (local dude and Berklee grad) and bass player Doug Wimbish (a veteran session musician who joined the band after their second album and has played with everyone from Mick Jagger to Madonna). But the real star of the show was guitarist urlLink Vernon Reid. An exceptional, highly influential and hyper-creative guitarist, he's one of the best-known facets of this band. He was greeted with the most enthusiasm from the crowd (most of them guitarists, no doubt) and the audience members constantly shouted their approval at him throughout the set. While Living Colour's music contains some elements that I don't care for -- an overabundance of preachy lyrics and a bit too much heavy-metal guitar wanking -- combining that sound with an assured blast of funk is what gives the band its edge. It's been copied many times over the years, but never duplicated. The band was hugely energetic -- and pretty freaking loud to boot. Some of the highlights for me included their new 9/11 song "Flying," an absolutely ferocious "Cult of Personality" and perhaps the best part of all, an inspired version of their song "Type" that eventually slowed down to a reggae pace and became a cover of urlLink Junior Murvin's classic "Police and Thieves." After hearing this transcendental cover, I'm convined these guys would make a great reggae band if they chose to go that route. Easily one of the best (if not the best) opening acts I've ever seen. After the band left the stage, gear was dissassembled and moved out of the way in order for Crimson's stuff to be loaded on and set up. This was some very unusual gear. Besides a somewhat normal-looking drumset (albeit a few electronic alterations), there were two strange bass guitar-type instruments, a small keyboard station surrounded by monitors and amps, and another guitar station off to the corner by a stool. The "strange bass guitar-type instruments" are actually urlLink Warr guitars, a rather odd touch-style bass guitar that Crimson bass player Trey Gunn uses, heartily endorses, and plays the living shit out of. When the band hit the stage, Trey was dressed like some sort of futurisic science-fiction orderly in a white long-sleeve shirt and white polyester pants. Groovy! Adrian Belew took his place at the keyboard/guitar/wall of monitors station, Pat Mastelotto hit the drums and the little stool with the guitar was reserved for none other than urlLink Robert Fripp, Crimson's only original member and the guy who started this whole thing more than 34 years ago. Here's the deal with Fripp: during the show, he sits at the aforementioned stool, facing sideways (in order to supervise his bandmates, I suppose, control freak that he is), and plays. No movement except the fingers. A robot. Smiling occasionally, but that's it. This guy makes John Entwhistle look like Iggy Pop. Fortunately, he's one hell of a guitarist. Also one hell of a guitarist is Belew. I've always thought he was more of a quirky vocalist who simply provided rhythm guitar behind Fripp's six-string madness, but he's quite the kick-ass musician in his own right (his solo albums, which I've sadly ignored, are supposedly brilliant). Although I suppose anyone who's played in bands with Frank Zappa, David Bowie and Talking Heads (his voice sounds uncannily like David Byrne's, by the way) knows what he's doing. Anyone unfamiliar with anything King Crimson has done after the seventies would be confused beyond belief by the sound they've crafted since their 1981 album "Discipline." They've moved from the ponderous elements of prog rock to a heavier, more disciplined sound. There are definitely elements of heavy metal (lots of crunchy, stuttering guitar riffs), but also a very textured sound (Fripp's guitar normally has some kind of synth patch, which practically puts him in the role of "keyboard player") and lots and lots of experimentalism. One of the most amazing, surreal moments of the show came when Trey Gunn's Warr guitar was spotlighted on the ethereal, meditative and indescribable song "ConstruKction of Light." These guys must have telekinetic powers or something. There's no other explanation as to how they can play so tightly and make so few mistakes. I don't think they're human. While primarily instrumental, Belew sang on several of the songs, mostly the spiky hard rock stuff like "Dinosaur," "Facts of Life" and "Happy With What You Have To Be Happy With" (a very funny song about the cliches of rock music). Like Living Colour, the band used electronic samples -- mostly recorded voices -- in the songs, and the Warr guitar was even used to trigger some of the samples. Very cool. Very scary. I can't say I've ever attended a show quite like this. The band only dipped into the seventies repertoire once (as far as I could tell, I don't own every single album), when they played the menacing title track to the 1974 album "Red" as an encore. Anyone attending this show who has any interest in bold, experimental music that can push boundaries and ring ears was most likely extremely happy by the end of the night. Oh, and a word of warning if you plan on seeing King Crimson live -- they are very serious about the concept of no photography, to the extent that everyone entering the venue was frisked, not necessarily for weapons, but cameras. When the "frisker" saw my cellphone, he asked if it was the kind that took photos. Just a heads-up.

it's only rock and roll urlLink Sarah made some interesting observations on her blog this morning about urlLink the Rolling Stones and how they are not only quintessential all-purpose bar music, but are also, as she puts it, "the soundtrack to life...everyone loves the Stones, whether they know it or not." I'm not sure how people who are in denial about their Stones-ness would react to such a statement, but as a fan, I wholeheartedly agree. The Stones are pretty much the Default Rock Band, as far as I'm concerned. Sure, they peaked years ago, and in my opinion haven't made a vital album since 1981's urlLink "Tattoo You," but their back catalog spans decades and is full of gems. Let's say you want to go under the assumption that the British Invasion changed rock and roll (which is true in many ways, but not an assumption without its arguments). In that case, while the Beatles gave rock and roll its songwriting craft, the Stones gave it the balls. Not to mention the blues (blue balls?). Like urlLink Dylan before them, the Stones' first few albums contained a large amount of cover songs, and it wasn't until their 1966 masterpiece urlLink "Aftermath" that they began writing all their own songs. And what songs they were! The Stones were masters at fusing the blues sounds of their idols (Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf) with rebellious rock and roll that fueled teen angst and female lust. How could you not shimmy along to the sexy marimba of "Under My Thumb," or Brian Jones' trippy sitar in "Paint It, Black?" The band has what you might call the essential rock and roll line-up: a charismatic lead singer in Mick Jagger, who can also blow a mean blues harp that seems to negate his materalistic jetsetting public persona; guitarist Keith Richards, who by all forms of logic should've kicked the bucket 25 years ago but still lays out those seemingly endless Chuck Berry-influence leads; the silent, stone-still yet completely original bass playing of Bill Wyman; and the jazz-influenced drumming of Charlie Watts, who always looks like he wishes he were somewhere else but has managed to stick with the band since the Kennedy administration. The fifth slot of the Stones is the one that's harder to define. The band's starting lineup included guitarist/multi-instrumentalist/blues freak/walking pharmacy Brian Jones, who guided the boys through some of their most fervent blues mining -- not to mention their deepest experimenting. Although he never wrote a song with the band, his musical contributions were crucial to the Stones' early days. Sadly, his drug habit got the best of him and he died in 1969. Mick Taylor replaced Brian soon after, and was around for their scary excursion to Altamont Speedway (see urlLink "Gimme Shelter" if you want to witness that madness), as well as two of their finest albums, urlLink "Sticky Fingers" and urlLink "Exile on Main Street." Although Taylor was -- and is -- an impeccable guitarist, he didn't seem to fit the Stones' personality and eventually ditched the band in the mid-seventies. As far as personality goes, Ron Wood fit the band to a tee: his time spent with urlLink the Faces, perhaps the ultimate British party band , ensured that. If you want vital Stones material, I would suggest picking up the following: "Aftermath," urlLink "Beggars Banquet," "Sticky Fingers," "Exile on Main Street" (in my opinion, one of the finest albums ever made by anyone), urlLink "Some Girls" and "Tattoo You." As far as compilations go, check out urlLink "Hot Rocks" or urlLink "Get Yer Ya-Ya's Out" (a flawless live album). There's really no appropriate place to stick this thought in my little Stones essay, so here goes: is there anyone out there who isn't completely charmed by the Stones songs that Keith sings? Is there anyone with a heartbeat who doesn't absolutely love the manic, gleeful "Happy" or the raunch-fest known as "Little T&A?" Mick may be a legend, and the Stones certainly wouldn't be around without him, but on those rare occasions when Keith takes the vocal duties, the world somehow seems like a better place.

they might be in the store Last night the urlLink Borders where I work part-time was a flurry of activity as John Linnell and John Flansburgh, also known as urlLink They Might Be Giants, performed some songs and signed some product. They've actually been in our store at least twice before, and I've had the pleasure of seeing them at the Cambridge Borders last year, in addition to seeing them twice in concert and meeting them in 1995 at the TV station in Virginia where I used to work, so forgive me if I'm getting a bit jaded on the subject of the Two Johns. I realize it sounds like I'm trying to be all cool and elitist by saying, "oh, I've seen them before, I've done that, big deal," but the truth is...oh hell, that is the truth. I'm totally getting elitist on your ass. Sorry. I've been a fan of the Giants (the band, not the football team) since 1990 when I first heard their "Flood" album and fell in love with it. The problem I have with them nowadays is that their fan base is the most annoying, obsessive, get-a-life bunch of freaks I've ever had the misfortune of being caught in the middle of. And of course, last night our store was full of them. I made the mistake a few years ago of signing on to their newsgroup. First of all, they refuse to admit that anything the band has ever done was wrong or misguided. There is no such thing as a least favorite TMBG song among these people. Every single TMBG song is the greatest song ever written. Also, the only stuff TMBG fans listen to is either TMBG or bands that sound like them (Barenaked Ladies, Moxy Fruvous, anything that involves parodies). They have musical tunnelvision and therefore I can't respect them. Still, John and John are pretty damn cool, write brilliant songs and are very friendly and completely anti-rock star. So I'll continue to buy their music. After the store closed I couldn't help noticing that one of the big green plastic tubs that holds our CD security "keepers" (that we haul up to the music department at the end of the night) was old and busted to the point where big plastic chunks were falling off. It was time to put it to rest. So I made an announcement over the PA that the "Jolly Green Giant" was being decommissioned and that I was getting ready to celebrate this historic event by tossing it down the escalator (keep in mind, the store is closed at this point, of course). A small crowd of employees checked out history in the making and the "tub toss" was greeted, to my sheer delight, with a round of applause and much rejoicing. I have it on fairly good authority that John and John were in the store at the time, packing up their gear. I only wish they could have checked out the ceremony. Maybe they could have written a song about it! Can't you just picture Linnell's whiny voice (over an accordian): "He's throwiiiiiinnnnng...the keeper tub...down the eeeeeescaaaaalaaaaatorrrrr...." Maybe not.

the movies Remember when I wrote on this blog about two months ago that with Liza gone for a semester in Europe, I'm going to the movies at least once every weekend? Wasn't that funny? Actually, it's not that unrealistic, but laziness tends to set in, especially on Sunday mornings, what with an apartment to myself, a coffee pot and over a thousand CDs. Yay for Sunday laziness! With all that in mind, however, I have to admit that I wish I was back on the movie-every-weekend kick. I haven't been to the movies in about two or three weeks, when I saw "Wonderland" (exhilirating) and "Intolerable Cruelty" (enjoyable, but partially ruined by a few brats in the back row). This weekend sees the release of "Human Stain," which I'd like to see for several reasons. It looks like a good story (although I have yet to read Philip Roth's novel), the cast is pretty nifty, and it was directed by Robert Benton. Benton is hardly a prolific director, but he did direct "Kramer vs. Kramer," which is probably one of my top twenty favorite films of all time. He also directed "Still of the Night," an excellent 1983 thriller starring Roy Scheider and Meryl Streep that was seen by absolutely nobody but me. This will probably ruin my "indie cred," but "Love, Actually" actually looks quite entertaining. Yes, it's a chick flick, but the cast looks good and I love ensemble films, for the most part. Poopieheads.

one of a kind: bill bruford at scullers Over the past four years or so -- since I've been back in a large city with easy access to concerts -- I've had the wonderful opportunity of not only seeing bands I enjoy casually, but also those who I consider major influences, whose music I listen to often and have been fans of for many years. The Beautiful South, Billy Bragg, Paul Weller, Graham Parker, Branford Marsalis, Joe Jackson -- these are just a few of the artists I've seen lately who fit into that category. Last night was no exception as my friend Bob and I went to urlLink Scullers to see Bill Bruford in a fascinating show I won't soon forget. urlLink Bill Bruford is a name that may not ring a bell with the casual music fan. He started out in the late sixties as the drummer for the original line-up of urlLink Yes, the prog-rock band everyone loves to hate. Not only is my love for the cheesiness of certain prog bands evident (as readers of this blog can attest), Bruford's tenure in Yes (1968-1972) constitutes what I feel is the creative peak of that band (during which they would release a mighty fine trilogy of masterpieces: "The Yes Album," "Fragile" and "Close to the Edge"). What set Bruford apart from the rest of his fellow rock musicians was a deep affinity for jazz music. It permeated everything he played. You could always hear in his playing a jazz drummer wanting to break out of the confines of rock. Although, truth be told, Yes -- for all the critical slams they took and continue to take -- were a quite adventurous band back in the day. Bruford had a crisp, regimented sound that gave an air of class to whatever he played. Ultimately he tired of Yes and moved on the the still-prog-but-more-experimental urlLink King Crimson. Crimson were (and still are, in a far different permutation) like Yes in the fact that they fit the "prog" mold, yet there was always something much more bold, experimental, and dark about their sound. Among the best work they did with Bruford was the dark, utterly devastating "Red," which -- unless this is an urban legend -- Kurt Cobain considered one of his all-time favorite albums. Bruford continued to work on and off with Crimson until the mid-nineties, but he also busied himself with a vaiety of solo projects along the way, including an amazing fusion record called "One of a Kind" in 1979 and a good-but-not-as-good one called "Feels Good to Me" (which is ruined, in my opinion, by an annoying female singer that adds nothing to the music). Freed from the shackles of rock music, Bruford has embraced his first love -- jazz -- in his most recent incarnation: founder and leader of a revolving combo of musicians known as Earthworks. Their show at Scullers last night was, for jazz fans, a stunning display of musicianship and, for the casual rock fan, an affirmation of Bruford's status as one of rock's most amazing drummers. The band consisted of Bruford, a sax player, a pianist and bass player. Bruford explained -- to an astonished crowd -- that the pianist and bass player had only begun playing with Bruford forty-eight hours earlier. This was difficult to believe, given the fantastic interplay between all the band members. Saxophonist Tim Garland (I forgot the other members' names, sorry) has apparently been with Bruford for some time and played amazingly, alternating between different saxes and even switching to a bass clarinet for a couple of songs (an instrument I've heard before but never actually seen -- it looks like a clarinet fused with a saxophone, very odd). Garland was incredible, a brilliant, eclectic musician from whom I'd love to hear more. The music was pretty much standard jazz improvisation, but the band were always able to duck out of the soloing and into the written figures with amazing ease. I'm no expert, but if there were any flubbed notes, I didn't hear them. Bob and I were lucky enough to be sitting about ten feet away from Bruford himself. This was not only entertaining, but quite an education for me as well. I started playing drums at the age of ten (24 years ago), and Bruford was one of my inspirations for doing so. It was both exhilirating and a bit depressing to watch him in action and wonder how the hell he does it. Fortunately, Bruford was kind enough to sign autographs outside the venue after the show. As I saw prog fans approach him to have various Yes and Crimson memorabilia signed, I cursed myself for not bringing anything like that along. Unlike some artists who refuse to acknowledge their past, Bill is perfectly happy to discuss his "rock life" and sign the appropriate CDs and books. As I approached The Man with my ticket stub for his signature, I shook his hand and told him the perfectly truthful fact that he indeed was one of my inspirations for learning the drums at age ten. Unfortunately I was unprepared for his question: "Do you still play?" Slightly embarrassed, I admitted to him, "No. You could say I'm lapsed." I haven't been in a band for ten years, actually. Bill smiled and shook my hand again. I wish I could have told him that I was in some big band making millions, but I guess only one of us can claim that.

mushi-mushi Happy holidays! Why the long face? Yes, Christmas is over, but we still have New Year's Eve to look forward to, and 2004 promises an optimistic shimmer of hope for you and me and all of mankind! Really! Trust me on this. I don't know what that was all about, I just feel bad about not blogging much lately and I figured that an overenthusiastic greeting would distract you from the lack of attention I've been paying to my blog. Christmas Eve was nice. Liza and I finished off a shift at Borders (where the store closed at 7 pm, which is two hours early, but still...c'mon people, if you haven't bought your gifts five hours before Christmas, you ain't buying them at all), then we headed to Aunt Linda and Uncle Bobby's, where we feasted on catered food that was saved for us (everyone else ate a few hours earlier). We ended up staying at my sister Julie's place from the 24th to the 28th, since she flew down to Baltimore to visit my mother and her dog-sitting plan fell through at the last minute. So Liza and I had the place to ourselves, and took care of Barney and Bea (Julie's dogs). Fun! On Christmas Day we headed over to my place, where my roommate Frank made a lovely brunch and invited over our co-worker Eileen and her partner Laura. There was salad, quiche, potatoes, apple pie, three kinds of booze (champagne, wine and Bailey's) and a plethora of present-opening. Frank of course was a wonderfully tipsy host, to the point where he even broke out his story about meeting Ginger Rogers in the men's room at Studio 54 (a classic). I should mention at this point that Julie's house has a brand-new computer, and I was planning to burn CDs and do some blogging over the weekend, but I accomplished neither. Oh well. Julie lent us not only her home, but also her car, so we took full advantage of that. Liza even drove me to work at Borders on Saturday morning when the subway would have worked just fine. We also drove to a mall in Braintree where we used the Banana Republic gift certificates my mother got us. Then we saw the latest "Lord of the Rings" installment. What did you all think of that movie, anyway? Not being a Tolkien expert by any means, I've accompanied Liza to all three of these movies (she's a big fan), and found myself pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed them. The first one was really nice (I loved all the stuff that took place in the Hobbit village), the second one a little gloomy and rather tedious in parts, and the latest one...well, first of all: three and a half hours? Jesus, people...it's called "editing." Look into it. Don't get me wrong. It was a highly enjoyable, very well-made film. But that last half-hour...how many loose ends do they need to wrap up? There were about six times in that last part where I thought the credits would roll, and then: ta-da! Another scene. We get it. It's over. Everyone's sad. Sam and Frodo love each other. Take some Kleenex and get on with your lives already. Sorry. I really liked it. But once you get past the 200 MINUTE mark, "epic" far too easily translates to"excess." I also saw "Lost in Translation" for the third time. That's right. Hey, I like this movie, okay? I saw it when it first came out back in September. Then I convinced Suarez a.k.a. Sanchez to see it with me a couple of weeks ago. We both like it so much that we went again over the weekend, with Liza (who loved it). We also found it to be endlessly quotable (particularly any dialogue spoken by the airhead actress character -- "I have the worst B.O. today!"). I think you're all caught up now. Forgive the lack of links, creating them is such a pain in the ass on Blogger.

get over yourself, part two I can't really say that I've heard any of Ryan Adams' music -- except for that song he wrote about New York that was played ad nauseum after 9/11 -- but whether he's talented or not, he apparently has an overwhelming need to get over himself. First, there was the infamous story earlier this year about a guy in the audience at one of Adams' shows who suggested he play "Summer of '69" -- get it, the Bryan Adams song? -- and then Adams throwing a ten-dollar bill at the heckler, suggesting that he leave the venue with his "refund." What a crybaby! And now there's Jim Derogatis' urlLink review of an Adams show from earlier this month that documents this prima donna's petulant, whiny behavior. The nadir for me was his pointless ridicule of Wilco. Derogatis put it nicely: "Adams can release three CDs in a three-week span, but the fact remains that he still can't write one song as original or as heartfelt as anything by Jeff Tweedy." Maybe I'm just biased since I love Jeff Tweedy, but I'm looking forward to Ryan Adams' eventual self-destruction.

return of the liza After three months in Europe, Liza's back in town! Having my girlfriend back in the same continent, let alone the same room as me is indeed quite a delightful situation and I'm insanely happy about it. The night she got back, we got together for dinner at Anna's Taqueria on Beacon Street with a bunch of the new friends she made during her urlLink semester abroad. I'm happy to say that they're all just peachy. Yay for new friends. Our first weekend back together consisted of Liza meeting me at urlLink Borders after my shift, a which point we walked over to the apartment I found for her in the North End that she still hasn't seen the inside of yet (I did some apartment-searching for her while she was gone). Her friend Nicole is a definite lock for a roommate, and they have some prospects for a third, but they need to find someone by January 1st. Whatever the case, Liza really likes the *outside* of the apartment, it looks like the realtor is going to give her and Nicole a set of keys tomorrow. I feel really strange knowing that two people (one of them I've only known for a few days) are about to move into a place that I picked out that they still haven't seen yet, but I'm dealing with it. Hey, it has a roof deck! That should seal the deal for anyone. Later, we went to Central Square, where Liza had a dance audition. I killed time by wandering around Central Square, walked down Vassar Street (where I was hypnotized by a stunningly modern-looking MIT building known as urlLink Simmons Hall ), back around Central Square, down to Harvard Square and back to Central. I also checked out Skippy White's, a lovely used record store that specializes in classic R&B. I picked up a nice urlLink Hank Ballard CD, which made my trekking around Cambridge a lot more fun (especially since I ended up playing "Let's Go, Let's Go, Let's Go" about five times in a row. I can never get sick of that song). Liza and I then went to see urlLink "Love, Actually," which I saw a couple of months ago with my sister Julie, but had to see again since it basically has "Liza" written all over it. Silly, sappy but very entertaining sort-of chick flick. Of course. She loved it, and I enjoyed it once again. Bill Nighy's performance as aging pop star Billy Mack is worth the price of admission. Sunday we went with her friend Zoe to see urlLink "Kill Bill." I'm still on the fence about this movie. I can't really 100 percent wholeheartedly recommend it, but there are definitely some nice moments that remind me why Quentin Tarantino deserves a lot of the praise he's been given in his career. Unfortunately, there was much to fault as well. I have nothing against gratuitous violence per se, but it almost seemed as if Tarantino was trying to see how much he could get away with. It seemed misguided. Also, I think that he's trying to outdo "Pulp Fiction." He probably realizes that 99 percent of the people out there (myself included) find that film to be his crowning acheivement, a work of art that he will most likely never top. So he decides to push the "overkill" button and hope we'll ignore the flimsy plot and enormous amount of disbelief suspension required. "Yeah, I know that this character would not be conscious after losing all that blood when her arm was chopped off," he seems to be saying, "but look at that fountain of blood and how majestically it shoots out of the dead guy's neck!" The cinematography is quite something. The fight sequences (and there's a lot of them) are very well-choreographed. The music, as always with Tarantino, is wall-to-wall and very well chosen. But it seems like all style and no substance. Maybe when the excellent, underrated and relatively low-key "Jackie Brown" failed to blow anyone away at the box office, Tarantino decided to do a complete 180, buy fake blood in bulk and go for broke. Who knows. Anyway, where was I...oh, after the movie, Liza and I met my sister Julie for dinner at urlLink Chef Chang's. I'm not a huge expert (or even a huge fan) of Asian food, but this place is fantastic. I've been here about four times so far, and every experience has been wonderful. The food is great, the ambience very cozy, the service impeccable, and...well, just go there. Julie also gave us our Christmas gifts...memberships to the urlLink Museum of Fine Arts. Julie rocks. It's official.

2003: music in review, part two More stuff from this year that made me happy: urlLink Randy Newman: Songbook, Vol. 1 This was the year that I discovered Newman and his witty, engaging songwriting. Good thing, too: this was also the year he released this truly unique form of anthology. "Songbook" is a collection of Randy's songs, stripped down and re-recorded with just vocals and piano. Sort of an "Unplugged in the Studio" kind of thing. You get the big songs ("You Can Leave Your Hat On," "Sail Away," "Louisiana 1927"), a few obscure ones (the hilarious "Great Nations of Europe") and a few instrumental themes from his voluminous soundtrack work. A great way to discover this winning singer/songwriter. urlLink King Crimson: The Power to Believe Crimson was another one of my 2003 discoveries, and I'm amazed it's taken me this long. I've been a closet prog freak for decades (literally), and these guys pretty much wrote the book on the genre. Despite (or perhaps because of) the fact that guitarist Robert Fripp is the only remaining original member since their 1969 debut, their music has remained amazingly fresh over the years. The secret is not only Fripp's willingness to move into uncharted waters, but also his knack for picking the most daring and talented musicians to join the fray. The band has moved from medeival art-rock stylings to a jarring world music/Talking Heads mode to their current incarnation, which can be best described as intelligent fusion metal. "The Power to Believe" is one of the best things I've heard from this band's current incarnation. Fripp, guitarist/vocalist/lyricist Adrian Belew, bass player Trey Gunn and drummer Pat Mastelotto craft a unique, highly experimental sound that guides them through tricky, trippy instrumentals and good old-fashioned rock stompers. A band that refuses to compromise is captured here at the height of their powers. urlLink The Beautiful South: Gaze Rising from the ashes of the Housemartins in the late eighties, singer/lyricist extraordinaire Paul Heaton formed this quirky band to wide acclaim in their native England, but they've made little impression on this side of the pond. It's a shame, since their brand of witty, catchy songwriting is unlike anything else out there. The best way to describe the Beautiful South is "Squeeze meets early Elton John with a touch of the Smiths." Heaton's cynical, bitingly satiric and often disturbing lyrics are wrapped in sweet, irresistible melodies (written by guitarist Dave Rotheray). Heaton is aided vocally by former Housemartins drummer Dave Hemingway and Alison Wheeler (the latest of the band's female singers, who seem to rotate in and out of the band like Spinal Tap drummers). "Gaze" isn't their finest moment, but that's like saying that the Ritz may not be the nicest hotel in town since there's a Four Seasons down the street. It's all relative, and I personally feel that these guys are incapable of making a bad album. There's a lot of great stuff here, including the catchy first single, "Just a Few Things That I Ain't," the anti-homophobic "101 Percent Man" and the gorgeous "Get Here." urlLink Me First and the Gimme Gimmes: Take a Break Call me a sell-out, call me a bandwagon jumper, strip me of whatever "indie cred" I may possess, but God help me, I can't help loving these guys. What they do is fairly simple and has the possibility to get old after a few albums: take a variety of cover songs and turn them into punk rock rave-ups. Why not? Most of the Me First albums have a theme, and this one seems to be about R&B, past and present. The guys deconstruct every thing from "You Make Me Feel Like a Natural Woman" to "I Believe I Can Fly" to "Mona Lisa" to "Nothing Compares 2 U," and they do it all beautifully. There's no message here, this band will never change the world, they just have a lot of fun. And that fun is extremely contagious. Lighten up and enjoy. urlLink Warren Zevon: "The Wind" The story's been chronicled ad nauseum, but it's still worth retelling: Zevon was diagnosed with terminal lung cancer in the summer of 2002, and instead of going quietly, he rushed out one more album, enlisting the aid of friends and fans. That album, "The Wind" (released in late August, about two weeks before his death) isn't necessarily the best thing he's ever done, but as with the Beautiful South, it's all relative. It's not better than "Excitable Boy," "Life'll Kill Ya" or "Sentimental Hygiene," but it definitely has some great moments. Highlights include "Disorder in the House" (his rousing collaboration with Bruce Springsteen), a beautiful cover of Dylan's "Knockin' on Heaven's Door," "Numb as a Statue" (a piano-based mid-tempo number than recalls old-school Zevon) and an expecially poignant closer, "Keep Me In Your Heart" (which I can't listen to without a tear welling up. You got a problem with that?) Warren amassed a huge collection of strong, beautiful music in his lifetime, and "The Wind" is a fitting swan song. I'd also like to thank everyone responsible for the first batch of Bob Dylan reissues, as well as the continuation of the Elvis Costello and Yes reissues. They made my year.

2003: music in review, part one It's that time of year. You can't escape it. Writers, reviewers and bloggers of all shapes and sizes can't wait to dispatch their "Best Of" lists of 2003. Let's dispense with the pleasantries, shall we? Here is a totally random list, in no order whatsoever, of a bunch of albums that came out this year that made me very happy. urlLink Paul Weller: Fly on the Wall Collections of b-sides and rarities are often an artist's way of biding time while waiting for a new burst of creative inspiration. If that's the case here, so be it. Weller's been cranking out amazing music for a quarter-century, he can afford to relax. Plus, this collection is more than just filler. There's three discs of alternate takes and b-sides that stand up very well on their own. Two things stand out in this set: one, there's a handful of enganging instrumentals that make you wish Weller would release more of that kind of stuff; and two, the third disc consists entirely of covers (ranging from the Beatles to Ben Harper to Sonny and Cher) that is worth the price of admission alone. You haven't lived until you've heard Paul belt out "Bang Bang." urlLink Joe Jackson: Volume 4 I've been a Joe Jackson fan since the age of ten, when I learned how to play the drums on a friend's set with "Is She Really Going Out With Him" on the headphones. After numerous mostly successful musical experiments, Joe reunited his original "Look Sharp" band and foisted an endlessly catchy, completely winning set of brand new songs on the world. The old power-punk bile is intact, along with some lovely ballads he's perfected along the way. This isn't just some old fart attempting to relive his glory days: it could be a quartet of hungry twentysomethings if you didn't know better. urlLink Elvis Costello: North Like Jackson, Costello has done his share of musical experimentalism over the years. Every thing from straight country-western to string quartets to collaborations with noted classical vocalists. In 1998, he teamed up with legendary songwriter/arranger Burt Bacharach for "Painted From Memory," an album that contained a few great songs, but a bit too much sappiness for my tastes. Ditching Bacharach this time around, Costello continued in that album's vein with "North," which consists of vocals and piano (ably assisted by his keyboard-playing partner-in-crime, Steve Nieve), in addition to some lovely, tasteful orchestration. The result is a sumptuous, jazzy masterpiece -- what "Painted..." should've been. urlLink The Beatles: Let it Be...Naked "Let it Be," for me, was always a spotty effort from the Fab Four. It contained some great songs, but a lot of filler, and those Phil Spector-arranged strings were just as sappy as the critics claimed. So in 2003, a new version emerged, without the strings, without the short joke songs ("Maggie Mae," "Dig It") and with the addition of the sexy single "Don't Let Me Down." Yes, there are the usual Beatles crowd-pleasers here ("Get Back," the title track), but also a few semi-obscure gems that I consider to be among their best songs ("I Dig a Pony," "I've Got a Feeling"). urlLink Bryan Beller: View Beller is probably best-known as the bass-playing right hand man of the obscenely talented urlLink Mike Keneally, and after years of standing in the shadows, he decided to take the plunge and record his very own solo album. The absurdly musical "View" is mostly what you would expect from this hyperactive Berklee grad: expertly played jazz/rock fusion that doesn't take itself too seriously. But there's also some warm, lyrical acoustic bass solos, in addition to a few tunes with lyrics (which mostly work). The whole thing just reeks of manic fun in the studio. Beller is joined by Keneally, in addition to other MK cohorts like Rick Musallam and Tricia Steele. A beautiful piece of music. Please buy this and make Beller rich. He deserves it. urlLink Fountains of Wayne: Welcome Interstate Managers The third album from these crunchy power-popsters finds them finally enjoying the success they deserve. Sure, "Stacy's Mom" is being played on pop radio and TRL, but that doesn't mean I can't enjoy it. These songs are so sweet and catchy, they're like a digital sugar rush. I don't even know where to begin with this one: there's the kickin', working-class woe of "Bright Future in Sales," the erzata cry-in-your-beer country of "Hung Up on You" (which blatantly rips off Elvis Costello's "Stranger in the House"), the new wave psychedelia of "No Better Place," the hilarious "Fire Island." These guys have something that's sore lacking in today's music scene: songwriting craft. Live long and prosper, Fountains. urlLink Soundtrack: The Harder They Come (deluxe edition) This seminal reggae soundtrack, first released in 1973, has always been a favorite of mine, fusing the talents of Desmond Dekker, Jimmy Cliff, the Maytals and a host of other reggae greats from the time. The new Universal reissue is a huge leap forward, including a second disc of similar reggae music from the same period. Classics like "Isrealites," "It Mek," "Pomps and Pride," "Cherry Oh Baby" and Jimmy Cliff's "Vietnam" are placed in the best possible context, and the whole collection becomes a primer for all that's good in reggae music. All due respect to the late great Bob Marley: shelve that worn copy of "Legend" for a while and put this on. Stay tuned for the next installment: prog rock redux, little-known British songsmiths, power-punk covers and some sorely needed reissues come to light in '03, and I'll discuss them tomorrow.

coolidge corner becomes tokyo So last Saturday night, Suarez and I went to see urlLink "Lost in Translation" at the inimitable Coolidge Corner Theater. I already saw the movie a few months ago (the day it was released, in fact), but there was nothing else playing that I really wanted to see, and since she hadn't seen it yet, we decided to go for it. I was struck once again by many fascinating things while watching this movie, including how incredibly bright and garish downtown Tokyo seems to be, how beautiful urlLink Scarlett Johansson is, and what a nice little acting niche urlLink Bill Murray's made for himself lately. He could have easily gone the Chevy Chase route and made self-parodying comic flops until he keeled over and died, but instead he's chosen quirky, original roles in films like "Rushmore," "The Royal Tenenbaums" and a Jim Jarmusch film called urlLink "Cigarettes and Coffee" (I know nothing about this film other than what IMDB says -- but hey, it's Jim Jarmusch, it can't be half bad). Many people were ticked off when Murray didn't get an Oscar nomination for his role as Herman Blume, the wealthy industrialist in "Rushmore" -- which I felt he deserved -- but the fact that he's even being considered for these types of awards is admirable, considering the fact that most people associated him with "Ghostbusters" and "Saturday Night Live" during the first ten to fifteen years of his career. Other things I love about this movie: the spacey soundtrack that combines the Jesus and Mary Chain, Air, My Bloody Valentine and more; Giovanni Ribisi as the absent-minded, career-obssessed husband; the numerous panoramic shots from inside the high-rise hotel; the karaoke scenes; the orange camouflage t-shirt Murray wears during one of his nights on the town; and Anna Faris' portrayal of the typical airhead movie star. There are more, and I'll think of them the next time I see this film.

blog in c-minor In the spring of 1997, I was living in Naples, Italy and my wife and I had been separated for a few months already. I was enjoying my newfound freedom by spending my evenings reading books in my apartment. One of these books was urlLink "Icon" by Frederick Forsyth, and I distinctly remember listening to my new urlLink Beethoven piano sonata CD at the same time. I was still pretty green on the subject of classical music at the time, and the Sonata No. 8 in C-minor (the "Pathetique") had an enormous effect on me, to the extent that it's still, six and a half years and a couple hundred CDs later, one of my favorites. A few years later, I became the proud owner of a Mozart two-disc freebie that included, among other things, Mozart's Piano Sonata No. 14 in C-minor (K. 457), which also had a profound effect on me. Many piano pieces have come in and out of my ears in the interim between the espionage book background of Beethoven's "Pathetique" and the promo CD-induced discovery of K. 457, but there was something about these two pieces that fascinated me to the point where I know I'll never tire of them. Suddenly, it hit me: the common thread that runs through these two sonatas...c-minor! That must be it. The key of c-minor just...I don't know... does something for me. It's strange, since normally minor chords depress the hell out of me. But in the context of solo piano, it just works. Incidentally, if you want a definitive (for me) interpretation of K. 457, in addition to all of Mozart's piano sonatas and variations, buy urlLink this box set. It's a beautiful thing (I raved about it upon initial purchase in my May 13 blog entry, "Box Sets and John Cusack").

descanse en paz Ruben Gonzalez urlLink died yesterday at the age of 84. If you're unfamiliar with this name, I don't blame you. I never heard of the guy until about three years ago, when I bought the CD urlLink "Introducing Ruben Gonzalez" after urlLink Mike Keneally raved about it on his website. Ruben was a Cuban-born pianist who enjoyed fame in his native country and eventually shot to American and international stardom just a few years ago after he was featured in urlLink "Buena Vista Social Club," Ry Cooder's love note to the music of Cuba. Gonzalez, along with other Cuban stars such as Ibraham Ferrer, Omara Portuondo and Compay Segundo (who also passed away recently) were featured recording in a Havana studio and eventually performing live in Amsterdam and Carnegie Hall. It's an inspirational story of a small cadre of dedicated and immensely talented performers undaunted by age. Words can only say so much. You have to hear Ruben's music to believe it. "Introducing..." is a gem, nine tracks of pure exhiliration. Ruben's piano playing -- sort of a Latin-tinged Thelonious Monk -- defies his age. He glides up and down the keyboard with pure grace. Buy this disc. I have yet to play it for anyone who didn't love it.

the weather outside is frightful I live in Boston, so I'm sort of bound by law to post something on my blog to the effect of, "how about that snow, huh?" Since I don't own a car, the weather didn't really have too much of an effect on me. That is, until I changed my mind about going to the movies that night (hey, walking to the Kendall Square Cinema from the subway station is enough of a trek without the snow) So I ended up staying home and cuddling up with true crime TV. That's right, a nice one-two punch of urlLink "American Justice" and urlLink "Cold Case Files." Love that Bill Kurtis. Sunday was going to be a "laze around the house, drink coffee and watch documentaries" kind of day, until my sister Julie called and asked if maybe I wouldn't mind helping her dig her car out from a good 12 to 18 inches of snow. Why of course. I'm such a good brother. I was rewarded for my hard work with lunch at a nearby pub/restaurant, Gerard's, which is a decent place except for the fact that you have to access it by walking through a convenience store. My Dijon burger was yummy. We then watched her rented DVD of urlLink "Finding Nemo" and took her dogs, Barney and Bea, for a walk. I also started a rather good book last night: urlLink "Mission Flats" by William Landay. I picked up a free copy at Borders after I was allowed to take five advance galley copies of various books from the managers office after busting my hump on an overtime-sucking project last weekend. The book is turning out to be quite entertaining. A gritty, boston-based crime novel very much in the vein of Dorchester homey urlLink Dennis Lehane. Good stuff. Highly recommended. By the way, now that I think about it, the weather not really having much an effect on me is wrong on two counts: first of all, clearing sidewalks is apparently not a huge priority in my neighborhood, which makes my walk to the subway not unlike some psychotic obstacle course. Second of all...despite my occasional bitching and moaning, I really love this weather.

1940-1993 I meant to post something about this yesterday, and then things got so crazy at the office and I completely forgot about it. urlLink Frank Zappa died ten years ago yesterday. Anyone who knows my musical tastes to any great extent knows that Frank is my musical hero. I became a fan in 1983 at age fourteen thanks to the voracious musical appetite of my older brother. What initially attracted me to Frank's music was the toilet humor. I was, after all, in junior high school at the time. But as I got older I realized what an amazingly talented composer, arranger, guitarist, producer and bandleader this unique gentleman truly was. The man was a genius. Most people use the word "genius" to describe everything from a stand-up comedian to the guy who fixed their sink. I hardly ever use the word. It's overused in our society and therefore its value has been cheapened. I'm a massive film and music fan, but I can think of few actual geniuses in the entertainment industry. Stanley Kubrick was one. As far as rock music goes -- again, this is a genre I love dearly -- Frank is the only one that springs to mind. His mind was simply overflowing with rich musical ideas. For a good overview of Frank's catalog, check out "We're Only In It For the Money," "Hot Rats," "You Can't Do That On Stage Anymore Vol. 2 (The Helsinki Concert)," "One Size Fits All" and "The Yellow Shark." These albums should put to rest anyone's misconceptions that Frank was simply a guy who wrote silly songs about sex.

a hardly silent night Some people actively seek out Christmas music. They'll go to the store, buy it, play it at home -- either alone or at a get-together -- while some people detest it with a passion. Like urlLink Tom, I'm somewhere in the middle. I've accepted it as part of our culture. It's out there, you don't have to embrace it, but try to deal with it for the next few weeks. But working part-time at Borders, it's hard to catch a break. We're pretty much forced to play it 24/7 during the holiday season. I make do by playing the stuff I like. Here's a guide to what I can stand and what makes me retch in the holiday music arena: Stuff I like: urlLink "Ultra-Lounge Christmas Cocktails" -- hey, holiday music is supposed to be cheesy, so why not go all out. The Ultra-Lounge series embraces the concept of gaudy hammond organs and cha-cha beats, and this time, they've given Kris Kringle and his gang the lounge treatment. Favorite cut: "Cha-Cha All the Way," with the immortal line, "Jingle bells, jing-jingle cha-cha-cha, jingle all the way / love the rhythm of Christmas time down South America Way..." Last week in the store I played that song three times in a row. urlLink "A Christmas Gift For You From Phil Spector" -- forget for a minute that Phil apparently wasted his girlfriend. A legendary producer, Spector redefined recording techniques in the 1960s with his "Wall of Sound," breathing life into girl groups like the Crystals and the Ronettes (so what if he fucked up "Let it Be"). Here, classic female artists under Spector's wing, like the aforementioned ones in addition to Darlene Love and Bob B. Soxx and the Blue Jeans, make you long for skinny ties and beehive hairdos while decorating the tree. urlLink "Mahalia Jackson Sings Songs of Christmas!" -- despite what capitalism may tell you, Christmas is, after all, a religious holiday. And if you're gonna raise the roof, who better than Mahalia to help you get in the mood? Blessed with a gorgeous singing voice, this pillar of sacred music sings her heart out almost enough to make you forget Stevie Nicks' croaking version of "Silent Night." Almost. urlLink Marcus Roberts: "Prayer for Peace" -- as usual, Roberts -- an incomparable jazz pianist -- is all class in a series of solo piano holiday pieces. His stuff is usually a little hard to find, but if you like this one, try his non-holiday stuff too, like "Alone With Three Giants" and "As Serenity Approaches." urlLink Vince Guaraldi: "A Charlie Brown Christmas" -- yes, we've heard it all a thousand times. But who cares? This stuff is timeless, from the kids singing the carols out of tune to the beautiful rendition of "O Tannenbaum" to the impossible-to-resist "Linus and Lucy." Some things never get old. The stuff I hate: Paul McCartney: "Wonderful Christmas" -- I'm going along with urlLink Dan on this one. He called it "a truly vile song." I'll go one further: it's without a doubt one of the most simpering, condescending, amateurish, annoying, brain-numbing pieces of trash that any human being could ever have the stomach to commit to sheet music. Elmo & Patsy: "Grandma Got Run Over By A Reindeer" -- stupid, annoying, overplayed, painfully unfunny, stupid, overrated, and, oh yeah...stupid. Let's put this one to rest, and bury it next to grandma, okay? Various Artists: "Very Special Christmas" -- there's no way in hell I'm providing a link to this piece of trash, since the last thing it needs is more publicity. I realize that it's for charity, but there are more worthwhile ways to contribute to a cause than having to buy into this compost heap one more time. First things first: this thing gets overplayed every year since it first came out (about 15 years ago). Where do I begin? There is no reason why anyone should have to suffer through Bryan Adams painfully bad rendition of "Run Rudolph Run" when far superior versions by both Chuck Berry and Dave Edmunds are available. As far as "Christmas in Hollis" by Run-DMC is concerned: it was funny the first time. Not anymore. Madonna doing "Santa Baby?" I dislike Madonna enough as it is; when she's in faux-Marilyn Monroe mode, she's even worse. And that's not even half the album. Resist the urge to buy this. If you own it, I'm sure urlLink CD Spins will take it off your hands.

happy thanksgiving, where's the dayquil? Now that I've succeeded in casting a pall over my entire blog with that thoroughly depressing post about my sad dream, how about I do what everyone else seems to be doing -- talk about my Thanksgiving weekend? Okay? Okay! Wednesday night -- the night before Thanksgiving -- is, as urlLink Heather revealed in her latest post, the busiest night for bars. I took advantage of this neighborhood camaraderie by visiting the closest thing I have to a "local" -- the Harp & Bard in Dorchester. My roommate Frank and I kicked off the extended weekend by scarfing down their award-winning BLTs and washing it all down with a couple of beers. My sister Julie and I spent Thanksgiving at Aunt Linda and Uncle Bobby's house in nearby Stoneham. Also attending the festivities were their two sons -- my cousins -- Brendan and Ryan (who are probably the nicest two people I've ever met in my life), my Uncle Jack and Aunt Elaine and their son -- another cousin -- Steve. Steve is a nice guy but doesn't talk much. You may recall he was mentioned briefly in my video game tribute post, "Forgive the Overwhelming Rush of Nostalgia." Steve, by the way, has spent the last few years designing a video game. After much prodding by family members (excluding myself, who felt kind of bad for the guy), Steve finally gave in and went online to show us some screen shots of the nearly-completed war strategy game, which looked quite impressive. He's submitted the game to a company for possible publishing, so keep your fingers crossed. The food was excellent. That's a given. If there's anything my mother's side of the family can claim -- besides incomprehensible Boston accents -- it's a flair for cooking. As great as the food was, however, I have to say that the highlight of the day was a surprise phone call from Liza, who as most of you know is nearing the end of her three-month semester abroad in Holland. Yay Liza! Seventeen more days. Unfortunately, by the end of the day I started getting a sore throat and was almost positive that I was in the beginning stages of a cold. As fate would have it, I woke up the next morning with just that. Originally planning to spend a couple hours working some overtime at Borders, I stayed in bed all day, which was quite all right by me, since TLC was airing a urlLink "What Not To Wear" Don't Dress Like a Turkey Thanksgiving Marathon. I watched the damn thing for eight hours straight. No kidding. All due respect to urlLink The Fab Five, I have to say that I enjoy "What Not To Wear" more. Co-host Stacy is cute as a button and her better half, Clinton, wears the coolest shirts. Before I settled in for this marathon, I also caught bits and pieces of a James Bond marathon on the silly, testosterone-fueled Spike channel. Saturday and Sunday saw me working oodles of overtime at Borders, which will be a great help to me when I have to pay for that gargantuan phone bill. I managed to grab discs from artists as diverse as Shirley Horn, Dave Holland, John Coltrane, Mars Volta, Los Straitjackets, Accentus, Leonard Bernstein and a few others I can't think of right now. Free stuff is fun! I also caught a film Saturday night with a co-worker. We saw urlLink "Shattered Glass," a great little true story indie film about Stephen Glass, a young writer for the New Republic who comes under fire after he's suspected of fabricating stories. Hayden Christiansen, aka Young Darth Vader, plays the charismatic young crook with amazing believability and the film captures the politics of journalism better than anything I've seen since urlLink "All the President's Men." Highly recommended.

the dream I had a very vivid, emotional, and rather sad dream last night. For some reason, the dream reminded me a lot of the film urlLink "Far From Heaven," perhaps because it deals with social repression in 1950s suburbia. In the dream, I'm the young son (probably about 12 years old) of a businessman and his bored housewife, again, sometime in the late 1950s. One day -- I forget exactly how it happens -- the housewife (my mom) meets some sort of military officer and they begin to have a relationship. I know about the relationship, but I don't blow mom's cover because she seems to really love this guy and dad doesn't seem to give her the time of day. One evening, dad comes home early and unexpectedly, so the "boyfriend" (who's at our house at the time) is introduced as an aquaintance, nothing more. This doesn't seem to faze dad, even when the lipstick on the boyfriend's shirt is lamely explained away as "ketchup." Boyfriend then excuses himself, saying that he must catch a transport back to his base (somewhere in Asia, I think). Mom is sad because she's not able to say goodbye "properly," since dad is standing right there. Once the boyfriend is gone, dad suggests the three of us go out to dinner. After dinner, we return home, where mom seems to be in better spirits about the situation in general. Just as we get ready to settle in for the night, The doorbell rings. It's some sort of detective (or FBI agent or something). He asks us if we know the officer/boyfriend (he says the guy's name, but I honestly don't remember it). My mom says yes, but is close to tears because she knows the news can't be good. The detective said that he found our home through the boyfriend's phone records and was sorry to have to tell us that our friend's plane crashed over the Pacific Ocean. Mom faints. The detective starts crying because he knew the man personally. Then I woke up. This dream has stuck with me for the past five hours (when I woke up), probably because it was so clear to me, and because it didn't really seem too far-fetched. This is a story that could actually happen. I don't know about you, but normally my dreams are somewhere in urlLink David Lynch mode -- what little I can actually remember doesn't make a whole lot of sense. But this one was very sad and very clear.

oscar blathering The 2003 Oscar nominations were announced earlier this week, and apart from a few of the usual gripes, I'm pretty happy with the variety of big names and little indies that could. All in all, a pretty eclectic bunch of films. Roger Ebert wrote a great little urlLink article that, in many ways, sums up my feelings about this year's nominees. Having said that, here's a few of my complaints: Paul Giamatti was not nominated for best actor in "American Splendor." Huh? I don't get it. Critics were practically guaranteeing him a nomination when the film was released last fall. And with good reason: he was damn good. A friend of mine pointed out that Giamatti is still known primarily as a character actor, and a best actor nomination is a bit too much of a leap at this point. But as long as he keeps acting this good in films of this quality, he should have no problems being recognized by the academy sometime in the future ("American Splendor," by the way, comes out on DVD next Tuesday. I highly recommend you rent it as soon as possible). Audrey Tautou was another glaring omission, as far as I'm concerned. Her performance as a troubled illegal immigrant in London was one of the best things about the fantastic (but little-seen) "Dirty Pretty Things." Of course, I don't know a whole lot of other people who saw this movie, which makes commiserating about it equally frustrating. Stephen Frears' gritty film about black market organ donation in the sleazy back streets of London was one of this year's hidden gems. Lots of critical acclaim, but no nominations, except for a well-deserved one for original screenplay. I've singled out Tautou because she not only managed to avoid being stereotyped as a cute, dimply French waitress (as she played in "Amelie"), but she also pulled off the unique task of being French and speaking English with a Turkish accent. Let's see some of you try that. Val Kilmer in "Wonderland." Once again, this is a movie nobody (but me) saw. And actually, the critics weren't particularly kind to it. One thing that did stand out (even with the critics) was Kilmer's sublime performance as strung-out porn star John Holmes in this true story of a drug deal that turns into a bloodbath in the Hollywood hills. As he continues to step away from mainstream roles, Kilmer is proving time and time again that he's a force to be reckoned with. Peter Sarsgaard in "Shattered Glass." There was some Oscar buzz about this role, but nothing came of it. Pity. Sarsgaard played the boss of Stephen Glass in this true story about a reporter who fabricates stories while writing for the New Republic. His performance was perfectly understated, at first trusting and standing by his young protege and slowly losing faith in the reporter as evidence piles up against him. It would have been nice to see recognition for this kind of role when most Oscar nominations seem reserved for hysterical, over-the-top scenery chewing. Albert Finney in "Big Fish." Finney's been nominated more times than I care to look up, but has never taken home the Oscar. He's one of today's most versatile elder statesmen. He can play an eccentric Belgian sleuth, a tough-as-nails mobster, or a self-defeating alcoholic ("Murder on the Orient Express," "Miller's Crossing," "Under the Volcano," respectively) but can't seem to take home the ultimate statue. His performance as the dying storyteller in Tim Burton's beautiful fantasy epic was, in my opinion, one of his finest in a long line of excellent roles. My predictions? I'm working on it. When I know, you'll know.

The closest I ever came to anything slightly more high-tech than that was when the broadcasting facility in Iceland (where I spent three-and-a-half glorious years) acquired an ACE 25 video production center, which I didn't get to use very much, since it was mainly a tool of our newly minted "video production department" (basically Peter Watson and urlLink Terry Welch producing some very clever PSAs that perpetuated their reputation as rebellious geniuses). At any rate, the point is that I'm learning this thing virtually by myself, which can be frustrating, but whenever I cross a hurdle and am able to accomplish a particularly tricky feat, the feeling is pretty nice.
