music update Picked up two excellent CDs over the weekend. First, in the continuing effort to rebuild my Miles Davis collection following my 2001 burglary, I finally re-purchased the lovely reissue of urlLink "Sketches of Spain." This album bothered me quite a bit when I first bought it in 1993. In the early nineties, I began a healthy obsession with jazz, and enjoyed other Miles albums like "Kind of Blue" and "Round About Midnight." But "Sketches of Spain threw me for a loop. This can be a tough album to love. It's dissonant, slow, and not exactly the improvisational hard bop that was Miles' bread and butter in the forties and fifties. Collaborating once again with legendary arranger Gil Evans, "Sketches" shows Miles embracing a heavily orchestrated, Spanish-flavored sound. I wouldn't even characterize this as a jazz album. It sounds more like a classical film score. It took me several years (around 2000 or 2001, I think) before I really sat down and gave it a hard listen. What it lacks in the more familiar jazz sounds it more than makes up for with a lush, truly original feel. A new series entitled "Under the Influence" began surfacing last year that has me very interested. Each volume is a collection of favorite songs and influences by a particular artist. Previous releases included collections from Morrissey and former Stone Roses vocalist Ian Brown. Earlier this month, the Paul Weller urlLink "Under the Influence" disc was released, and of course I had to buy it. One thing I've always known about Weller was reinforced by the track list of this collection -- the man has impeccable, not to mention eclectic, taste in music. The whole thing starts with Little Richard's "Slippin' and Slidin'" and includes experimental jazz (Charles Mingus' "Passions of a Man," John Coltrane's "Ole"), reggae (the Wailers' "Small Axe," Big Youth's "Hit the Road Jack," John Holt's "Ali Baba"), obscure sixties pop (the Kinks' "Big Black Smoke," the Casuals' gorgeous "Jesamine") contemporary funk and hip-hop (D'Angelo's "Devil's Pie" and Funkdoobiest's "Doobie to the Head") and much more. It's as if Paul Weller made a mix tape for you. Oh, and there's liner notes from the man himself. I hope they continue this series, but Weller's collection will be hard to top.

book update One of my goals this year is to get back to reading more books. Right now I'm in a bit of a mystery streak. Last week I finished urlLink "Noise Abatement," a thriller by a Scottish author named Carol Anne Davis, about a young couple who are deprived of sleep and sanity by their upstairs neighbors from hell, and decide to take matters into their own hands. The book was pretty enjoyable, but the ending was depressing as hell. Monday night I started reading urlLink "The Conspiracy Club" by Jonathan Kellerman and I really love it. I'm really not sure where the book is headed at this point (I'm on page 76), but that's a good thing. I feel that movies and books are best enjoyed when you have no idea what the hell is going on (which is why I tend to avoid those spoiler-heavy Amazon reader reviews). I've read three Kellerman books in the past ("The Web," "The Clinic" and "Bad Love") and they were all very good.

life after phoenix: back in my town What a busy week. Not on this blog, of course. I'm sure you've seen the tumbleweeds passing through here from time to time. Liza and I returned from Phoenix late Monday night -- two hours later than originally scheduled, in fact. Our flight landed at 12:30 am, but our baggage was among the first pieces to tumble onto the carousel, followed by a hop, skip and jump to the taxi stand and the next thing you know -- we're home in bed by 1 am. Not bad at all. Wednesday saw Liza -- with the help of a hastily rented U-Haul -- move into her new apartment virtually by herself (I couldn't get any more time off work). That night I helped her cart several thousand boxes from the building's stairwell into her fourth floor apartment. It's a bit tiny and kind of old, but it's in Boston's lovely North End. Those of you from out of town who are unfamiliar with this particular neighborhood -- it's a quaint, very Italian section of Boston with tons of great restaurants, a great urlLink comedy club (where Liza works part-time) and easy access to most of downtown Boston (including Liza's urlLink school ). It's also a bit of a tourist trap -- you can tell the tourists pretty easily from the locals, though. They're the ones clutching the urlLink Mike's Pastry boxes. Over the last couple of days I've been busy at my urlLink real job, working on a media highlights video for a trustee meeting. Unfortunately, I'm using urlLink Adobe Premiere Pro, which is a great system...if I only knew what the hell I was doing. I'm learning, though. Slowly. I guess I can't be a Boston blogger without an obligatory post about our recent cold weather. But I share urlLink Stacey's attitude: buck up and deal with it. It's New England. I really wish our local TV newscasters would stop spending so much damn time talking about how cold it is. We know it's cold. It's winter time. Put on a hat, scarf and glvoes and live your life already. Cool CD purchases of the week: Frank Zappa's urlLink "Grand Wazoo" (an album I've heard many, many times, courtesy of my brother's vinyl copy, but never owned until this week -- probably my favorite of his jazz-oriented stuff) and urlLink "Blackberry Belle," the latest from the Twilight Singers (former Afghan Whigs frontman Greg Dulli's newest band -- dark and funky). Both highly recommended. Enjoy your three-day weekend.

revelations in the desert It's now day four-and-a-half of my latest Arizona vacation. A little less than 48 hours left. It's really amazing how much my stress level drops when I'm here. I realize that at least some of that has to do with the fact that I'm not working when I'm here, but I still contend that the lack of urban congestion and stressed-out city life is to blame as well. Liza and I both tend to get conflicted about our suburban feelings whenever we're here. Read my July 1, 2003 blog entry, "The Confused Urbanite," for more details on that subject. Don't get me wrong, I love the city. I always have. I even love the cold, crappy weather out there. But warm suburbia certainly has its advantages as well. Am I just getting old? I don't know.

an update from phoenix, if you're interested Yesterday was our first full day in Phoenix since Liza and I arrived here for our vacation. giving away the plot Good morning, loyal readers (and the not-so-loyal ones). Liza and I have been in Phoenix since late last night. A long day of packing and flying was capped off (rather nicely, I must say), by a brief dip in her parents' jaccuzzi. As much as I hate flying, being out here is certainly worth the trip. I've been in Phoenix in January before (three years ago), and I guess I forgot that it wasn't going to be as hot as usual. It's 8:30 in the morning and the temperature is a brisk 48 degrees. Still, it beats the deep-freeze that Boston is getting ready to experience. I haven't been buying a whole lot of music lately, what with my rent due last week and the aftermath of Christmas putting a slight hold on extracurricular purchases. But I have attempted some sort of New Year's resolution when it comes to books: I'm going to read more of them. A long time ago (before I put a television set in my bedroom), I read a lot of books. Mostly fiction, nothing terribly challenging, but I enjoyed -- and still enjoy -- the simple pleasures of plowing through a good story. Over the last couple of years, instead of making specific resolutions, I basically tell myself that I am going to treat myself better, mentally and physically. I can treat my body better by doing more exercise, and I can give the brain a good workout by reading more books. Less time in front of the television and more time reading. Listen to me, berating myself. It's official. I've become my own parent. Anyhoo, last weekend Liza and I made a brief stop at urlLink McIntyre & Moore, a great, huge used bookstore in Porter Square, and while I wasn't planning on buying anything, I caved and picked up urlLink "Noise Abatement," a mystery by a Scottish writer named Carol Anne Davis. It's a great little story about a young couple who are sleep-deprived by upstairs neighbors from hell and decide to take matters into their own hands. Fun! I also managed to get my hands on John Irving's urlLink "The Water-Method Man," which I was inspired to pick up after Liza started reading Irving's urlLink "A Widow For One Year" (a choice influenced by her mother, a big John Irving fan). Once I'm finished with "Noise Abatement," I'll give John a try, since I really need to expand my literary horizons beyond mysteries and books by Nick Hornby and Jay McInerney. Speaking of mysteries, I finally finished urlLink "Mission Flats," which I've been reading off and on for almost a month. Not that it wasn't a good book -- I quite liked it -- but again, I'm having problems carving out reading time for myself. It's quite an easy task to accomplish, really -- just turn off the damn TV once in a while. "Mission Flats" will inevitably draw comparisons to urlLink "Mystic River," since they're both about murders in Boston. Well, actually, the murder in "Mission Flats" takes place in Maine, with the ensuing investigation taking place in Boston. Whatever. If you like "Mystic River," there's a good chance you'll like this one too. All this pontificating is making me hungry. It's breakfast time.

in your ear 2004 is starting out pretty strangely for me -- yesterday morning I woke up with my right ear all blocked up and it won't go away. How strange is that? It's as if my right ear needs to "pop," but won't. I'd love to go to the doctor, but my "doctor" situation is a little confusing right now: I had a primary care provider at a hospital in Malden (where I used to live), but in the nearly two years since I've been to the doctor, I've moved and Malden is hardly convenient for me. So I need to find a new provider, preferably in closer proximity to where I work. That all takes paperwork and phone calls to people who are probably still on vacation. In the meantime, Liza has reassured me that it's probably just "fluid that needs to come out." That's all well and good, but how is this fluid planning on making its exit? My guess is, it will come out when it's good and ready. In the meantime, could you please speak up? listening and reading In my last post (three days ago), I indicated that this week was starting out quite nicely. Well, it hasn't necessarily turned into a bad week...just a boring one. Seriously. Nothing's going on right now. Some boring work stuff, but nothing to write about. Literally. Those of you who follow my unusually out-of-character obsession with 70s urlLink prog rock will be happy to know that I purchased one of the three new urlLink Yes reissues that came out this week. The latest in urlLink Rhino's reissue batch are urlLink "Tormato," urlLink "Drama" and urlLink "90125." I haven't heard "Tormato" since my brother bought it about 25 years ago, but I've yet to hear anything positive about it. "90125" was mildly interesting when it was released back in 1983, but it sounds laughably dated today. So I picked up "Drama," which is an unusual release in that it's the only Yes album that doesn't feature Jon Anderson on vocals (he was temporarily replaced by former Buggles vocalist Trevor Horn on this 1980 album). The songs sound a lot like what you would expect from Yes -- there's a few long numbers, like the dark, almost King Crimson-esque "Machine Messiah" -- in addition to some shorter, more pop-oriented stuff that shows them leaning toward the "90125" sound of that would follow three years later, but still quite listenable. The bonus tracks feature some interesting instrumental noodling and single edits, in addition to some demos that were recorded in Paris just before Anderson and keyboard player Rick Wakeman jumped ship. It's a good thing these songs were never completed, because they sound pretty horrible. Still, good for a laugh. Although I found a lot to like about it, I eventually ditched David Mitchell's urlLink "Ghostwritten" last night since it was taking me an infuriatingly long time to finish. I decided instead to read some brain candy thriller stuff for a little while, so I started Brad Meltzer's urlLink "The Zero Game," (I snagged a free copy of at Borders a couple of months ago). By the way, has anyone read Chuck Klosterman's urlLink "Sex, Drugs and Cocoa Puffs," the follow-up to his brilliant urlLink "Fargo Rock City?" I'm thinking of reading that next.

...and they put him in a suit of lights So far, this is turning out to be quite a nice week. Why? Last night I got a voicemail message from my sister Julie, who asked me if I was interesting in seeing Elvis. The first time I saw him, in April 1987, it was a solo acoustic college tour (with the amazing urlLink Nick Lowe opening up); in June 1999 I saw him at Suffolk Downs as the headliner for the Guinness Fleadh Festival, accompanied by pianist Steve Nieve; last July I caught him at the Fleet Pavillon with "The Imposters," which is basically the Attractions with Davey Faragher replacing Bruce Thomas on bass. This time around, Elvis will be once again joined by Nieve, along with the urlLink Brodsky Quartet, who collaborated with Elvis on his 1993 album urlLink "The Juliet Letters." Judging by the classy instrumentation, it seems as if the focus will be on his latest album, last year's "North," which you can listen to here: urlLink And that's fine with me. "North" is a beautiful album, and the swanky Wang Center is just the place. Am I happy? You bet your ass I am.

the hurt and the anger and the joy of the pain Having a horrible song stuck in your head can be an infuriating thing. But having a really good song in there -- which doesn't happen nearly as often -- can be wonderful, like your head is tuned into some cool radio station programmed just for you. Ever since about 8 a.m., I've had "Black Coffee in Bed" by urlLink Squeeze stuck in my head, and it's had such a nice effect on my day that I've even used the song's title as my latest "blog tag." It all started this morning, on my way to work, when I decided to put Squeeze's excellent greatest hits disc, urlLink "Singles: 45s and Under," on my Walkman. I realized once again how incredible this selection of songs really is, how much I love Squeeze, and how indelibly this album changed my musical tastes in the summer of 1985. "Singles..." is a great introduction to Squeeze, but please don't stop there. "East Side Story" is a fantastic album (produced by Elvis Costello) and it includes not only the famous "Tempted," but 13 more terrific songs as well (15 more if you buy the import reissue version). Have a spiffy weekend.

a note to the mutiplex crowd I try not to become addicted to prime time TV shows. I only watch a couple of them, and I think that's more than enough. Lately, however, I've become a fan of urlLink "CSI: Miami," a rather well-written show, despite its annoying tendency to be too superficially slick for its own good (which is why I love urlLink "Law & Order" -- no frills, just tell me the story). I also love David Caruso's quirky character, with all the weird speech inflections ("this...is NOT an ACCIDENT..."). But anyway, I was watching it last night and the Caruso character made a reference to urlLink "Blowup," Michelangelo Antonioni's 1966 cinematic masterpiece. Predictably, one of Caruso's pretty-boy technicians shrugged and mumbled, "never heard of it." AAAARRRGGHHH!! Once again, I must vent my frustration at how little attention today's moviegoer pays to our celluloid past. I can understand, maybe, if you've never seen this movie. But never even heard of it? Meanwhile, "50 First Dates" continues to break box-office records. I normally don't care for movie reviews that take the form of "fake" letters to the editor or "imaginary" interviews with the film's star or director (neither does Tom at unproductivity.com -- his outrage at Pitchfork Media's condescending review of Metallica's "St. Anger" prompted some of the urlLink his best blogging moments ). I will make an exception in the case of dvdjournal.com's recent urlLink review of "Blowup" (which is being released on DVD today for the very first time). Read and enjoy. Then go buy the damn thing. confessions of a former expatriate Yesterday was the five-year anniversary of my return to Boston, after three years in Italy, eighteen months in Virginia and seven years in the navy. Prior to that, I spent my high school years in Florida. So my return to civilian life in the city of my birth, while without fanfare or ticker-tape parades, was a big deal to me. I was both excited and terrified at the prospect of being completely independent, having to find a job and an apartment virtually by myself (with some valuable help from my family, of course), without the navy footing any of the bill (my years in Italy were "civil service" and I spent a small part of them still married to a military member -- I was also a "navy wife," so to speak, while in Virginia). After some rocky starts, I think things have worked out quite nicely. I have one and a half decent jobs, a wonderful girlfriend whom I love very very much, and although I no longer have the shithole Malden apartment to myself, I am sharing a rather comfortable apartment with a co-worker. Five years, lots of changes. I wonder what I'll be up to in 2009.

jack, diane and the architect Two more movies were crossed off the list over the weekend. Sunday night, after realizing that the last two movies we saw ("Monster" and "21 Grams") were thoroughly depressing (yet very good), Liza and I -- in the spirit of "Valentine's Weekend" -- caught urlLink "Something's Gotta Give." The film does in fact fit into my "February Oscar Marathon" criteria, since Diane Keaton was nominated for Best Actress. Did I like the film? Sure, it was fun and I laughed a lot. Did Diane Keaton deserve the nomination? I think so, although I doubt she's going to beat Charlize Theron. I'm probably preaching to the choir here, but the film did little to sway my belief that Keanu Reeves can't act, although he was playing a bit of an airhead, so I guess you could say he was good for the part. Yesterday afternoon, Liza attended a meeting at school to discuss a project, so I headed to the wonderful urlLink Kendall Square Cinema to see a wonderful film: urlLink "My Architect." See this film. Trust me. It's amazing. It's a documentary about Louis Kahn, an eccentric architect who died of a heart attack in 1974. Besides leaving a wife, he also left two mistresses with whom he fathered a child apiece. One of these children, Nathaniel Kahn, decided to make a film about his long-lost father and in the process, learned a lot about this unusual and elusive man. Many of his interview subjects -- co-workers, employees, family members, fellow architects -- are not shy about expressing their contempt for this oddball curmudgeon, but they almost all agree that he was a groundbreaking genius. Nathaniel ends up with a reverent yet realistic portrait of his father. Deep-six the blockbuster crowd and treat yourself to this simple yet winning film.

not exactly family films Over the weekend, Liza and I continued our quest to see as many of the Oscar-nominated films as possible by checking out urlLink "Monster" and urlLink "21 Grams." Severe depression, anyone? The major buzz around "Monster" is Charlize Theron's blistering, Oscar-nominated, typcast-crushing role as hooker-cum-serial killer Aileen Watrous. It's no hype, folks. Not only is Theron visually transformed into a white-trash, bottom-feeder Florida highway hooker, her acting is sublime. All nervous ticks and amped-up desperation, she quite simply is this woman. Hopefully, Theron will now be able to get parts that require her to act instead of just standing in front of the camera looking pretty. This is a disturbing film. I was expecting some brutal realism, but not nearly what I eventually got. There's a particularly shocking rape scene, but apart from that, what really tore me up was the fact that Watrous and her young lesbian lover, Selby (played by Christina Ricci) were so out-of-touch and naive as to assume that with a few pilfered bucks in their pockets, they could escape "the life" and infiltrate suburbia, their white-picket-fence dreams fully realized. When Aileen -- dressed in an outfit that a thrift store would probably turn down -- sits down for a law firm secretary job interview ("I know how ta operate a Rolodex," she explains), you just have to feel sorry for her. Well, until she starts killing people non-stop. "21 Grams" was disturbing on a different level. While "Monster" was more of a character study, this film had elements of a thriller. Directed by Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu ( urlLink "Amores Perros" ), the film takes its sequences and jumbles them up like jigsaw puzzle pieces (not unlike urlLink "Memento" ), and figuring out where the pieces fit is half the fun (although it's hardly a "joyful" experience). Eventually, the pieces start to make sense and as the story unfolds. It sounds like a gimmick -- and indeed, some critics have complained as such -- but you can't deny that it's an interesting way to keep the audience's attention. The story revolves around three central characters -- a math professor and heart transplant recipient (Sean Penn), a woman (Naomi Watts) whose husband and two children are hit by a car, and an ex-con born-again Christian (Benicio Del Toro). A car accident brings these three very different people together, then splits them up, and are reunited again through revenge. Watts and Del Toro were nominated for Oscars, and while I thought Watts was very good and Del Toro his usual amazing self, I was disappointed that Penn's performance wasn't given a nomination as well. I realize that his (admittedly excellent) turn as a tortured, grieving father in urlLink "Mystic River" is more up Oscar's alley, but in "21 Grams" he was understated, and that's what really got my attention. I find it refreshing that the dude who played Jeff Spicoli in urlLink "Fast Times at Ridgemont High" is turning in brilliant, cathartic roles 20 years later.

curled up like invertebrates A couple of weeks ago I hit the jackpot in the free promo department at urlLink my part-time job with a copy of the latest John Wesley Harding album, urlLink "Adam's Apple" (thanks, Dave!). The album, which will be released Feb. 17, is the long-awaited follow-up to 2000's brilliant urlLink "Confessions of St. Ace." The new one was a bit disappointing when I first listened to it, but I spent a good deal of time reexamining it on the Walkman over the weekend (particularly during my Saturday afternoon excursion out to the urlLink Garment District, which, fine vintage clothing store that it is, still couldn't provide me with the pair of red pants I so desperately needed -- red pants? More on that later...). I initially found myself constantly comparing the album to "Confessions..." and was put off by the fact that the quality of the songs on "Adam's Apple" just didn't match up to its predecessor. I still feel that way, to some degree, but the songs have definitely grown on me, to the point where I find it a highly enjoyable album (but not to the extent of AllMusic Guide critic John D. Luerssen, who called it "the finest album of his career" -- in my opinion, that distinction belongs to 1989's urlLink "Here Comes the Groom" ). I will agree, however, with Luerssen's assessment that it contains some of Wes' best singing to date. His voice is strong and confident, and is perfectly suited to the album's sterling production and performances. Favorite songs so far? "Nothing at All" is a slice of Beatlesque heaven. "Sussex Ghost Story" (a collaboration with classical composer Gavin Bryars)is just as haunting and beautiful as its title suggests. "Sluts" is a hilarious, funky ode to the Beautiful People. "She Never Talks" not only rocks out with some excellent guitar riffing, it's also the only song I've ever heard that makes a reference to urlLink "Die Fledermaus." And so on. I guess I have more favorite songs on this new album than I initially thought. Anyway, it comes out in eight days. Please buy it. And if Wes ever goes on tour, try to see him in concert. He's a talented singer and musician who also happens to be funny as hell.

payday I got paid yesterday (and today...having two jobs can be very rewarding), and after last week's rent check rendering me broke for several days, I decided to celebrate with some Borders purchases. Yay cashflow! Here's the skinny: Echo and the Bunnymen: urlLink "Ocean Rain" I'm not a huge fan of Echo's entire output...as eighties British college rock goes, it's pretty good, but not as good as, say, the Smiths or New Order. But "Ocean Rain" (first released in 1984) is a flat-out masterpiece, as far as I'm concerned. I think I first bought the CD in 1990 or '91 and I'd have to say that it would rest comfortably in my list of top twenty favorite albums of all time. What makes it so wonderful: first of all, the songwriting. The band manages to craft a creepy, gothic Joy Division-meets-the Cure sound, while incorporating soaring melodies and delicious hooks. Also, the production: acoustic guitars meld with tasteful strings, and Ian McCullogh's lovely, world-weary voice -- all echoey and somber -- come together to create a unique, haunting sound. This is an amazing album. Rhino has rereleased this album (in addition to the rest of the Echo catalog) with several bonus tracks, mostly live and radio station recordings. If you like the Smiths but are put off by Morrissey's self-loathing, you should check this out. Harry Nilsson: urlLink "Nilsson Schmilsson" I became enamored of this album when I was about 11 years old. My Uncle Bobby and Aunt Linda owned this on vinyl and whenever my mother and I would visit their house in Stoneham, I would head down to the finished basement to watch TV and pore over their record collection. I probably just listened to "Jump Into the Fire" over and over, but I'm not sure. Nilsson was a singer-songwriter who gained a reputation for a variety of things: being named John Lennon and Paul McCartney's favorite songwriter during a Beatles press conference in the late sixties; being Lennon's drinking and carousing companion during the late Beatle's separation from Yoko; hitting number one on the pop charts with a cover of Badfinger's "Without You" (later decimated by Mariah Carey); and scoring an odd novelty cult hit with the song "Coconut," later repopularized by its inclusion on the "Reservoir Dogs" soundtrack (the aforemtioned "Jump Into the Fire" was also used to great effect in the soundtrack of "Goodfellas," during the scene when coked-up Ray Liotta's car is being chased by helicopters). One of the critical and commercial highlights of Nilsson's career was the 1971 album "Nilsson Schmilsson," which includes all the songs mentioned in the above paragraph, in addition to some wonderful R&B covers ("Early in the Morning," "Let the Good Times Roll") and lots of examples of Nilsson's classic songwriting and beautiful voice. The fact that he caught the attention of the Fab Four is not surprising when you hear the Beatlesque flourishes in much of the melodies. I also hear a strong Randy Newman influence, particularly in the strings and heavy dependence on piano. The CD was reissued this month with lots of liner notes and a healthy selection of bonus tracks (including an odd Spanish-language version of "Without You"). Carter Burwell, urlLink "Fargo/Barton Fink (soundtracks)" There are many reasons why I love the films of Joel and Ethan Coen, and one of them is the scores. Coen regular Carter Burwell has composed the music for most of their films, crafting haunting cues for their quirky noir tales. Two of the best scores are included in this collection. Burwell doesn't feel the need to include swelling, bloated orchestral sweeps every thirty seconds and I appreciate that. There's a heavy emphasis on dark, brooding strings. By the way, if you buy this and like it, I wholeheartedly recommend Burwell's soundtrack to the Coen's "The Man Who Wasn't There," which also includes excerpts from Beethoven piano sonatas. urlLink "American Splendor" While "Lost in Translation" was rightfully hailed by nearly every critic under the sun as the best film of 2003, this quirky gem was unfairly brushed aside, particularly in the Oscar nominations. The true story of comic book writer and oddball legend Harvey Pekar, "American Splendor" tells the tale of this grumpy-but-lovable file clerk who befriends legendary comic artist Robert Crumb, begins writing the seminal comics that Crumb would illustrate, and meets a motley crew of fellow oddballs through his life's journey. Interspersed within the film are testimonials from the real Pekar (and his wife), in addition to some enjoyable animation sequences. Pekar may not be warm and fuzzy (at least on the outside), but this is one warm and completely winning film. Paul Giamatti is absolutely brilliant as Pekar, and I was stunned that he wasn't nominated for an Oscar (but the film's screenplay got a nod, which is nice).

bach versus britney Anthony Tommasini wrote an insightful piece in yesterday's New York Times called urlLink "No Requiem for Classical CD's, Please," wherein he bemoaned the current state of classical music sales in this age of music downloading and cultural apathy. Not only is classical music another victim of the Internet, it's also facing heavy competition from more popular music forms, particularly from a financial standpoint. One point in particular stood out for me: "In the glory decades artists like Arthur Rubinstein and George Szell made big money from their recordings. Today, with the exceptions of a handful of stars, most artists understand that recordings will not make them a living. It is hard to speak of classical and pop recordings as the same industry. A violin recital album that sold 5,000 to 10,000 copies over three to five years would be considered a solid success. Sales of 50,000 would be considered extraordinary. By contrast EMI paid $28 million just to buy out Mariah Carey's contract in 2002." Who's to blame here? A lot of people, quite frankly. Our schools aren't properly funded for music appreciation programs, which are all but extinct. Nobody seems to care that children are virtually oblivious to classical music, yet MTV shoves Kid Rock, Justin Timberlake, 50 Cent, Janet Jackson and her nipple down their throats. Consequently, a variety of musical styles is failing to reach kids. Today's marketing geniuses are horribly wrongheaded, in my opinion, when it comes to selling the concept of classical music. It seems to me they feel that it should appeal to the lowest common denominator. Instead of showcasing slightly more obscure, challenging works by both modern composers and the centuries-old ones, labels like Decca and RCA are putting out moronic, pandering, condescending collections like "Classical Music for People Who Hate Classical Music" and "Midnight Adagios," poor, simpering excuses for a sublime art form that deserves far better. These compilations invariably include the same pile of overplayed classics: Mozart's "Eine Kleine Nachtmusik," Beethoven's "Fifth Symphony," Pachelbel's "Canon," Wagner's "Flight of the Valkyries," and of course, that old warhorse of the Victoria's Secret changing room, Vivaldi's "Four Seasons." How can you expect people to embrace this music if you're only showing them a small, overexposed portion of it? Classical music goes back (at least) to the 12th century. How can you expect the average music listener to look beyond the relatively mediocre talents of Andrea Bocelli when nobody else seems to have his advertising budget? (It should be stated, however, that there are several labels still doing it right. ECM, Nonesuch, and the venerable Deutsche Grammaphon - among others - continue to put out quality product. You generally can't go wrong with 99 percent of the discs released by these labels. And while there are many classical budget labels out there whose quality is questionable, the Naxos budget brand is almost always of the best possible quality, ideal for classical fans looking to save some money). Back to music appreciation...I spent grades one through four in an English-speaking school outside of Paris (named, strangely enough, urlLink the American School of Paris ). Some of the best times I had in that school were in music class. Our teacher was a young music freak named Chris Chater (he now runs the school's website). Mr. Chater didn't just ramble on in a monotone voice in front of a chalkboard about the virtues of Debussy. He got us excited about the music, in a hands-on way. On any given day, he would bring out a particular instrument and let us all take turns trying it out. We sang songs, read music, and even participated in a musical that Mr. Chater wrote himself. I consider Chris Chater one of the dozen most important people in my childhood because he helped me appreciate music, a trait I carry with me to this very day. Variety is indeed the spice of life. Don't let a thousand years of musical variety pass you by.

my oscar predictions As a self-confessed, unabashed Oscar freak (who hates all other awards shows, I must point out), I feel it's my duty to give you my predictions for this year's ceremony. I was originally going to wait until later in the month to form my opinions, but I doubt my mind is going to change about any of these. It seems to me there's a lot of "sure things" this year, although I'm sure there will be at least one major upset (there always is -- last year it was Adrien Brody winning best actor over heavily favored Daniel Day-Lewis, and the year before that, Jim Broadbent took home best supporting actor when everyone thought that Ian McKellan would win, etc etc), but this is as good as it's going to get in my mind. Two things: first of all, I'm going to tell you who I think should win (keeping in mind my own personal tastes), in addition to who will win (keeping in mind the history of Oscar voting). Second, I'm going to only give predictions for the top six categories. All due respect to the technical folks, I could care less who wins best sound or best costume design. Best Picture: Lord of the Rings: Return of the King Lost in Translation Master and Commander: the Far Side of the World Mystic River Seabiscuit "Lord of the Rings" was a gargantuan epic that won over critics and audiences alike. The best picture Oscar usually goes to an epic film and this is as epic as it gets. "Master and Commander" has an epic quality and received rave reviews, but "Lord of the Rings" simply overshadowed it. "Lost in Translation" was my favorite film of 2003, and the Academy has shown uncharacteristic taste this year in nominating lots of smaller, quirker films, but let's not kid ourselves. This ain't Sundance. "Mystic River" is probably the closest thing to serious competition that "Lord" has in this category, and I won't be too surprised if it in fact wins, but "Lord" is a steamroller that will not be stopped. Oh, and as far as "Seabiscuit" goes, the fact that this is the film's only major nomination is a bad sign. Who will win: "Lord of the Rings: Return of the King" Who should win: "Lost in Translation" Best Actor: Johnny Depp, "Pirates of the Caribbean: the Curse of the Black Pearl" Ben Kingsley, "The House of Sand and Fog" Jude Law, "Cold Mountain" Bill Murray, "Lost in Translation" Sean Penn, "Mystic River" It's nice to see Depp -- a terrific actor -- get a nomination, and seeing the Academy nominate such an offbeat, comedic part is a nice surprise. But let's face it: the Oscars are about dramas. Kingsley is a highly accomplished actor and a favorite with the Academy, but this film didn't get hugely positive reviews (he really deserved a best supporting actor award for "Sexy Beast" two years ago, which he didn't get). Law is getting lots of praise for "Cold Mountain," but it's not his time yet. It's really between Murray and Penn, who both won Golden Globes this year. As great as Murray was in "Lost in Translation," it was Penn who got slightly better reviews, he's been up for an Oscar a few times before, and "Mystic River" is a very dramatic, Oscar-friendly film. So the scales are tipped slightly in his favor. Who will win: Sean Penn Whould should win: Bill Murray Best Actress: Keisha Castle-Hughes, "Whale Rider" Diane Keaton, "Something's Gotta Give" Samantha Morton, "In America" Charlize Theron, "Monster" Naomi Watts, "21 Grams" She's one of the two dark horses in this category, but don't count out Castle-Hughes: the Academy loves to honor underage nominees (Tatum O'Neal, Anna Paquin). Still, she's in pretty heavy competition. Keaton wouldn't be a total shock, since the Academy loves her and everyone is cheering on the fact that a fiftysomething is being nominated in a romantic role. Morton is another dark horse, but may get swept up in the surprising wave of "In America" nominations. Watts is a highly regarded actor, but the fact of the matter is that everyone's predicting Theron will win and so do I. Seeing this gorgeous woman transformed into a battered, broken-down serial killer says a lot about Theron's talent and dedication to the role, and besides, actors who radically transform their appearance for a film have the edge. Ask Nicole Kidman and her schnozz in "The Hours." Who will win: Charlize Theron Who should win: Charlize Theron Best Supporting Actor: Alec Baldwin, "The Cooler" Benicio del Toro, "21 Grams" Djimon Hounsou, "In America" Tim Robbins, "Mystic River" Ken Watanabe, "The Last Samurai" I'd love to see Baldwin win; he was great in "The Cooler" and is just such a great actor, period. He may very well pull an upset. Del Toro's a great actor but he won an Oscar three years ago (for "Traffic") and if he does get another Oscar, it'll be further down the road. Hounsou is the dark horse here. Nobody saw this nomination coming and he most likely won't get the award. Watanabe has received great reviews, particularly for out-acting Tom Cruise, but "Mystic River" has gotten much more praise, particularly for the acting of Penn and Robbins. Who will win: Tim Robbins Who should win: Alec Baldwin Best Supporting Actress: Shohreh Aghdashloo, "The House of Sand and Fog" Patricia Clarkson, "Pieces of April" Marcia Gay Harden, "Mystic River" Holly Hunter, "thirteen" Renee Zellweger, "Cold Mountain" Aghdashloo is the dark horse here, and regardless of her performance, nobody's heard of her and that will definitely play against her. Clarkson is a critically acclaimed actress, but "Pieces of April" may be too quirky for the Academy, and most people felt that Clarkson should have been nominated for "The Station Agent" instead. Marcia Gay Harden. I just don't get her. I just don't think she's an Oscar-caliber actress. She won an Oscar for "Pollock" two years ago that I felt was totally undeserved (Ed Harris should have won the best actor Oscar that year for the same film, if you ask me). She was decent in "Mystic River," but was overshadowed by the other actors. I haven't seen "thirteen" yet, but a lot of people are disappointed that Hunter's co-star, Evan Rachel Wood, wasn't nominated. Hunter was probably nominated simply because she's Holly Hunter (also known as the Jack Nicholson/Meryl Streep Syndrome). That leaves Renee Zellweger. She's been nominated before (some people think she's been robbed in the past) and I think it's her year. Who will win: Renee Zellweger Who should win: Renee Zellweger Best Director: Fernando Meirelles, "City of God" Peter Jackson, "Lord of the Rings: Return of the King" Sofia Coppola, "Lost in Translation" Peter Weir, "Master and Commander: the Far Side of the World" Clint Eastwood, "Mystic River" Jackson is as close to a sure thing as you'll get here. He was snubbed for the two previous LOTR installments and I think everyone realizes what kind of superhuman ability it takes to put together a film of this caliber. "City of God" got excellent reviews but nobody saw it. Coppola -- the first American woman ever nominated in this category -- would have a chance if Jackson weren't in the running. Weir has been nominated a few times before and has never won, which would give him a nice career acheivement/sympathy vote (like Scorcese almost got least year), and everyone loves Eastwood. But all that is moot. Jackson will win. Bank on it.

the workers are going home... One of the coolest reissue programs in CD history is outdoing itself once again. Universal's two-disc Deluxe Edition Series has recently released a, you guessed it, two-disc deluxe edition reissue of the urlLink first Weezer album. Is this too cool for words or what? The "bonus disc" features some b-sides, live material and such that may be old news for die-hard fans, but I don't necessarily consider myself a die-hard "I must touch Rivers Cuomo's beard in order to live a complete life" kind of person. I think that Weezer are easily one of the best bands to come out of the nineties, and Cuomo is a power-pop songwriter of the highest order, but so far, I've only bought the standard releases, choosing to forgo CD singles, rare bootlegs, et al. So this reissue, once I get my hands on it (sooner rather than later), will be a welcome edition to my collection. I remember when the first Weezer album came out in 1994. I remember seeing videos for "Buddy Holly," "Undone (the Sweater Song)" and "Say It Ain't So" constantly (and laughing my ass off at the sheer brilliance of the "Buddy Holly" video). For some obscure reason, I put off buying this stellar collection of Ric Ocasek-produced tunes until the Spring of 1997. My wife and I split up in January of that year, and I spent the next year or two discovering bands I'd previously given the shaft during my marriage. Weezer was one of those bands. Listening to that album still brings back memories of my too-cool-for-words apartment in Naples that I shared with my friend Jeremy. Soon afterwards I bought Weezer's second album, "Pinkerton," which was initially doomed a sophmore slump until it reached fan-approved classic status to the point where most fans consider it their best. I remember driving through the hellacious Naples traffic in my beat-up 1982 Alfa Romeo Giulietta with "El Scorcho," "Getchoo," "The Good Life" and the rest of those darkly catchy songs embedding themselves into my musical consciousness. Subsequent Weezer albums have fared almost, if not equally as well with me. The long-awaited "Green Album" was simple and to the point -- without the darkness of "Pinkerton," but no less successful in my book. "Maladroit" was a return to some of the experimentalism of "Pinkerton," and it also contains "Dope Nose," which fits easily into my list of the Top Ten Catchiest Songs in Music History (if such a list existed).

the death of a legend A truly sad day in the history of cinema. Sir Peter Ustinov urlLink has left us. . In a world of hyperbole, exaggeration and undeserved kudos, Ustinov was the real deal. An actor's actor. In addition to his thespian accomplishments, he was also a gifted humanitarian (particularly for his tireless efforts on behalf of UNICEF). His acting, however, was what really gave him the well-deserved recognition. In addition to his two Oscars (for "Topkapi" and the incomperable "Spartacus"), he also received a screenplay nomination (for "Hot Millions") as well as an additional acting nomination (for "Quo Vadis"). It may not have gotten him official accolades in the form of Oscars, but his portrayal of Agatha Christie's Belgian sleuth, Hercule Poirot, in "Death on the Nile" and "Evil Under the Sun" were the perfect cinematic interpretation of both obsessive-compulsive behavior and high camp. Let's hope his headstone is marked with what he really wanted: "keep off the grass."

After a scrumptious meal at Anna's Taqueria, we headed to the Starbucks in Washington Square ("the greatest Starbucks ever," Suarez opines) and then trekked out to Suarez' lovely Brighton apartment, where a CD burning party was whipped into shape. It's better than shelling out money for a cab, but the train ended up sitting on the platform for about 30 minutes. A rather blah ending to an excellent evening. aerosmith's indie moment Right now as I type this, I have all the songs that I've imported onto Liza's iBook (for various compilations I've made over the past few weeks) playing in random. Total random. This makes for some rather awkward, yet positively eclectic transitions (Bach into Aerosmith has been my favorite so far), but it also provokes some interesting theories. For example, last week I made an Aerosmith mix, a bunch of their obscure seventies tracks ("Dream On" and "Walk This Way" were passed over in favor of "Somebody" and "Nobody's Fault," for instance). One of their most interesting and daring songs from that era was a Joe Perry composition called "Bright Light Fright," from their drug-addled 1977 album, "Draw the Line" ("days full of night" was how Steven Tyler described the making of that album on "Behind the Music"). Joe himself sings the song, and it's about two minutes long, lightning fast with a manic sax solo right in the middle. In the midst of bloated corporate rock, Aerosmith made a punk rock song. There's no other way to describe it. Boy, I love that song. And its punkness was validated once again as I heard it this afternoon, merged right into "Perfect Lines" by the Promise Ring. Wonderful transition. Unbeatable.

listen to the book Various posts and comments (on this and other blogs) by urlLink Dan, urlLink Heather and myself have prompted me to pose a unique question to the general population, particularly those of you who read a lot of books: if you listen to an unabridged audio book, can you tell someone in all honesty that you've "read the book?" Personally, I think you can. You've digested every word that's been printed (again, we're talking unabridged ), it just so happens that you listened to it (word for word) instead of read it. I, for one, went through a lengthy audiobook obsession in the mid-late nineties. From 1994 to 1995, I lived in Virginia Beach, and commuted by myself by car to my job at a TV station in downtown Norfolk -- about a 45-minute drive each way. I checked out unabridged audiobooks from the local library on a regular basis and it made my commute a hundred times more pleasant, particularly when sitting in traffic. Later, when living and working in Italy (1996-1999), I resumed this habit -- although a good chunk of that time was spent owning a beat-up, primer-red 1982 Alfa Romeo sedan with a beat-up boombox in the passenger seat serving as a tape deck. But it did the trick. One time I got a little obsessive -- I had an audiobook of "The Hunt For Red October" in my car and the printed book at home. I went back and forth between listening to the tapes in the car and reading the book at home. This may be one of the reasons my marriage didn't work out. Once again, I implore anyone looking into passing their commuting time by reading audio books to get unabridged versions -- they're a bit harder to find and more expensive, but definitely worth it. Also, since the price of these items tends to be a little on the expensive side (depending on the size of the book and the amount of CDs or tapes required), I would look into checking them out from your local library.

There's an occasional running gag on "Law & Order" where, whenever Briscoe and Green are chasing a fleeing suspect, Briscoe has to stop and catch his breath every once in a while. This is most likely played as a humorous aside, but the fact is, Orbach's pushing 70. Let's be realistic here. I'll always treasure his battle-scarred, been-there-done-that, twice-divorced wisenheimer character on my favorite TV show of all time, but he'll live on forever in syndication, and besides -- some fresh blood might be good for the show (the writing has faltered a bit over the past couple of seasons, and the SVU spin-off, in my opinion, has been excelling the original series in terms of general quality lately). the sickness update So here's the deal: I called in sick on Wednesday, then felt marginally better on Thursday morning, so I returned to work. What a mistake that was. I spent the rest of Thursday back to my old crappy self again, scarfing down Dayquil like it was Halloween candy and cursing my own overabundant snot. To make matters worse, work was extremely busy and I ignored my better instincts by actually heading to my part-time job at Borders instead of calling it a night at 4 p.m. A workaholic's work is never done. So I basically forced myself to call in sick again today. Which hasn't been so bad. Apart from the coughing and aforementioned omnipresent boogers, it's been a nice, relaxing day -- perfect for recuperation. Liza, angel that she is, brought over her iBook, so I spent the day burning CDs. I created three nifty compilations that I must say, I'm pretty proud of. The problem is, I have little to no food left in the house, so I imagine I'll have to brave the outdoors sometime soon and do some shopping. Sad news via CNN.com this morning: J.J. Jackson died of a heart attack. Those of you glued to MTV in its infancy -- as I was -- will recognize the name. J.J. was one of MTV's five initial veejays when the station first launched in 1981. Sure, all those guys -- including Mark Goodman, Alan Hunter, Nina Blackwood and Martha Quinn (my junior high school crush of the highest order) -- were supreme geeks, but they were around when MTV was doing what it was supposed to do: show music videos. And the cool thing about showing videos in those days was that few people were producing them, so a lot of bands who wouldn't get the time of day in 2004 were in heavy roation in the early 80s. It wasn't uncommon to turn on MTV in 1981 and see Elvis Costello, Graham Parker, Squeeze, Madness, Joe Jackson...hell, they even broadcast a Frank Zappa concert! They were probably "cutting edge" because there were few mainstream artists embracing this art form -- but at least it made for somewhat interesting television. Oh well. That was then, this is now.

sick I called in sick yesterday. I don't do that very often, I'm sort of paranoid that one day, I'll be laid up with a debilitating sickness that will require weeks of sick-time, so I'm really frugal about it. I've been at my current job for about three and a half years, and I believe that yesterday was the fourth or fifth time I've called in sick. I'm so boring. Anyhoo, I woke up Tuesday morning with a sore throat that made me feel like someone ripped out my tonsils. Things eventually got a little better, but I was still sick. I was warning people at work that I probably wouldn't be in the next day, which, come to think of it, doesn't look good. It sounds as if I'm planning some big all-day drinking binge and didn't want anyone to expect me at work. But let's assume nobody really did think that. the end of an era They were granted a "stay of execution" last year, but this time it's really going to happen: urlLink Avenue Victor Hugo Books is closing its doors for good in May. This wonderful used bookstore was originally planning to close last year, but found a new location (a few doors down from its original spot on Newbury Street). However, the loss of former customers who thought the store had closed at the end of 2002, compounded with an overall loss of business to chain stores, not to mention the changing shopping patterns on Newbury Street, made the store's continuing the struggle impossible. I realize it seems hypocritical for me, a part-time employee at a large bookstore chain, to mourn the loss of this fine establishment, but Avenue Victor Hugo Books is a wonderful place that recalls a former time when people did the unthinkable: browsed in bookstores. For hours. I remember one particular visit to AVH in January 2002: on a snowy Saturday afternoon, I wandered into the store and spent about an hour looking around their paperback mystery section, finding a book to purchase, spending the entire afternoon reading the book and even sitting in Pinocchio's in Harvard Square with it, scarfing down a slice of pizza before catching a Jimmy Smith concert at the House of Blues (okay, that was quite a tangent, but it proves a point: this place has some genuinely nice memories for me). Then there was the time after work last year that I headed over to the store to see, just out of curiosity, if they might have a copy of "666," an out-of-print horror book by Jay Anson (the author of "The Amityville Horror"), a book that I read (and was thoroughly scared to death by) at age 13. They had it. I bought it (and took it home, only finding it mildly scary and largely lame). At Borders, you can look up a book on a computer (okay, the software isn't perfect -- I realize that), you can listen to a CD on the listening stations, buy a cup of coffee, power up your laptop with our wireless Internet signal...but in a place like Avenue Victor Hugo, it's like a book freak's equivalent of mainlining their favorite drug: the pure pleasure of wandering through the stacks and soaking it all in. Starting April 1, AVH will be holding a 50% off sale, with further reductions to follow if necessary. Give them their last gasp of business. It's the least you can do. And if you still need your used bookstore jones fulfilled, there's always the slightly fancier-but-still authentic urlLink McIntyre and Moore in Davis Square in Somerville.

nice work if you can get it Working in the media relations department of a medical institute, our office receives a subscription to, among other things, the Journal of the American Medical Association (or JAMA). I don't normally read this publication, but as I was waiting to meet with a co-worker this afternoon, I began thumbing idly through the latest issue in our front desk reception area. The headline "Stool-Sniffing Science" caught my eye. Wouldn't it do the same for you? Anyway, here's the first paragraph of this scintillating report (not recommended for lunchtime reading): "Infectious diarrhea has many causes, and in the days it takes for current diagnostic techniques to diagnose the microbe responsible, the infection can spread quickly and kill. Now scientists from the British Royal Infirmary and the University of the West of England, both in Bristol, England, have proposed a novel solution to the problem: a technique that uses gas chromatography and mass spectroscopy to identify the culprit by analyzing the odor of the patient's stool." I'm wondering how these lucky scientists bring up the subject of their jobs during dates.

the people's republic of cambridge The reason I didn't post anything about my birthday weekend festivities wasn't because it didn't go well or there was nothing to write about -- I just didn't get around to it. The fact is, I had a fantabulous time. As I mentioned last week, Liza suggested we "get away" for the weekend, but limited funds meant that we spend the weekend in Cambridge. Which is fine by me. Cambridge is a great town. Harvard Square, Central Square, Porter Square, Davis Square -- there's a lot of great squares in that snooty city across the river. We stayed at the urlLink Royal Sonesta with a wonderful view of the Charles River and the Boston skyline. On Saturday afternoon, while hanging out at the Au Bon Pain in Harvard Square (where a scene between Minnie Driver and Matt Damon was shot for urlLink "Good Will Hunting" ), we ran into my cousin Maria and her husband Kenny, which was very strange since they live out in the sticks and are hardly ever in Boston. They ended up staying in the city for the weekend, celebrating Maria's birthday, which was Sunday. We also saw urlLink "Mystic River," which I saw when it first came out, but Liza hadn't because she was in Europe at the time. We also visited the wonderfully funky Black Ink on Brattle Street, where I bought a sumptous urlLink Tintin appointment book. Oh, and Liza and I bought a new computer on Friday. A computer? Why, yes. Liza has been meaning to get one for the longest time. She was using my old one for a couple of years, but it finally died last year. Our friends Briana and Erin both have urlLink iBooks, and we both liked them a lot, so Friday night we walked over to urlLink Cambridgeside Galleria (right across the street from our hotel, literally) and bought an iBook. With a printer. And a wireless internet card. We are both slowly coming around to the fact that Bill Gates is Satan and Mac is the way to go. God, I love this computer. Let the CD burning begin! Now that I've got this Mac, I'm seriously thinking about getting an urlLink iPod. Let me say right off the bat that I don't download music off the internet. Not necessarily because it's illegal or immoral. I just like browsing around for CDs. I like packaging. I like poring over liner notes. That's me and I can't see not doing those things as part of my obsessive musical rituals. As long as CDs are manufactured, packaged and sold, I'll be buying them. But the convenience of having all my music in one little cellphone-size box (particularly for commuting) is extremely appealing to me. One question for you iPod experts, though: I have nearly a thousand CDs. Can I fit all that music in an iPod? That information will help me with my decision.

a right purdy hurdy-gurdy This week's Newsweek has a small urlLink piece on a relatively obscure stringed instrument called a hurdy-gurdy, which has spiked a bit in popularity since Stink, I mean Sting was seen playing one on the Oscars (accompanying Alison Krauss during her performance of "You Will Be My Ain True Love" from "Cold Mountain"). Erin's roommate Mike thought that it looked like a device Sting was using to "control" Alison, who was actually a robot. I realize that telling this story after the fact without you actually being there may not seem funny, but at the time -- while watching the performance -- it made all of us laugh really hard. It turns out that Sting, a.k.a. the Obscenely Rich and Famous Musician Who Hasn't Done Anything Relevant in At Least 20 Years, wasn't even really playing it -- much. According to hurdy-gurdy "expert" Cali Hackmann, "he was, to be honest, more or less using it as a prop," using the "drone" strings and not the "melody" strings. A Sting spokeswoman said he had "just learned to operate it." Can you say "poseur?"

in time, you can turn these obsessions into careers I have a really boring meeting that I must attend in about 20 minutes, so I'll make this brief: yes, the Elvis Costello show last Friday night was indeed spectacular. Of the four times I've seen him in concert, this was probably the best. A great selection of songs: there was stuff from "North," in addition to lots of older chesnuts from EC's catalog, and several obscure ones as well (performances of "Home Truth" and "Inch by Inch" from his much-maligned "Goodbye Cruel World" album proves once again my theory that the album suffered from horrible production values, not horrible songwriting). The Brodsky Quartet (who accompanied Elvis on several songs, along with EC's pianist right-hand-man, Steve Nieve) sounded fantastic. In addition to adding the necessary gravitas to his newer material, their arrangements of older Elvis stuff like "Pills and Soap" and "Rocking Horse Road" were terrific. A few of the nice surprises included a cover of Randy Newman's "Real Emotional Girl" and "Scarlet Tide," the Oscar-nominated song he co-wrote with T-Bone Burnett for the "Cold Mountain" soundtrack (performed on the soundtrack by Alison Krauss). Elvis played that one by himself, on ukelele. He also covered "You'll Never Walk Alone" from "Carousel" (Liza wanted to strangle the woman in the lobby after the show who told her friend it was from "Carnival" -- I'm dating a musical theater snob and I love it!). One minor gripe: Elvis needs to retire "Pump It Up" and "Watching the Detectives." Period. I realize that they're classic tunes in his repertoire, and they're really not bad songs, in my opinion. But does he really need to drag out interminable versions of these war-horses at every single opportunity, like his own personal "Freebird?" The guy's got enough great songs. He can ditch those two. urlLink Here's the setlist.

what a turn-off Last week was urlLink TV Turn-Off Week, an annual, sadly underpublicized event where people are encouraged to, you guessed it, turn off their television sets for seven days and seek alternate forms of entertainment. I personally believe that I watch too much television. Not as much as most Americans, but I still use it as a crutch, turning it on when I get home simply because it's there. I can spend fifteen minutes flipping the channels, almost "willing" something interesting to come on. Instead of turning it off and reaching for a book, I'll usually settle for watching the most tolerable piece of crap. I happen to think that my viewing tastes are a cut above most of the country's (I avoid reality shows like the plague and am even weaning myself off VH1's ubiquitous "list-themed" programs), but still -- I don't turn it off nearly enough. Reading about this turn-off week, I said to myself, "Self? Let's do it! Turn it off!" I personally feel that it was a week well spent, but I should first say that I cheated a little. My main infraction was that I still watched DVDs. I think there's a big difference between watching "Survivor" reruns and a quality documentary handpicked from Netflix or my own disc library. If that's cheating, so be it. Hey, it's not my fault that this boycott took place the week I started Netflix! What am I supposed to do? I've got discs coming to me by mail, I'm not gonna just sit on them! Am I searching for absolution? You bet I am. I should also point out that the discs I watched were all in the realitvely "highbrow" category: three documentaries ("Lost in La Mancha," "Capturing the Friedmans," the Ric Burns "New York" series [that I'm halfway done with as we speak]) and one foreign film ("Persona" -- it doesn't get any snootier than Bergman). So while I did stare at an "idiot box" during the week in question, it was not for the sake of idiotic programming. One of my responsibilities at my job is archiving television news segments where urlLink our organization is featured, so I was in fact locked in a closet for several hours, scanning TV newscasts. But hey -- it was my job. What was I supposed to do? The one instance where I was at home, not in any work-related capacity, watching television, was Saturday night. Liza and I were getting ready for bed and she was watching a Saturday Night Live rerun. I caught the "Weekend Update" segment. But again, what was I supposed to do? Get all smug and sanctimonious on her, ordering her to turn off the television? "Unplug that wretched device! You are interfering with my culturally superior sociological experiment!" No, I don't think so. So, for the most part, I participated in this event. I read more, spent my morning getting ready for work with NPR on the radio as opposed to blow-dried anchormen on TV, and maybe -- just maybe -- I'm a slightly better person for it. But in the meantime -- there's an all-new urlLink "Law & Order" on tonight! Whee!

the neck I was home sick yesterday and had no access to a computer, hence the lack of posting around these parts. A few days ago, my chronic neck and upper back pain (which hits me once or twice a year) flared up pretty bad. Usually, a bunch of Motrin gets rid of it after a day or two, but it's been putting up quite the fight lately. Getting out of bed was taking me -- literally -- a good ten minutes of maneuvering. Going from horizontal to vertical was a process that took several steps and a hell of a lot of wincing. Finally, on Sunday morning (after reaching for a bottle of shampoo gave me such a sharp blast of pain that I almost passed out), I headed to the emergency room at Mass General, where they told me to double my Motrin dosage (I'm now taking 12 of those a day) and prescribed a muscle relaxant known as Flexeril. The doctor recommended that I take at least one day off, which I did. Monday was spend sipping coffee, checking out the urlLink Today Show and continuing to plow through my urlLink Netflix -provided episodes of Ric Burns' urlLink "New York" miniseries (four down, four to go). The back still hurts a bit, but it's a lot better that it was two days ago. Things are getting a bit stagnant over at urlLink Delicious Media, my brand new reviews-only site. Don't let that deter you from continuing to check it out. I plan on doing at least two or three reviews a week, even though I've only got two up there for now. I want the reviews up there to be of a good, consistent quality (i.e., not slapped together like my old Amazon reviews), so I need to actually sit down and write coherent, helpful reviews that warrant a place on that site. I'll get a new review up there by tomorrow, I promise.

"carmine said one blog...here are two!" Big news here at pressure drop headquarters (which is basically my cubicle, where they pay me to do something completely different; unless I'm using Liza's iBook, in which case it could be her apartment in the North End, or my place in Dorchester...whatever...). The news is that I've created a new blog. Not a replacement for this blog, but a separate one. It's called Delicious Media and can be found urlLink here. Don't get too excited, there's really nothing there yet. Why another blog, you ask? Well, Delicious Media is going to be devoted strictly to reviews. Mostly music (albums and concerts) and movies, but also books and maybe television as well. I've always had reviews on this site and they seem to coexist peacefully with the usual ranting and raving, weekend reports, and emergency bulletins about what I ate for lunch. But lately I've noticed that when I'm perusing the archives (which I do mainly for quality control, not because I'm a vain arse), there's a noticeable change of flow when I go from, say, morning subway vent to a review of the new Cornershop CD. I guess it's part of my obsessive-compulsive nature and a need to have things in their little organized areas that's provided the impetus for this new site. Also, it's quite possible that some of you out there don't care for the reviews but seem to enjoy my observations about day-to-day life in the big city. Or some of you enjoy the reviews but wish I would just shut my yap about how much I love Dunkin' Donuts Coolattas. In all of those cases, you need serious help. But more than that, you can now pick and choose (to an extent) what side of my writing you want to subject yourself to: My lame attempts at erudite criticism, or my pathetic endeavors to be the next Bill Hicks. I won't totally ban music, movies, or other assorted pop culture from pressure drop. But if something falls squarely into the category of "review," chances are you'll find it over at the DM (being on the front line of this exciting new web development, you can be among the first to use this hip new abbreviation!). A note about the name: after spending my lunch break agonizing over a title ("Bright Grey" was a leading contender for a while), I chose Delicious Media after realizing last night while reading Jonathan Franzen's urlLink "How To Be Alone" that by page 65, he'd used the word "delicious" three times, and not once to describe food. I like the idea of using the word that way. I happen to think, for example, that the packaging of CDs by urlLink Nonesuch Records is quite delicious. And hopefully, you'll enjoy taking a big delicious bite of the new site. Don't worry, I'll get some content up there soon enough. Oh, I almost forgot...the title of this post is a paraphrase of a quote from the very funny and sadly underrated 1990 film urlLink "The Freshman," uttered by Larry London (played by Maximillian Schell). The line is actually "Carmine said one boy...here are two!" I guess out of context, it's not really funny. Liza will probably be the only person to appreciate this, so I hope she reads it.

persona Over the last couple of days, I watched and returned my first three urlLink Netflix movies. Can I say one more time how much I love Netflix? What a great idea. Good job, people. Give yourselves a raise. Actually, I bet they just did, since Netflix's monthly fee just went up a tad (which is no problem for me -- $22 a month for all the movies I can watch is still a great deal). I'm going to try and give brief (probably somewhat lame) reviews of as many of my Netflix films as possible. I'll start with urlLink "Persona," and hopefully, in the next day or two, I'll tell you what I thought of the other two. "Persona" was a very good film that I can't believe I just saw for the first time two days ago, considering the fact that I've been a fan of Ingmar Bergman's films for at least two years now. I was actually holding out hope that urlLink Criterion would put out the DVD of this film (like they have with so many other Bergman movies), but that dream was quashed when MGM released it, along with several other MIA Bergman discs. No worries...they did a fine job. How was the film? I liked it a lot, although you have to sort of prep yourself for Bergman movies. They're not exactly a rip-roarin' good time. I've always had tremendous respect for what Bergman does, with cinematography, acting, and extreme subject matter. In "Persona," a famous actress (played by Bergman mainstay Liv Ullmann) is struck with a rare condition where she is unable to speak, and is cared for by a young nurse at a beach cottage. Their relationship begins hesitantly, but they are soon close and one night, the nurse (with the help of a bottle of wine), relates a story of an impromptu orgy she participated in with a girlfriend and two young boys. Later, the nurse finds out (through an opened letter she planned to mail) that the actress finds her "an amusing study." Soon it's jealousy, rage, betrayal, violence...you know, standard stuff. I still think urlLink "The Seventh Seal" is Bergman's best, but this one probably runs a close second. Besides the acting (particularly Bibi Andersson's role as the nurse), the dissonant modern classical score was probably my favorite aspect of this film.

meanwhile... You know how once every month or so I don't post for a few days, then I post something about how busy I've been lately? Well here I go again. Wish me luck. Other fun facts that I've kept from you for the past week or so: I joined urlLink Netflix this morning. After Suarez and urlLink Ben -- two people I have lots of respect for -- sang its praises, I finally decided that the thing wasn't really a scam. I adore DVDs and buy way too many of them, and the only decent video rental place in Boston, as far as I'm concerned, is urlLink Cinemasmith -- not exactly across the street. This is just too cool for words: twenty bucks a month, create a "wish list" of stuff to rent, they send the movies to you (three a month), you return them in the prepaid envelope when you're done. I realize that I sound like a TV commercial for this, but it really is a great deal. Unfortunately, I started my "rental queue" without consulting urlLink my favorite movie companion in the world, so I hope she's up for some snooty foreign films, because I've got a shitload of those waiting to be shipped my way. Last weekend Suarez, Liza and I watched Suarez' DVD of urlLink "School of Rock." I can't believe I just got around to watching that film. Jack Black is hilarious when given the right material, and that was certainly the case here. Although the main theme wasn't exactly original (geeks fight overwhelming odds to succeed), it had a nice, not-so-subliminal pro-music-in-schools message and with Black at the helm, the idea of loving music with every fiber of your being, critics be damned, came through loud and clear. It was also funny as hell. Two weeks ago we threw caution to the winds and saw two, count 'em two movies in one Sunday (without theater-hopping, I might add). urlLink "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" and urlLink "The Dreamers." "Eternal Sunshine" was a beautiful, funny, crazy, touching work of art that I'll probably buy when the DVD comes out. Jim Carrey is proving time and time again that he doesn't have to make fart jokes to win people over. This is easily the best thing he's ever done. Screenwriter Charlie Kaufman continues his odd, mindbending streak with this one, with better results (in my opinion). "Being John Malkovich" was good, "Adaptation" better, but this one resonated deepest with me, probably due to the fact that it tapped into real human emotion better that the other two combined. And the soundtrack is a killer. Check out the Beck song in the closing credits. "The Dreamers" is Bernardo Bertolucci's exquisite love letter to late sixties radical Paris, with creepy Michael Pitt playing an American student who befriends a French twin brother and sister, spending the summer with them in their apartment while the parents are away. It's NC-17 and fully deserves the controversial rating, with lots of sex (the incest angle probably didn't hurt much). Sure, it's twisted and not exactly for the whole family, but I loved the cinematography, Bertolucci's loving tributes to French new-wave cinema, the psychedelic soundtrack (mixed nicely with traditional French artists like Francoise Hardy and Edith Piaf) and some pretty good acting, too (I find Pitt oddly compelling and would love to see him in more films). I think you're all caught up.

will there be a 2001 centrifuge? If anyone out there lives in the Frankfurt area, do you think you could steal me some Kubrick memorabilia? A really cool exhibit is happening there for uber-fans like me. I'm doing the old cut-n-paste since the New York Times is a pay site and I wouldn't want to deprive any of you from this news: The first major exhibition of props, possessions and memorabilia associated with the filmmaker Stanley Kubrick, whose creations include "2001: A Space Odyssey," "Dr. Strangelove" and "Paths of Glory," has opened in Frankfurt. Among the objects on display, assembled with the help of his widow, Christiane, and his longtime executive producer, Jan Harlan, Mrs. Kubrick's brother, are personal letters, including one from Katharine Hepburn gently rejecting a request to star in a film; a Dali-inspired lip-shaped red settee seen in "Lolita"; and the zero-gravity bathroom door used in "2001." Indicative of Kubrick's notorious meticulousness are his preparations for "Napoleon," down to the shooting schedule, an armoire full of books and index cards cataloging the important people surrounding Napoleon and their year-by-year movements. The film was never made because of technical problems and exorbitant production costs. Kubrick wanted to shoot indoor scenes by candelight. The exhibition continues through July 4 at the German Film Museum and the adjacent German Architecture Museum.

george's dilemma I can't say that I consider myself a fan of his music, but I have respect for the talents of George Michael. That's why I find it strange that, in a supposedly sexually open-minded music business, his career has seemed to be on a downward spiral ever since he publicly announced several years ago that he was gay. It should be noted that Michael continues to enjoy success in other parts of the world. His latest album, "Patience," debuted at the top of the charts in Denmark, Germany, Italy, Sweden and England. It has yet to even be released in the United States (except as an import). Renee Graham's urlLink article in today's Boston Globe ponders this strange set of circumstances. In 1987, he was a mega-star, here and everywhere else in the world, when he released the monster hit album "Faith." These days, in the U.S., George can't...well, I won't say he can't get arrested, but you know what I mean. It's easy to say that Michael's arrest a few years ago for indecent exposure in a California public restroom is the cause for his stateside decline. But doesn't controversy sell? The crux of the argument comes about midway through the article, where Graham makes an interesting comparison between Michael and R. Kelly, another popular artist whose reputation was compromised after a controversial incident: Compared to R. Kelly's ongoing legal troubles surrounding child-pornography charges, Michael's restroom mishap is akin to a parking ticket. Yet Kelly's career has only seemed to flourish in light of the charges. He's gotten standing ovations at awards shows and enjoyed two megahits, "Ignition" and "Step in the Name of Love," from his 2003 multimillion-selling album, "Chocolate Factory." Simply put, absolutely no one seems to care Kelly may have participated in a heinous act. (Kelly is innocent until proven guilty, but his brief 1994 marriage to the late singer Aaliyah, then 15, is at least a totem of troubling behavior.) If this is about getting in trouble with the law, it's painfully unfair. Michael tried to get his rocks off with a guy he thought was a willing participant but ended up being an overzealous undercover cop (entrapment, anyone?). R. Kelly is being accused of multiple counts of underage sex. Who's getting screwed here?
