the alienist I don't remember how it started, but about a week ago, I became obsessed with reading Caleb Carr's 1994 mystery novel urlLink "The Alienist." When the novel was first published, I recall a flurry of critical acclaim surrounding the fictional tale of a serial killer in 1896 New York City, but I wasn't interested, simply because period fiction wasn't really my cup of tea. Times have changed. I've recently become more and more intrigued by American History and "The Alienist" combines a hair-raising murder mystery with frightening period accuracy. One of the more interesting aspects of the novel is the fact that a genuine historical figure plays a substantial role: Theodore Roosevelt, who was New York City's police commissioner at the time. My recent interest in Roosevelt - particularly after seeing the History Channel's wonderful "TR: An American Lion" - has given me even more incentive to check out the book. I asked my roommate Frank, who is a voracious reader, and a particularly avid fan of history and period fiction, if he'd read the book, and he told me that he did, and loved it. I asked him if he happened to own the book so that I could possibly borrow it. He answered in what may be considered by people who don't know Frank to be a peculiar response: "I think I might." You see, Frank owns piles and piles of books. To the point where he loses track of what titles he actually owns. He invited me to plow through the collection. I checked out the hardcover selections, easily available for browsing in the bookcases of his bedroom. No luck. So the next afternoon, I embarked on the Herculean task of attacking the enclosed bookcase-cum-china cabinet that contains dozens and dozens of paperbacks, several rows deep. This took at least an hour (although some of that was due to the fact that I was enjoyably browsing -- I felt like I discovered the hidden nook of a used bookstore). But in the end, the search proved fruitless. Frank apparently doesn't own the book - unless he lent it to someone years ago and it was forgotten. So I broke down and spent five bucks at Borders to pick up a paperback copy. I've been reading it little by little the last couple of nights before going to sleep, and I'm enjoying it quite a bit. Maybe not enough to plow through someone's bookshelves for an hour, but certainly more than worth five bucks.

If you're a fan of jazz music -- the real stuff, not the smooth crap -- you'll be sad to know that the legandary Elvin Jones urlLink passed away at the age of 76. Even if the only thing he did was play drums on John Coltrane's ferocious, groundbreaking urlLink "A Love Supreme," his place in jazz history would still be secure. But he did so much more than that, adding his unique, revolutionary talents to the bulk of Coltrane's recordings, in addition to those of Duke Ellington, Art Pepper, Bill Evans, Stan Getz, Rahsaan Roland Kirk, Charles Mingus and many more. Despite his recent death, he seemed ageless and played right up until the end (although he had been in poor health in the last few months, according to the above obituary). In his seventies, he continued to tour (I idiotically passed up a chance to see him at the Berklee Performance Center last year) and showed no signs of letting up his manic playing style. As a jazz fan and someone who took formal drum lessons from ages 10 to 17, I've always been amazed at what Elvin could do with a drum set and an improvisational jazz setting. If you want to hear jazz drumming at its absolute peak, listen to "A Love Supreme," or anything Elvin's recorded. "I figured that a lot of things drummers were doing with two hands could be done with one," Jones once said. "What was needed was a flow of rhythm all over the set. I never learned any tricks, anything flashy -- like juggling sticks or throwing them in the air. That kind of thing stops me inside. After all, Artur Rubenstein doesn't play runs on the piano with his chin."

The uber-knowledgeable folks at urlLink dvdjournal.com have just announced that "Goodfellas" will finally be re-released in August, and this time, they're doing it right. The reason I never bought a DVD of this, one of my all-time favorite films, was because it came out in the early days of the DVD format and contained virtually no bonus material. Even worse, it's a "flipper" (not to be confused with urlLink this kind of flipper). Back then, movies that were over a certain length (maybe two-and-a-half hours, I'm not sure) had to be spread out over two sides of a disc, and you had to "flip" them halfway through (early DVD versions of "Amadeus" were flippers, until a nice special edition was released in 2002). Anyway, not only will this edition be one side of the disc, it also contains an extra disc of supplements. Several other Scorsese films that were released in inferior DVD editions (or never released at all) will come out this summer as well, including "Mean Streets," "Who's That Knocking on My Door," "Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore" and the hilarious, sadly underrated "After Hours" (the only film I know of that stars Teri Garr, Griffin Dunne, Rosanna Arquette, Linda Fiorentino, Bronson Pinchot and Cheech and Chong). You can get them separately or as a box set. Salud!

for lack of a creative post... urlLink Dan did it, urlLink Heather did it, and being the mind-numbing yes-man that I am, here's my take on it: 1. What time do you get up? If I'm going to work, between 5:30 and 6. It often makes me wish I worked from home, but I know for a fact that if I did in fact work from home, I would get absolutely nothing accomplished. Really. 2. If you could eat lunch with one person, who would it be? That's a tough one. If we're talking "alive or dead," probably someone whose art I've always admired, like Kubrick or Zappa (or Bach). But alive? Since I watched several hours of a "Queer Eye" marathon yesterday, I'd say urlLink Ted Allen. He's a fabulous cook and seems like a really nice guy to boot. 3. Gold or silver? I don't get it. I'm not much for "bling bling," so let's say neither. 4. What was the last film you saw at the cinema? The Dreamers. 5. What is your favorite TV show? Law & Order. 6. What do you have for breakfast? It depends. There's always a cup of coffee involved, sometimes I have a bowl of cereal, on a Sunday I like to have a big breakfast like bacon, eggs and toast. I don't have a specific "breakfast regimen," but I always try to have something. 7. Who would you hate to be stuck in a room with? Paris Hilton. Or the new security guard they just hired at my Borders -- the guy never shuts up. 8. Who/what inspires you? I have a great admiration for people with enormously positive attitudes, because I'd like to be that way myself. I get too bitter and jaded far too often and would love to change that. I'm also a great admirer of artists who do what they want with little to no regard for public opinion, current trends or mainstream acceptance. Again, the Kubrick/Zappa thing comes to mind. 9. What is your middle name? Rand. It was my father's mother's maiden name and has become a sort of default male middle name in my family (it's also the middle name of my father and one of my nephews). I hated it when I was a kid, but I sort of admire the uniqueness of it nowadays. 10. Beach, city or country? What really irks me about these kinds of lists is that they assume everyone fits into little categories. I like all three of these choices for a variety of different reasons. 11. Favorite ice cream? I go through phases. Right now I love Starbucks Java Chip. 12. Butter, plain or salted popcorn? Butter and salt, please. And no, I do not want a deluxe "combo" for just 25 cents more. 13. Favorite color? Depends. Growing up it was blue. Then I went through a black phase. Nowadays red's been making me pretty happy. 14. What kind of car do you drive? The nonexistent kind. For pressure drop trivia buffs, the last car I owned was a 1988 Ford Taurus. It was especially fun trying to park that beast in downtown Naples, Italy. 15. Favorite sandwich? I don't think that I have ever, in the 30-plus years that I have ingested solid foods, been disappointed in a grilled cheese sandwich. Helpful tip courtesy of my roommate Frank: grill it with mayo on the bread instead of butter. Yum! 16. What characteristics do you hate in a person? I hate bandwagon-jumping (or general lack of individuality). Lack of sense of humor sucks a lot, too. 17. Favorite flower? What? 18. If you could go anywhere in the world for vacation, where would it be? Somewhere I've never been before? I've heard lovely things about New Zealand. And I find it baffling that I've never been to England, so maybe there too. 19. What color is your bathroom? I think it's sort of an off-white affair, with green rugs. 20. Favorite brand of clothing? Hel- lo! Banana Republic! I'm their biggest straight customer. 21. Where would you retire to? Somewhere in France. 22. Favorite day of the week? Saturday. 23. What did you do for your last birthday? Liza got us a weekend at the Royal Sonesta in Cambridge. We hung out in Harvard Square, saw a movie, ordered lots of room service, and the rest is none of your business. 24. Where were you born? Winchester, Massachusetts. 25. Favorite sport to watch? Watching sports bores me. Especially baseball and football. If I absolutely had to watch something, I'd make it basketball or soccer. 26. What fabric detergent do you use? This is getting rather personal, don't you think? Tide. 27. Coke or Pepsi? Neither. I don't drink soda unless there's nothing else available, in which case it's ginger ale or Sprite. 28. Are you a morning person or a night owl? I'm not really either. I love the idea of being awake obscenely early, but I love sleeping too much to really be able to do that. 29. What is your shoe size? 10 1/2 30. Do you have any pets? No, but I have plenty of pet peeves.

this one's for my savin hill peeps The subway stop closest to my house, urlLink Savin Hill, is being torn down on May 9 in order for a brand new station to be built in its place. This will make the Savin Hill stop inoperable until January 2005. Despite the inconvenience this places on me as a daily T rider, I welcome the opportunity for this stop -- a foul, smelly, decrepit shack -- to be modernized. My neighborhood deserves it. Regardless, I'm having a hell of a time trying to figure out what the MBTA is planning to do for those of us who depend on the Savin Hill stop. Flyers have been distributed to the commuters. Apparently, we have to take a shuttle bus (closest stop to my house -- the corner of Dorchester & Savin Hill Avenues) to the JFK/UMass stop and pick up the Red Line there. Fine. No problem. But I have a thousand other questions. Will they accept the regular T subway pass on this shuttle bus? If not, how much is the fare? How will I know which bus to take, either at the temporary Dorchester Avenue stop or at JFK/UMass when I'm going home? And so on. So, as part of the MBTA's highly touted "Write to the Top!" program, I fired off an e-mail to the Powers That Be, hoping my various (and not really unusual) questions could be answered. A few days later (this afternoon), I get an e-mail that, at first glance, can't be a form letter, since it begins, "Dear Mr. Ingalls." Unfortunately, the e-mail they sent me includes the same facts included in their hand-out flyers. Not exactly what I had in mind. Don't you just love bureaucracy? So if anyone knows the deal with these Savin Hill shuttle bus things, please let me know.

so nice they named it twice My urlLink Netflix adventures continue to go along smoothly. I'm still slogging through the Ric Burns urlLink "New York" miniseries. So far, of the eight episodes, I've watched 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 7. Perhaps I should explain. When I first received episode 5, it was damaged, so I returned it. In the meantime, 7 showed up, and I didn't feel like waiting around for 6 or the replacement disc for 5. Last night I watched my new copy of episode 5. I'll watch 6 tonight. Confused? Sorry. Episode 8, which I should be getting on Friday, is a post-9/11 World Trade Center special that was posthumously added to the documentary (which first aired in 1999). I think they'll do a great job with it, but I still get the creeps watching anything related to the Towers. The series has been a total joy for me. I've never been much of an expert on New York City, but now I feel like I know the place (and its history) like the back of my hand. I've also enjoyed the commentary by brilliant New York historians like Robert Caro, Mike "not the 60 Minutes guy" Wallace, Ray Suarez, and the very strange-looking Marshall Berman (who really needs to do something about his frazzled hippie appearance - can we get the Fab Five on the case?). I also learned a lot about post-war urban renewal and the destructive, out-of-control Robert Moses. Being generally lax in large chunks of our nation's history, I was shocked to learn of this man's destructive path through New York City, building highways and wiping out entire neighborhoods as casually as blowing his nose. This is the guy who created the borough-destroying Cross Bronx Expressway, and tried to get a highway to run straight through Manhattan, virtually wiping out Greenwich Village, until cooler heads finally intervened. This is also the guy who brought down Penn Station. What a story. My history-nut roommate Frank informed me that Moses started out with good intentions, but eventually wielded so much power that his highway expansion pipe dreams were almost unanimously approved every time, with little dissent or regard for displacement of families or businesses. I personally have never really spent any time in New York City, with the exception of driving through it a few times (although I did spent about two years of my toddler era outside of Greenwich, Connecticut, so it's quite possible that I've been in the Empire State Building and nobody ever told me -- Dad, if you're reading this, could you clarify?). Liza may be spending some time in NYC this summer with our friend Briana (who "represents" Brooklyn, big ups yo), and I may spend a weekend there. I can't wait! I can't believe it's taken me this long to get there.

The long-awaited new album from urlLink Wilco comes out tomorrow, and my long-awaited pre-ordered special two-disc edition of urlLink Mike Keneally's latest should be in my mailbox in the next week (or so), but that hasn't stopped me from buying even more new music. Case in point: urlLink To the 5 Boroughs , the latest, long-awaited release from the Beastie Boys. I picked it up Saturday afternoon and listened to almost all of it, and so far I really enjoy it. I don't consider myself a huge BB fan, but I do enjoy their stuff. I'm not really much of a hip-hop fan -- I consider most of the genre's masochistic, materialistic posing to be boring and predictable -- but every once in a while, a group comes along that makes it interesting and refreshing. De La Soul, the Roots, Jurassic Five and Outkast are a few examples of those types of "exceptions to the rule." What I like best about the Beastie Boys (King Ad-Rock, Mike D and MCA) is that they're so damn geeky. Even while pretending to come off as tough, you can't shake the fact that they're three upper-middle class Jewish white boys. I didn't always like them, though. I was a senior in high school when their debut, License to Ill, came out. Not a day would go by when that song wasn't blasting from the school parking lot or being quoted by some hipster doofus classmate. I hated it. Fortunately, the Boys thickened up the sound considerably with their follow-up, Paul's Boutique, which I bought and played endlessly and still love to this day. Of course, it tanked with the public. What else is new? (It should be noted that it's been critically lauded since day one and still maintains its status as an underappreciated classic). The Beastie Boys have continued their high quality of dorky white boy rhymes, teaming up with endlessly creative producers like the Dust Brothers and Mario Caldato, Jr, as well as utility player Money Mark. Perhaps influencing later hip-hop musicians like the Roots, the Beastie Boys went back to their DIY punk roots by playing their own instruments on the groundbreaking Check Your Head. Further establishing their reputation as intelligent multi-taskers (while still being smart-ass rappers), the Boys started their own record label (and magazine), Grand Royal, and MCA (born Adam Yauch) began making his social conscience heard by organizing the hugely successful Tibetan Freedom Concerts. Maybe white rap isn't so bad after all. There have been some criticisms of To the 5 Boroughs , mainly the fact that these three, on the cusp of their forties, have outlived their usefulness and have nothing new to add to the genre. Bullshit. Listen to the album. It's a predictable cliche to refer to any album that pleads for peace, love and unity as a "post 9/11 statement," but that's exactly what that is. Songs like "Time to Build" and "An Open Letter to NYC" are potent, pertinent, and totally on point. They still sound great and have a lot to say. And the music still sounds great. And wow, I love that packaging. A nice textured O-card that doubles as a tribute to their shattered yet resilient hometown.

Ten years ago this week (I'm not sure of the actual day, but I know it was mid-June), I was discharged from the navy after serving for seven years. A lot has changed. I'm not getting paid to travel to exotic locales anymore, the government is no longer paying my bills, and I can technically be fired for not doing my job well. But other than that, I think things are a lot better for me now. I joined the navy in 1987, during the latter half of my senior year in high school, when I was feeling particularly aimless and had no immediate plans to further my education beyond a high school diploma. On a Saturday afternoon in February, when my father suggested the service, I have to admit that I laughed. He couldn't be serious! But he wasn't smiling. "Oh, you really want me to do this?" I asked him (although probably to myself). I have to admit, the idea sounded interesting to me. I honestly didn't feel any need to "serve my country" and I was already a confirmed liberal and not interested in "killing commies." But in a rush of "here goes nothing" nihilism, I said sure. There were a few conditions. First of all, I was determined to enjoy my last summer of freedom first, and wouldn't actually go to boot camp until at least mid-August. Second, I would choose a job field that would interest me. I picked journalism. It's fun, and hey -- something I can use on the outside when my time is up. I hate to break it to you, Popeye, but there's not much call for a "Botswain's Mate" in 21st century America. So in August 1987 I entered navy basic training at the Recruit Training Center in Great Lakes, Illinois, followed by 10 months at the amazingly challenging yet pleasantly alcohol-fueled Defense Information School (in Indiana, but since moved to Maryland), then two surreal years at the Navy Broadcasting Service detachment in Diego Garcia (a British island in the middle of the Indian Ocean -- you can see photos of the place on urlLink this nice unofficial site). My final three-and-a-half years of service were spent at the NBS detachment in Keflavik, Iceland, where I continued to subvert the radio airwaves, be a dumb military TV news reporter, honed my videotape editing skills, mastered the art of the public service announcement, learned how to drive on black ice, caught my girlfriend in bed with another guy, directed the only one-take prerecorded TV newscast in the history of the station (Marc Boyd said he did one shortly after me, but I heard he cheated), rode in a helicopter for the first time, was the subject of a brief rumor that I was gay, learned how to drive a stick shift, got married (and divorced several years later), became a dad, got a fancy certificate that proves I crossed the arctic circle, and met a few of my best friends ever: Jamie Salafia, Terry Welch, and that lovable doofus, Gerard Johnson (does anyone know where he is these days?). My time in the navy was spent dealing with some pretty conservative, middle-of-the-road types with whom I tried to argue and realized it was pointless (they were also pretty big Wrasslin' fans), but I was also lucky enough to be in a little corner of the military where people often thought daring and original thoughts, questioned authority and voted Democrat. DINFOS grads will never let you down. I had a great time, saw a lot of interesting things, laughed my ass off, and drank a lot of booze...but I got out when I'd had enough (which is more than I can say for some people I knew). To paraphrase urlLink Mike Keneally, 1994 was a million years ago.

The word "genius" is thrown around so much these days, but this is one case where it fits. Ray Charles, along with Bo Diddley, Little Richard, and Chuck Berry, basically invented rock and roll. He was also one of the first true multifaceted talents of the genre. He blended pop, rock, soul, gospel, jazz, and even country, and made it all seem so easy. There are few people even today who possess his eclecticism. Just a sampling of his repertoire -- "What'd I Say," "Hit the Road, Jack," "Busted," "I Can't Stop Loving You," "Georgia on my Mind," "Hallelujah, I Love Her So," "Drown in My Own Tears" -- reads like a list of rock's most essential songs. Every once in a while, a gentle soul comes into the world and creates beautiful, timeless art. Ray Charles did just that, and while he will be deeply missed, we'll always have his music. Stupid, pointless story that for some reason, I feel a need to share in this post: Back in 1988 or 1989, I was making a mix tape. I have some pretty anal-retentive rules about mixes and one of them is that I never do more than one song by an artist. Anyway, I had just put "Hallelujah, I Love Her So" by Ray Charles on the tape and I realized that there were only a couple minutes left. I then concluded the mix with Ray's "Drown In My Own Tears." Later, when my roommate and I were listening to the tape, he remarked -- fully aware of my rules -- that there were two songs in a row by the same artist. "It's okay," I told him. "It's Ray Charles." "His music is way beyond marketing. This music is global, and its appeal is universal. Ray Charles changed music just by being himself -- by doing what he did and translating it to millions of people with the wide-ranging effect of his one-of-a-kind soul. That's his legacy. I think that the music of Ray Charles will probably outlive us all -- at least I hope that it will." - Van Morrison

urlLink Doug posted this on his blog (and he found it urlLink here ), now I'm going to do the same. Feel free to copy the questions and put them on your own blog, if you're so inclined. 1. Your favorite song with the name of a city in the title or text. Roadrunner by Jonathan Richman. (it's the real Boston anthem, not that Dirty Water crap). 2. A song you've listened to repeatedly when you were depressed at some point in your life. I cant think of a song in particular where I actually did that, but if you want a fun, carefree, upbeat song, try Were Not Deep by the Housemartins. 3. Ever bought an entire album just for one song and wound up disliking everything but that song? Gimme that song. Severe Tire Damage by They Might Be Giants contains, in my opinion, one decent song (Why Does the Sun Shine?). Thats not why I bought the album, but this is the best answer I could come up with. 4. A great song in a language other than English. Jaures by Jacques Brel or Sotto Le Stelle Del Jazz by Paolo Conte. 5. Your least favorite song on one of your favorite albums of all time. Luxembourg is the only song on Elvis Costellos Trust album that I dont love with all my heart. 6. A song you like by someone you find physically unattractive or otherwise repellent. Most of the music I listened to is composed and performed by ugly people. Apostrophe by Frank Zappa is an instrumental that was co-written by Jim Gordon (who played drums on the song), and he was later convicted of bludgeoning his mom with an ax, and thats repellent. So there. 7. Your favorite song that has expletives in it that's not by Liz Phair. Im going to have to go with a Frank Zappa song. For sheer gleeful shock value, nothing beats Stick it Out. 8. A song that sounds as if it's by someone British but isn't. Well, the obvious answer is anything by Spinal Tap. Strange question. 9. A song you like (possibly from your past) that took you forever to finally locate a copy of. Up All Night by Boomtown Rats. Its originally from their album V Deep, which has been out of print for a while. I still dont have it Ive seen it on a really bad eighties compilation that Im not sure I want to buy just for that song. 10. A song that reminds you of spring but doesn't mention spring at all. The orchestral version of If I Could by Erasure (from their album The Two-Ring Circus ). 11. A song that sounds to you like being happy feels. Live in Japan by Mike Keneally. 12. Your favorite song from a non-soundtrack compilation album. Level the Vibes by Half-Pint, from an obscure reggae compilation called Reggae Jamdown the RAS Tapes. I lent the CD to someone in 1990, just a few months after I bought it, and I never got it back. Nowadays its impossible to find. 13. A song that reminds you of high school. Its impossible to isolate this to one album, let alone one song. How about anything from King of America by Elvis Costello or Labour of Lust by Nick Lowe. 14. A song that reminds you of college. Never went to college, but I did attend military broadcast journalism school (The Defense Information School, or DINFOS) from Oct. 1987 to Aug. 1988. Its basically college in a military uniform. There are about five million songs that remind me of my time there, but lets just say The Walk by the Cure. 15. A song you actually like by an artist you otherwise dislike. I have a strenuous dislike for anything involving Madonna, but I have to admit that I like Ray of Light. Dont tell anyone. 16. A song by a band that features three or more female members. Riding on the Rocket by Shonen Knife. 17. One of the earliest songs that you can remember listening to. Lean on Me by Bill Withers. My dad used to love that song. 18. A song you've been mocked by friends for liking. Most of my friends mock me for my love of prog rock. Fuck em. 19. A really good cover version you think no one else has heard. Im a big fan of obscure covers, particularly if theyre wildly rearranged. I love Wilson Picketts version of Hey Jude, John Wesley Hardings version of Like a Prayer, Graham Parkers version of A Change is Gonna Come, Frank Zappas version of Stairway to Heaven, Joe Jacksons version of Any Major Dude (never recorded, he performed it on his last tour), the Jams version of In the Midnight Hour and many many more. 20. A song that has helped cheer you up (or empowered you somehow) after a breakup or otherwise difficult situation. Normally anything by Mike Keneally makes me very happy, not just because his music is upbeat (although a lot of it is), but because he has a love for music that comes through in everything he does and is absolutely infectious.

Lou Reed has lots of rabid fans who know his classic albums by heart. "Transformer." "Berlin." "The Blue Mask." As for me, the one Reed album I have memorized (or did, some 19 years ago) is the obscure and uncharacteristically upbeat "New Sensations." June, 1985. I was living in Orlando and about to finish my sophomore year in high school. One of my best friends, Mike Lee, taped a copy of this album for me. I spent that summer (like all of my high school summers) staying with my mom in Derry, New Hampshire, enjoying her apartment complex swimming pool and spending a couple of weeks visiting my sister Julie in Boston. This cassette was definitely in heavy rotation on the old Walkman. Coming from a guy who normally sang songs about heroin and drag queens, this was an odd album. It was radio friendly (yet full of nice crunchy guitar riffs). Positive. Almost... uplifting. I remember wandering the streets of downtown Boston listening to "Endlessly Jealous" and wishing I wrote that song. I loved the eloquent, soul-searching title track, the achingly beautiful "Fly Into the Sun" and the gleeful "I Love You, Suzanne." Lou seemed to be comfortable in his early forties. And I was loving it. Unfortunately, "New Sensations" appears to only be available these days as an import, but if you see it around, I recommend picking it up. It was one of the highlights of my summer of '85.

This is an album that my sister Julie bought in 1977 or 1978 when we lived in France. The artist, a singer named France Gall, first hit it big in the mid-sixties as a teen pop sensation, and continued to release albums through the seventies and beyond (this album was released in 1977). The only thing I remember about this album was the song "Musique," which got a lot of airplay in our house for some reason. I actually like this cover. It's very evocative of a Parisian "night on the town," and the logo on the ashtray of the couple doing "the hustle" is very much of its time. What do you think?

While I feel deep sorrow for Nancy Reagan and her family, and applaud the fact that she stood by her husband during the many years he struggled with Alzheimer's disease (not to mention the fact that she blew off the Christian Right by supporting stem-cell research), I agree with urlLink April that the media is blowing Reagan's death way out of proportion. He died. He was 93 years old. He's been out of office for more than 15 years. Let's move on. And I'm not going to pretend I liked the guy. Let's face it: Reagan left public office with the country three trillion dollars in debt, and completely blew off the AIDS epidemic. I've known people who died of AIDS. I'm not going to pretend this guy didn't stand by while people succumbed to a disease he cared nothing about. Meanwhile, they're talking about putting his face on the ten dollar bill? And don't get me started on the whole Mount Rushmore thing. Death is a sad, sad thing. But let someone who liked the guy deliver a eulogy.

Its been something like six days since I last commented on how much I love the new Morrissey album. The last time I was so chatty about a musical purchase was when Joe Jackson released Vol. 4, his comeback album. I guess you could call You Are The Quarry a comeback for Morrissey, too (it's his first album in seven years). What I originally thought of as a strong album a couple of weeks ago (when I first heard it) is now a flat-out masterpiece. I could go down a laundry list of what I like about it, butaw hell, why not? Here is said laundry list: The loud, distorted guitars in You Know I Couldnt Last (my current favorite song on the album you know its a good album when your favorite song changes regularly) The flute (or is it a recorder?) solo in Im Not Sorry, which is so un-Morrissey but so perfect The minor-key electric piano riff that runs through I Have Forgiven Jesus That totally wack-ass electronic sound that opens All The Lazy Dykes The line such a silly boy (and the way its delivered) on The First of the Gang To Die That little falsetto part at the end of Come Back to Camden and finally, the one thing I do not like about the album: That damn inconvenient gatefold sleeve that will not fit in my CD rack. Jesus, Morrissey! What possessed you to design that? Thats right, Im talking to you! The credits say that you designed it yourself. I have nothing against paper/cardboard Digipaktype packaging. But the proportions of this thing are so wrong. My obsession with this album has given me the opportunity to dive back into Morrisseys catalog with unabashed glee and utter concentration. I plan to purchase the two albums I previously passed on (his mid-nineties titles Southpaw Grammar and Maladjusted) as well as a more thorough examination of the Smiths, the band I fell in love with the summer after high school graduation, cavorting around Florida with my best friends in bad quasi-bohemian mod/punk fashions with big hair and vodka tonics. Ah, memories.

I have a confession to make. Ive always loved those big, wanky rock reference books that crowd the music sections of bookstores. In the days of my youth, my brother Gary used to buy books like The Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock and The Rolling Stone Record Guide. This was back when Rolling Stone was an informative, somewhat respectable magazine, mind you, before they became an offshoot of Maxim . Additionally, I loved poring over Rolling Stone every month, even reading reviews of bands I didnt care for just admiring the writing and pontificating and hearing stories about bands on the road (Almost Famous was a particularly poignant film for me). Anyway, I loved these books, and in a rather guilty-pleasure-nostalgic way, still do (although my tastes have broadened somewhat to include jazz and classical reference books, I might add). One of my favorite 1982 Christmas gifts was a book given to me by my mother entitled Rock Chronicles, basically a 365-page this day in rock music history guide. So it should come as no surprise that I really want urlLink this book. My brother bought the first edition back in 1982, and Im assuming that this is a heavily updated version. Why do I like stuff like this? Easy. Some people are students of military history. Some revel in political history. Me, I love rock music history. I eat that shit up. I love reading about histories of various bands, who released what album when, how old so-and-so was when they keeled over from too much smackyou name it. If you know me, you know that the need to fill my head with useless music trivia must constantly be fed. Oh, and these books also make for great bathroom reading. No plots to mull over, just open it up anywhere and read away.

About a month ago, I told myself ( urlLink and all of you ) that I would be making a Weezer mix disc for my eleven-year-old daughter Audrey (who lives in Illinois with my ex-wife, for those of you unfamiliar with this blog's cast of characters). We have practically zero common ground when it comes to music, and I'm a firm believer in letting kids listen to what they want instead of forcing your "old fart" tastes on them -- but since she's already starting to get into these guys, I figured a nice compilation would be fun. Well, I made the mix shortly afterwards, but kept putting off making some artwork for the thing. Thanks to some office software, I put a nice little action shot of Rivers Cuomo on the front, along with a track listing and graphics on the actual disc that mirror that of Weezer's "Blue" album (I even used the Weezer "font"). Looks pretty decent, if I do say so myself. And the songs? Twenty-four tracks of crunchy, sugary Weezer goodness: 1 my name is jonas 2 buddy holly 3 say it ain't so 4 in the garage 5 holiday 6 mykel and carli 7 suzanne 8 jamie 9 getchoo 10 no other one 11 why bother 12 the good life 13 don't let go 14 photograph 15 island in the sun 16 crab 17 knock down drag out 18 smile 19 american gigolo 20 dope nose 21 keep fishin' 22 burnt jamb 23 fall together 14 possibilities A few points to make: first of all, I don't really have much in the form of Weezer b-sides or rarities, except for the two-disc deluxe edition of the Blue Album (which is where I got tracks 6-8). So if you don't see the KROQ Weenie Roast Speed Metal version of a previously unreleased song that Rivers wrote on the tour bus that only 15 people have ever heard, that's because I don't really have much of that stuff. Also, since this is, after all, for my eleven-year-old daughter, I am being a (sigh) responsible parent by avoiding songs with "questionable" lyrical content. Unfortunately, that means bypassing personal favorites like "Tired of Sex," "Across the Sea" and "El Scorcho" (the Pinkerton album kinda got the short shrift as a result). Other than that, I think it's a pretty decent mix if I do say so myself.

Fuckin' NBC. First, they cancel urlLink "Homicide: Life on the Street," easily one of the most original, well-written and well-acted cop shows in the history of television, then they do the same thing a few years later to a similarly high-quality show like urlLink "Boomtown." I normally don't go out of my way to catch a new prime-time TV show, and "Boomtown" was no exception when it debuted in 2002. I saw a shitload of ads for it, and one Sunday night, when I was bored and decided to just channel-surf for a little while, I happened upon this show. My immediate reaction was, "Oh, this is that dumb cop show with Donnie Wahlberg that I've heard so much about." Then I kept watching. And watching. And wouldn't you know it, I was hooked. This was a good show. A great one, in fact. The characters were well-defined, the plots intricately constructed to show the entire cast -- the cops, the lawyers, the reporters, and yes, the criminals, using flashbacks and other non-linear forms of storytelling. It was high-quality TV viewing, more suited to HBO than NBC. Liza and I became addicted to this show, and not in a "watching a train wreck" type of addiction that you might get from drivel like "Fear Factor" or "The Apprentice." We tuned in almost every Sunday night (right after "Law & Order: Criminal Intent," making for a nice one-two punch of police drama). Then, suddenly, I saw a story on CNN that talked about TV shows that were "on the bubble," in other words, shows whose future was uncertain as far as being renewed for another season. "Boomtown" was one of those shows (I urlLink lamented the situation on this blog more than a year ago). I was surprised, not because a quality show was possibly getting axed (that happens all the time), but because I was under the impression that "Boomtown" was a big hit. Apparently not. Maybe in my household, but I guess too many people were hooked on "Who Wants To Marry My Cousin's Best Friend" or "Celebrity Blind Date Mole 14." I believe that "Boomtown" (like "Homicide" and the similiarly brushed-off "Freaks and Geeks") was more suited for a channel like HBO or Showtime. These "pay" stations nurture a show and give it time to grow, instead of re-tooling the cast, dumbing down the writing and finally cancelling it for good (three things that happened to "Boomtown"). What I'm really trying to say (and it's taking me a lot of time and plenty of venting to say it) is that "Boomtown" is now available on DVD. Buy it, rent it, get it from urlLink Netflix -- however you can swing it, experience what network TV can really be with good writing and good performances.

Spending five years of my childhood in France was indeed a trip. Not only was I cut off from a good deal of American culture, I was exposed to a lot of extracurricular childhood activities that my U.S. counterparts didn't even know existed. Sure, there were impromptu neighborhood soccer matches, but there was also a treasure trove of European comics and children's books. I devoured the stories of Tintin, not to mention Asterix and the lesser-known Lucky Luke, and fell completely in love with a book called urlLink "Le Petit Nicolas," a collection of stories from the point of view of a Parisian grade school troublemaker. My brother and I both read the book (at least twice) and used to enjoy comparing what parts of the book made us laugh the most. Like most of my old Tintin and Asteix books, I still have my original copy of "Le Petit Nicolas," although it's tattered beyond belief. The book was written by the late, great Rene Goscinny, who wrote most of the Asterix books (before he passed away and Asterix' illustrator, Albert Uderzo, began writing them, though not nearly as well). The book manages to capture both the innocence and deviousness of childhood in a way that kids will want to have Nicolas as a friend, and adults will nod in recognition at the antics.

In addition to the 40 percent discount, all Boston Borders employees received either a $45 gift certificate (for part-timers) or a $50 one (for full-timers), as thanks for last month's particularly good sales. I'm happy to say that I went nicely underbudget on my saturday spree, only spending about $56 of my own money (not counting the $45 gift certificate). Whenever I'm able to go on sprees like this (which isn't often, unfortunately), I try to be as eclectic as possible in my purchasing choices, and I think I accomplished that this weekend. Here's what I got: urlLink Marshall Crenshaw: Marshall Crenshaw This 1982 self-titled debut album from one of rock's most underappreciated singer/songwriters is something I've been inexplicably avoiding for some time now, and a nicely remastered version (complete with bonus tracks) courtesy of Rhino Records fits nicely in my CD collection. The 80s are alive and well with some cheesy, somewhat dated production techniques (why in the world were we all so obsessed with "big drums" back then?), but the songs are what matter here. Any album that contains "Someday, Someway," "Cynical Girl" and excellent covers of "Rave On" and "Solder of Love" needs to be recognized. Power-pop at its best. urlLink Uncle Tupelo: No Depression My recent reading of the Wilco biography, "Learning How To Die," has got me more interested in Jeff Tweedy's salad days with this twangy midwestern band of misfits. "No Depression" is the band's debut, and is a lot louder and rowdier than I expected. Which is good. The opening "Graveyard Shift" contains some of the most infectious guitar riffs I've heard in a long time. urlLink Peter Gabriel: Security I've been a PG fan since the early eighties, after being introduced to his music by my former step-uncle. His first four albums are all masterpieces, in my opinion, and his later forays into world music sorta left me cold. "Security" is album number four (the first three were all simply titled "Peter Gabriel," oddly enough) and while it does show a slight shift into exotic rhythms, with songs like "Rhythm of the Heat" and "San Jacinto," Gabriel's neo-prog madman persona is still alive and well. Gabriel's entire catalog was the subject of a nice reissue program about two years ago, and this is the last of the first four albums that I've finally upgraded from vinyl. urlLink Tony Williams Lifetime: Emergency! I've decided to go back to my junior high school roots and revisit jazz fusion. My first taste of this particular type of music took place during an early drum lesson when one of my teachers broke out "Spectrum" by Billy Cobham and I promptly found out that 4/4 time signatures are not an absolute. Williams is a drummer I've heard a lot about, but never really heard anything from. This landmark fusion album consists of drums, organ and guitar and borrows heavily from Miles Davis' concept of turning jazz on its ear. Recommended for people who like their music loud and distorted but still swinging. urlLink Chick Corea: Now He Sings, Now He Sobs Corea has explored many different areas of jazz and jazz-fusion, but this 1968 album -- his first real "solo" album -- is bare-bones jazz improv at its finest. Some of the best jazz piano you'll ever hear. urlLink Bach: St. Matthew Passion Okay, here's where I start to get snooty. I'm not an expert on this piece, but I've heard that McCreesh's version is one of the best around. My experience with Bach's choral works doesn't extend much beyond "Mass in B-Minor" (unless you include the Hilliard Ensemble's gorgeous urlLink "Morimur," which you should buy immediately), but "St. Matthew Passion" is a good place to resume my curiousity. urlLink Wilbert Hazelzet: Bach Hazelzet takes Bach's cello suites and plays them on the flute, along with some flute sonatas, making for a truly relaxing, beautiful disc. I took a three-hour nap Saturday afternoon after listening to this. urlLink Vivaldi: Concerti per Archi Vivaldi is sort of my classical guilty pleasure. I like a lot of modern, dissonant classical works, in addition to some of the old "greats" like Bach and Beethoven, and Vivaldi's music tends to all sound the same, but if you're in the mood for some relatively harmless classical music, Vivaldi always fits the bill. This particular recording received a highly favorable review in the latest issue of Gramaphone magazine, and they always seem to know what they're talking about.

Hi! Remember me? Are some of you still getting a big hunk of blank space at the top of my blog which requires you to scroll down ad infinitum until you get to the text? If so, I wish I could help you. I don't know why that's happening, but it doesn't seem to happen to me. Chalk it up to my amateurish web skills. How about people who use ad infinitum in regular conversation? Do you get a lot of that? Don't you just hate it? So how was your Fourth? Liza and I spent the afternoon picnicking (or is it "picnicing?" whatever...) at the Arboretum in Jamaica Plain. One of Liza's Emerson classmates, the perpetually cool Dylan Babb, suggested the idea, and we went with her and her friend Kristen (or is it Krista? I forget). I had never been to the Arboretum before and I intend to go again many times in the future. What a beautiful place. I was so relaxed that I dozed off on the picnic blanket for a little while, which hopefully wasn't considered too offensive by my picnic-mates. Liza, Suarez and I hung out on Liza's roofdeck that night with some Mexican snacks and cerveza mas fina , hoping to catch a glimpse of the fireworks, and while we saw some impressive amateur neighborhood ones, we decided to head out by the Fleet Center to see the real ones. Good stuff. Last week I put a couple of new reviews up on urlLink delicious media, including a review of the new Tragically Hip album from regular DM contributor and all-around nice guy Tom Johnson, in addition to my own review of "Learning How To Die," the extremely readable new Wilco biography. I've started to write a review of Dog , the long-awaited new urlLink Mike Keneally album, but I have many complex issues to cover, all of them good, and I want to do it right. The bottom line is that it's a wonderful album -- no surprises there -- and you should buy it immediately. It won't be available in retail stores until probably the fall, but in the meantime you can order it on Mike's site, either in the standard edition, or an autographed, numbered "deluxe edition" which features a DVD with concert, studio and rehearsal footage that simply rocks the hizzouse. Guess which one I bought. Favorite songs so far include the fiery "Louie," the groovin' "Splane," the moody "Bober" and the utterly inexplicable 15-minute mindfuck known as "This Tastes Like a Hotel." Me likes. It's been at least a week since I extolled the virtues of urlLink Netflix, so here we go again. I'm almost finished with season four of The Sopranos, and as usual, it's not disappointing me. This seems to be a pivotal season, what with the family's increasing distrust of Paulie, the truckload of issues surrounding Ralph, Christopher's drug problems, Pie-Oh-My, Furio's lust for Carmela, the return of Svetlana, blah blah blah. If you've been avoiding this show because of the overabundance of hype surrounding it, do yourself a favor and check it out. This is television at its finest, with incredible performances, first-rate writing, and the best, most eclectic selection of music I've ever heard for a TV show. I also watched urlLink "One Day in September" a few days ago. It's a documentary about a group of Palestinian terrorists who took a group of Isreali athletes hostage during the 1972 Munich Olympics. Very informative and well-made. There was one scene near the end of the film where a montage of still photos of the aftermath is set to a very creepy, falsetto-laden Deep Purple song ("Child in Time"), to an extremely chilling effect. Roger Ebert complained about that scene in his review (calling it "tasteless"), but I think it worked very well. Okay, that's it for now. Oh, and the new urlLink Wilco album is very good, but like the new Keneally, I need to let it seep more deeply into my consciousness before I can write anything worthy.

Today is a good day for urlLink Elvis Costello fans. Rhino is continuing their stellar reissue program of Elvis' catalog with the release of new, double-disc special editions of Almost Blue, Goodbye Cruel World and Kojak Variety . I realize that these are hardly the three best albums in the EC catalog, but they all have something to offer. Rhino has been reissuing Elvis' albums three-at-a-time, roughly every nine months, since around 2001. While the Rykodisc reissues (from the mid-nineties) certainly offered a lot in terms of bonus tracks and liner notes, Rhino has gone the extra mile by including an extra disc of nothing but bonus material in each reissue. Pretty convenient for a guy like me, who's been an Elvis fan going on 20 years, and who had his entire EC collection stolen a few years ago. urlLink Almost Blue was the first album to throw Elvis fans for a loop. Released in 1981, it's a collection of country cover songs, not exactly punk rock, but pretty fitting for a guy who's always been a closet George Jones fan. You haven't lived until you hear Elvis' version of "Sweet Dreams." Oh, and the bonus disc is supposed to contain a duet with George Jones, singing Elvis' own "Stranger in the House." urlLink Goodbye Cruel World is almost uniformly considered his worst album (by Elvis himself, among others), but my personal feelings about this much-maligned 1985 album are that the songs are mostly very good, but the production values stink to high heaven, all big drums and Yamaha DX-7 synthesizers. Some real gems (like "Worthless Thing," "Peace in Our Time" and "Home Truth") are on this album, you just have to wade through the big hair and John Hughes cheese. urlLink Kojak Variety was a fun 1995 covers album with some excellent moments (particularly his soulful remake of the Louvin Brothers' "Must You Throw Dirt in My Face"). Not exactly groundbreaking, but a nice diversion.
